致我的老师、朋友、学生。

To my teachers, friends, students.

银周年纪念版序言

Preface to the Silver Anniversary Edition

《计算机程序设计心理学》是一本令人惊叹的书——令人惊讶的是，一个人活到 125 岁就令人惊叹。我们身处瞬息万变的行业。据我所知，没有哪本第一版计算机书籍能活到 25 岁——而且还在计算。

The Psychology of Computer Programming is an astonishing book—astonishing in the sense that a person who lives to be one-hundred and twenty-five years old is astonishing. We are in a fast-changing business. No other first-edition computer book, as far as I know, has lived to be twenty-five years old—and still counting.

更让我惊讶的是，在我写这篇文章的时候，我从没想过会有什么特别的事情发生。十五年来，我一直在编写代码、领导程序员团队、培训程序员和咨询程序员。我想写一本关于计算机编程业务的小说（当时外界鲜为人知），但我意识到我不是一个足够熟练的小说作家，无法让任何人相信。因此，1969 年在意大利度过了一个充满灵感的 8 周假期，我写下了计算机编程心理学的初稿。

Even more astonishing to me is the fact that at the time I wrote it, I never imagined there was anything special going on. I had been writing code, leading groups of programmers, and training and consulting with programmers for about fifteen years. I thought of writing a novel about the computer programming business (which was then little known to the outside world), but I realized I wasn't a sufficiently skilled fiction writer to make anyone believe it. So, on an inspired 8-week vacation in Italy in 1969, I wrote the first draft of The Psychology of Computer Programming.

到那时，我已经写了几本关于如何为各种机器编程的畅销技术书籍，但是心理学对我来说是一个新的冒险。我很难让它出版——这是我以前的书没有发生过的。当时我的出版商 McGraw-Hill 从手稿的早期评论者那里得到了很好的评价，但他们说他们不相信有人会买这样的书。我把它提供给 Prentice-Hall，他们勉强地说，如果我同意与他们一起出版我的一些赚钱的“技术”书籍，他们会出版它。我决定我需要一个更有热情的出版商，所以我同时向其他四家出版商提供了它。两年过去了——我决定接受第一次录取。四家出版商都接受了，但第一个接受的是 Van Nostrand Reinhold——这本书终于在 1971 年出版了。具有讽刺意味的是，这本书出版的那天，我的编辑被解雇了，“

I had, by that time, written a couple of best-selling technical books on how to program various machines, but Psychology was a new venture for me. I had a hard time getting it published—something that hadn't happened with my previous books. McGraw-Hill, my publisher up to that time, got great comments from early reviewers of the manuscript, but said they didn't believe anybody would buy such a book. I offered it to Prentice-Hall, and they said, with reluctance, they would publish it—if I would agree to publish some of my money-making "technical" books with them. I decided I needed a publisher with a bit more enthusiasm, so I offered it simultaneously to four other publishers. Since two years had elapsed—decided I would go with the first acceptance. All four publishers accepted it, but the first to accept was Van Nostrand Reinhold—and the book was finally published in 1971. Ironically, the day the book came out, my editor was fired, "for not understanding the computer publishing field."

尽管 VanNostrand 对我的编辑的判断有意见，尽管他们无法保持这本书的存货，《心理学》还是迅速成为技术书籍中的畅销书，印刷了 20 次，印刷时间超过 25 年。Van Nostrand 最终将它的版权和他们所有的计算机书籍卖给了另一家大房子——它在那里闲置了几个月，缺货了。经过似乎永无休止的谈判，我获得了版权，使 Dorset House 能够出版这本银周年纪念版。

In spite of VanNostrand's opinion of my editor's judgment, and in spite of their inability to keep the book stocked, Psychology quickly became a best-seller among technical books, running through twenty printings and staying in print for more than twenty-five years. Van Nostrand eventually sold the rights to it and all their computer books to another large house—where it sat dormant, out of stock, for months. After what seemed an eternity of negotiating, I acquired the rights back, enabling Dorset House to publish this Silver Anniversary Edition.

出于以下几个原因，我想发布银周年纪念版：

I wanted to release a Silver Anniversary edition for several reasons:

1.让新一代的软件人都能接触到原著

1. to make the original book available to a new generation of software people

2.提供我们年轻领域通常缺乏的历史视角

2. to offer a historical perspective that is usually lacking in our young field

3. 利用千载难逢的机会——评论一个行业的发展并重新审视我认为可能是什么的机会。

3. to take advantage of a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity—the chance to comment on an industry's development and to revisit what I thought might have been.

我没有承接这个新版本来更新软件心理学领域。一方面，Ben Shneiderman 和其他人在这方面做得比我好得多。另一方面，正如 Ben 曾经说过的那样，这本书实际上与软件心理学无关，而与软件人类学有关——我在后续书籍中继续发展这两个主题。

I didn't undertake this new edition to update the field of software psychology. For one thing, Ben Shneiderman and others are doing a much better job of that than I could do. For another, as Ben once remarked, the book is really less about software psychology and more about software anthropology—two topics I've continued to develop in my subsequent books.

最重要的是，我认为，在回顾这本书和写下我的感想时，我想停下来回顾一下我和软件行业在 25 年里走了多远。尽管第一版可能不是行业的转折点，但对我来说却是一个转折点。从那时起，我写的代码少了很多，也很少管理组。另一方面，我培训了数以千计的程序员和团队领导，并为数百个软件项目提供咨询。我做了更多的代码审查、设计、设计审查、开发需求和审查需求。而且，我特别花了很多时间培训未来的软件经理，并向他们咨询。然而，我的一部分仍然希望我能回到更简单的全职编写代码的生活中，而不是纠缠于这些其他问题。那'

Most of all, I think, in reviewing the book and in writing my impressions, I wanted to pause and take stock of how far I and the software industry had come in twenty-five years. Though the first edition may not have been a turning point for the industry, it was a turning point for me. Since that time, I've written far less code, and done little managing of groups. On the other hand, I've trained thousands of programmers and team leaders, and consulted on hundreds of software projects. I've done more code reviewing, designing, design reviewing, developing requirements, and reviewing requirements. And, I've especially spent a lot of time training would-be software managers, and consulting with them. Yet part of me still wishes I could return to the simpler life of writing code, full time, and not dwell on these other issues. That's a common feeling in the industry, but few of us every act upon it.

我现在可以清楚地看到的一件事是，第一版心理学是我自己研究的处方，例如团队研究、领导力研究、问题解决和问题定义研究。我花了二十多年的时间来填补那些看起来既重要又未被充分理解的主题的细节。看看自从心理学以来我写的书，我现在可以清楚地看到我在填补“漏洞”。按时间顺序看书，

One thing I can see clearly now is that the first edition of Psychology was a prescription for my own studies, such as the study of teams, of leadership, of problem-solving and problem-defining. I've spent more than two decades filling in details of those topics that seemed both important and insufficiently understood. Looking at the books I've written since Psychology, I can now clearly see that I was filling the "holes." Taking the books chronologically,

• 1973 年：Structured Programming in PL/C, An Abecedarian，是对编程教学和编写编程文本的新方法进行实验的结果。

• 1973: Structured Programming in PL/C, An Abecedarian, was the outcome of an experiment in new ways of teaching programming and writing programming texts.

• 1975 年：《通用系统思维导论》直接探索了系统思考的思维过程。（这本书在二十多年后仍在印刷。）

• 1975: An Introduction to General Systems Thinking was a direct exploration of the thought processes that go into thinking about systems. (This book is still in print after more than twenty years.)

• 1975 年：结构化编程。丹尼斯盖勒、汤姆普拉姆和我制作了这部屡获殊荣的结构化编程电影系列，再次探索了思考和教授编程的新方法。

• 1975: Structured Programming. Dennis Geller, Tom Plum, and I produced this award-winning structured programming film series, again exploring new ways of thinking about and teaching programming.

• 1976 年：High Level COBOL Programming诞生，试图将COBOL 程序员的思维转变为新的模式。它可能没有用。

• 1976: High Level COBOL Programming was produced in an attempt to transform the thinking of COBOL programmers into new patterns. It probably didn't work.

• 1977 年：民族技术评论手册。Daniel Freedman 和我自行出版了这本手册的第一版，试图激励和教授处于各个发展阶段的程序的阅读。当时，没有商业出版商愿意处理技术评论的话题。（本书的最新版本仍在印刷中。）

• 1977:The Ethnotechnical Review Handbook. Daniel Freedman and I self-published the first edition of this handbook, attempting to motivate and teach the reading of programs in all their stages of development. At the time, no commercial publisher wanted to handle the topic of technical reviews. (The latest edition of this book is still in print.)

• 1977 年：人性化输入：可靠键控输入技术是对人机界面设计的早期尝试。

• 1977: Humanized Input: Techniques for Reliable Keyed Input was an early foray into human interface design.

• 1979 年：对民族技术评论手册进行了修订，添加了我们正在学习的关于阅读和分析程序的无数内容。

• 1979: The Ethnotechnical Review Handbook was revised to add the myriad things we were learning about reading and analyzing programs.

• 1979 年：与 Bob Marcus 一起制作的规范设计原则电影系列和工作簿代表了我们在改进问题定义方面的第一次尝试。

• 1979: The Principles of Specification Design Film Series and Workbook, produced with Bob Marcus, represented our first crack at improving problem definition.

• 1979 年：与我的合作伙伴 Dani Weinberg 合着的《关于稳定系统的设计》将思维模式外推到系统如何设计以生存。这本书的第二版仍在印刷中，标题为General Principles of System Design。

• 1979: On the Design of Stable Systems,written with my partner, Dani Weinberg, extrapolated thinking patterns into how systems are designed to survive. This books second edition is still in print, entitled General Principles of System Design.

• 1982 年：你的灯亮着吗？：如何找出真正的问题所在。Don Gause 和我继续这项工作的问题定义工作，这仍然是对该主题的流行介绍。

• 1982: Are Your Lights On?: How to Figure Out What the Problem Really Is. Don Gause and I continued the work in problem definition with this work, which is still a popular introduction to the subject.

• 1982 年：重新思考系统分析和设计着眼于系统分析师如何思考或应该如何思考。

• 1982: Rethinking Systems Analysis and Design looks at how systems analysts think, or ought to think.

• 1985 年：计算机信息系统：数据处理导论。丹尼斯盖勒和我继续探索软件工作的教学方法和思维过程。

• 1985: Computer Information Systems: An Introduction to Data Processing. Dennis Geller and I continued our explorations into teaching methods and thought processes for software work.

• 1985 年：咨询的秘密解决了软件开发人员（和其他人）与其客户之间的咨询关系。这本创新的书今天仍然很畅销，证明了咨询的普遍原则。

• 1985: The Secrets of Consulting addresses the consultative relationship between software developers (and others) and their clients. This innovative book remains a strong seller today, demonstrating that there are universal principles of consulting.

• 1986 年：成为技术领导者扩展了领导力和团队的主题，并且仍然非常受欢迎。

• 1986: Becoming a Technical Leader expands on the topic of leadership and teams, and is also still very much in demand.

• 1988：了解专业程序员着眼于程序员如何思考或应该如何思考。

• 1988: Understanding the Professional Programmer looks at how programmers think, or ought to think.

• 1989：Exploring Requirements: Quality Before Design，与 Don Gause 一起编写，将问题定义带到更深层次。

• 1989: Exploring Requirements: Quality Before Design, was written with Don Gause to carry problem-definition to a deeper level.

• 1990 年：演练、检查和技术审查手册，第 3 版，以当前版本出版，目前仍在印刷中。

• 1990: Handbook of Walkthroughs, Inspections, and Technical Reviews, 3rd edition, was published in its current version and is still in print.

• 1991：你说什么？与 Edie 和 Charlie Seashore 合着的The Art of Giving and Receiving Feedback总结了已知的旨在来回传递信息的人类互动。

• 1991: What Did You Say? The Art of Giving and Receiving Feedback, written with Edie and Charlie Seashore, summarized what is known about human interaction designed to pass information back and forth.

• 1991-1997：Quality Software Management，四卷系列，总结了我对软件工作和软件人员管理的所有了解。该系列涉及系统思考、测量、行动和变化的心理学主题。

• 1991-1997: Quality Software Management,a four-volume series, wrapped up all I knew about the management of software efforts and software people. The series takes up the psychological subjects of systems thinking, measurement, action, and change.

通过质量软件管理系列，我觉得我已经结束了四分之一个世纪前开始探索的主题。回顾这些年，尤其是从《心理学》第一版的角度来看，我发现我的预测能力比我想象的要差，但值得赞扬的是，我认为我的预测能力比我想象的要差。实际上，这就像任何技术审查一样——比我希望的更糟，但也没有我担心的那么糟。

With the Quality Software Management series, I felt I had concluded the subject that I started to explore a quarter-century earlier. Looking back over these years, especially with the perspective of the first edition of Psychology, I see that I turned out to be a worse prognosticator than I thought, but to my credit, I thought I would be a worse prognosticator than I thought. Actually, it was just like any technical review—worse than I hoped, but not as bad as I feared.

对于这个银周年纪念版，我决定向那些在技术评论中审查工作的人提出自己的建议：我不会试图隐藏我的错误，因为它们将是我的读者学习最多的源泉。我决定保留原始文本的原样——古董和所有东西——以供您照明，并在精神感动时简单地添加一些“后见之明”的评论。我希望你发现这个时间胶囊对比带来的观点对你有用，因为它对我很有启发。

For this Silver Anniversary Edition, I decided to take my own advice to people whose work is reviewed in technical reviews: I would not to try to hide my errors, for they would be the source of the most learning for my readers. I decided to leave the original text as it was—antiques and all—for your illumination, and simply to add some "wisdom of hindsight" remarks whenever the spirit moved me. I hope you find the perspective brought by this time-capsule contrast as useful to you as it was enlightening to me.

__________

__________

添加到电子书版本的注释：我现在了解到不可能跟上我的书单，所以我不会尝试。我将尝试在我的网站上维护该列表： http://www.geraldmweinberg.com。例如，在那里你会看到，我已经开始写包含这些教训的小说，其形式可能比我的非小说类书籍更适合一些读者。

Note added to the eBook edition: I've now learned that it's impossible to keep up with my list of books, so I won't try. I will try to maintain the list on my website: http://www.geraldmweinberg.com. There you will see, for example, that I have begun to write novels that contain these lessons in a form perhaps more palatable to some readers than my nonfiction books.

前言

Preface

 

本书只有一个主要目的——开启一个新的研究领域：将计算机编程作为一种人类活动，或者简而言之，计算机编程的心理学。所有其他目标都从属于那个目标。例如，我试图尽可能使本书有趣且非技术性，以鼓励尽可能多的人阅读它：不仅是程序员，还有编程经理和其他以多种方式与编程相关的人。这些天与编程有关。我想要完成的是让读者在读完本书后说：“是的，编程不仅仅是硬件和软件的问题。从现在开始我将不得不以一种新的方式看待事物。”

This book has only one major purpose—to trigger the beginning of a new field of study: computer programming as a human activity, or, in short, the psychology of computer programming. All other goals are subservient to that one. For instance, I have tried to make the book interesting and nontechnical, insofar as is possible, so as to encourage the greatest number of people to read it: not just programmers, but programming managers and others connected with programming in the many ways we are connected with programming these days. What I am trying to accomplish is to have the reader say, upon finishing the book, "Yes, programming is not just a matter of hardware and software. I shall have to look at things in a new way from now on."

因为这是一个新领域——一种看待熟悉事物的新方式——并不总是能够用“科学”证据来支持某些想法。事实上，书中的许多观点仅仅是作者的观点——通常是强烈的观点，但除了个人多年的观察之外，没有任何更好的依据。毫无疑问，这些观点中的许多都是完全错误的，许多观点也得到了更多证据的支持。但是，错误的想法和无用的想法之间存在着天壤之别。如果有任何读者对这里表达的内容有异议，我最希望他能进行实验并证明我是错的。

Because this is a new field—a new way of looking at familiar things—it has not always been possible to support certain ideas with "scientific" evidence. Indeed, many of the views in the book are merely the author's opinions—often strong opinions, but not based on anything better than personal observation over many years. No doubt, many of these opinions are just plain wrong, as are many of the ideas supported by more evidence. But there is a world of difference between a wrong idea and a sterile one. If any reader takes issue with something expressed here, my fondest hope is that he will set up an experiment and prove me wrong.

正如我希望本书用大量例子证明的那样，我们的职业承受着神话和半真半假的巨大负担，我和我的学生已经能够通过极其简单的实验来挑战其中的许多。但是我们资源有限，问题很大。据各种估计，今天有数十万程序员在工作。如果我们的经验有任何迹象，那么如果他和他的经理只学会将程序员视为人而不是另一台机器，那么他们每个人都可以更有效地运作，并获得更大的满足感。

As I hope the text demonstrates with numerous examples, our profession suffers under an enormous burden of myths and half-truths, many of which my students and I have been able to challenge with extremely simple experiments. But our resources are limited and the problem is great. There are, by various estimates, hundreds of thousands of programmers working today. If our experiences are any indication, each of them could be functioning more efficiently, with greater satisfaction, if he and his manager would only learn to look upon the programmer as a human being, rather than as another one of the machines.

我认为如果我们能够采用心理学的观点，我们的硬件和软件的设计也有可能取得长足的进步。我希望这本书能鼓励我们的设计师将这个新维度添加到他们的设计理念中。并不是说本书中的一些想法和推测就可以为他们提供所需的全部信息；但希望这本书能激发他们去寻找新的信息来源。目前，编程——从工程或数学的角度来看可能是复杂的——在心理上是如此粗糙，以至于即使是最微小的洞察力也应该有不可估量的帮助。我自己的经历，以及我学生的经历，在教学、学习和编程时都考虑到心理问题，证实了这一论断。我希望我的每一位读者都能亲自尝试一下。

I think that great strides are possible in the design of our hardware and software too, if we can adopt the psychological viewpoint. I would hope that this book would encourage our designers to add this new dimension to their design philosophy. Not that the few ideas and speculations in this book will give them all the information they need; but hopefully the book will inspire them to go to new sources for information. At the moment, programming—sophisticated as it may be from an engineering or mathematical point of view—is so crude psychologically that even the tiniest insights should help immeasurably. My own experience, and the experience of my students, in teaching, learning, and doing programming with psychological issues in mind, bears out this assertion. I hope each of my readers will try it for himself.

从阅读本书中可以明显看出，本书代表了许多人的想法，其中大部分是我在纽约和日内瓦的 IBM 系统研究所以及纽约州立大学宾厄姆顿分校的学生。十多年来，我有这么多在职程序员作为学生，我已经能够将我自己的小经验替代地扩展到任何人都不可能希望在一生中体验的各种编程情况。不用说，为了保护无辜的人，有时甚至是有罪的人，不得不将其中一些经历虚构出来。

As will be obvious from reading it, this book represents a composite of ideas from many people, most of all my students at the IBM Systems Research Institutes in New York and Geneva and The State University of New York at Binghamton. Having had so many working programmers as students over ten years, I have been able to extend vicariously my own small experience into all sorts of programming situations which no one person could hope to experience in a lifetime. Needless to say, some of these experiences have had to be fictionalized to protect the innocent, and sometimes the guilty.

没有与我的学生长时间的讨论，没有他们的许多聪明的实验，这本书就不可能写成。假装谦虚地说书中的所有错误都是我的，这是毫无意义的——毫无疑问，与我有关的一些经历以这样或那样的方式被扭曲了。我的责任是接受这些经验作为某些想法的基础——正如读者有责任根据自己的经验和需要权衡这里的每个想法。我最不希望发生的事情是将本书中所说的任何事情都当作福音——这正是我们试图废除的态度。下面的材料是思想的食粮，而不是它的替代品。

Without the many long hours of discussion with my students, without their many clever experiments, this book could never have been written. There is no sense assuming a position of false modesty by saying that all of the mistakes in the book are mine—no doubt some of the experiences related to me were distorted in one way or another. What is my responsibility is the acceptance of these experiences as the basis for certain ideas—just as it is the reader's responsibility to weigh each idea herein in the light of his own experiences and needs. The last thing I should wish to happen is to have anything said in this book taken as gospel—that is just the attitude we are trying to abolish. The material which follows is food for thought, not a substitute for it.

我要感谢我所有的学生，他们对我个人和本书都做出了巨大贡献，就像我要感谢我所有的老师和朋友一样。老师、朋友、学生——真的，他们是一体的，我希望他们发现我是一体的。这本书是献给他们的，不仅在献词页上，而且在每句话和段落中。对于我的妻子，她除了对我的生活做出一贯的贡献外，还从人类学家的角度阅读了本书的每一页，我对她的感激之情超出了单纯的奉献精神所能表达的。

I wish to thank all of my students who have contributed so much to me personally as well as to this book, just as I wish to thank all my teachers and my friends. Teachers, friends, students—really they are all one and the same, and I hope they have found me to be so. To them the book is dedicated, not just on the dedication page, but in every sentence and paragraph. To my wife, who, in addition to her usual contribution to my life, read every page of this book from an anthropologist's point of view, I owe more than can be expressed in a mere dedication.

- 杰拉尔德·M·温伯格

- Gerald M. Weinberg

对前言的评论

Comments on the Preface

“这本书只有一个主要目的——开启一个新的研究领域：将计算机编程作为一种人类活动，或者简而言之，计算机编程的心理学。”

"This book has only one major purpose—to trigger the beginning of a new field of study: computer programming as a human activity, or, in short, the psychology of computer programming."

25 多年前，序言就这样开始了。发生了什么变化？我是否成功实现了这个崇高的目标？

So the Preface began, more than a quarter-century ago. What has changed? Did I succeed in this high-blown purpose?

好吧，我比我大了四分之一个世纪，即使不是更聪明，至少也更谦虚了。现在，有很多人将计算机编程作为一项人类活动来研究，但我不会说这本书触发了这个新领域——或者它是否真的可以被视为一个“领域”。

Well, I'm a quarter-century older and, if not wiser, at least more humble. There are, now, many people studying computer programming as a human activity, but I wouldn't say that this book triggered that new field—or if indeed it can truly be considered a "field."

第 1 部分。作为人类表现的编程

Part 1. Programming as Human Performance

 

重要的是不要停止提问。好奇心有其存在的理由。当一个人沉思永恒、生命和现实的奇妙结构的奥秘时，他会情不自禁地感到敬畏。如果一个人每天尝试理解一点这个奥秘就足够了。永不失去圣洁的好奇心。- 艾尔伯特爱因斯坦*

The important thing is not lo stop questioning. Curiosity has Its own reason lor existing. One cannot help but be In awe when he contemplates the mysteries of eternity, of life, of the marvelous structure of reality. It is enough if one tries to comprehend a little of this mystery every day. Never lose a holy curiosity. - Albert Einstein*

 

计算机编程是一项人类活动。人们很难对这一断言提出异议，然而，也许是因为强调编程的机器方面，许多人——许多程序员——从未从这个角度考虑过编程。在程序员中，有一种神秘感——每当有人试图探究编程的完成方式时，就会出现某种挥手的动作。他们说，编程不是以某种方式完成的，它只是完成了。你要么可以编程，要么不能。有些人拥有它；有些没有

Computer programming is a human activity. One could hardly dispute this assertion, and yet, perhaps because of the emphasis placed on the machine aspects of programming, many people —many programmers—have never considered programming in this light. Among programmers, there is a certain mystique—a certain waving of the hands which takes place whenever one tries to probe the manner in which programming is done. Programming is not done in a certain way, they say, it is just done. Either you can program or you cannot. Some have it; some don't

这种神秘的必然结果之一是必须支付给那些“拥有它”的程序员的高薪——甚至是一些没有的程序员，只是在他们可能有机会的情况下。也许是因为这些高薪，或者因为他们不能容忍被他们不理解的神秘所摆布，计算机主管一直意识到编程中的人为因素。然而，他们通常关心的是消除而不是理解人为因素。

One of the corollaries of this mystique is the high salaries that must be paid to those programmers who "have it"—and even to some who don't, just on the chance that they might. Perhaps because of these high salaries, or because they cannot tolerate being at the mercy of a mystique they don't understand, computer executives have always been aware of the human element in programming. Their concern, however, has usually been with eliminating, rather than understanding, the human element.

多年来，高管们一直以巨额资金支持他们淘汰程序员的愿望。数十个简单化的方案已经投入大量金钱和赞誉，并承诺——尚未兑现——直接从销售建议到工作数据处理系统。但我们不应该责备这些高管在评估技术价值时天真无邪。我们应该为他们在感知我们这么多问题的根源方面的老练而鼓掌。他们对技术魔力的感人信念应该激励我们这些每天背负程序员重担的人。也许他们的愿望——尽管它们肯定永远无法实现——应该让我们停下来——让我们从编码板或终端上抬起鼻子——并从人类的角度考虑我们的这种人类活动。

Over the years, executives have backed their desire to eliminate programmers with staggering funds. Dozens of simplistic schemes have been heaped with money and praise on the promise—as yet not kept—of going directly from a sales proposal to a working data-processing system. But we should not chide these executives for their naivete in assessing technical merits. We should applaud them for their sophistication in sensing the source of so many of our problems. Their touching faith in the magic of technology should serve as inspiration to those of us who daily bend our backs to the programmer's burden. Perhaps their wishes—though they can surely never be fulfilled—should give us pause—make us lift our noses from the coding pad or the terminal—and consider this human activity of ours from a human point of view.

__________

__________

* 来自威廉·米勒 (William Miller) 的《天才之死》，《生活》杂志，1955 年 5 月 2 日 0 1955 Time Inc.

* From Death of a Genius, by William Miller, LIFE Magazine, May 2, 1955 0 1955 Time Inc.

第 1 部分的评论：作为人类表现的编程

Comments on Part 1: Programming as Human Performance

“多年来，高管们一直以惊人的资金支持他们淘汰程序员的愿望。”

"Over the years, executives have backed their desire to eliminate programmers with staggering funds."

25 年来这里唯一发生变化的是，高管们用于从工资单中裁掉程序员的资金比我当时想象的要多得多。而且，现在，我终于在这位高管的欲望中认识到一种如此强烈、如此情绪化的模式，以至于这些高管对两个事实视而不见：

The only thing that's changed here in twenty-five years is the fact that the funds dedicated by executives to eliminating programmers from their payrolls have become far more staggering than I imagined back then. And, now, I finally recognize in this executive desire a pattern so strong, so emotional, that it's blinded these executives to two facts:

一个。这些方案都没有成功地消除程序员。（我们现在至少是当时的十倍）。

a. None of these schemes has succeeded in eliminating programmers. (We have now at least ten times as many as we did then).

b. 这些计划中的每一个都是程序员自己编造的，而这些人正是高管们如此热情地想要消除的。

b. Every one of these schemes has been concocted by programmers themselves, the very people the executives want so passionately to eliminate.

因此，尽管人们说程序员缺乏人际交往能力，但他们显然拥有超过已故伟大的 PT Barnum 的说服技巧，后者以证明他的理论而闻名：“每分钟都有一个笨蛋诞生。” 和“没有人因为低估美国公众的智慧而破产。”

So, although people say that programmers lack interpersonal skills, they evidently have a skill at persuasion that surpasses that of the late, great P.T. Barnum, famous for proving his theories: "There's a sucker born every minute." and "Nobody ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American public."

第 1 章阅读程序

Chapter 1. Reading Programs

 

几年前，当 COBOL 成为白人编程的伟大希望时，人们听到很多关于高管能够阅读程序的可能性的讨论。从时间的角度来看，我们可以看出，这种说法只是为了吸引那些希望摆脱程序员束缚的高管的资金。没有人会认真地相信高管会阅读程序。他们为什么要这样做？甚至程序员也不阅读程序。

Some years ago, when COBOL was the great white programming hope, one heard much talk of the possibility of executives being able to read programs. With the perspective of time, we can see that this claim was merely intended to attract the funds of executives who hoped to free themselves from bondage to their programmers. Nobody can seriously have believed that executives could read programs. Why should they? Even programmers do not read programs.

但是，只有机器才能读取程序，这不是很合适吗？程序不是为机器写的吗？是和不是。即使我们不关心程序修改和程序之间的接口，从学习编程的角度来看，阅读程序也不是一个坏主意。

But isn't it quite proper that only the machine should read programs? Weren't the programs written for the machine? Yes and no. Even if we were not concerned with program modification and with the interfaces between programs, reading programs might not be such a bad idea from the point of view of learning about programming.

编程是一种写作。学习写作的一种方法是写作，但在所有其他形式的写作中，也需要阅读。我们阅读例子——好的和坏的——以促进学习。但是有多少程序员是通过阅读程序来学会写程序的呢？有一些，但不是很多。随着终端的出现，情况变得更糟，因为程序员可能甚至看不到适合阅读的形式的自己的程序。在过去——在计算领域不久之前——我们不太容易接触到机器，也不能等待从实际机器运行中学习。周转时间通常很糟糕，以至于程序员会通过阅读彼此的程序来打发时间。有些人甚至从程序库中读取程序——那时候程序库还是旧意义上的库。

Programming is, among other things, a kind of writing. One way to learn writing is to write, but in all other forms of writing, one also reads. We read examples—both good and bad—to facilitate learning. But how many programmers learn to write programs by reading programs? A few, but not many. And with the advent of terminals, things are getting worse, for the programmer may not even see his own program in a form suitable for reading. In the old days—which in computing is not so long ago—we had less easy access to machines and couldn't afford to wait for learning from actual machine runs. Turnaround was often so bad that programmers would while away the time by reading each others' programs. Some even went so far as to read programs from the program library—which in those days was still a library in the old sense of the term.

但是，唉，时代变了。正如电视让年轻人不再享受老式的书籍阅读乐趣一样，终端和普遍改进的转变也使阅读节目成为无可救药的老式程序员的标志。深夜，当头发花白的老前辈蜷缩在床上处理性感的子程序或神秘的宏时，年轻的刀片正忙着与他的终端对话。毫无疑问，与巨型计算机面对面比仅仅沉浸在对他人工作的沉思中要激动得多。但它更有启发性吗？

But, alas, times change. Just as television has turned the heads of the young from the old-fashioned joys of book reading, so have terminals and generally improved turnaround made the reading of programs the mark of a hopelessly old-fashioned programmer. Late at night, when the grizzled old-timer is curled up in bed with a sexy subroutine or a mystifying macro, the young blade is busily engaged in a dialogue with his terminal. No doubt it is much more thrilling to be face to face with the giant computer than merely wrapped in quiet contemplation of the work of others. But is it more edifying?

我们这个时代的一位年轻小说家最近被问到他最喜欢的作家是谁。他简单地回答说他从不读小说，因为他的思想比任何人都新奇和优越，阅读只会浪费他的时间。如您所料，他的工作并不支持他的论文。也许对于我们一些激进的年轻程序员来说也是如此。或许阅读其他人的程序会有所收获——如果只是他们的坏榜样所带来的乐趣。也许如果我们想了解程序员是如何编程的——揭开编程神秘面纱——我们可以从阅读程序中学到什么开始富有成效。

A young novelist of our time was recently asked who were his favorite authors. He responded simply that he never read novels, as his ideas were so new and superior to anyone else's that reading would only be a waste of his time. As you might expect, his work did not support his thesis. Perhaps the same could be said for some of our radical young programmers. Perhaps there is something to be gained from reading other people's programs—if only the amusement engendered by their bad examples. Perhaps if we want to understand how programmers program —to lift the veil of the programming mystique—we could fruitfully begin by seeing what is to be learned from the reading of programs.

一个例子

AN EXAMPLE

为了说明程序阅读的乐趣和成果，让我们举一个从专业的程序阅读生涯中收集到的小例子——成千上万的小程序。假设我们遇到了图 1-1 所示的 PL/I 程序。我们该怎么办？

In order to illustrate the joys and fruits of program reading, let us take a tiny example gleaned from a professional lifetime of program reading—one small program from among thousands. Suppose then that we come across the PL/I program shown in Figure 1-1. What are we to make of it?

 

图 1-1 一个要读取的程序。

Figure 1-1 A program to be read.

 

我们需要一种阅读程序的方法，因为与小说不同，阅读程序的最佳方式并不总是从头到尾。它们甚至不像悬疑小说，我们可以翻到倒数第二页以获得最精彩的部分——也不像性感书籍，我们可以打开最折痕的页面以找到最温暖的段落。不，程序的好的部分不会出现在任何必要的地方——尽管我们稍后会看到如何发现调试和优化等任务的关键部分。相反，我们可能会将阅读建立在由每个部分的起源组成的概念框架上。换句话说，当我们查看每一段代码时，我们会问自己一个问题，“为什么这段代码在这里？”

We shall need a method of approach for reading programs, for, unlike novels, the best way to read them is not always from beginning to end. They are not even like mysteries, where we can turn to the penultimate page for the best part—or like sexy books, which we can let fall open to the most creased pages in order to find the warmest passages. No, the good parts of a program are not found in any necessary places—although we will later see how we can discover crucial sections for such tasks as debugging and optimization. Instead, we might base our reading on a conceptual framework consisting of the origin of each part. In other words, as we look at each piece of code, we ask ourselves the question, "Why is this piece here?"

机器限制

MACHINE LIMITATIONS

考虑代码片段的原因之一是，相对于解决问题的理想机器，运行程序的机器在某种程度上受到限制。在我们的例子中，我们看到总共有 10,000 个数字被读入计算机并求和，但是它们是以 1000 个为一批读取的。由于这些数字显然是以 PL/I LIST 格式打孔的，因此没有理由要进行此除法除非总存储量有限，以至于无法一次存储所有 10,000 个数字。换句话说，由于没有 40,000 字节可用，程序员不得不将他的求和分成更小的部分，这导致包含一个额外的循环。如果他能够存储所有 10,000 个数字，他可能会编写如图 1-2 所示的程序。

One of the reasons which account for pieces of code is that the machine on which the program is to be run is limited in some way relative to the ideal machine for the problem. In our example, we see that a total of 10,000 numbers are read into the computer and summed, but they are read in batches of 1000. As the numbers are evidently punched in PL/I LIST format, there is no reason why this division should be made, unless perhaps the total storage was limited so that all 10,000 numbers could not be stored at once. In other words, not having 40,000 bytes available, the programmer had to break up his summing into smaller sections, which led to the inclusion of an extra loop. If he had been able to store all 10,000 numbers, he might have written the program as shown in Figure 1-2.

 

图 1-2 删除了存储限制。

Figure 1-2 Storage limitation removed.

 

当然，当程序员包含一些旨在克服机器某些限制的东西时，他很少明确地这样标记它。尽管这种遗漏增加了阅读程序的趣味性，但它确实对程序不利，例如，当它被转移到另一台机器上时。程序员甚至可能没有意识到他的一些编码是为了弥补机器的局限性，在这种情况下，他很难被期望去标记它。例如，必须进行大量编程才能克服我们机器的有限精度——或者更好的是，它们不使用实数进行计算，而只使用一组有限的有理数。然而，程序员往往会忘记这些是硬件的局限性，并开始将它们视为生活中的事实。

Of course, when the programmer includes something that is intended to overcome some limitation of the machine, he rarely marks it explicitly as such. Although this omission adds to the intrigue of reading programs, it does penalize the program when, for example, it is transferred to another machine. The programmer may not even be aware that some of his coding is intended to compensate for a limitation of the machine, in which case he could hardly be expected to mark it. For instance, much programming has to be done to overcome the limited precision of our machines—or better still, the fact that they do not calculate with real numbers but only with a limited set of the rationals. Yet programmers tend to forget that these are limitations of the hardware and come to think of them as facts of life. When we include such words as REAL in our programming languages, we compound the difficulty, and make it less likely that machine designers will become aware of the difficulties this difference causes programmers.

另一个普遍存在机器限制的领域是中间存储。首先，如果我们知道如何以足够低的成本构建正确类型的主存储设备，我们就根本不会有中间存储。但是，如果没有 Nirvana，我们仍然需要应对过多的鼓、磁盘、磁带等——所有这些都会导致大量的编码。此外，每个设备都有独特的时序特性、寻址模式和存储容量，我们发现许多编程致力于克服我们碰巧拥有的（从程序员的角度来看）不太理想的配置。

Another area in which machine limitations are rife is intermediate storage. In the first place, we wouldn't have intermediate storage at all if we knew how to build the right kind of primary storage devices cheaply enough. But short of that Nirvana, we still have to contend with a plethora of drums, disks, tapes, and the like—all of which lead to enormous amounts of coding. Moreover, each device has peculiar timing characteristics, modes of addressing, and storage capacity, and we find much programming devoted to overcoming the less-than-optimum (from the programmer's point of view) configuration we happen to have.

语言限制

LANGUAGE LIMITATIONS

但是机器的局限性并不是我们主要关心的问题，因为我们正在寻找编程的人类基础。更接近这些基础的是编程语言——假设没有人——但没有人——再用机器语言编程了。超越机器语言的后果之一是用户可能会失去硬件的某些功能。这种类型的一个例子是某些 FORTRAN 系统中存在的文件结束情况。在这些系统中，机器完全能够识别文件结尾并将控制权传递给程序的另一部分，但 FORTRAN 语言不提供这种功能。因此，程序员不得不求助于诸如“文件结尾卡”之类的设备——一个必须修改编码和数据以克服语言限制的示例。

But machine limitations are not our primary concern here, for we are seeking the human underpinnings of programming. A step closer to these underpinnings is the programming language—assuming that nobody—but nobody—programs in machine language anymore. One of the consequences of moving up above machine language is that certain facilities of the hardware may be lost to the user. An example of this type is the end-of-file situation which exists in some FORTRAN systems. In these systems, the machine is perfectly able to recognize an end-of-file and pass control to another section of the program, but the FORTRAN language provides no such facility. Thus, the programmer has to resort to devices such as the "end-of-file card"—an example in which both the coding and the data have to be modified to overcome language limitations.

在我们的示例中，语言限制更为微妙。PL/I 为程序​​员提供了一个称为 SUM 的内置函数，用于对数组的元素求和。然而，在该语言的原始定义中，在编写此程序时，SUM 是所谓的“数学”函数，而不是“算术”函数。这意味着它采用浮点输入，并在必要时将其输入转换为浮点。除了效率问题之外，如果数组（如本例中）由带小数部分的 FIXED DECIMAL 数字组成，则此转换可能意味着精度损失。许多程序员在尝试使用 SUM 平衡帐户时发现丢失了便士，这让他们很苦恼。由此产生的抗议导致将 SUM 重新定义为通用算术，但是，同时，它不能成功地用于我们的例子这样的问题。如果没有这种语言限制，程序可以缩短为如图 1-3 所示。

In our example, the language limitation is more subtle. PL/I provides the programmer with a built-in function called SUM for taking the sum of the elements of an array. In the original definition of the language, however, at the time this program was written, SUM was a so-called "mathematical" function, rather than an "arithmetic" function. What this meant was that it assumed floating point input—and converted its input to floating point if necessary. Aside from questions of efficiency, this conversion could mean the loss of precision if the array—as in this example—consisted of FIXED DECIMAL numbers with fractional parts. Many programmers were distressed to discover that pennies were being lost when they tried to balance accounts using SUM. The resulting protest led to a redefinition of SUM as arithmetic generic, but, in the meantime, it could not be used successfully on a problem such as our example. Without this language limitation, the program could have been shortened to read as in Figure 1-3.

 

图 1-3 使用算术泛型 SUM。

Figure 1-3 Using arithmetic generic SUM.

 

在此图中，我们还删除了 PROCEDURE 语句中的 OPTIONS(MAIN)，说明了另一种形式的语言限制——特定实现的限制。由于与操作系统的接口，这种笨拙的属性只在某些系统中才需要，这要求 MAIN 程序的处理方式与子程序略有不同。

In this figure, we have also eliminated the OPTIONS(MAIN) on the PROCEDURE statement, illustrating another form of language limitation—the limitation of a particular implementation. This clumsy attribute was only required in certain systems because of the interface with the operating system, which required that MAIN programs be handled somewhat differently than subroutines.

当然，PL/I 以其没有许多其他语言中大量存在的愚蠢的小限制而著称。仅举几个例子，考虑用 FORTRAN 编写的所有额外编码，因为 DO 循环不能倒数，或者因为表达式不能作为迭代的增量或边界出现，或者因为数组下标必须开始有一个，或者因为只有少数下标表达式是可能的。尽管如此，在这些限制从我们身上解除之前，我们可能不会感觉到这些限制，就像我们通常直到突然感觉好些才知道自己生病了一样。因此，有理由期待未来的语言会让我们感受到今天无法检测到的 PL/I 的局限性。请注意，这是一个心理学问题——我们将有机会回到这个问题上。

Of course, PL/I is noted for its absence of silly little restrictions such as abound in many other languages. To take just a few examples among many, consider all the extra coding that has been written in FORTRAN because DO loops could not be counted backwards, or because expressions could not appear as increments or bounds of an iteration, or because array subscripts had to start with one, or because only a small number of subscript expressions were possible. Still, we may not feel these limitations until they have been lifted from us, just as we often do not know we are sick until we suddenly feel better. Therefore, it is reasonable to expect that future languages will make us feel those limitations of PL/I that are not detectable today. Notice that this is a psychological question—one to which we shall have occasion to return.

程序员的限制

PROGRAMMER LIMITATIONS

更直接的心理问题是由于程序员没有完全掌握他的计算机、他的语言或他自己而完成了多少编码。例如，在我们的示例中，程序员并不真正理解 PL/I 中的数组表示法——以至于他没有意识到将数组名称放入数据列表以获得数组的所有元素的可能性。如果他熟悉这个特性——毕竟，即使在 FORTRAN 中也是如此——他可能会编写出如图 1-4 所示的程序。

More directly psychological is the question of how much coding is done because the programmer did not have full mastery of his computer, his language, or himself. For instance, in our example, the programmer did not really understand array notation in PL/I—to the extent that he was unaware of the possibility of putting an array name in a data list in order to obtain all the elements of the array. Had he been familiar with this feature—which was, after all, even in FORTRAN—he might have written the program shown in Figure 1-4.

 

图 1-4 提高了程序员的意识。

Figure 1-4 Increased programmer awareness.

 

当然，除了不了解语言的全部功能之外，还有程序员的局限性——我们可能会说词汇量的局限性。例如，程序员可能不知道某些算法，或者他可能无法一次掌握问题的足够大的部分来避免某些重复。随着我们的继续，我们将对这些和其他限制有很多话要说，因为这些显然属于编程心理学的范畴。

There are, of course, programmer limitations other than merely not knowing the full power of the language—vocabulary limitations, we might say. For instance, the programmer may be unaware of certain algorithms, or he may be unable to grasp a sufficiently large portion of the problem at one time to see that certain duplications may be avoided. We shall have much to say about these and other limitations as we proceed, for these are obviously in the province of the psychology of programming.

历史痕迹

HISTORICAL TRACES

我们经常在程序中找到可能属于上述类别之一但由于程序开发历史而真正存在的材料。例如，一旦将 SUM 函数更改为算术泛型函数，就没有任何理由再出现图 1-2 中的程序。然而，就编程行业的情况而言，任何人都不太可能仅仅因为 SUM 函数的定义已更改而深入研究工作程序并对其进行修改。因此，几年后，一个被赋予修改这个程序的工作的新手程序员会庆幸自己比最初编写这个程序的人更了解 PL/I。由于那个人可能是他的主管，因此可能会形成不健康的态度——顺便说一句，

We often find material in programs that might be accounted for under one of the above categories but is really present because of the history of the development of the program. For example, once the SUM function is changed to an arithmetic generic function, there is no longer any reason for the program in Figure 1-2 to appear. Nevertheless, things being what they are in the programming business, it is unlikely that anyone is going to delve into a working program and modify it just because the definition of the SUM function has been changed. And so, some years later, a novice programmer who is given the job of modifying this program will congratulate himself for knowing more about PL/I than the person who originally wrote this program. Since that person is probably his supervisor, an unhealthy attitude may develop—which, incidentally, is another psychological reality of programming life which we shall have to face eventually.

某些代码片段的史前起源几乎令人难以置信。在一个例子中，两名程序员在社会保障管理局深入研究其中一个基本代码时发现了一个奇怪的人工制品。每当发现具有多个来源代码之一的输入卡在某一列中有一个“A”时，“A”就会被转换为“1”。鉴于此列中只能出现数值这一事实，这一点尤其令人好奇——而且有一个预编辑程序可以确保这一点。尽管如此，程序员还是不愿意修改一些他们不明白的目的的代码，所以他们开始了调查。最终，他们找到了解决方案。

The prehistoric origins of certain pieces of code are almost beyond belief. In one instance, two programmers digging into one of the basic codes at the Social Security Administration discovered a curious artifact. Whenever an input card with one of several origin codes was found to have an "A" in a certain column, the "A" was transformed into a "1." This was especially curious in view of the fact that only numeric values could appear in this column—and there was a pre-edit program to ensure that this was so. Still, the programmers were properly reluctant to modify some coding whose purpose they did not understand, so they started an inquiry. Eventually, they turned up a solution.

几年前——这意味着一些商店的几代程序员（这是另一个心理学问题，不是吗？）——其中一个贡献地区办公室的一个按键出现了一个错误，导致它打出一个“1 ”作为本专栏中的“A”。由于这是在预编辑程序时代之前，这些打错的卡片设法渗透到内部程序并导致其挂起。到发现问题时，流通中的此类卡片数量不详，因此最简单的做法似乎是对程序进行“临时”修改。补丁制作完成后，效果非常好，以至于每个人都忘记了它——更多的是心理学——直到多年后被两位考古学家程序员发掘出来。

Several years earlier—which means several programmer generations in some shops (which is another question of psychology, isn't it?)—one of the keypunches at one of the contributing district offices had developed a bug which caused it to punch a "1" as an "A" in just this column. Since this was before the days of the pre-edit program, these mis-punched cards managed to penetrate the inner program and caused it to hang up. By the time the problem was detected, there were an unknown number of such cards in circulation, so the simplest course seemed to be to make a "temporary" modification to the program. Once the patch was made, it worked so well that everyone forgot about it—more psychology—and there it sat until unearthed many years later by two archeologist programmers.

并非所有历史代码都像这些示例所暗示的那样容易区分。特别是，一个项目越大，其生命早期做出的特定历史选择的影响就越分散。甚至程序的结构也可能由最初编写它的程序组的规模和组成决定——因为工作必须分配给一定数量的人，每个人都有一定的长处和短处。事实上，编程组的社会组织将是我们主要感兴趣的领域。

Not all historic code can be so easily differentiated as these examples might imply. In particular, the larger a program grows, the more diffuse are the effects of particular historical choices made early in its life. Even the very structure of the program may be determined by the size and composition of the programming group that originally wrote it—since the work had to be divided up among a certain number of people, each of whom had certain strengths and weaknesses. Indeed, the social organization of programming groups will be an area of major interest to us.

规格

SPECIFICATIONS

当我们查看图 1-1 和图 1-4 之间的差异时，我们可能会开始相信，世界上完成的编码很少与我们试图解决的问题有很大关系。考虑到所有因素，这将是对情况的相当公平的陈述——尽管在几乎每个程序中可能都有一些代码实际完成了指定的工作。然而，即使我们成功地提取了程序的这个内核，我们也不能被误导，以为我们可以从这个内核作为规范开始，让某个系统处理其他限制。除了在程序员不太了解时确定他的意图或根据对计算机可以做什么一无所知的情况下编写的规范生成高效代码方面的明显困难之外，

When we look at the difference between Figures 1-1 and 1-4, we might begin to believe that very little of the coding that is done in the world has much to do with the problems we are trying to solve. Everything considered, this would be a pretty fair statement of the situation—although there probably is, in almost every program, some code which actually does the work that was specified. Yet even if we succeed in extracting this kernel of the program, we must not be misled into the illusion that we could have started with this kernel as a specification and had some system take care of the other limitations. Aside from the obvious difficulties in determining a programmer's intentions when he doesn't know very much or in producing efficient code from a specification that is written without the slightest understanding of what computers can do, there will always remain the fact that, in most cases, we do not know what we want to do until we have taken a flying leap at programming it.

规范与程序和程序员一起发展。编写程序是一个学习的过程——对于程序员和委托程序的人来说都是如此。此外，这种学习发生在特定机器、特定编程语言、特定工作环境中的特定程序员或编程团队的上下文中，以及一组特定的历史事件，这些事件不仅决定了代码的形式，还决定了内容。代码确实如此！

Specifications evolve together with programs and programmers. Writing a program is a process of learning—both for the programmer and the person who commissions the program. Moreover, this learning takes place in the context of a particular machine, a particular programming language, a particular programmer or programming team in a particular working environment, and a particular set of historical events that determine not just the form of the code but also what the code does!

在某种程度上，研究人们编写程序的过程最重要的原因不是为了使程序更高效、更紧凑、更便宜或更容易理解。相反，最重要的收获是从我们的计划中获得我们真正想要的东西的前景——而不是我们笨拙、笨手笨脚的方式所能产生的东西。

In a way, the most important reason for studying the process by which programs are written by people is not to make the programs more efficient, more compact, cheaper, or more easily understood. Instead, the most important gain is the prospect of getting from our programs what we really want—rather than just whatever we can manage to produce in our fumbling, bumbling way.

概括

SUMMARY

程序以这种方式构建的原因有很多，尽管我们可能无法认识到原因的多样性，因为我们通常是从外部查看代码而不是阅读代码。当我们阅读代码时，我们发现有些代码是由于机器限制而编写的，有些是由于语言限制，有些是由于程序员限制，有些是因为历史事故，还有一些是因为规范——必要的和非必要的。但无论出于何种原因，一段特定的代码被插入到最终产品中，这个原因有心理方面的原因——这使我们相信，将编程作为人类行为来研究将产生许多并不总是预期的成果。

There are many reasons why programs are built the way they are, although we may fail to recognize the multiplicity of reasons because we usually look at code from the outside rather than by reading it. When we do read code, we find that some of it gets written because of machine limitations, some because of language limitations, some because of programmer limitations, some because of historical accidents, and some because of specifications—both essential and inessential. But for whatever reason a particular piece of code gets inserted into the final product, there are psychological aspects to that reason—which leads us to believe that studying programming as human behavior will bear numerous and not always expected fruits.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1、如果你是一线管理者，你的程序员写的程序你看得懂吗？或者你阅读程序的能力是否随着上一代机器或语言而失效？如果你有能力，你会读吗？如果你不这样做，为什么不试试看你发现了什么？

1. If you are a first-line manager, are you capable of reading the programs written by your programmers? Or did your ability to read programs lapse with the previous generation of machines or languages? If you are capable, do you read them? If you don't, why not try it and see what you find?

2、如果你是高层管理人员，你的一线管理人员是否有能力看懂他们程序员写的程序？你确定吗？问问程序员自己，然后再回答这个问题。然后再看看一线管理人员是否真的会读程序，即使他们有能力。我们的调查表明，出于某种原因，十分之九的人没有这样做。你觉得一个一线经理不偶尔看一下他们的程序，有可能知道他的程序员有多好，或者他们做的有多好吗？

2. If you are a higher-level manager, are your first-line managers capable of reading programs written by their programmers? Are you sure? Ask the programmers themselves, then answer this question again. Then find out if the first-line managers actually do read programs, even if they are capable. Our surveys indicate that nine-tenths do not, for one reason or another. Do you think it is possible for a first-line manager to know how good his programmers are or how well they are doing without occasionally reading their programs?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 你最后一次看别人的程序是什么时候？为什么这么久了？上一次有人阅读您的程序并与您讨论是什么时候？是你的经理吗？

1. When was the last time you read somebody else's program? Why has it been so long? When was the last time somebody else read one of your programs and discussed it with you? Was it your manager?

2. 从程序库或您的朋友那里借一个程序。尝试将其分析为由于文本中描述的各种原因而存在的代码片段。你从这个练习中学到了什么？

2. Borrow a program from the program library or from one of your friends. Try to analyze it into pieces of code that are there for the various reasons described in the text. What did you learn from this exercise?

3. 拿一个你自己一个多月前写的程序，按照问题 2 进行分析。你从这个练习中学到了什么？

3. Take one of your own programs written over a month ago, and analyze it as in Question 2. What did_you learn from this exercise?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

Bucholz, Werner, ed., Planning a Computer System: Project Stretch , New York, McGraw-Hill, 1962.

Bucholz, Werner, ed., Planning a Computer System: Project Stretch, New York, McGraw-Hill, 1962.

计算机也是由出于各种原因进入其中的部件组成的。对于计算机如何成为现在的样子的绝佳视角，这本书没有被超越。此外，这本书包含许多关于机器对编程的限制问题的见解，因为 Stretch 旨在成为“程序员的机器”，从而消除了我们认为在其他机器设计中理所当然的许多东西。

Computers too are made up of parts that get into them for various reasons. For an excellent view of how computing machines come to be the way they are, this book has not been surpassed. In addition, the book contains many insights into the question of machine limitations on programming, since Stretch was intended to be, among other things, a "programmer's machine" and thus eliminated many of the things which we take for granted on other machine designs.

PL/I 语言日志，IBM 公司，机密文件。

PL/I Language Log, IBM Corporation, Confidential File.

这可能很难获得，但现在 IBM 不再单独负责维护 PL/I 的完整性，可能会看到一份副本。Language Log 是关于我们今天所知的 PL/I 语言的争论和决定的运行记录，因此包含了关于如何制定编程语言的精彩教育。希望有人会在一本组织得当的书中发布此日志的部分内容。

This may be hard to obtain, but now that IBM is no longer solely responsible for maintaining the integrity of PL/I, it may be possible to see a copy. The Language Log is a running record of the controversies and decisions that went into the PL/I language we know today, and as such contains a marvelous education in how programming languages have been formulated. Hopefully, someone will publish parts of this Log in a suitably organized book.

任何用户组或计算机制造商的程序库。

Program Library of any user group or computer manufacturer.

您的程序库包含丰富的信息。光顾它！

Your program library contains a wealth of information. Patronize it!

Weinberg, GM, PL/I Programming: A Manual of Style，纽约，McGraw-Hill，1970 年。

Weinberg, G. M., PL/I Programming: A Manual of Style, New York, McGraw-Hill, 1970.

如果您想更详细地了解作者关于程序如何变成现在这样的想法，请阅读本书。

Read this book if you want a lot more detail on the author's ideas on how programs come to look the way they do.

Gruenberger, Fred, ed., Fourth Generation Computers: User Requirements and Transition , Englewood Cliffs, NJ, Prentice-Hall, 1970.

Gruenberger, Fred, ed., Fourth Generation Computers: User Requirements and Transition, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., Prentice-Hall, 1970.

展望集前三代所有智慧于一身的“第四代”，本书中的几位作者似乎终于要面对计算机用户的心理需求问题。Murray Laver 追溯了过去设计师、销售人员和制造商比使用他们产品的人具有更大影响力的方式。Jacques Bouvard 讨论了在软件级别的系统设计中需要更多的用户导向。

Looking to the "fourth generation" with all the wisdom garnered from the first three, several authors in this collection seem at last to be facing the problem of the psychological needs of the computer user. Murray Laver traces the ways in which designers, salesmen, and manufacturers have had more influence in the past than the people who were to use their products. Jacques Bouvard discusses the need for more user orientation in the design of systems at the software level.

第 1 章：阅读程序的评论

Comments on Chapter 1: Reading Programs

这里没有太大变化。程序的阅读仍然是了解我们如何制作程序的关键。一项改进是最近才出现的：要学习的作品库——例如类库——尽管这些通常缺乏批判性评论，这将使它们成为更有价值的培训资源。模式运动终于解决了这一需求。遗憾的是，组织声称阻碍他们转向新技术的障碍之一是理解开发环境附带的类库所需的努力。

Not much has changed here. The reading of programs is still the key to understanding how we make programs. One improvement is only recently emerging: libraries of works to study—such as class libraries—though these generally these lack the critical commentary that would make them a more valuable training resources. The patterns movement is, at long last, addressing this need. On a sad note, one of the obstacles organizations claim keep them from moving to a new technology is the effort required to understand the class libraries that come with the development environments.

一个变化是代码中历史痕迹的增长。毕竟，他们还有二十五年的积累，而且肯定是积累了。这种积累不利于软件维护，但可能有利于研究作为人类行为的编程，前提是我们可以访问这些痕迹和一些说明代码如何形成这种方式的文档。

One change is the growth of historical traces in code. After all, they've had twenty-five more years to accumulate, and they have definitely accumulated. This accumulation is bad for software maintenance, but possibly good for the study of programming as human behavior, assuming we have access to these traces and some documentation suggesting how the code got that way.

然而，有一些证据表明，在软件维护期间最常阅读的代码并不是最好的例子。大多数情况下，这就是它首先进行维护的原因。如果读者不知道什么是好什么是坏，那么阅读代码将无济于事。二十五年来，这一点没有改变。

However, there's some evidence that the code that's read most frequently during software maintenance is not the best of examples. Mostly, that's why it is in maintenance in the first place. Reading code won't help much if the reader has no sense of what's good and what's bad. That much hasn't changed in twenty-five years.

但是，为什么开发人员很难将自己的工作提交给其他人审阅，或者试图通过审阅他人的工作来提高自己的技能呢？奇怪的是，优秀的开发人员往往会发现走查和检查过程的价值，而仅仅聪明的人却不会。所以，一如既往，好的变得更好，坏的变得更糟。

But why is it so hard for developers to submit their work for review by others or to try to improve their own skills by reviewing the work of others? Curiously, superior developers tend to find value with walkthrough and inspection processes while the merely clever do not. So, as always, the good get better and the bad get worse.

第 2 章什么是好的程序？

Chapter 2. What Makes a Good Program?

 

如果我们计划将编程作为一项人类活动来研究，我们将不得不制定一些衡量编程性能的方法。也就是说，当我们说一个程序员比另一个好，或者一个程序比另一个好时，我们将对我们的意思有所了解。尽管我们对这些问题都有自己的看法，但我们会发现答案并不像我们想的那么简单。因为编程不仅仅是人类行为；这是复杂的人类行为。

If we plan to study programming as a human activity, we are going to have to develop some measures of programming performance. That is, we are going to have some idea of what we mean when we say that one programmer is better than another, or one program is better than another. Although we all have opinions on these questions, we shall find that the answers are not as simple as we might wish. For programming is not just human behavior; it is complex human behavior.

再次考虑我们的编程示例。通过相当彻底地分析图 1-1，我们发现其中只有一小部分——不超过 20%——是为了满足问题规范。在其他 80% 中，即使不是大部分，也有很多可以通过心理改变而不是身体改变来消除。事实上，即使是有限存储的问题也可以通过适当的虚拟机来解决，因此即使是机器限制也可以通过适当的心理设计来克服。

Consider our programming example once again. By analyzing Figure 1-1 rather thoroughly, we discover that only a small portion of it—no more than 20 percent—is directed at meeting the problem specifications. Of the other 80 percent, much, if not most, can be eliminated not by physical change but by psychological change. In fact, even the question of a limited storage could have been dealt with by an appropriate virtual machine, so that even machine limitations can be overcome by proper psychological design.

图 1-1 中的程序虽然很小，但在实际用于解决给定问题的编码百分比方面是典型的。因为很多人不读程序，所以很少有人知道这种情况有多普遍。但它很常见，它为我们的编程提供了很大的改进空间。尽管如此，良好编程的问题远不止衡量无关代码（或至少是外围代码）的百分比。确实，我们无法真正衡量一个程序本身，并说它是好是坏。

The program in Figure 1-1, though small, is typical in the percentage of coding that is actually devoted to solving the given problem. Because many people do not read programs, few are aware of how common this situation is. But common it is, and it gives us much scope for improvement in our programming. Still, there is more to the question of good programming than measuring the percentage of extraneous—or at least peripheral —code. Indeed, we cannot really measure a program by itself and say whether it is good or bad.

大多数程序员都觉得有好的编程这回事。尽管这种感觉可能是正确的，但这并不意味着有好程序这样的东西。至少，在某种意义上，我们可以脱离程序开发和使用的环境来研究程序，并宣布它具有 83.72% 的良好度。

Most programmers feel that there is such a thing as good programming. Although this feeling may be valid, it does not follow that there is such a thing as a good program. Not, at least, in the sense that we can study the program out of the context in which it was developed and in which it will be used and declare it to have a goodness of 83.72 percent.

考虑图 1-1。这是一个好程序吗？也许这是一个笨拙的程序，但这只是一部分。毕竟，我们只知道它很笨拙是因为我们读了它，而对于普通的程序，从来没有人会去读它，所以优雅度很难成为衡量程序好坏的绝对标准。这是一个有效的程序吗？如果不知道运行它的机器、编译器和成本情况，我们很难回答这个问题。是否按时完成？它花了多少钱？它符合规范吗？我们不能仅仅通过查看代码来了解这些事情。

Consider Figure 1-1. Is it a good program? It is a clumsy program, perhaps, but that is only part of the mark. After all, we only knew it was clumsy because we read it, and for the ordinary program, nobody is ever going to read it, so grace is hardly an absolute measure of program goodness. Is it an efficient program? We can hardly answer this question without knowing the machine, the compiler, and the cost situation under which it will be run. Was it done on time? What did it cost? Does it meet specifications? We cannot know these things merely by looking at the code.

在我们对编程心理学的研究中，我们将因无法在绝对范围内衡量程序的优劣而受到阻碍。但我们是否可以在相对尺度上衡量它们——我们可以说程序 A 比程序 B 更好还是更差？不幸的是，出于多种原因，我们通常甚至无法做到这一点。首先，什么时候有其他程序可以与之比较？当存在 FORTRAN 编译器时，我们如何才能就程序不同属性的相对重要性达成一致。快速编译慢代码的编译器是否比慢编译快速代码的编译器更好？

In our studies of the psychology of programming, we shall be hampered by our inability to measure the goodness of programs on an absolute scale. But can we perhaps measure them on a relative scale—can we say that program A is better or worse than program B? Unfortunately, we will generally not even be able to do that, for several reasons. First of all, when is there ever another program with which to compare? And when there is, as in the case of, say, a FORTRAN compiler, how can we agree on the relative importance of the different attributes of the program. Is a compiler that quickly compiles slow code better than one that slowly compiles quick code?

不过，不是也有相对排名的时候吗？快速编译快速代码的编译器难道不是比缓慢编译慢速代码的编译器更好吗？我们不得不承认，有时可以进行这样的比较——尽管我们不能操之过急。除了速度之外，编译器性能还有其他方面。仅举几例，包括诊断、所涵盖的语言范围、目标代码的可靠性和执行时间监控。我们很少会发现两个程序非常相似，以至于可以逐点比较它们，然后找到一个在所有方面都更胜一筹的程序。

But still, aren't there times when we can make a relative ranking? Isn't a compiler that quickly compiles quick code better than one that slowly compiles slow code? We have to admit that sometimes such comparisons can be made—although we must not be too hasty in making them. There are dimensions of compiler performance other than speed. There are diagnostics, scope of language covered, reliability of object code, and execution time monitoring, to mention a few. Only rarely will we find two programs so sufficiently similar that they can be compared point by point—and then find one superior on all points.

更常见的是，我们对程序进行评估时，不是针对彼此，而是针对一种情况——一种总体情况——它们是在何种情况下开发的。老老实实看情况，我们从来不是找最好的方案，很少找好的方案，而是一直在找符合要求的方案。

More often, then, we will be doing evaluation of programs not with respect to one another but with respect to a situation—a total situation —in which they are developed. Looking honestly at the situation, we are never looking for the best program, seldom looking for a good one, but always looking for one that meets the requirements.

规格

SPECIFICATIONS

在我们可能对程序提出的所有要求中，首要的是它必须正确。换句话说，它应该为每个可能的输入提供正确的输出。这就是当我们说一个程序“有效”时的意思，人们经常真实地说“任何有效的程序都比任何无效的程序都要好”。

Of all the requirements that we might place on a program, first and foremost is that it be correct. In other words, it should give the correct outputs for each possible input. This is what we mean when we say that a program "works," and it is often and truly said that "any program that works is better than any program that doesn't."

一个例子可能有助于让那些头脑纠结于效率和其他次要问题的人明白这一点。有一次，一位程序员被叫到底特律帮助调试一个新程序——一个确定制造某组汽车的零件要求的程序。程序的输入是一个文件，每条记录代表汽车的采购订单，不同的代码代表客户选择的不同选项。该程序体现了与所需零件的各种选项相关的规范。例如，后座内饰的选择可能取决于车身颜色、车身风格、豪华或人造革内饰的选择以及汽车是否装有空调等因素。空调选项是问题基本复杂性的一个很好的例子，因为尽管对于未经训练的人来说，空调的选择可能与后座内饰的选择无关，但它很可能需要额外的管道空间。一般来说，每个选项都可能对零件的选择产生一些影响，因此确定零件要求对计算机来说是一项出色的工作。

An example may serve to drive home this point to those whose minds, are tangled in questions of efficiency and other secondary matters. A programmer was once called to Detroit to aid in the debugging of a new program—one that was to determine the parts requirements to build a certain set of automobiles. The input to the program was a file, each record representing a purchase order for an automobile, with different codes representing the different options selected by the customer. The program embodied the specifications relating the various options to the parts that would be needed. For instance, the choice of upholstery for the rear seat might be determined by such factors as body color, body style, options for deluxe or leatherette upholstery, and whether or not the car was air conditioned. The air-conditioning option is a good example of the basic complexity of the problem, for though to an untrained eye the choice of air conditioning might have no connection with the choice of rear seat upholstery, it might very well require spaces for extra ducts. In general, then, each option might have some effect on the choice of parts made, so the determination of parts requirements was an excellent job for the computer.

不幸的是，当这位程序员到达现场时，解决问题的基本方法早已定下来——而且定得不好。每个选项——因为它影响每个选择——都反映为程序中单独编程的测试和分支。在某种程度上，该程序是一棵巨大的树，有 5000 多个分支，代表导致零件选择的决策。以这种形式投射——同时有 16 名程序员同时工作——不可能调试，因为每个案例都必须单独测试。为了测试该程序，将输入一个特定的订单并观察输出。当我们的程序员到达时，情况非常糟糕，典型的输入要求生产具有八个轮胎、没有发动机和三套内饰的汽车。简而言之，一场灾难。

Unfortunately, when this programmer arrived on the scene, the basic approach to the problem had long been settled—and settled badly. Each option—as it affected each choice—was reflected as an individually programmed test and branch in the program. In a way, the program was an enormous tree, with more than 5000 branches, representing the decisions leading to part selection. Cast in this form—and with 16 programmers working at the same time—it was impossible to debug, as each and every case had to be tested separately. To test the program, a particular order would be entered and the output would be observed. When our programmer arrived, things were so bad that typical inputs were calling for the production of cars with eight tires, no engine, and three sets of upholstery. In short, a disaster.

就像编程灾难一样，没有人意识到它是这样的。

As is usual with programming disasters, nobody recognized it as such.

取而代之的是，全体工作人员轮流值班以解决漏洞，包括我们的英雄在内的新程序员从全国各地调来。自然地，这导致比以往任何时候都更混乱，几天后，我们的程序员确定这是一项没有希望的业务——无论如何都没有足够的理由离开他的家人和夜以继日地工作。他因不合作的态度受到严厉谴责，但被允许离开。

Instead, the whole crew had gone on double shift to get out the bugs, and new programmers, including our hero, were brought in from all over the country. Naturally, this led to worse confusion than ever, and our programmer, after a few days, determined that it was a hopeless business—and in any case not reason enough to be away from his family and working night and day. He was roundly condemned for his uncooperative attitude but was allowed to leave.

在飞机上，他有了一周来第一次冷静反思的机会。他立即看出了方法中的错误，并认为更好的方法是将工作分为两个阶段。主要操作程序将简单地循环遍历一组专门构建的规格表，以便所有决策都可以通过将单个测试重新应用于表的不同部分来做出。这样一来，该计划至少可以确保生产出正确数量的轮胎、发动机等。表格本身将根据以工程规范形式编写的输入进行编译。这将允许工程人员而不是程序员检查规范，并且还允许更改规范的一部分而不更改决策树下的所有部分。

While on the plane, he had his first opportunity in a week to reflect calmly. He immediately saw the error in the approach and perceived that a much better approach would be to divide the work into two phases. The main operational program would simply loop through a set of specially constructed specifications tables, so that all decisions would be made with a single test reapplied to different parts of the table. In that way, the program was at least assured to produce the right number of tires, engines, and so forth. The tables themselves would be compiled from input written in essentially the form of the engineering specifications. This would allow the engineering personnel, rather than the programmers, to check the specifications, and also permit one part of the specification to be changed without changing all parts further down a decision tree.

等他下飞机时，他已经完成了这两个程序的编码。检查它们需要一天的工作，另外两天与当地装配厂的工程师一起创建输入形式的规范。在工厂进行了一周的测试后，他正准备返回底特律通知这个消息，这时他收到一封电报说该项目已被取消——因为该程序无法编写。

By the time he got off the plane, he had coded the two programs. It was a day's work to check them out, and another two days' work with the local assembly plant engineers to create the specifications in input form. After a week's testing in the plant, he was about to return to notify Detroit of the news when he got a telegram saying that the project had been cancelled—since the program was impossible to write.

在快速打电话和乘飞机旅行后，他带着他的程序版本回到了底特律。向高管们演示后，他们相信该项目可以继续进行，然后他被要求向其他程序员做演示。自然地，他们是一群相当冷静的听众——我们将在讨论中回到这种现象——但在他对方法的解释中，他们足够安静地坐着。甚至到了最后，也没有提出质疑——直到旧制度的始创者举起了手。

After a quick call and a plane trip, he was back in Detroit with his version of the program. A demonstration to the executives convinced them that the project could continue, and then he was asked to make a presentation to the rest of the programmers. Naturally, they were a rather cool audience—a phenomenon to which we shall return in our discussions—but they sat quietly enough through his explanation of the method. Even at the end, there was a lack of questioning-—until the original creator of the old system raised his hand.

“你的程序需要多长时间？” 他问——强调所有格。

"And how long does your program take?" he asked—emphasizing the possessive.

“这因输入而异，”回答说，“但平均而言，每次输入约十秒。”

"That varies with the input," was the reply, "but on the average, about ten seconds per entry."

“啊哈，”这是胜利的回答。“但我的程序每次输入只需要一秒钟。”

"Aha," was the triumphant reply. "But my program takes only one second per entry."

观众们——毕竟，他们都为一秒钟的版本做出了贡献——似乎松了一口气。但是我们的英雄，他还很年轻，很天真，并没有因为这句话而失望。相反，他平静地观察到，“但是你的程序不起作用。如果程序不需要起作用，我可以写一个每次输入需要一毫秒的程序——这比我们输入一个条目要快。”

The members of the audience—who had, after all, all contributed to the one-second version—seemed relieved. But our hero, who was rather young and naive, was not put down by this remark. Instead, he calmly observed, "But your program doesn't work. If the program doesn't have to work, I can write one that takes one millisecond per entry—and that's faster than we can input an entry."

这一观察——尽管它无疑未能为我们的英雄赢得任何朋友——包含了所有编程评估必须基于的基本事实。如果一个程序不起作用，那么衡量效率、适应性或生产成本的措施就没有意义。不过，我们必须现实一点，承认可能从来没有编写过完美的程序。每个非常大和重要的程序都“只是多了一个错误”。因此，存在满足规范（“工作”）的程度，并且程序评估必须考虑不完善的类型。

This observation—though it undoubtedly failed to win our hero any friends—contains the fundamental truth upon which all programming evaluation must be based. If a program doesn't work, measures of efficiency, of adaptability, or of cost of production have no meaning. Still, we must be realistic and acknowledge that probably no perfect program was ever written. Every really large and significant program has "just one more bug." Thus, there are degrees of meeting specifications—of "working"—and evaluation of programs must take the type of imperfection into account.

例如，任何编译器都会至少有一些无法正确编译的“病态”程序。然而，什么是病态的，在某种程度上取决于你的观点。如果它发生在您的程序中，您很难将其归类为病态，即使成千上万的其他用户从未遇到过该错误。然而，编译器的生产者必须根据遇到这些错误的用户数量以及它们产生的成本对这些错误进行一些评估。这并不总是科学地完成。事实上，它通常相当于评估谁喊得最响，或者谁给最高行政人员写信。但是无论选择什么系统，都会存在一些错误，并且有些人会对同一个满足数千人的编译器不满意。

Any compiler, for example, is going to have at least some "pathological" programs which it will not compile correctly. What is pathological, however, depends to some extent on your point of view. If it happens in your program, you hardly classify it as pathological, even though thousands of other users have never encountered the bug. The producer of the compiler, however, must make some evaluation of the errors on the basis of the number of users who encounter them and how much cost they incur. This is not always done scientifically. Indeed, it often amounts to an evaluation of who shouts the loudest, or who writes to the highest executive. But whatever system is chosen, some bugs will remain, and some people will be unhappy with the same compiler that satisfies thousands.

因此，实际上，为一个用户编写的程序与一个“软件”是有区别的。当有多个用户时，就有多个规格。当有多个规范时，程序何时工作的定义也有多个。在讨论编程实践时，我们将不得不考虑为一个用户开发的程序与为许多用户开发的程序之间的区别。它们将被不同地评估，它们应该通过不同的方法产生。

In effect, then, there is a difference between a program written for one user and a piece of "software." When there are multiple users, there are multiple specifications. When there are multiple specifications, there are multiple definitions of when the program is working. In our discussions of programming practices, we are going to have to take into account the difference between programs developed for one user and programs developed for many. They will be evaluated differently, and they should be produced by different methods.

日程

SCHEDULE

即使在满足规范的问题被搁置之后，效率问题仍然不是最重要的。编程中反复出现的问题之一是满足时间表，而迟到的程序通常毫无价值。至少，我们必须衡量没有该计划的成本与更有效的计划可能产生的任何潜在节省。在一个值得注意的案例中，一家软件公司的客户估计，正在开发的线性编程代码将为公司的炼油业务每月节省超过 100 万美元。如果计划免费运行十年，即使延迟一个月，也会造成无法弥补的损失。

Even after questions of meeting specifications have been set aside, the question of efficiency is still not uppermost. One of the recurring problems in programming is meeting schedules, and a program that is late is often worthless. At the very least, we have to measure the costs of not having the program against any potential savings that a more efficient program would produce. In one noteworthy case, the customer of a software firm estimated that the linear programming code being developed would save more than one million dollars per month in the company's oil refining operations. Even one month's delay in schedule would result in a loss that could not be recovered if the program were run free of charge for ten years.

延迟交付项目造成的损失并不总是那么严重，但即使成本可以忽略不计，至少在美国，当没有按时交付时，似乎也会产生令人难以置信的烦恼。事实上，一般的项目经理更愿意将一个项目估计为十二个月并花费十二个月，而不是将同一项目估计为六个月并花费九个月。在这个领域进行一些心理学研究可能会有所收获，但其他情况表明，令人烦恼的不是估计时间的平均长度，而是实际花费时间的标准差。因此，大多数人宁愿每天早上等公共汽车固定十分钟，也不愿四天等一分钟，每周一次等二十六分钟。

Losses from late delivery of programs are not always so severe, but even were the costs negligible, there seems to be, in the United States, at least, an incredible amount of annoyance when schedules are not met. In fact, the average programming manager would prefer that a project be estimated at twelve months and take twelve than that the same project be estimated at six months and take nine. This is an area where some psychological study could be rewarding, but there are indications from other situations that it is not the mean length of estimated time that annoys people but, rather, the standard deviation in the actual time taken. Thus, most people would prefer to wait a fixed ten minutes for the bus each morning than to wait one minute on four days and twenty-six minutes once a week-. Even though the average wait is six minutes in the second case, the derangement caused by one long and unexpected delay more than compensates for this disadvantage.

如果这个观察结果适用于编程，那么任何关于某些编程实践的影响的研究都应该衡量对生产时间可变性的影响——而不是像目前大多数研究所做的那样仅仅测量平均时间。我们将在所有后续讨论中尝试估计这种影响。

If this observation holds true for programming, then any studies of the effect of certain programming practices should measure the effect on variability in production time—not just mean time as most studies currently do. We shall try to estimate this effect in all our subsequent discussions.

适应性

ADAPTABILITY

解决了满足规范和时间表的问题后，我们可能会认为我们终于到达了效率问题，作为衡量程序优劣的标准。然而，在不回避这两个因素的相对重要性的问题的情况下，首先处理程序的适应性因素将被证明是有利的。毫无疑问，有些程序只用了一次就扔掉了。毫无疑问，还有更多的程序在使用之前就应该被丢弃。尽管如此，绝大多数编写的程序，尤其是由专业程序员编写的程序，在一定的生命周期内仍然存在。在那段时间里，它们中的大多数都被修改了。

Having disposed of the questions of meeting specifications and schedules, we might suppose that we had finally arrived at the question of efficiency as a measure of the goodness of programs. Without begging the question of relative importance of the two factors, however, it will prove advantageous first to dispose of the factor of adaptability of a program. No doubt there are programs that are used once and then thrown away. No doubt there are even more programs that should be thrown away before ever being used. Nonetheless, the great majority of programs that are written, especially by professional programmers, remain in existence for a definite life span. And during that span, most of them become modified.

几乎没有任何经验的程序员会反驳大多数程序在其生命周期中被修改的断言。那么，为什么当我们被迫修改程序时，我们会发现这是一项艰巨的任务，以至于我们常常决定放弃它们并重新开始？阅读程序给了我们一些洞察力，因为我们很少能找到一个程序包含任何证据表明其编写时着眼于后续修改。但这只是一种症状，并不是一种疾病。我们应该问，为什么完全知道程序将不可避免地被修改的程序员在编写程序时却不考虑这些修改？确实，为什么他们的程序有时看起来像是经过恶作剧来抵制修改——像法老的坟墓一样受到保护以防止所有入侵者？

Few programmers of any experience would contradict the assertion that most programs are modified in their lifetime. Why, then, when we are forced to modify programs do we find it such a Herculean task that we often decide to throw them away and start over? Reading programs gives us some insight, for we rarely find a program that contains any evidence of having been written with an eye to subsequent modification. But this is only a symptom, not a disease. Why, we should ask, do programmers, who know full well that programs will inevitably be modified, write programs with no thought to such modifications? Why, indeed, do their programs sometimes look as if they had been devilishly contrived to resist modification—protected like the Pharoah's tomb against all intruders?

这些问题都是有答案的，它们是我们心理调查的方向。但我们目前的工作不是回答它们，而只是提出它们并提醒我们自己它们在任何关于什么是好的编程的讨论中的重要性。当然，一个相关的问题是文档，如果不是为了使程序更容易修改，为什么我们要记录一个程序？我们都同意文档的质量和进行修改的难易程度，无论是计划内的还是计划外的，都应该在程序或编写该程序的程序员的任何分级中发挥重要作用。那么，我们都会进一步同意，从心理调查中获得的任何改进都是值得付出努力的。

There are answers to these questions, and they lie in the direction of our psychological investigations. But our job for the moment is not to answer them, but merely to raise them and remind ourselves of their importance in any discussion of what makes good programming. A related question is, of course, documentation, for why do we document a program if not to render it more easily modifiable? We would all agree that the quality of documentation and the ease of making modifications, both planned and unplanned, should count heavily in any grading of a program, or of the programmer who writes that program. We would all agree further, then, that any improvement here to be gained from psychological investigations will be well worth the effort.

但是，在我们继续讨论效率问题之前，请注意一点。适应性不是免费的。有时，可以肯定的是，我们得到的程序恰好在所有其他方面都具有适应性并且令人满意，但我们通常会为我们得到的东西付出代价——而且往往得不到我们付出的代价。在他对遗传系统的数学研究中，RA Fisher 推导出了一个经常被称为 Fisher 基本定理的定律，考虑到 Fisher 的许多其他定理的重要性，这是一个非常重要的名称。费舍尔基本定理指出——用适合当前语境的术语——一个系统对特定环境的适应性越好，它对新环境的适应性就越差。通过稍微扩展我们的想象力，我们可以看到这如何适用于计算机程序以及蜗牛、果蝇和乌龟。

But, a word of caution before we proceed to the question of efficiency. Adaptability is not free. Sometimes, to be sure, we get a program that happens to be adaptable as well as satisfactory in all other ways, but we generally pay for what we get—and often fail to get what we pay for. In his mathematical studies of genetic systems, R. A. Fisher derived a law that has often been called Fisher's Fundamental Theorem, a very significant name in view of the importance of Fisher's many other theorems. Fisher's Fundamental Theorem states—in terms appropriate to the present context—that the better adapted a system is to a particular environment, the less adaptable it is to new environments. By stretching our imagination a bit, we can see how this might apply to computer programs as well as to snails, fruit flies, and tortoises.

为了使程序高效，它必须利用问题的特殊性和运行它的机器。忽略机器结构的程序这样做可能会招致严重的成本损失，而能够利用问题中的特殊情况的程序员是能够加快速度并使事情变得更小的人。此类编程的一个特殊示例（并非完全不典型）是一个汇编程序，它采用一种特殊技术来查找要翻译的操作代码。程序员已经观察到——或者发现——有一个数字，当它被用来乘以解释为数字的操作代码位模式时，会产生一个几乎固定且完全不重复的地址列表。使用这个乘数，

For a program to be efficient, it must take advantage of the peculiarities of the problem and the machine on which it is to be run. Programs that ignore the structure of the machine do so at the risk of incurring heavy cost penalties, and programmers who can exploit special situations in a problem are the ones who can speed things up and make them smaller. One peculiar example, not entirely untypical, of this type of programming was an assembly program that employed a special technique for looking up operation codes to be translated. The programmer had observed—or figured out—that there was one number which, when used to multiply the operation code bit pattern interpreted as numeric, yielded an almost solid and completely unduplicated list of addresses. Using this multiplier, he was able to effect a compact and equally fast transformation from symbolic codes to machine language.

程序员的这种独创性受到了极大的祝贺——这个例子作为他们应该做的工作的原型展示给了几代程序员。然而，令人遗憾的是，这部分代码的寿命并不长，因为，正如经常发生的那样，机器的操作代码库被扩展了。当大约十几个代码被添加到集合中时，旧的乘数不再具有同样令人满意的紧凑性和唯一性。事实上，找不到任何乘数可以以这种方式用于新代码。

The programmer was much congratulated for this ingenuity—the example was displayed to several generations of programmers as a prototype of the kind of work they should be doing. Sadly, however, this section of code did not have a very long life, for, as so frequently happens, the operation code repertoire of the machine was expanded. When a dozen or so codes had been added to the set, the old multiplier no longer had the same desirable properties of compactness and uniqueness. In fact, no multiplier could be found that would work in this way for the new codes.

寻找新乘法器的尝试的结果是放弃这种特殊技术，转而使用更通用的哈希表搜索——一种允许重复项存在的方法。不幸的是，在付出大量努力试图使它适应变化的环境之前，旧技术并没有被放弃。事实证明这是浪费时间。回想起来，专门技术节省的时间在其生命周期内从来没有支付过添加新代码时胡闹的额外成本。如果一开始就使用通用的哈希表方法，效率会低一些；但是——这就是构成示例的“但是”——修改本来是完全微不足道的。事实上，除了添加 .

The outcome of attempts to find a new multiplier was to abandon this special technique for a more general hash table search—one that allowed for the existence of duplicates. Unhappily, the old technique was not abandoned before a great deal of effort had been expended on the attempt to adapt it to the changed circumstances. This proved to be time wasted. In retrospect, the savings in time of the specialized technique never paid in its lifetime for the extra cost of fooling around when the new codes were added. If a general hash table method had been used in the first place, somewhat lower efficiency would have been the result; but—and this is the "but" that makes the example—the modification would have been entirely trivial. In fact, essentially no modification would have been required except the addition of the. new codes to the appropriate places in the table.

这个例子可以用数百个其他例子来补充，但要点是一样的。当我们要求效率时，我们通常要求的是难以修改的“严密”编码。在高级语言方面，我们经常下降到机器语言级别以使程序更高效。这至少失去了使用高级语言编写程序的好处之一——机器之间的可移植性。事实上，它的效果是将我们冻结在我们已经承认我们的行为并不令人满意的机器或实现上。

This example could be supplemented with hundreds of others, but the point would be the same. When we ask for efficiency, we are often asking for "tight" coding that will be difficult to modify. In terms of higher-level languages, we often descend to the machine-language level to make a program more efficient. This loses at least one of the benefits of having the program in the higher-level language—that of transportability between machines. In fact, it has the effect of freezing us to a machine or implementation that we have admitted by our very act is unsatisfactory.

然而，那些为提高效率而大喊大叫的经理们，在被告知修改成本时却泪流满面。相反，要求通用和易于修改的程序的经理们在发现这些程序变得多么缓慢和庞大时习惯于抱怨。我们必须对这些事情保持成熟：无论是心理学还是魔法都无法帮助我们同时实现相互矛盾的目标。在同一个节目中要求效率和适应性，就像要求一个美丽谦虚的妻子或一个帅气谦逊的丈夫。虽然众所周知，美丽和谦逊会出现在同一个人身上，但我们可能不得不满足于其中之一。至少那总比没有好。

However, the same managers who scream for efficiency are the ones who tear their hair when told the cost of modifications. Conversely, the managers who ask for generalized and easily modified programs are wont to complain when they find out how slow and spacious these programs turn out to be. We must be adult about such matters: neither psychology nor magic is going to help us to achieve contradictory goals simultaneously. Asking for efficiency and adaptability in the same program is like asking for a beautiful and modest wife or a handsome and humble husband. Although beauty and humility have been known to occur in the same person, we'll probably have to settle for one or the other. At least that's better than neither.

效率

EFFICIENCY

衡量一个程序的真正效率并不是乍看起来那么简单。首先，效率并不总是简单地用在计算机上的时间来衡量，因为通常可以用在计算机上的时间来换取计算机运行前后的时间。例如，编译器速度的常用衡量标准是它每分钟处理的行数。如果我们使用这个度量来比较一个汇编程序，比如说，一个 FORTRAN 编译器，汇编可能会显得更有效率，因为每个输入行携带的信息更少。有时会根据每分钟生成的机器指令数来比较编译器，但这种衡量标准使我们面临仅仅因为编译器在生成目标代码时过于冗长而将其归功于编译器的危险。

Measuring the true efficiency of a program is not the simple task it first seems. In the first place, efficiency is not always measured simply in terms of time on the computer, for it is often possible to trade time on the computer for time before and after the computer run. For example, a commonly used measure of the speed of a compiler is the number of lines per minute it processes. If we use this measure to compare an assembly program with, say, a FORTRAN compiler, the assembly is likely to appear more efficient, since each input line carries less information. Sometimes compilers are compared on the basis of the number of machine instructions produced per minute, but this measure exposes us to the danger of giving credit to a compiler simply because it is verbose in the production of object code.

当然，编译器无论如何都是一种特殊的野兽，因为我们必须衡量生成的代码的效率以及编译过程的效率。尽管如此，由于编译器效率是一个经常讨论的主题，因此继续这个例子来说明我们在效率问题上是多么容易被误导可能是值得的。例如，考虑根据“每分钟行数”度量对同一语言的两个编译器进行比较。这里的第一个陷阱在于术语“相同的语言”。很少有编译器处理完全相同的语言，因此如果两者之间存在任何差异，我们将不得不调整从每分钟行数获得的效率以说明两种语言的价值差异。

A compiler, of course, is a special kind of beast anyway, since we must measure the efficiency of the code produced as well as that of the compilation process. Still, since compiler efficiency is a subject of much discussion, it may be worthwhile to pursue this example to illustrate how easily we can be misled on efficiency questions. Consider, for instance, the comparison of two compilers for the same language in terms of the "lines per minute" measure. The first pitfall here lies in the term "same language." Very few compilers handle exactly the same language, so if there is any difference between the two, we will have to adjust the efficiency obtained from lines per minute to account for the difference in value of the two languages.

源语言的细微差别对编译器效率的影响可能是惊人的。通常，如果编译器编写者可以选择他不会实现的语言的 10%，他可以生产出速度提高 50% 的编译器。不幸的是，选择哪 10% 因一台机器和一种编译技术而异，因此语言设计者不能简单地提供要实现的“更有效”的子集。
