The effect of slight differences in source language on compiler efficiency can be striking. Typically, if the compiler writer can choose 10 percent of the language which he will not implement, he can produce a 50 percent faster compiler. Unfortunately, which 10 percent is chosen differs from one machine and one compiling technique to the other, so that language designers cannot simply provide "more efficient" subsets to be implemented.

通过在其他领域类似地放宽规范，可以实现类似的效率改进。事实上，如果我们在特定应用程序中的主要关注点是效率，那么第一步应该始终是寻找可以更改规范以适应计算机效率而非用户便利性的领域。当然，计算机时间并不是典型项目中唯一的成本要素。人们的时间也需要金钱。因此，我们可以让报告的接收者完成某些交叉脚注，但我们可能只是以牺牲纸笔执行时间为代价来节省计算机时间。我们可能会非常理性地决定做出这个选择，但更多的时候是在高管没有任何发言权的情况下做出的选择。

Similar improvements in efficiency are possible from similar relaxation of specifications in other areas. Indeed, if our primary concern in a particular application is efficiency, the first step should always be to look for areas in which the specifications can be changed to suit computer efficiency rather than user convenience. Of course, computer time is not the only cost element in a typical project. People time also costs money. Thus, we can leave certain crossfootings to be done by the recipient of a report, but we may only be saving computer time at the expense of executive time with paper and pencil. We may decide quite rationally to make this choice, but more often the choice is made without the executive having anything to say about it.

修整外部规范甚至会对计算机使用时间产生与预期相反的影响。例如，如果系统中保留了大量手动输入处理以简化计算机运行，我们可能会发现自己在重新运行中付出的代价比在单次运行效率上节省的成本要多。当比较两个编译器时，这种效果相当普遍，即使它们处理相同的语言，但它们产生的诊断和执行监控不同。如果我们通过消除或减少错误检查来节省 20% 的原始编译时间，我们最好确保用户不会发现自己要多运行 40% 才能获得相同数量的信息。

Trimming the external specifications can even have the opposite of the intended effect on computer time used. If, for example, a great deal of manual handling of input has been left in the system to simplify the computer run, we may find ourselves paying more in reruns than we saved in single-run efficiency. This effect is rather common when comparing two compilers which, even though they handle identical language, differ in the diagnostics and execution monitoring they produce. If we save 20 percent in raw compile time by eliminating or trimming error checking, we had better be sure that the user will not find himself making 40 percent more runs to get the same amount of information.

尽管在单机、简单调度程序环境中进行简单的效率测量是危险的，但与在多处理或多程序环境中获得有意义的效率估计的困难相比，这是小儿科。例如，占用 40K 字节的主存储器一小时还是占用 80K 字节的主存储器 30 分钟更好？这个问题的答案取决于作业运行时计算机的情况——并且可能会在每次作业运行时发生变化。例如，有一天可能会向机器负载添加一个 40K 的作业，而不会影响其他作业的性能一秒钟；然而第二天，同样的 40K 工作可能会在整个小时内锁定另一个工作。

As hazardous as it is to make simple measures of efficiency in a single machine, simple-scheduler environment, it is child's play compared with the difficulties of obtaining meaningful efficiency estimates in a multiprocessing or multiprogramming environment. Is it better, for instance, to occupy 40K bytes of main storage for one hour or 80K bytes for 30 minutes? The answer to this question depends on the situation in the computer at the time the job is run—and may change each time the job is run. For example, one day it may be possible to add a 40K job to the machine load-without affecting the performance of the other jobs by one second; yet the next day the same 40K job may lock out another job for the full hour.

在能够进行动态负载调整的系统上运行可以缓解我们今天经常看到的多程序性能的一些不稳定性。很可能，就像编程的时间表一样，用户想要的不是一个小的平均时间来执行他的程序，而是一个小的标准差，这样他就可以合理地计划他的工作。如果这是真的，则必须考虑工作从起点到终点的整个时间表，而不仅仅是“计算机上的时间”。

Running on systems capable of dynamic load adjustment may alleviate some of the instabilities in multiprogram performance that we often see today. It may very well be that, as with schedules for programming, what the user wants is not a small mean time to execute his program but a small standard deviation, so he can plan his work reasonably. If this is true, the entire schedule from origin to destination of the work must be considered, not just the "time on the computer."

我们可能正在转向这样一种计算环境，在这种环境中，最好的程序是那些能够在各种大小的主内存和各种机器配置上运行的程序。这样的程序可能在任何一种配置上都不是非常有效——考虑在相反意义上应用费舍尔基本定理——但可能会导致更一致的周转性能，因为它永远不会发现自己只等待当天时间表中的正确时段。具有虚拟内存的机器为我们提供了这种无需特殊编程的灵活性，尽管有迹象表明即使在这种环境下通过考虑特殊特性也可以获得性能改进。

We may be moving toward a computing environment in which the best programs are those that retain the ability to be run in various sizes of main memory, on various machine configurations. Such a program may not be very efficient on any one of the configurations—considering Fisher's Fundamental Theorem applied in the inverse sense—but may lead to more consistent turnaround performance because it will never find itself waiting for just the correct slot in the day's schedule. Machines with virtual memories give us this kind of flexibility without special programming, although there are indications that performance improvements can be obtained even in this environment by taking special characteristics into account.

例如，如果我们知道我们系统的页面大小，我们可以通过定制我们的程序部分以适应单个页面而不跨越页面边界来避免过度分页，除非在程序中的逻辑中断处。然而，如果我们这样做，程序就会变得不太适合在具有不同页面大小的系统中运行。类似地，我们可以选择一种算法，它需要的页面空间不会比我们的系统通常允许的多也不会少；但是同样，这种程序将无法利用额外的页面空间，并且会在页面空间较小的系统中提供最差的性能。

For instance, if we know the page size of our system, we can avoid excessive paging by tailoring our program sections to fit into single pages and not to cross page boundaries except at logical breaks in the program. If we do this, however, the program becomes somewhat less well adapted for running in a system with a different page size. Similarly, we can choose an algorithm that will require no more and no less page space than is commonly allowed by our system; but again, this kind of program will fail to take advantage of extra page space and will give the worst possible performance in a system with a smaller page space.

所有这一切意味着效率正在成为计算中的一个阴云密布的问题。此外，随着每单位计算的成本逐年下降，而每单位编程的成本不断增加，我们早已过了典型安装在编程上比在生产工作上花费更多的钱的地步。当所有不恰当地归类为“生产”的工作都被置于“调试”的正确标题下时，这种不平衡就更加明显了。但无论以何种标准衡量，这种不平衡都是存在的。并成长。因此，我们预计随着时间的流逝，我们将越来越少听到有关效率的信息，而越来越多地听到有关有效性的信息。

What all of this means is that efficiency is becoming a clouded issue in computing. Moreover, with cost per unit of computation decreasing every year and cost per unit of programming increasing, we have long since passed the point where the typical installation spends more money on programming than it does on production work. This imbalance is even more striking when all the work improperly classified as "production" is put under the proper heading of "debugging." But by any measure, the imbalance exists. And grows. And so we expect that with each passing year we will hear less and less about efficiency—and more and more about effectiveness.

概括

SUMMARY

什么才是好的程序这个问题并不简单，甚至可能不是一个恰当的问题。每个项目都必须考虑其自身的优点并与其周围环境相关。一些重要因素是：

The question of what makes a good program is not a simple one, and may not even be a proper question. Each program has to be considered on its own merits and in relation to its own surroundings. Some of the important factors are:

1.程序是否符合规范？或者，更确切地说，它符合规范的程度如何？

1. Does the program meet specifications? Or, rather, how well does it meet specifications?

2. 它是否按计划生产，我们可以从特定方法中预期的计划可变性是什么？

2. Is it produced on schedule, and what is the variability in the schedule that we can expect from particular approaches?

3. 条件改变时是否可以更改程序？进行更改需要多少费用？

3. Will it be possible to change the program when conditions change? How much will it cost to make the change?

4. 程序的效率如何，我们所说的效率是什么意思？我们是否以一个领域的效率换取另一个领域的低效率？

4. How efficient is the program, and what do we mean by efficiency? Are we trading efficiency in one area for inefficiency in another?

以后，尤其是在本书的讨论中，我们应该避免使用“好程序”或“好程序员”的概念，就好像它是普遍认同的东西，或者甚至可以普遍认同的东西，或者什么甚至应该得到普遍同意。

In the future, and particularly in the discussion of this book, we should refrain from using the concept "good program" or "good programmer" as if it were something universally agreed upon, or something that even can be universally agreed upon, or something that even should be universally agreed upon.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1.你们奖励程序员的依据是什么？您的某些标准是否相互矛盾，例如要求高效但通用的程序？你对你的程序员在表明你在他们的程序中寻找什么方面有多明确？或者您只是告诉他们您希望程序快速、小巧、整洁、易于修改、无错误并在一周内完成？

1.On what bases do you reward programmers? Are certain of your criteria mutually contradictory, as in asking for efficient but general programs? How explicit are you with your programmers in indicating what you are looking for in their programs? Or do you just tell them that you want the programs to be fast, small, neat, easily modifiable, errorless, and done In a week?

2. 您安装的程序在适应性方面如何？修改程序是否是您安装中的主要费用？如果是这样，您能否在您的编程实践中（在您设定的最初目标中）看到可能导致这种费用的事情？

2. How do the programs in your installation stack up on adaptability? Is modifying programs a major expense in your installation? If so, can you see things in your programming practices—in the original goals you set—that may lead to this kind of expense?

3. 在你的店里制定时间表有多重要？是“失手如误”，还是您奖励的是一致性而不是偶尔的幸运投篮？你能看出程序员如何选择不可靠的做法，因为它给了他完成进度表的唯一希望，即使它可能有根本无法完成程序的风险？

3. How important is making the schedule in your shop? Is "a miss as good as a mite," or do you reward for consistency rather than the occasional lucky shot? Can you see how a programmer can choose an unreliable practice because it gives him the only hope of making the schedule, even though it may risk not finishing the program at all?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 当你开始一个项目时，你心里有明确的标准吗？这些标准是从您自己对重要事项的印象中获得的，还是从您的经理那里获得的？您的标准是否会随着项目的进展而改变，或者您是否有一些方法可以牢记这些标准？

1. Do you have criteria explicitly in mind when you start on a project? Are these criteria obtained from your own impression of what is important, or do you get them from your manager? Do your criteria change as the project progresses, or do you have some device for keeping them firmly in mind?

2. 你有多少次在写程序的时候想过将来某个人可能会修改它？您曾经诅咒过多少次您正在修改其程序的人？

2. How many times have you ever thought, when writing a program, of some person in the future who might modify it? How many times have you ever cursed someone whose program you were modifying?

3. 你是否曾经为了“效率”而以完成工作为代价？为了“赶上最后期限”而以做对为代价？

3. Have you ever tried for "efficiency" at the expense of getting the job done? For "meeting the deadline" at the expense of doing it right?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

Fisher, Ronald A.，《自然选择的遗传理论》，纽约，多佛出版社，1958 年。

Fisher, Ronald A., The Genetical Theory of Natural Selection, New York, Dover Publications, 1958.

参见第 11 章对自然选择基本定理的讨论。

See particularly Chapter 11 for a discussion of the Fundamental Theorem of Natural Selection.

Weinberg，GM，PL/I 编程，风格手册，纽约，McGraw-Hill，1970 年。

Weinberg, G. M., PL/I Programming, A Manual of Style, New York, McGraw-Hill, 1970.

特别参见第 4 章关于“好”程序的各种标准之间的折衷问题。

See especially Chapter 4 on the question of the compromises among the various criteria for "good" programs.

第 2 章的评论。什么是好的程序？

Comments on Chapter 2. What Makes a Good Program?

决定我们如何判断代码质量的最大新因素是经济因素。一个能够销售并赚取利润的程序显然比没有销售的程序要好。至少有几个非程序员告诉我，比尔盖茨是世界上最伟大的程序员。在我作为程序员的职业生涯中，我编写的大部分操作系统代码都被赠送了，所以我自然会对这种财务措施持怀疑态度。但是，老实说，如果写程序的目的是为了赚钱，那么程序赚钱最多的人肯定是最好的程序员——最善于实现需求的人。

The biggest new factor for determining how we judge the quality of code is the economic factor. A program that sells, and makes profits, is obviously better than one that doesn't. At least several non-programmers have told me that Bill Gates is the world's greatest programmer. In my career as a programmer, most of the operating system code I wrote was given away, so naturally I'm suspicious of this financial measure. But, in all honesty, if the purpose of writing the program is to make money, then the one whose program makes the most money is certainly the best programmer—the best at realizing the requirements.

在原始章节的效率与有效性的故事中，文件阅读活动当然与示例有关，但无论使用何种输入媒介，这一点都是相同的。多年来，我得出了一个概括这种情况的质量定义：对某些人的价值。对于那个时代的程序员来说，速度是比功能一致性更重要的价值衡量标准。价值心理学解决了许多关于我们的前辈为何做出他们所做选择的软件难题，这些难题否则将只是古老的谜团。

In the original chapter's story of efficiency versus effectiveness, the file-reading activity certainly dates the example, but the point is the same regardless of what input medium is used. Over the years, I've arrived at a definition of quality that generalizes this case: value to some person. To the programmers of that era, speed was a more important measure of value than was conformance to function. The psychology of value solves a great many software puzzles about why our predecessors made the choices they did, puzzles that would otherwise simply be ancient mysteries.

过去的几年已经证实了差异在质量管理中的重要性。我们的平均表现要好得多，但差异仍然存在，甚至有所扩大，客户仍然不满意。

The passing years have validated the importance of variance in managing for quality. We are doing much better in the mean, but the variance remains, or has even grown, and customers are still dissatisfied.

十年前，我会对七十年代如此无意识地使用性别歧视的语言感到尴尬（“美丽而谦逊的妻子”，以及“他”和“他的”，而“她”和“她的”会做得很好），因为我已经很清楚这种用法的假设，并努力将其从我的写作中根除。今天读原著，我只是觉得这种语言上的变化是我成长的一个有趣的衡量标准，希望社会也在成长。25 年前，我们当中很少有人意识到我们对性别歧视的写作做出了哪些假设。

Ten years ago, I would have been embarrassed by the sexist language used so unconsciously in the Seventies ("beautiful and modest wife," and "him" and "his" where "her" and "hers" would have done fine), because I had become well aware of the presumption of this usage and worked hard to root it out of my writing. Reading the original today, I simply find this change in language an interesting measure of my growing up, and hopefully society's growing up. Twenty-five years ago, few of us were aware of what assumptions we were making with our sexist writing.

许多经理似乎仍然什么都想要，并且不明白为了获得最好的产品而要求明智权衡的重要性。就好像他们认为管理纽约洋基队所需要做的就是告诉每个击球手打出本垒打，让每个投手将击球手击出局。

Many managers still seem to want everything, and fail to understand the importance of asking for intelligent trade-offs in order to get the best product they can. It's as if they think all you have to do to manage the New York Yankees is tell every batter to hit a home run, and every pitcher to strike the batter out.

正如预测的那样，计算机时间和人类时间之间的权衡已经发生了变化。“因此，我们预计随着时间的流逝，我们会越来越少地听到有关效率的信息，而越来越多地听到有关有效性的信息。” 尽管如此，仍然有一些工作对效率至关重要，但不是全部。我们正在学习这个。

The trade-off between computer time and human time has changed, as predicted. "And so we expect that with each passing year we will hear less and less about efficiency—and more and more about effectiveness." Nevertheless, there are still jobs where efficiency is essential, just not all. We are learning this.

在大多数情况下，我很惊讶章节末尾的问题部分经得起时间的考验——除了一些有趣的例外。书目参考也是如此，但不是特定于计算机的参考。似乎人类行为有一定的一致性，如果不是人类技术的话。

For the most part, I'm astonished at how well the Questions sections at the end of the chapters stand up to the test of time—with some hilarious exceptions. The same is true for the bibliographic references, though not the computer-specific ones. It seems that there is some consistency to human behavior, if not to human technology.

第 3 章我们如何学习编程？

Chapter 3. How Can We Study Programming?

 

在前两章中，我们试图为研究编程作为人类行为奠定基础。我们表明，虽然编程是人类行为的一种形式——一种复杂的形式，但很少有人从这个角度研究过编程。但也许编程没有被如此看待是有原因的？也许编程是一种过于复杂的行为，无法研究，并且必须在很大程度上保持神秘的过程。

In the first two chapters we have tried to set the stage for a study of programming as human behavior. We showed that although programming is a form—a complex form—of human behavior, few people have studied programming from this point of view. But perhaps there is a reason why programming has not been so viewed? Perhaps programming is too complex a behavior to be studied and must remain largely a mysterious process.

人类知识必然是不完整的。我们无法事先知道我们可能知道什么以及本质上可能无法知道什么。但有一件事我们可以肯定：如果我们不尝试去发现问题，我们将永远不会成功。对于那些对这次冒险的成功感到绝望的读者，我只能建议他们重新阅读本书这一部分开头的爱因斯坦名言：“重要的是不要停止提问。”

Human knowledge is by necessity incomplete. We cannot know in advance what we might be able to know and what might be essentially unknowable. But of one thing we can be sure: if we do not try to find things out, we shall never succeed. To those readers who despair of success in this venture, I can only suggest they reread the Einstein quote at the beginning of this part of the book: "The important thing is not to stop questioning."

那么，我们应该如何开始我们的提问呢？由于编程是人类行为，从人类行为科学中寻找两种信息似乎是明智的：我们可以直接应用于编程的结果，以及我们可以用来获取无法直接获得的信息的方法。当然，这些方法可能不适用于编程的研究，在这种情况下，我们必须发明新的方法，这是所有社会科学家一直在做的事情。但是让我们先看看我们通常可以使用哪些类型的方法。

How, then, shall we begin our questioning? Since programming is human behavior, it would seem wise to look to the sciences of human behavior for two kinds of information: results that we can apply directly to programming, and methods that we can use to get information not available directly. Of course, these methods may not be appropriate for the study of programming, and in such cases we shall have to invent new methods, something that all social scientists are doing at all times. But let us begin by seeing what types of methods are generally available to us.

内省

INTROSPECTION

尽管一些研究人类行为的现代学生倾向于认为它不科学，但内省一直是他们科学的第一块基石。例如，我们可以引用西格蒙德·弗洛伊德 (Sigmund Freud) 的话：*

Although some modern students of human behavior tend to discredit it as nonscientific, introspection has always been the first foundation stone of their science. We may quote, for example, Sigmund Freud:*

精神分析首先是通过对自己人格的研究在自身身上学习的。这并不完全是内省的意思，但可以这样描述是因为找不到更好的词了。有一整套非常普遍和广为人知的精神现象，当一个人对这种方法有了一些了解时，可以将其作为自我分析的材料。

Psychoanalysis is learnt first of all on oneself, through the study of one's own personality. This is not exactly what is meant by introspection, but it may be so described for want of a better word. There is a whole series of very common and well-known mental phenomena which can be taken as material for self-analysis when one has acquired some knowledge of the method.

 

或者我们可以引用美国心理学创始人威廉·詹姆斯**的话：

Or we may quote William James,** the founder of American psychology:

简而言之，很明显，我们对自己精神状态的了解远远超过了我们对其伴随的大脑状况的了解。如果没有对言语心理因素的内省分析，失语症学说是生理学中最璀璨的明珠，将是完全不可能的。

It is in short obvious that our knowledge of our mental states infinitely exceeds our knowledge of their concomitant cerebral conditions. Without introspective analysis of the mental elements of speech, the doctrine of Aphasia, for instance, which is the most brilliant jewel in Physiology, would have been utterly impossible.

 

诚然，这些是早期精神分析和心理学的引述，但这正是当我们着手研究人类行为的新领域时，它们的先例对我们如此重要的原因。并不是说我们打算停止反省——如果弗洛伊德和詹姆斯那样做了，他们的名字今天就不会被记住。但是在一个新的领域或子领域的开始，有大量的信息需要从人们的头脑中收集，而无需精心的预防措施或实验方法。我们一开始需要的是关于采取什么一般方向的想法，而不是旅程的详细后勤计划。

Now admittedly these are quotes from the early days of psychoanalysis and psychology, but that is precisely why their precedents are so important for us when we are embarking on the study of a new area of human behavior. Not that we intend to stop at introspection—if Freud and James had done that, their names would not be remembered today. But at the beginning of a new field or subfield, there is a great deal of information to be gleaned from the heads of people without elaborate precautions or experimental methods. What we need at the beginning are ideas as to what general directions to take, not detailed logistic plans for the journey.

内省可以产生什么样的见解？文中给出了几个例子，但此时应该用一个例子来说明该方法的用途和滥用。几年前，我的一个学生在用 PL/I 做一道课堂题时，对图 3-1 中所示的陈述遇到了异常多的困难。当他终于完成了这个项目时，我请他和我一起坐下来回忆一下他对这句话所经历的思考过程——困难。

What kinds of insights can introspection yield? Several examples are given in the text, but one at this point should serve to show the uses and abuses of the method. Some years ago a student of mine, in doing a classroom problem in PL/I, was having an inordinate amount of difficulty with the statement shown in Figure 3-1. When he finally finished the program, I asked him to sit down with me and recall the thought processes —the difficulties—he had experienced with this statement.

 

图 3-1 长 PL/I 语句。

Figure 3-1 A long PL/I statement.

 

这位学生提出了以下问题列表：

This student came up with the following list of problems:

• 他很难匹配括​​号，因为括号太多了。

• He had trouble getting the parentheses matched, because there were so many of them.

• 原来的ANGLES(I) 是一个结构体，不是数组，所以编译器抱怨下标列表不合法，但他没能找到问题，因为下标列表太多了。

• The original ANGLES(I) was a structure, not an array, so the compiler complained of an illegal subscript list, but he had not been able to find the problem because there were so many subscript lists.

当程序最终开始执行时，还有这些进一步的困难：

When the program finally got into execution, there were these further difficulties:

• IND 是列表另一页上的矩阵，他很难找到它。

• IND was a matrix on another page of the listing, and he had trouble finding it.

• 尽管现在括号匹配了，但其中一对放在错误的位置并且最难找到。

• Even though the parentheses were now matched, one pair was in the wrong place and was most difficult to find.

• 最后一个困难原来是由反复无常的不同数据类型声明、大表达式和除法引起的精度问题——如果使用 ATAND 的双参数形式，这就没有必要了。

• The last difficulty turned out to be a problem of precision caused by capricious declaration of different data types, by the large expression, and by the division—which would not have been necessary if the two-argument form of ATAND had been used.

现在，像这样的一个案例包含了对计算中许多问题的洞察：语句的适当大小、数据结构的选择、程序不同部分的安排、使用括号而不是其他分解技术、设计编译器和执行时诊断，以及用于学习和教授编程的技术。如果不进行这种自省，就无法获得这些见解，但每天都有成千上万的程序员遇到同样的问题，并且只是抱怨他们遇到了“错误”。如果没有内省，他们只会继续有“错误”，直到最后，错误会拥有它们。

Now, a single case such as this contains insights into many problems in computing: the proper size of statements, the choice of data structures, the arrangement of different parts of a program, the use of parentheses rather than other techniques for decomposition, the design of compiler and execution-time diagnostics, and techniques for learning and teaching programming. None of these insights could be obtained without introspection of this sort, yet thousands of programmers each day have these same problems and simply grumble that they are having "bugs." Without the introspection, they will simply continue to have "bugs" until, in the end, the bugs will have them.

然而，即使我们必须从内省开始，我们也不能就此止步，因为那样我们就是在实践魔法或宗教，而不是科学。基于这样一个例子，我们很难得出这样的一般规律：

However, even though we must start with introspection, we cannot stop there, for then we would be practicing magic or religion, not science. Based on one example such as this, we can hardly conclude such general laws as:

1. 大脑无法处理超过五层的括号。

1. The mind cannot cope with more than five levels of parentheses.

2. 编译器诊断应该更明确。

2. Compiler diagnostics should be more explicit.

3. PL/I 精度规则太复杂使用。

3. PL/I precision rules are too complicated to use.

尽管这些陈述中的每一个都可能成为编程心理学中的“法则”，但是根据一个内省的例子来写它很难成为法则。要成为“法律”，必须探索一个原则以对其应用设置限制，因为所有法律都有限制。事实上，限制通常比法律本身更重要，只有通过调查大量案例才能设定限制。因此，没有自省，研究就毫无意义；没有研究，自省的应用价值就成问题。

Although each of these statements might turn out to be a "law" in the psychology of programming, writing it on the basis of a single introspective example hardly qualifies it as a law. To be a "law," a principle must be explored so as to set limits to its application, because all laws have limits. Indeed, the limits are usually more important to know than the laws themselves, and it is only by investigating a multitude of cases that limits can be set. Thus, without introspection, investigation would be sterile, but without investigation, introspection will be of questionable value in application.

观察

OBSERVATION

跟进内省的一种方法是观察人们实际做了什么，而不是他们认为他们做了什么。例如，如果我们想研究括号级别的问题，我们可以观察其他人使用的级别数量，以及他们在使用它们时似乎遇到的困难。然而，观察的问题之一是它告诉我们人们做了什么，但不一定告诉我们他们能做什么做。因此，如果我们观察了数百名程序员并且从未发现任何人使用超过五级的括号，我们就无法得出人们无法使用六级括号的结论。然而，这种观察可以平息关于人们不能做什么的某些猜想，因为如果我们发现人们成功地使用了六层或更多层的括号，我们就解决了这个问题。

One way to follow up introspection is by observation of what people actually do, as opposed to what they think they do. If, for instance, we want to study the question of levels of parentheses, we could observe the number of levels that other people use, and the difficulties they seem to have in using them. One of the problems with observation, however, is that it tells us what people do do, but not necessarily what they can do. Thus, if we observed hundreds of programmers and never found any using more than five levels of parentheses, we could not conclude that people are unable to use six levels. Nevertheless, observations of this kind can lay to rest certain conjectures about what people cannot do, since if we find people successfully using six and more levels of parentheses, we settle the issue.

或者至少我们解决一些问题。观察的第二个问题是确定我们正在观察什么。程序员不会在任何情况下都使用六级括号——可能在某些情况下她真的无法成功地使用六级括号。一旦我们观察了六个层次，我们的工作才刚刚开始。接下来，我们必须划定可以发现和不能发现此类行为的情况。我们必须划定多远取决于我们打算如何使用观察结果。例如，如果我们正在设计一种编程语言，并且出于高效编译的原因，我们希望将嵌套括号的深度限制为五个，我们希望估计不使用六个会给人带来不便的频率。我们不一定要知道他为什么使用六个。

Or at least we settle some issue. A second problem with observation is deciding just what it is we are observing. A programmer doesn't use six levels of parentheses in just any context—there may be situations in which she really cannot use six levels successfully. Once we have observed the six levels, our work has only begun. Next we have to delimit the circumstances under which such behavior can be found and under which it cannot. How far we have to delimit depends upon the use we intend to make of the observation. For example, if we are designing a programming language and we would like—for reasons of efficient compilation—to limit the depth of nested parentheses to five, we would like to have estimates of how often somebody would be inconvenienced by not using six. We would not necessarily have to know why he was using six.

然而，我们在进行这样的观察时必须非常小心，因为编程是一种极其复杂的行为。例如，许多语言将数组的维数限制为三——不是出于任何心理原因，而是基于偶然的观察，似乎没有人使用超过三的维数。除了偶然性之外，这样的观察可能由于多种原因而出错。首先，如果程序员使用的语言只允许三个维度，那么我们永远不会观察到超过三个维度。其次，该语言的其他特征可能会阻止用户有效地使用三个以上的维度，即使该语言允许它们。也许更高阵列的打印格式没有选择好，或者下标的规范太笨拙以至于超过三个下标会造成混淆。因此，我们在尝试将观察结果从一种情况转移到另一种情况时必须非常小心，因为这些情况总是会在几个方面有所不同。

We must be extremely careful in making observations such as this, however, because programming is extremely complex behavior. Many languages, for instance, limit the number of dimensions that an array may have to three—not on any psychological grounds, but only on the casual observation that nobody seems to use more than three. Such an observation may be faulty for a number of reasons other than haphazardness. In the first place, if the programmer is working in a language that allows only three dimensions, we are never going to observe more than three. Secondly, other features of the language may prevent the user from making effective use of more than three dimensions, even though the language permits them. Perhaps the printing format for higher arrays is not well chosen, or perhaps the specification of subscripts is so clumsy as to be confusing beyond three. So, we must be most careful in trying to carry observations from one context over into another, because the contexts will always differ in several ways.

观察的第三个问题是观察者对被观察对象的干扰问题——一种不确定性原理。在这里，我们可以从社会科学中得到很多借鉴，社会科学长期以来一直关注这个问题，并提炼出了“霍桑效应”这样的现象。这种效应以西方电气公司的霍桑工厂命名，在 1924 年至 1927 年间，工业心理学的某些实验失败了。他们失败了，因为无论工作条件如何改变，生产率都提高了。最终，实验者开始意识到，缺失的因素是工人们为成为所有这些关注的对象而感到自豪。正是观察行为本身产生了被观察的现象。

A third problem with observation is the problem of interference of the observer with the subject being observed—a kind of Uncertainty Principle. Here we have much to draw on from the social sciences, which have long been concerned with this problem and have extracted such phenomena as the "Hawthorne Effect." This effect was named after the Hawthorne Works of the Western Electric Company, where between 1924 and 1927 certain experiments in industrial psychology failed. They failed because no matter how conditions of work changed, productivity rose. Eventually, the experimenters came to realize that the missing factor was the pride the workers took in being subjects of all this attention. It was the act of observation itself which was producing the phenomenon being observed.

被观察者和观察者的干扰不仅发生在工业心理学中，而且发生在所有研究人类行为的科学中。人类学家在他们的实地研究中经常被一种折磨人的恐惧所困扰，他们担心所观察到的行为是适合来访的人类学家的行为。通过“参与观察”的方法，人类学家试图通过成为文化的一部分而不被人们注意到，使自己对人们“隐形”，这样文化就可以像没有外人一样继续下去。参与观察法当然是编程学习中可以采用的一种方法。我们的学生，通常是程序员，已经很好地利用它来获取本书中报告的一些数据。

The interference of the observed and observer occurs not only in industrial psychology, but in all sciences that study human behavior. The anthropologists are constantly plagued in their field studies by the gnawing fear that the behavior being observed is that behavior appropriate for a visiting anthropologist. Through the method of "participant observation," the anthropologist tries to make herself "invisible" to the people by becoming so much a part of the culture that she is not noticed, so that the culture can go on as if no outsider were there. The method of participant observation is certainly one which can be used in the study of programming. Our students, who are often working programmers, have made good use of it in obtaining some of the data reported in this book.

另一种“隐形”的方式是以被观察者实际上不可能知道他们正在被观察的方式进行观察。存在许多这样的方法，它们都可以归类为“非侵入性措施”。我们没有必要在这里详细介绍这些措施，因为许多书籍和文章不仅讨论了这些方法，而且讨论了使用它们时的伦理和道德问题。但是我们应该花时间讨论一种或多或少是计算机研究所特有的非侵入性测量——计算机直接记录用户行为。

Another way of being "invisible" is to observe in ways in which the people observed actually have no possibility of knowing that they are under observation. Many such methods exist, and they may all be classified under the rubric of "unobtrusive measures." There is no need for us to go into detail about such measures here, as a number of books and articles discuss not only the methods but the ethical and moral problems in using them. But we should take time to discuss one type of unobtrusive measure which is more or less unique to computer studies—the direct recording of user behavior by the computer.

在某种程度上，任何进行自我核算的计算机系统都在对编程行为进行不引人注意的观察。已经进行了许多明确的研究，特别是分时系统，以了解用户在终端上的行为。（参见 Sackman，*** 1970，第 2 章，对这项工作的总结。）这些研究主要是统计，但由于计算机记录数据如此详细，所以没有理由不研究个人用户，即使在很长一段时间内。事实上，正是大量的细节迫使这些研究中的大多数成为统计数据，而潜在观察者面临的主要问题之一就是扔掉什么。一个人坐在终端前一小时产生的数据远远多于心理学家在一小时内能够有效分析的数据，当五十个用户共享该系统时，

In a way, any computer system that does self-accounting is doing unobtrusive observation of programming behavior. A number of explicit studies have been made, particularly of time-sharing systems to see how users behave at terminals. (See Sackman,*** 1970, Chapter 2, for a summary of this work.) These studies have been in the main statistical, but because the computer records data in such detail, there is no reason why individual users cannot be studied, even over long periods of time. In fact, it is the enormous amount of detail that has forced most of these studies to be statistical, and one of the major problems faced by the would-be observer is what to throw away. One man sitting at a terminal for one hour generates considerably more data than a psychologist can fruitfully analyze in one hour, and when fifty users are sharing the system, the situation is certainly not improved.

然而，我们绝不能被如此巨大的数量所迷惑，相信这些数据，就其绝对数量而言，一定包含我们想要的信息。虽然使用系统生成的正常记帐或日志信息很方便，但通常需要提供一些硬件或软件才能在仔细研究中得到我们真正想要的东西。例如，会计所需的时间信息通常不足以用于心理目的。首先，计时的单位可能不是我们希望研究的单位，而且很少有系统会在每次交易时记录时间。其次，出于会计目的，时间的分辨率级别可能足以达到一秒或更多，但对于许多心理学研究，我们可能希望降低到毫秒。

However, we must not be lulled by this enormous quantity into believing that such data, by its sheer bulk, must of needs contain the information we want. Although it is convenient to use the normal accounting or logging information generated by a system, it will usually be necessary to provide some hardware or software to get what we are truly after in a careful study. For example, the timing information needed for accounting will usually not suffice for psychological purposes. In the first place, the units timed may not be the units we wish to study, and few systems log a time with every transaction. Secondly, the resolution level of the timing for accounting purposes may be adequate to a second or more, but for many psychological studies, we may want to get down to milliseconds.

实验

EXPERIMENT

降低观察产生的大量数据成本的一种方法是设计实验。通过使用实验，更少的数据可以产生更多关于我们感兴趣的行为方面的信息。然而，实验的首要危险之一恰恰是它们可能过于精细以至于绕过了最有趣的数据。实验情境可能会如此限制受试者的行为，以至于我们永远不会看到我们在自然环境中观察她时所看到的。

One way to reduce the cost of the bulk of data produced by observation is to design experiments. Through the use of experiments, fewer data can produce more information about the aspects of behavior which interest us. One of the first dangers of experiments, however, is precisely that they may be so refined that they bypass the most interesting data. The experimental situation might so constrain the subject's behavior that we will never see what we saw when observing her in a natural setting.

影响主体行为的约束可能是有计划的，也可能是无计划的。举一个例子，Sackman 引用了比较在线和批处理系统的研究，其中批处理系统是通过在线运行作业但在交付给用户之前将工作保留一段固定时间来模拟的。该模拟的目的是确保两组程序员使用相同的语言工作并具有相同的可用系统设施。

The constraint influencing the subject's behavior may be either planned or unplanned. To take one example, Sackman cites studies comparing on-line and batch systems where the batch system is simulated by running the jobs on-line but holding the work for a fixed period before delivery to the user. The purpose of this simulation was to ensure that the two groups of programmers were working in the same language and had the same system facilities available.

然而，以这种方式模拟的批处理系统可能不同于真正的批处理系统。例如，使用的语言是根据终端用户的需要量身定制的。一些面向终端的系统命令不能使用，但没有被面向批处理的命令所取代。诊断面向终端使用，批处理系统可能提供的纠正措施可能不存在，因为终端用户更容易进行自己的纠正。最后，周转的规律性可能会带来更微妙的影响。正常的批处理系统不会在作业提交后的两个小时内准确返回作业，周转时间的差异对用户行为有重大影响。通过无意中消除方差，实验者可能使研究偏向一个方向或另一个方向。

A batch system simulated in this manner, however, may differ from a true batch system. For instance, the language used is tailored to the needs of terminal users. Some terminal-oriented system commands cannot be used, but are not replaced by batch-oriented commands. Diagnostics are oriented to terminal use, and corrective measures that might be provided in a batch system are probably not present, since it is easier for a terminal user to make her own corrections. Finally, a more subtle effect may be introduced by the very regularity of the turnaround. A normal batch system does not give jobs back precisely two hours after they are submitted, and the variance in the turnaround is a major influence on user behavior. By inadvertently eliminating the variance, the experimenters may have biased the study in one direction or the other. Only another study could tell which.

另一项研究！是的，有问题！研究需要花钱，而在编程方面，它们比人类行为的其他领域花费更多。例如，在一项小型研究中，我们使用了九名经验丰富的程序员四分之一的时间三个月。他们的平均工资为 14,000 美元，再加上适度的间接费用，即每人 20,000 美元，或在整个研究过程中每人 1250 美元。再加上实验者的薪水、电脑时间、各种用品和秘书服务的成本，账单很容易就达到 30,000 美元——九个受试者。

Another study! Aye, there's the rub! Studies cost money, and in programming they cost more than in other areas of human behavior. For instance, in one small study, we used one-quarter time of nine experienced programmers for three months. Their average salary was $14,000, which with modest overhead came to say, $20,000 apiece, or $1250 apiece over the course of the study. Add to this the cost of the experimenters' salaries, the computer time, and various supplies and secretarial services, and the bill comes easily to $30,000—for nine subjects.

在经典的心理学研究中，成本并没有那么高。首先，没有使用计算机——尽管现代趋势正朝着这个方向发展。然而，更重要的是科目通常是免费的。正如一个摇摆人所说，“心理是18岁大学新生的心理”。他的意思是，典型的科目来源是大学新生心理学课程，其中一项学分要求是作为科目参与一个实验。通常情况下，这些科目根本没有报酬，更不用说每年 14,000 美元了。

In the classical psychological study, costs do not run so high. In the first place, computers are not used—though the modern trend is in that direction. More important, however, is that subjects are usually free. As one wag put it, "psychology is the psychology of 18-year-old college freshmen." What he meant was that the typical source of subjects is the freshman psychology course in a university, where one of the requirements for credit is participation as a subject in one experiment. Normally, such subjects are not paid at all, let alone $14,000 a year.

在选择科目时，不经意的约束可能会溜进来。心理学可能是大学新生的心理学，而编程心理学很容易成为程序员实习生的心理学。出于同样的原因——成本。受训人员的薪水较低，但更重要的是，他们并没有像经验丰富的程序员那样做任何非常关键的事情。因此，无论它们是否适合作为特定实验的主题，它们都更容易获得用于实验。稍后，我们将讨论专业编程与业余编程的问题，并展示这种混淆是如何一直主导和混淆编程思想的。如果，在编程的心理学研究中，我们坚持使用受训者是为了成本或方便，

In selecting subjects, inadvertent constraint may slip In. Whereas psychology may be the psychology of college freshmen, the psychology of programming could easily become the psychology of programmer trainees. And for the same reason—cost. Trainees are paid less, but, more important, they are not doing anything very critical, as experienced programmers seem to be. Thus, they are far more easily obtainable for experimentation, regardless of their suitability as subjects for a particular experiment. Later on, we shall discuss the question of professional versus amateur programming, and show how this confusion has always dominated and befuddled the thinking about programming. If, in the psychological study of programming, we insist on using trainees as a matter of cost or convenience, we shall only compound these confusions and give them the weight of "scientific evidence."

毫无疑问，有些实验可以在受训者身上做得同样好，但举证责任在实验者身上。更多的时候，从受训者那里获得的结果在他们的应用中会受到限制，因此它们可能只对培训计划的设计有用。在一项研究中，我们试图确定使用 OS/360 作业控制语言 (JCL) 的难度——当时和现在一样，这是许多投诉的来源。在测试OS/360初学者班时，我们发现难度确实存在，但在完成课程学习后或多或少会完全消失，因为课程需要完成精心设计的习题。如果我们只是简单地测试初学者并就此止步，我们确实会得出结论，OS/JCL 非常难以使用，而不是正确的结论——它很难学。一旦开始学习——无论是通过课程还是通过痛苦的经历——JCL 都不会比任何其他相当死板的编程语言更难使用。尽管语言或许应该重新设计，但改进训练方法可能会取得更丰硕的成果。如果我们只是测试有经验的程序员，我们很可能会想知道这到底是怎么回事。只有通过对两组进行测试，或者像我们所做的那样，通过跟踪一组受训者直到他们变得有经验，我们才能正确地看待 JCL 的问题。尽管语言或许应该重新设计，但改进训练方法可能会取得更丰硕的成果。如果我们只是测试有经验的程序员，我们很可能会想知道这到底是怎么回事。只有通过对两组进行测试，或者像我们所做的那样，通过跟踪一组受训者直到他们变得有经验，我们才能正确地看待 JCL 的问题。尽管语言或许应该重新设计，但改进训练方法可能会取得更丰硕的成果。如果我们只是测试有经验的程序员，我们很可能会想知道这到底是怎么回事。只有通过对两组进行测试，或者像我们所做的那样，通过跟踪一组受训者直到他们变得有经验，我们才能正确地看待 JCL 的问题。

Undoubtedly it will turn out that some experiments can be done equally well on trainees, but the burden of proof is on the experimenter. More often, the results obtained from trainees will be limited in their application, so that they may be useful only for the design of training programs. In one study, we tried to determine the difficulty of using OS/360 Job Control Language (JCL)—then, as now, the source of many complaints. In testing the class of OS/360 beginners, we found that the difficulty did indeed exist, but more or less disappeared completely upon completion of the course of study because the course required the completion of carefully designed exercises. If we had simply tested beginners and stopped at that, we would have indeed concluded that OS/JCL was very difficult to use, instead of the proper conclusion—that it is very difficult to learn. Once the learning has taken place—whether through a course or through bitter experience—JCL is no more difficult to use than any other rather rigid programming language. Although the language perhaps should be redesigned, more fruitful results would probably be obtained from improved training methods. If we had just tested experienced programmers, we might well have wondered what the fuss was all about. Only by testing both groups, or—as we did—by following a group of trainees until they became experienced, could we put the problem of JCL in the proper perspective.

然而，无论我们使用有经验的程序员还是实习生，我们总是面临着这些简单标题往往隐藏的另一个困难。在我们对 JCL 的研究中，一些学生是编程方面的新手，而另一些则相当老手。然而，所有人都是 JCL 的新手。因此，如果我们简单地将我们的结果与“编程年数”相关联，作为“编程经验”的衡量标准，我们应该根本没有结果。当小组在课程开始时接受测试时，有经验的和没有经验的人都表现不佳；在课程结束时，各小组的表现同样出色。因此，在这个问题中重要的不是一般的“经验”，而是 JCL 的具体经验。

Whether we use experienced programmers or trainees, however, we are always faced with another difficulty which these simple titles tend to conceal. In our study of JCL, some of the students were relative novices at programming, while others were rather old hands. All, however, were novices at JCL. Thus, if we had simply correlated our results with "years of programming" as a measure of "programming experience," we should have had no results at all. When the group was tested at the beginning of the course, experienced and inexperienced alike did poorly; at the end of the course, the groups did equally well. Thus, it was not "experience" in general that mattered in this problem, but the specific experience with JCL.

萨克曼对“有经验”程序员的一项研究中的一个例子说明了简单衡量经验或缺乏经验的困难。在那里，经验是通过编程年限（从 2 年到 11 年不等）等其他方式来衡量的。在其中一个问题上，最好和最差的表现是由研究中的两名 11 年程序员获得的。显然，除了单纯的“编程”时间长度外，还有其他因素在起作用。可能是因为编程经验如此多样，以至于时间长度成为一种徒劳的衡量标准，或者可能是人们并非都从相同的经验中学到相同的东西。

The difficulty with simple measures of experience or inexperience is illustrated by an example taken from one of Sackman's studies with "experienced" programmers. There, experience was measured, among other ways, by years of programming, ranging from 2 to 11 years. On one of the problems, the best and worst performance was obtained by the two 11-year programmers in the study. Obviously, there are other factors at work than sheer length of time in "programming." It may be that the experiences in programming are so diverse as to make length of time a fruitless measure, or it may be that people don't all learn the same things from the same experiences.

在我们离开经验和实验这个主题之前，我们必须处理另一个问题，这个问题很重要，因为很少有人质疑编程的观点——本书将花大量时间来质疑这一观点。这种观点认为编程是一种个人活动，而不是一种社会活动。就实验者所相信的程度而言，他们选择了个体程序员（无论是否有经验）作为合适的研究对象。但是，正如我们现在将要看到的那样，有很多证据表明，对编程的正确研究是在编程社会单位的层面上完成的。并不是说个人水平不重要，但我们可能会首先问为什么，如果普通程序员花费三分之二的时间与其他人一起工作而不是单独工作（是的，这是真的！），

Before we leave the subject of experience and experiments, we must deal with one other problem, which is important because of a seldom-questioned view of programming—a view which this book will spend a great deal of time in questioning. That view is that programming is an individual activity, not a social activity. To the extent that experimenters have believed this, they have chosen the individual programmer—experienced or not—as the suitable object for study. But there is much evidence, as we shall see presently, to argue that the proper study of programming is done at the level of the programming social unit. Not that the individual level is unimportant, but we might start by asking why, if the average programmer spends two-thirds of his time working with other people rather than working alone (yes, it's true!), that 99 percent of the studies have been on individual programmers.

当然，一个答案是，如果研究程序员很昂贵，那么研究一群程序员就太奢侈了。此外，并不是任何一组程序员都会这样做——例如，不是将一组受训者放入一个“团队”。让一群人解决同一个问题并不能使他们成为一个团队——正如全明星赛马虎的表现应该告诉我们的那样。此外，即使研究今天的团队构成也可能不够，因为这些团队是在一个充斥着编程是个性最后堡垒的神话的环境中成长起来的。

One answer, of course, is that if studying programmers is expensive, studying groups of programmers is extravagantly so. Moreover, not just any group of programmers will do—not, for example, a collection of trainees put into a "team." Putting a bunch of people to work on the same problem doesn't make them a team—as the sloppy performance in all-star games should teach us. And furthermore, even studying teams as they are constituted today may not be sufficient, for these are teams which have grown up in an environment pervaded by the myth that programming is the last bastion of individuality.

对社会影响的忽视也对所有个人研究产生了怀疑，因为这些研究迫使个人将自己与正常的工作环境分开。在我们的一项研究中，一位程序员在完成编码后来找我，询问谁可以检查他的工作。在他的家庭小组中，这是开发阶段的标准做法，但在研究期间不允许这样做——以免使结果“无效”。回想起来，强迫程序员孤立地工作，就像试图通过切断青蛙的腿并将这些腿放在水中观察它们游泳来研究青蛙的游泳行为一样。毕竟，每个人都知道青蛙用它的腿游泳，那么为什么要用青蛙的所有其他部分进行实验呢？

The neglect of social effects also casts doubt upon all individual studies, since these studies force the individual to separate himself from his normal working environment. In one of our studies, one of the programmers came to me when he had finished coding and asked who could check his work. In his home group, this was the standard practice at this point in development, but it was not allowed during the study—lest it should "invalidate" the results. Looking back, it seems that forcing programmers to work in isolation is like trying to study the swimming behavior of frogs by cutting off their legs and putting those legs in the water to watch them swim. After all, everyone knows that the frog swims with its legs, so why complicate the experiments with all the rest of the frog?

心理测量

PSYCHOLOGICAL MEASUREMENT

使用“多年编程”作为“经验”的衡量标准只是编程心理学家面临的衡量问题的一个例子。在任何涉及人类行为的观察或实验中，如果不是数百万个，实际上也有数千个变量可以被测量。我们可以记录年龄或敏捷度、眨眼率或出生顺序、脑容量或教会偏好、演绎推理或授予的学位、心电图或初等数学、皱眉率或父亲的职业、做出的手势或平均成绩、身高或仇恨、想法或理想、不安或行话、仁慈或知识、左撇子或潜在的同性恋、母亲的整洁或肌肉紧张、母语或神经抽搐、持有的观点或接触的物体、偏好的食物或瞳孔运动，提出的问题或回答的问题、响应时间或寻求帮助、支持来源或口误、一天中的时间或脚轻敲、大学学位或非常规行为、词汇或投票记录、体重或工资、X 光照片或仇外指数、打哈欠或大学年限、合子或黄道星座。毫无疑问，心理学家是所有科学家中最善于窥探的。

The use of "years of programming" as a measure of "experience" is but one example of the problems of measurement faced by programming psychologists. In any observation or experiment involving human behavior, there are literally thousands, if not millions of variables, which might be measured. We can record age or agility, blink rate or birth order, cranial capacity or church preference, deductive reasoning or degrees awarded, electrocardiogram or elementary mathematics, frown rate or father's profession, gestures made or grade-point average, height or hatreds, ideas or ideals, jitteriness or jargon, kindliness or knowledge, left-handedness or latent homosexuality, mother's tidiness or muscle tension, native tongue or nervous tic, opinions held or objects touched, preferred foods or pupillary motion, questions asked or questions answered, response time or requests for assistance, source of support or slips of the tongue, time of day or tap of the foot, university degree or unconventional behavior, vocabulary or voting record, weight or wage, X-ray photographs or xenophobic index, yawns or years in college, zygosity or zodiacal sign. Surely the psychologist is the snoopiest of all the scientists.

然而，这只是问题所在。在所有科学中，心理学似乎拥有最多可能的测量对象——超出任何有理智的人所能理解的范围。但这种盈余是心理学独有的吗？并非如此，除了心理学——像其他行为科学一样——还处于起步阶段。伟大的物理学家麦克斯韦曾经说过，“测量就是知道”，他的话经常被其他科学当作座右铭。麦克斯韦的意思可能是“知道如何测量就是知道”，或者更确切地说，“知道测量什么就是知道”。在物理学中，可能的测量数量似乎更少，因为物理学家通过长期的经验已经知道什么值得测量，什么不值得测量。知道什么值得测量，物理学家可以将实验范围缩小到这些问题。从某种意义上说，

However, that is just the problem. Of all the sciences, psychology seems to have the most possible things to measure—more than any reasonable person can comprehend. But is this surplus unique to psychology? Not really, except that psychology—like the other behavioral sciences—is in its infancy. Maxwell, the great physicist, once said, "To Measure is to Know," and his words are often taken as a motto by other sciences. What Maxwell probably meant was "To know how to measure is to know," or even better, "To know what to measure is to know." In physics, the number of possible measurements seems smaller because physicists have learned, through long experience, what is worth measuring and what is not. Knowing what is worth measuring, the physicist can narrow the experimental field to those matters. In a sense, physics is the science of those things that physicists can measure.

然而，当我们研究人类行为时，我们并没有幸免于这种简化。我们不是根据我们可以测量的东西来定义我们的主题，而是根据我们想知道的——人类行为来定义我们的主题。然后我们必须在许多可能的测量中搜索，希望其中一个或几个能给我们一些洞察力，我们可以把它带回我们开始的问题。在这次搜索中，没有任何线索是微不足道的，没有任何荒谬的先验建议。就拿我们之前提到的“黄道星座”来说，它是不是被列为不合法的一项？但我们怎么知道？并不是说我们支持占星术，而是例如医学家发现对民间医学保持谦虚是谨慎的，在人类行为研究中也应该保持同样的谨慎。

When we study human behavior, however, we are not blessed with this simplification. We do not define our subject by what we can measure, but by what we would like to know about—human behavior. We then must search among many possible measurements in hopes that one or a few will give us some insight which we can carry back to the problem with which we began. No clue is too tiny to be ignored in this search, no suggestion ridiculous a priori. Take the "zodiacal sign" we mentioned earlier, Did that stand out as the one item on the list which was not legitimate? But how do we know? Not that we are arguing for astrology, but medical scientists, for instance, have found it prudent to be a bit humble about folk medicines, and the same prudence should be exercised in the study of human behavior.

事实上，最近的几项研究声称表明出生月份或季节与某些心理和生理变量之间存在相关性。无论它们证明了持久的观察结果还是仅仅是虚假的，都与当前争论的重点无关。重要的是要了解认真的工作人员如何能够在没有错误风险的情况下提前排除任何变量。由于我们在黑暗中工作了这么多，我们当然不能放弃我们研究对象的“民间智慧”，即使它们最终被证明是毫无根据的，甚至是完全错误的。

In fact, several recent studies have purported to show correlation between birth month or season and certain psychological and physical variables. Whether they prove durable observations or simply spurious is beside the point for the present argument. What is important is to see how serious workers cannot rule out any variables in advance without risk of error. And since we are working so much in the dark, we most certainly cannot afford to pass up the "folk wisdom" of our subjects, even if they ultimately prove groundless, or even outright wrong.

民间智慧只是洞察力的来源之一。另一个是目前用于其他目的的工具的存在。由于该工具存在并且至少对它有所了解，我们必须允许它影响我们所做的研究类型。因此，例如，由于存在“智能”测试，我们做的第一件事就是在程序员身上进行测试，希望在他们测量的内容（“智能”）和我们想要理解的内容（“良好的编程”）之间找到某种关系”）。如果幸运的话，我们会找到一些关系。

Folk wisdom is but one source of insight. Another is the existence of a tool presently used for some other purpose. Since the tool exists and something, at least, is known about it, we must allow it to influence the type of study we make. Thus, for instance, since "intelligence" tests exist, one of the first things we do is try them out on programmers, hoping to find some relationship between what they measure ("intelligence") and what we want to understand ("good programming"). If we are lucky, we will find some relationship.

最正常的做法是走另一条路——从问题到工具。Sackman 的工作就是这种进展的一个例子——他想了解分时系统的功效，因此他构建了一系列研究并测量了许多变量。另一个例子是 ACM 人事研究特别兴趣小组。这个松散的联合会主要对从管理角度进行编程，尤其是人事管理感兴趣。因此，他们的研究倾向于选择和培训领域，他们衡量的事物反映了这种兴趣。我们自己的大部分兴趣都集中在编程语言的设计上，我们所做的各种测量受到这种兴趣和其他任何事物的影响一样大。

The most normal course is to go the other way—from problem to tool. Sackman's work is one example of this progression—he wanted to know about the efficacy of time-sharing systems, so he constructed a number of studies and measured numerous variables. Another example is the ACM Special Interest Group on Personnel Research. This loose federation is interested mainly in programming from the point of view of management, and, more particularly, personnel management. Thus, their studies tend to be in the area of selection and training, and the things they measure reflect this interest. Much of our own interest has been in the design of programming languages, and the kinds of measurements we make are influenced as much by that interest as by anything else.

但是，当您对某个主题了解不多时，您并不知道要衡量什么。所以你早期的实验并不是他们看起来的样子——它们不是为了测量事物，而是为了确定什么可以测量以及什么值得测量。人类学和社会学方法学家之间的差异很好地说明了这里的差异。社会学家在他自己的文化中工作，他认为他对自己的文化有足够的了解，可以构建例如问卷作为测量工具。但是人类学家不能使用问卷，因为她不知道什么问题在另一种文化中是有意义的。粗略地说，我们可以说社会学家正在寻找答案，而人类学家正在寻找问题。

However, when you don't know very much about a subject, you don't know in advance what to measure. So your early experiments are not what they might seem to be—they are not to measure things, but to determine what can be measured and what is worth measuring. The difference here is well exemplified by the difference between the methodologists of anthropology and of sociology. The sociologist is working in his own culture, about which he assumes that he is sufficiently knowledgeable to construct, say, a questionnaire as a measuring instrument. But the anthropologist cannot use a questionnaire because she does not know what questions will be meaningful in another culture. Roughly, then, we might say that the sociologist is looking for answers and the anthropologist is looking for questions.

目前，编程心理学的大部分工作都将不得不“寻找问题”。尽管我们可能会使用标准的心理测量工具——调查、测试等——但我们实际上是在探索工具而不是主题。这一点的后果之一是它将限制我们发布诸如“测试分数与经验之间的相关性为 0.72”之类似是而非的测量值。虽然我们当然可以将“考试成绩”定义为我们希望的小数位数，但我们肯定无法将“经验”衡量到小数点后两位，甚至一个数量级。因此，0.72 中的“2”具有噪声的性质——“7”可能也是如此。

For the present, most of the work in the psychology of programming is going to have to be "looking for questions." Although we may use standard psychological measuring instruments—surveys, tests, and the like—we are really exploring the instruments rather than the subjects. One of the consequences of this point is that it will restrain us from publishing such specious measurements as "the correlation between test score and experience was 0.72." Although we may certainly define "test score" to whatever number of decimal places we wish, we certainly have no way of measuring "experience" to two decimal places, or even an order of magnitude. Thus, the "2" in 0.72 is of the nature of noise—and so, probably, is the "7".

我们在这里没有足够的篇幅来概览心理测量或心理统计的整个领域，但我们提供了一些很好的参考资料。没有人，但没有人，应该在不研究行为科学家已经经历过的陷阱的情况下，试图从该领域获得的这些数据中得出明确的结论。在我们进行演示时，我们将有机会对特定实例发表评论。

We haven't the space here to survey the entire field of psychological measurement or psychological statistics, but we have given several fine references. Nobody, but nobody, should attempt to draw hard conclusions from such data as are being obtained in this field without studying the pitfalls which the behavioral scientists have already experienced. We shall have occasion to comment on specific instances as we proceed with our presentation.

使用行为科学数据

USING BEHAVIORAL SCIENCE DATA

正如我们所讨论的，对我们来说，以前在行为科学方面的经验的主要用途可能是在方法论领域。由于编程的性质，其他领域的实际成果直接转移到我们这里的希望不大。我们对结果的使用必须是为了洞察，而不是为了答案。

Probably the main use of previous experience in behavioral science for us is in the field of methodology, as we have discussed. Because of the nature of programming, there is not much hope that actual results can be transferred directly from other fields to ours. Our use of results has to be for insights, not for answers.

我们最有可能在哪里找到我们的见解，以及如何？最好的计划是避免对过于具体的理论着迷，因为它们最终会证明是基于编程无法满足的前提。例如，关于“解决问题”的主题已经有大量的心理学工作，但这项工作的细节不适用于编程，因为“解决”的“问题”太简单了。它们必须很简单，因为几乎所有在这一领域进行的实验都是基于这样一种想法，即“问题”有一个正确的“解决方案”——而且心理学家知道这一点！

Where are we most likely to find our insights, and how? The best plan is to avoid getting fascinated with theories that are too specific, for they will ultimately turn out to be based on premises which programming does not satisfy. For example, there has been a great deal of psychological work on the subject of "problem solving" but this work in its details is not applicable to programming because the "problems" which are "solved" are simply too simple. They have had to be simple because almost all of the experimenting done in this area is based on the idea that there is one right "solution" to a "problem"—and that the psychologist knows it!

然而，在编程中，没有正确的“解决方案”——这一点我们可以肯定。但即使有，我们也不会比我们的研究对象更了解它。一次又一次，学生或新手提出在某些方面优于教师或老手的“解决方案”。因此，我们不能直接从解决问题的文献中获取结果，但我们当然可以在那里寻找见解。

In programming, however, there is no right "solution"—we can be sure of that. But even if there were, we could be sure that we would not know it any better than our subjects. Time after time, the student or novice comes up with "solutions" which are superior in some regard to the teacher's or veteran's. Therefore we cannot draw directly on the problem-solving literature for results, but we can certainly look there for insights.

可以从中获得有用见解的领域非常丰富，因此必须对我们的演示文稿进行一定程度的组织。组织可以帮助我们记住重要的想法，并通过结构中的缺陷建议可能找到帮助的其他领域。然而，我们应该尽量不要把我们的组织看得太重，因为它只是一种方便——一种工具——而不是从山顶的石碑上流传下来的一套真理。

The abundance of areas from which useful insights will be available makes it mandatory to impose a certain amount of organization on our presentation. Organization can help us to remember important ideas and suggest, by defects in the structure, other areas where aid might be found. We should try, however, not to take our organization too seriously, for it is only a convenience—a tool—and not some set of truths passed down on stone tablets from the mountain top.

为我们提供最有用的计算机编程整体模型的社会科学是人类学。凭借一点点艺术许可和想象力，我们可以想象计算机程序员拥有一种文化——一套共同的信念和活动，这些信念和活动塑造了他们的日常活动。在我们的编程研究中，我们将首先检查该文化的“社会结构”——程序员之间以及与非程序员的其他人之间的关系方式。我们将发现在这个领域比目前的实践有一些令人惊讶的改进的可能性，甚至比第二个研究领域——作为一项个人活动的编程——还要多。虽然做类比有点牵强，但这项研究与人类学家的人格和文化研究有关。我们将看到个人如何将他的个性赋予他的程序，以及编程如何塑造程序员自己。在社会结构的讨论中，我们将大量借鉴社会心理学，而在这里，我们将借鉴个体心理学的成果——尤其是问题解决和人格方面的成果。

The social science that provides us with the most useful overall model for computer programming is anthropology. With a little artistic license and stretching of the imagination, we could imagine computer programmers as having a culture—a shared set of beliefs and activities which shape their day-to-day activities. In our study of programming, we shall first examine the "social structure" of that culture—the way programmers relate to one another and to other people who are not programmers. We shall find some surprising possibilities for improvement in this area over present practices, more even than in the second area of study—programming as an individual activity. Although stretching a bit to make the analogy, this study is related to the personality and culture studies of the anthropologist. We shall see how the individual lends his individuality to his program and how programming lends shape to the programmer herself. Whereas in the social structure discussion we shall draw heavily on social psychology, here we shall draw upon the results of individual psychology—especially the areas of problem solving and personality.

做好了这两部分的铺垫之后，我们就应该有一个正确的心态，从心理学的角度来审视程序员的工具——语言、操作系统和其他设备。这些工具是编程的“物质文化”——编程考古学家为了理解已死的编程文明而发现和研究的人工制品。此外，由于程序员并非生来就是这种文化，我们将研究他们是如何——或应该如何——被招募的，以及他们如何学习这种复杂的生活方式。在这里，学习心理学——尤其是语言学习——将发挥重要但并非唯一的作用。

Once these two sections have prepared the way, we should be in a proper frame of mind to examine the programmer's tools—languages, operating systems, and other devices—from a psychological point of view. These tools are the "material culture" of programming—the artifacts the programming archeologist would find and study to understand the dead civilization of programming. Also, as programmers are not born into this culture, we shall study how they are—or should be—recruited, and how they learn this complex way of life. Here the psychology of learning—and especially language learning—shall play a large, though not exclusive, role.

最后，当我们成功地通过所有这些时，我们可能会发现自己处于一个足够客观的思维框架中，可以检查一些编程神话——编程信仰的文章。信仰，正如伯特兰罗素所指出的那样，是对没有证据的事物的信仰。此外，正如安布罗斯比尔斯曾经定义的那样，神话是其他人的神圣信仰。或许我们应该简单地放弃我们的旧信念，但如果只是一个毫无根据的编程神话因此消亡，那么这本书将是值得的。

Finally, as we pass successfully through all this, we may find ourselves in a sufficiently objective frame of mind to examine some of the myths of programming—the articles of programming faith. Faith, as Bertrand Russell pointed out, is the belief in something for which there is no evidence. Moreover, myths, as Ambrose Bierce once defined them, are the sacred beliefs of other people. Perhaps we shall simply carry away our old beliefs unchanged, but if just one unfounded programming myth should die as a result, this book will have been worth the effort.

概括

SUMMARY

因为编程是一项如此丰富和复杂的活动，我们将需要我们可以从所有行为科学中借用的所有丰富的方法和结果。但借用过程并非没有危险，在我们准备研究编程心理学时，我们应该特别准备自己避免常见的陷阱。主要问题包括：

Because programming is such a rich and complex activity, we shall need all the richness of methods and results we can borrow from all of the behavioral sciences. But the borrowing process is not without danger, and as we prepare ourselves to make studies in the psychology of programming, we should particularly prepare ourselves to avoid the common pitfalls. Among the major problems are:

• 在没有验证的情况下使用内省。

• Using introspection without validation.

• 在过于狭窄的基础上使用观察结果。

• Using observations on an overly narrow base.

• 观察到错误的变量，或未能观察到正确的变量。

• Observing the wrong variables, or failing to observe the right ones.

• 干扰观察到的现象。

• Interfering with the observed phenomenon.

• 生成的数据过多而信息不足。

• Generating too much data and not enough information.

• 过度限制实验。

• Overly constraining experiments.

• 过度依赖受训者作为主体。

• Depending excessively on trainees as subjects.

• 未能研究群体效应和群体行为。

• Failing to study group effects and group behavior.

• 只测量容易测量的东西。

• Measuring only what is simple to measure.

• 使用不合理的精度。

• Using unjustified precision.

• 将借用的结果转移到不适用的情况。

• Transferring borrowed results to inapplicable situations.

但在任何新兴领域，最大的错误也许就是过度谨慎。尽管我们试图遵守礼仪，但尝试过并失败总比根本没有尝试过要好。

But in any fledgling field, perhaps the greatest mistake of all is overcaution. Though we try to observe the proprieties, better to have experimented and lost than never to have experimented at all.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1. 您的安装使用什么类型的会计系统？你使用这个系统的数据来评估程序员的表现吗？数据是否用于此目的？可以做些什么来改进系统，使其对您更有用？

1. What type of accounting system does your installation use? Do you use data from this system to evaluate programmer performance? Are the data intended for this use, and what can be done to improve the system so that it is more useful to you for this purpose?

2. 你会允许有经验的程序员进行行为科学实验吗？和你的实习生？如果有人反对参加这样的实验，你会怎么做？您会要求实验者采取哪些保障措施？

2. Would you permit behavioral science experiments to be conducted with your experienced programmers? With your trainees? What would you do if a person objected to participating in such an experiment? What safeguards would you ask of the experimenters?

3. 你读过《哈佛商业评论》、《读者文摘》、《花花公子》、《Think》、《今日心理学》等杂志上有关心理学的文章吗？您是否曾尝试将一些报告的结果用于您的工作？将其他环境上报的数据转给程序员管理有哪些经验？

3. Do you ever read articles on psychology in such magazines as Harvard Business Review, Reader's Digest, Playboy, Think, or Psychology Today? Have you ever tried to put some of the reported results to use in your work? What kinds of experiences did you have in transferring data reported from other circumstances to the management of programmers?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 当你刚发现一个 bug 时，你有没有坐下来试着在脑海中找出你走过的路？尝试对您发现的下一个错误执行此操作，并写一份简短的报告或概述您发现的内容。

1. When you have just found a bug, do you ever sit back and try to trace out the paths you took in your mind? Try doing this on the next bug you find, and write a brief report or outline of what you find.

2. 你有记录你的表现吗？您记录了哪些内容，记录的准确度如何？你从这些观察中得到了什么是你无法通过简单反思你正在做的事情得到的？您的安装核算程序是否曾让您深入了解您的行为或安装中其他程序员的行为？

2. Do you keep records of your performance? What kinds of things do you record, and how accurately do you record them? What picture do you get from these observations which you could not get by simple reflection on what you are doing? Does your installation accounting routine ever give you insights into your behavior, or the behavior of other programmers in your installation?

3. 你是否反对参加心理实验来学习编程？需要什么样的保证才能克服您的反对意见？如果您曾经参加过心理实验，请写一份小报告或概述您记得的关于该经历的最重要的事情。您是否看到研究结果可能无效或对编程无效的任何原因？您是否曾经向您展示过研究结果，或者是否向您解释了研究的原因？

3. Would you have any objections to participating in psychological experiments to study programming? What kinds of assurances would be required to overcome your objections? If you have ever participated in a psychological experiment, write a small report or outline of the most significant things you remember about the experience. Do you see any reasons why the results of the study might not be valid, or valid for programming? Were you ever shown the results of the study, or did you have the reason for the study explained to you?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

* Freud, Sigmund, A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis , Garden City, NY, Doubleday, 1953.（引用经 Sigmund Freud Copyrights. Ltd. 许可使用，英国伦敦。）

* Freud, Sigmund, A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis, Garden City, N.Y., Doubleday, 1953. (Quotation used by permission of Sigmund Freud Copyrights. Ltd., London England.)

这本书本身就很有趣，也可以作为关于人类行为新研究开始方式的历史文献。在当前语境中，特别有趣的是弗洛伊德必须让他的听众相信这个主题确实存在的方式。他这样做的方法之一是通过讨论错误——“口误”等。这个特别的讨论是编程人员特别感兴趣的。

Of great interest in and of itself, this book is also useful as a historical document on the way in which a new study of human behavior begins. Especially interesting in the present context is the way Freud has to convince his audience that the subject really exists. One of the ways he does this Is through his discussion of errors—"slips of the tongue" and the like. This particular discussion is of special interest to programming people.

** James, William, Psychology , Cleveland, The Living Library, 1948。这部由“第一个将现代科学的方法和精神扩展到人类思维”的人所著的经典著作的某些部分已经过时，但不多。与弗洛伊德一样，对詹姆斯的研究为计算机编程心理学的现代学生带来了很多成果，这两本书很可能是研究这一主题的合适起点，以免丢失历史视角。

**James, William, Psychology, Cleveland, The Living Library, 1948. Certain parts of this classic by the man who was "first to extend the methods and spirit of modern science to the human mind" are outdated, but not many. As with Freud, the study of James bears many fruits for the modern student of the psychology of computer programming, and these two books might well be the proper starting place for a study of this subject, in order that historical perspective not be lost.

JAC Brown，《工业社会心理学》，巴尔的摩，Penguin Books，1954 年。

Brown, J. A. C., The Social Psychology of Industry, Baltimore, Penguin Books, 1954.

关于研究工作组实践的可读性很强的说明，它对霍桑效应等问题提供了很好的历史观点。这本书被推荐为那些进入工业心理学领域的人的有效研究，尽管它可能与处理像编程这样复杂的任务的工作相关性有限，但任何认真参与该领域的人都必须研究。至少，Brown 对该领域早期的回顾将警告我们避免某些我们可能容易犯的过激行为。

A very readable account of the practice of studying working groups, which gives a good historical view of such matters as the Hawthorne Effect. The book is recommended as an effective study for those entering the field called Industrial Psychology, which, although It may have limited relevance to work on tasks as complex as programming, must be studied by anyone seriously involved in this field. At the very least, Brown's review of the early days of the field will warn us against certain excesses to which we might otherwise be prone.

Junker, Buford H„ Field Work— An Introduction to the Social Sciences，芝加哥，芝加哥大学出版社，1960 年。

Junker, Buford H„ Field Work—An Introduction to the Social Sciences, Chicago, University of Chicago Press, 1960.

作者声称——可能是真的——如果不亲身体验，就无法正确地欣赏田野工作。然而，通过承认他的局限性，他在反驳该陈述方面做得很好，读者可以对社会学和人类学的各种田野工作方法有所了解。

The author claims—with probable truth—that one cannot properly appreciate field work without experiencing it. Yet by acknowledging his limitations, he does as good a job as he can at disproving that statement, and the reader can obtain some sense of the various field work methods of sociology and anthropology.

Golde, Peggy, ed., Women in the Field , Chicago, Aldine, 1970.

Golde, Peggy, ed., Women in the Field, Chicago, Aldine, 1970.

标题中的“女性”有点误导，因为这本书展示的一件事是田野工作者的性别实际上造成的差异有多大。这本书可以从多个层面来阅读——既可以作为完全有趣的轶事材料，也可以作为对人类学田野方法的全面（如果没有组织的话）调查。

The "Women" in the title is a bit misleading, since one of the things the book demonstrates is how little difference the gender of a fieldworker actually makes. The book can be read at several levels—either as thoroughly enjoyable anecdotal material or as a comprehensive—if not organized—survey of anthropological field method.

Hammond, Phillip E., Sociologists at Work , New York, Basic Books, 1964。关于方法的轶事材料集，如实地女性，但面向社会学家而不是人类学家。其中有几章是关于研究的，编程心理学家对这些研究本身很感兴趣：“官僚主义的动态”、“管理人员”和“工会民主”。

Hammond, Phillip E., Sociologists at Work, New York, Basic Books, 1964. A collection of anecdotal material on method, like Women in the Field, but oriented to the sociologist rather than the anthropologist. Several of the chapters are about studies, which are in themselves of interest to the psychologist of programming: "The Dynamics of Bureaucracy," "Men Who Manage," and "Union Democracy."

Webb, Eugine J., et a/.. Unobtrusive Measures: Nonreactive Research in the Social Sciences , Chicago, Rand McNally, 1966. 对心理学研究技术专门子集的调查。

Webb, Eugine J., et a/.. Unobtrusive Measures: Nonreactive Research in the Social Sciences, Chicago, Rand McNally, 1966. A survey of a specialized subset of psychological research techniques.

Sackman, Harold，《人机问题解决》，普林斯顿：奥尔巴赫出版社，1970 年。

Sackman, Harold, Man-Computer Problem Solving, Princeton: Auerbach Publishers, 1970.

尽管副标题为“分时和批处理的实验评估”，但这本书是我们第一本关于编程心理学研究方法的书。因此，对于认真的学生来说，这是必不可少的阅读材料。

Although subtitled—Experimental Evaluation of Time-Sharing and Batch Processing—the book is the first we have on methods of psychological research in programming. As such, it Is essential reading for the serious student.

Hyman, HH, Survey Design and Analysis , New York, Free Press, 1955。可能是关于民意调查理论和实践的最好和最透彻的文本。

Hyman, H. H., Survey Design and Analysis, New York, Free Press, 1955. Possibly the best and most thorough text on the theory and practice of public opinion surveys.

Cronbach, LJ，《心理测试要点》，第 3 版，纽约，Harper and Row，1970 年。

Cronbach, L. J., Essentials of Psychological Testing, 3rd ed., New York, Harper and Row, 1970.

对各种心理测验的构建和应用的基本介绍，但因此作为介绍很有用。

An elementary, but therefore useful as an introduction, account of the construction and application of psychological tests of various kinds.

Hammond、KR 和 JE Householder，统计方法简介，

Hammond, K. R., and J. E. Householder, Introduction to the Statistical Method,

纽约，Knopf，1962 年。数百本关于心理统计的书籍中最好的一本，与任何一本介绍一样好。面向数学的程序员可能会被这样的书拒之门外，这些书是为未洗过数学的人而写的，但是这本书非常可口。无论如何，重要的是要了解心理学家如何看待定量数据。

New York, Knopf, 1962. One of the better of hundreds of books on psychological statistics, and as good as any as an introduction. Mathematically oriented programmers may be turned off by such books, which are written for the mathematically unwashed, but this one is quite palatable. In any case, it is important to know how psychologists think about quantitative data.

Morgenstern, Oskar, On the Accuracy of Economic Observations , Princeton, Princeton University Press, 1963. 经济学是另一门行为科学，虽然它与编程心理学没有太大直接关系，但我们可以从它的方法论问题中学到一些东西。摩根斯坦与博弈论的约翰·冯·诺依曼共同发明，将他的钢铁陷阱思想带到了经济数据到底有多好这个问题上。但这本书的前半部分绝不是专门针对经济学的，所有行为科学家都应该阅读。

Morgenstern, Oskar, On the Accuracy of Economic Observations, Princeton, Princeton University Press, 1963. Economics is another behavioral science, and although it does not have much direct bearing on the psychology of programming, we can learn something from its methodological problems. Morgenstern, co-inventor with John von Neumann of Game Theory, brings his steel-trap mind to the question of how good economic numbers really are. But the first half of the book is in no way really specific to economics, and should be required reading for all behavioral scientists.

第 N 届年度计算机人员研究会议论文集，纽约计算机协会。随着 N 的发展，这些会议的规模和范围也在扩大。因此，它们的可用性也有所提高，该领域的每个研究人员都应该知道它们。尽管早期的问题很难获得，但它们可能比后来的问题更有价值，因为它们将最早的斗争与尚未接近解决的问题联系起来，但我们已经变得更加复杂。

Proceedings of the Nth Annual Computer Personnel Research Conference, Association for Computing Machinery, New York. As N has grown, so has the size and scope of these conferences. So also has their availability grown, and they should be known by every researcher in this field. Even though the early issues are difficult to obtain, they are perhaps even more valuable than the later ones in that they relate the earliest struggles to come to grips with problems not yet nearly solved, but about which we have become a bit more sophisticated.

Parsons, Henry M„“基于计算机的数据处理系统中人为因素的范围”，人为因素，12, 2 (1970)，第 165-175 页。

Parsons, Henry M„ "The Scope of Human Factors in Computer-Based Data Processing Systems," Human Factors, 12, 2 (1970), pp. 165-175.

这篇文章出现在Human Factors中可能标志着人因工程师对编程产生了新的兴趣，尽管本文的大部分内容都与计算机的非编程方面有关。并不是说非编程方面不重要——远非如此——而是它们超出了本书的范围，可能需要三四本书才能全面了解。该文章不包含任何新数据，但提供了一些已完成工作的参考资料。

The appearance of this article in Human Factors probably signals the beginning of a new interest by human factors engineers in programming, although most of the article is concerned with non-programming aspects of computers. Not that nonprogramming aspects are unimportant—far from it—but only that they are beyond the scope of this book, and would probably require three or four books to survey. The article contains no new data, but gives a few references to work already done.

第三章点评：我们如何学习编程？

Comments on Chapter 3: How Can We Study Programming?

“也许编程是一种过于复杂的行为，无法研究，并且必须在很大程度上保持神秘的过程。” 经过四分之一个世纪的学习，我不认为编程是一种太复杂而无法研究的行为，但它可能太复杂而无法在实验室中研究。我想我已经改变了关于如何学习编程的想法，或者更准确地说，我改变了学习编程的方式。学术过程是必不可少的，但它对我的心理新陈代谢来说太慢了。对于我目前的客户来说，它也磨得太慢了，他们对稳健和实用的想法感兴趣，但不一定对科学的想法感兴趣。

"Perhaps programming is too complex a behavior to be studied and must remain largely a mysterious process." After a quarter-century of learning, I don't think programming is too complex a behavior to be studied, but it may be too complex to be studied in a laboratory. I guess I've changed my ideas on how to study programming, or more properly, how I study programming. The academic process is essential, but it grinds too slowly for my mental metabolism. It also grinds too slowly for my current clients, who are interested in robust and practical ideas, but not necessarily in scientific ones.

多年来，我观察到“最好的”程序员是最内省的。如果他们做错了什么，他们会检查导致问题的心理过程（或物理过程）；然后他们做一些事情来改变这个过程。这就是我们 Weinberg 和 Weinberg 试图在“根本原因分析”的标题下向组织传授的内容，但这种方法尚未受到很多人的青睐。他们中有太多人仍然关注“责备分析”，这种方法可以保证激励人们以隐藏根本原因的方式行事。

Over the years, I've observed that the "best" programmers are the most introspective. If they do something wrong, they examine the mental processes (or physical processes) that led to the problem; then they do something to change the process. This is what we at Weinberg and Weinberg try to teach to organizations, under the title "root-cause analysis," but this approach is not yet favored by very many people. Too many of them are still concerned with "blame-analysis," an approach that is guaranteed to motivate people to behave in ways that conceal root causes.

长期以来，在研讨会和书籍中，行为观察一直是我的主要关注点。例如，在我的解决问题领导力研讨会中，有人指责我“只”教人们看他们以前看不到的东西，或者以不同的方式看熟悉的东西。我学到的是，一旦他们有了这种新的观察方式，大多数聪明人都能够改变他们所观察到的错误并保留正确的地方。

Observation of behavior has long been a major focus of mine, in workshops and in books. In my Problem-Solving Leadership workshop, for example, I've been accused of "only" teaching people to see things they didn't see before, or to see familiar things in a different way. What I've learned is that once they have this new way of seeing, most intelligent people are quite capable of changing what's wrong and preserving what's right about whatever they observe.

霍桑效应（“被观察的过程通常会激发人们更好的表现”）可能是科学观察的祸根。然而，多年来，我学会了利用霍桑效应在我的咨询业务中发挥巨大的实际优势。这种优势的一个显着例子发生在几年前，当时我观察了一个客户的技术审查，试图帮助他们的开发人员确定他们的流程出了什么问题。我观察到的评论非常有成效，但他们说这不是典型的。我问他们是什么导致了不同，他们说是因为我在看。在我的注视下，他们不好意思表现得不好。因此，他们拍了我的照片并将其放大，将我制作成真人大小的纸板剪纸，以参加他们未来的所有评论。

The Hawthorne Effect ("the process of being observed often motivates people to better performance") can be the bane of scientific observation. Over the years, however, I've learned to use the Hawthorne Effect to great practical advantage in my consulting business. A striking example of this advantage occurred a few years ago when I observed a client's technical review, trying to help their developers determine what was going wrong with their process. The review I observed was highly productive, but they said it wasn't typical. I asked them what might have caused it to be different, and they said it was because I was watching. With me watching, they were too embarrassed to behave badly. So, they took my photograph and enlarged it to make a life-sized cardboard cutout of me to attend all their future reviews. It seems to have worked fine.

从这个和其他的观察中，我学到了管理心理学的一个基本原则：关注人的管理者会取得好的结果。

From this and other observations, I've learned a basic principle of the psychology of management: Managers who pay attention to people get good results.

许多经理（尤其是那些曾经是程序员的经理）希望他们的员工表现得像代码模块。这些经理认为程序员应该是小黑盒，任务输入和工作输出，不需要观察，尤其是不需要交互。许多软件开发经理只是讨厌与他们的员工一起工作，主要是因为他们从未接受过有关如何完成该任务的任何培训。

Many managers (especially those who were once programmers) want their people to behave like modules of code. These managers think programmers should be little black boxes that tasks are fed into and work comes out of, with no observing necessary, and especially no interaction. Many software development managers simply hate working with their staff, mostly because they have never received any training on how to do that task.

仅仅通过观察，我还发现了一些新的、丰富的信息来源。例如，通过研究几家软件公司服务热线的电话记录，我了解到一些奇怪的新人类行为模式。我还了解到，围绕计算机的人类行为的多样性远远超过我 25 年前的想象。

Simply by observing, I've also found some new, rich sources of information that are just laying around. For example, by studying records of phone calls to the service line of several software companies, I've learned some strange new patterns of human behavior. I've also learned that the diversity of human behavior around computers is far greater than even I could ever have imagined twenty-five years ago.

然而，涉及人类行为的实验证明与我预想的一样昂贵和困难。大多数研究都是在大学环境中进行的，虽然通常很吸引人，但对实际编程实践的影响缓慢且微乎其微。即使这项工作至关重要且值得认可，研究人员也必须将其变成有价值的交流。相反，大学教人们成为开发人员时的隐性交流通常与大学自己的研究结果背道而驰。许多受过大学培训的开发人员处理一个项目就像一个学期的课堂作业。他们考虑或忽略它一段时间，然后突然开始在键盘上即兴创作一些能获得及格分数的东西。在大学完成的软件项目通常不必是可维护的、可用的、或可由另一个人测试。专业软件需要做的不仅仅是表明开发人员掌握了计算机科学概念，我向那些要求更多学生项目的大学教授致敬。

Experiment involving human behavior, however, has proved as costly and difficult as I predicted. Most studies are carried out in university settings, and, though often fascinating, have had slow and minimal influence on actual programming practice. Even if the work is vital and worthy of recognition, the researchers must turn it into a worthy piece of communication. Instead, the implicit communications when universities teach people to become developers generally runs contrary to the university's own research results. Many college-trained developers approach a project like a one-semester class assignment. They think about it or ignore it for a while, then suddenly start jamming on the keyboard to produce something that will earn a passing grade. Software projects done at universities generally don't have to be maintainable, usable, or testable by another person. Professional software needs to do more than show that the developer has a grasp of computer science concepts, and I salute those college professors who demand more of their students' projects.

与 25 年前一样，个体差异是项目可预测性的祸根。团队编程的社会性可以用来对这种变化进行平均——但这种平均也阻止我们获得关于个体程序员的实验信息。实际项目中个体差异的毁灭性代价支持了我的预测的有效性，即单独工作的个体既不是一个富有成果的学习单元，也不是编程项目工作。

Individual variation is, as twenty-five years ago, the bane of project predictability. The social nature of team programming can be used to average out this variation—but such averaging also prevents us from getting experimental information about individual programmers. The devastating cost of individual variation on real projects has supported the validity of my prediction that the individual working alone is neither a fruitful unit of study, nor of programming project work.

在本章中，我写道麦克斯韦说：“测量即知晓。” 如今，每个人似乎都想将这句话的某些版本归功于开尔文勋爵，也许是为了增加贵族的声望。这种将开尔文勋爵与测量的重要性联系起来的愿望让我感到困惑，因为开尔文勋爵还在 1899 年断言“我可以直截了当地说，比空气重的飞行器是不可能的。” 那是莱特兄弟比空气重的机器飞行之前的 4 年。

In this chapter, I wrote that Maxwell said, "To Measure Is To Know." Nowadays, everyone seems to want to attribute some version of this quote to Lord Kelvin, perhaps to add the prestige of peerage. This desire to associate Lord Kelvin with the importance of measurement puzzles me, since Lord Kelvin also asserted in 1899 that "I can state flatly that heavier than air flying machines are impossible." That was 4 years before the Wright brothers' heavier than air machine flew.

人们对测量给予了很多关注，但没有多少测量专门用于理解编程是如何发生的。相反，许多衡量标准似乎旨在控制个别程序员而不与他们互动——也就是说，强迫他们按照其他人认为是他们编程的正确方式的某种模型工作。这并不总是一个好主意。

A lot of attention has been given to measurement, but not much measurement is devoted to understanding how programming happens. Instead, much measurement seems to be designed to control individual programmers without interacting with them—that is, to force them to work according to some model that someone else thinks is the right way for them to program. This is not always a good idea.

也许这个想法的出现是因为我们仍然坚信对于一个给定的编程问题只有一种解决方案——而且老师知道它是什么。许多培训仍然基于这种错误的信念，但我们正在侵蚀边缘。

Perhaps this idea comes because we are still stuck with the belief that there is one and only one solution to a given programming problem—and the teacher knows what it is. Lots of training is still based on this erroneous belief, but we are eroding the fringes.

“有了一点艺术许可和想象力的延伸，我们可以想象计算机程序员拥有一种文化——一套共同的信仰和活动，这些信仰和活动塑造了他们的日常活动。” 所以我在 1971 年写道，随着时间的推移，文化模式已经出现——无论是在事实上还是在我们的意识中。我在我的质量软件管理系列中提出了软件文化的概念，因为我认为文化是未来 25 年为数不多的重要思想之一。

"With a little artistic license and stretching of the imagination, we could imagine computer programmers as having a culture—a shared set of beliefs and activities which shape their day-to-day activities." So I wrote in 1971, and over time, cultural patterns have emerged—both in fact and in our consciousness. I have developed the idea of software culture in my Quality Software Management series, because I think culture is one of the few important ideas for the next twenty-five years.

第 2 部分。将编程作为一种社交活动

Part 2. Programming as a Social Activity

 

我在农奴主家庭长大，开始了积极的生活，就像我那个时代的所有年轻人一样，对命令、命令、责骂、惩罚等的必要性充满信心。但是，在早期，当我不得不管理严肃的企业并与人打交道时，当每一个错误都会立即导致严重的后果时，我开始意识到按照命令和纪律的原则行事与按照命令和纪律行事之间的区别。共识原则。前者在阅兵式上表现出色，但在现实生活中一文不值，只有众志成城、艰苦奋斗才能实现。- 彼得克鲁泡特金*

Having been brought up in a serf-owner's family, I entered active life, like all young men of my time, with a great deal of confidence in the necessity of commanding, ordering, scolding, punishing, and the like. But when, at an early stage, I had to manage serious enterprises and to deal with men, and when each mistake would lead at once to heavy consequences, I began to appreciate the difference between acting on the principle of command and discipline and acting on the principle of common understanding. The former works admirably in a military parade, but it is worth nothing where real life is concerned, and the aim can be achieved only through the severe effort of many converging wills. - Peter Kropotkin*

 

程序员通常不会孤立地工作。尽管个别程序员可能会发现自己被分配了编写程序的任务，但即便如此，她也有其他程序员可以向他们寻求帮助——同时，其他程序员也可能会向她求助。

Programmers do not ordinarily work in isolation. Although an individual programmer may find herself assigned the task of writing a program, even then she has other programmers to whom she may turn for help—and who, at the same time, may be turning to her.

事实上，正如我们将要看到的，独自工作的程序员在严重的障碍下工作。但是在与他人合作时，可能存在多种类型的关系。出于我们的目的，我们将确定三种程序员组合——团队、团队和项目。粗略地说，组就是程序员的集合，在同一个地方工作，很可能共享同一台机器和系统，但在不同的程序上工作，尽管其中一些程序之间可能存在关系。典型的编程小组可能出现在大学计算中心、工程公司或任何“开放式商店”运行的地方。

Indeed, as we shall see, the programmer working alone is working under a serious handicap. But when working with others, many types of relationships can exist.
