For our purpose, we shall identify three sorts of programmer assemblage—the group, the team, and the project. Roughly speaking, the group is a collection of programmers, working in the same place, probably sharing the same machine and system, but working on separate programs, although there may be a relationship among some of the programs. A typical programming group might be found in a university computing center, an engineering firm, or wherever an "open shop" is run.

另一方面，编程团队是一群试图通过合作来生成单个程序的程序员。一个团队可能由 2 到 12 名成员组成，但随着人数的增加，团队开始分解为两个或更多的团队。该团队可能存在于一个编程组中，或者可能是组成一个编程项目的许多人组成的一个团队。该项目是一组程序员加上他们的支持活动，这些活动可能被聚集在一起以产生一个单一的集成系统，或者至少是一个紧密结合的程序集合。它通常会有自己的机器，加上专门的团队来提供系统工作、测试、标准、文档和其他功能。它通常还会有一个项目经理和一个正规的官僚组织——就像奥地利军队一样。

A programming team, on the other hand, is a collection of programmers who are trying to produce a single program by working together. A team might consist of from two to twelve members, though with the larger numbers the team begins to break down into two or more teams. The team may exist within a programming group or perhaps be one team of many making up a programming project. The project is a group of programmers plus their supporting activities which has probably been brought together for the purpose of producing a single integrated system, or at least a closely knit collection of programs. It will often have its own machine, plus special teams to provide systems work, testing, standards, documentation, and other functions. It will also ordinarily have a project manager and a regular bureaucratic organization—like the Austrian army.

* 转载自彼得·克鲁泡特金 (Peter Kropotkin) 的《革命者回忆录》。版权所有 1968。经纽约 Horizo​​n Press 出版商许可。

* Reprinted from Memoirs of a Revolutionist, by Peter Kropotkin. Copyright 1968. By permission of the Publisher, Horizon Press, New York.

第 2 部分的评论：将编程作为一种社交活动

Comments on Part 2: Programming as a Social Activity

那时，我写道有

Back then, I wrote that there were

“......三种程序员组合——小组、团队和项目。粗略地说，小组是程序员的集合，在同一个地方工作，可能共享同一台机器和系统，但在不同的程序上工作，尽管某些程序之间可能存在关系。...”

"...three sorts of programmer assemblage—the group, the team, and the project. Roughly speaking, the group is a collection of programmers, working in the same place, probably sharing the same machine and system, but working on separate programs, although there may be a relationship among some of the programs. ..."

 

“...另一方面，一个编程团队是一群试图通过合作来制作单个程序的程序员。”

"... A programming team, on the other hand, is a collection of programmers who are trying to produce a single program by working together."

 

在又观察了 25 年的程序员群体之后，我改变了自己对团队的定义。现在，我会说，

After observing groups of programmers for another quarter-century, I have changed my own definition of team. Now, I would say,

“一个编程团队是一群程序员，他们试图通过合作来生产更好的产品。”

"A programming team is a collection of programmers who are trying to produce better products by working together."

 

换句话说，团队的显着特征是其成员通过合作生产产品的方式——他们无法通过单独工作生产（或如此有效地生产）的产品。一些团队共享一个共同的产品，而一些从事共同产品工作的团队则不是团队。一些团队让每个成员都从事不同的产品（尽管这种情况不太常见），而许多团队除了公共空间或公共经理外几乎没有共享。现在硬件变得越来越便宜，而劳动力变得越来越昂贵，与几年前相比，该集团不太可能共享机器和系统。

In other words, the distinguishing characteristic of the team is the way its members produce products by working together—products that they could not produce (or produce so efficiently) by working as individuals. Some teams share a common product, while some groups working on a common product are not teams. Some teams have each member working on a distinct product (although this is less usual), while many groups share little except common space or a common manager. Now that hardware has grown cheaper while labor has grown more expensive, the group is much less likely to share a machine and system than they were years ago.

不过，归根结底，是他们的学习方法将团队与群体区分开来。因为共同的目标常常会影响团队成员一起学习，所以今天很容易理解为什么我在 25 年前对这种区别感到困惑。但是有了更多的例子，我现在明白了一个共同的产品目标不一定会导致相互学习。另一方面，无论产品如何，团队成员总是有一个共同的目标——帮助彼此学习更好地执行的目标。

In the end, though, it's their method of learning that distinguishes teams from groups. Because a common goal often influences group members to learn together, it's easy to see today why I was confused about this distinction twenty-five years ago. But with lots more examples under my belt, I now understand that a common product goal need not lead to mutual learning. On the other hand, team members always have a common goal, regardless of the product—the goal of helping each other learn to perform better.

我的年度软件工程管理开发小组正是为这个目标而构建的团队。1998年团队成员Brian Pioreck评价这个进球：

My annual Software Engineering Management Development Groups are teams constructed with precisely this goal. Brian Pioreck, a member of the 1998 team, commented on this goal:

“那么这个标准如何用于帮助那些想要建立生产产品的团队而不是生产产品的团队的组织呢？学习什么？学习如何构建更好的程序？学习如何更好地倾听？更好地沟通？感觉更好自己？我认为所有这些问题的答案都是肯定的。

"So then how can this criterion be used to help organizations that want to build teams that produce products instead of groups that produce products? And learn what? Learn how to build better programs? Learn how to listen better? Communicate better? Feel better about themselves? I think the answer to all these questions is yes.

 

“当我问客户关于他们作为团队一员的最佳体验时，最常被提及的记忆是，这就像一个家庭——感恩节前后的一个家庭。每个人都会做一些东西，然后把它带到餐桌上，在那里他们可以分享和庆祝.我认为一个健康团队的另一个属性是它可以自我延续。它可以帮助一个成员中断并开始并支持一个拥有相同价值观和习俗的新团队。

"When I ask clients about their best experiences of being part of a team the most often cited memory is that it was like a family—a family around Thanksgiving time. Everybody makes something and brings it to the table where they can all share and celebrate. I think another attribute of a healthy team is that it can perpetuate itself. It can help a member break off and start and support a new team that will share the same values and customs."

 

第 4 章编程组

Chapter 4. The Programming Group

 

对编程组的研究对于理解其他类型的编程组织很重要。即使程序员正式组织成团队和项目，也会出现非正式联系，就像他们在“非结构化”小组中所做的那样。事实上，我们必须从社会心理学中吸取的第一课是正式和非正式群体之间的区别。

The study of the programming group is important for an understanding of the other types of programming organization. Even when there is a formal organization of the programmers into teams and projects, informal connections arise much as they do in an "unstructured" group. Indeed, the first lesson we must learn from social psychology is the difference between formal and informal groups.

正式和非正式组织

FORMAL AND INFORMAL ORGANIZATION

组织结构图对于经理来说是个不错的玩具，但如果程序员之间的交互必须遵循其狭窄的直线，那么很少有编程工作能完成。也许是因为组织结构图看起来很像流程图，晋升的编程经理似乎对它们过于信任，而不是对他们自己在维修站时使用得如此成功的不太正式的机制抱有太大的信心。但人与人之间的互动从来都不是狭隘的，也不是直截了当的，也几乎不会按照组织结构图所示的方向进行。认为正式结构是组织中唯一的结构的想法犯了很多严重的错误。

The organization chart is a nice toy for a manager, but little programming work would ever get done if interactions among programmers had to follow its narrow, straight lines. Perhaps because organization charts look much like flow diagrams, programming managers who have come up through the ranks seem to place too much confidence in them, rather than in the less formal mechanisms which they themselves used so successfully when they were in the pits. But human interactions are never narrow, never straight, and hardly ever in the directions shown an organization charts. Many serious mistakes have been made in imagining that formal structure was the only structure in an organization.

当然，在项目中，很多非正式结构是由工作结构决定的，因此可能或多或少地遵循组织结构图，这取决于项目的组织程度。但是在一个计算中心，即使它完全为个别程序员服务，一个非正式的结构也总是会发展以纠正和补充任何存在的正式结构的工作。有时，如果当权者足够聪明，非正式结构中的创新可以正式实施，尽管并不总是完全等同。

In projects, of course, much of the informal structure is determined by the structure of the work, and thus may follow organization charts more or less closely, depending on how well the project is organized. But in a computing center, even if it is completely at the service of individual programmers, an informal structure always grows to correct and complement the work of whatever formal structure exists. Sometimes, if the powers-that-be are sufficiently wise, innovations in the informal structure can be implemented formally, although not always as exact equivalents.

这种类型的一个例子发生在一家咨询工程公司的计算中心。作业以远程批处理的方式运行，大多数程序员分布在与他们一起工作的团队附近的三座建筑物周围。周转时间不规律，并且没有可靠的方法可以提前确定工作何时完成。最后处理的作业的编号张贴在返回窗口外的一块板上，但是来自远程办公室的程序员很容易浪费半个小时来阅读该板并发现他们的作业还没有准备好。

An example of this type took place in the computing center of a consulting engineering firm. Jobs were run on a remote batch basis, and most programmers were spread around the three buildings near to the group with which they worked. Turnaround time was irregular, and there was no reliable way to determine in advance when a job would come out. The number of the last job processed was posted on a board outside the return window, but programmers from remote offices could easily waste half an hour coming to read the board and find out that their job was not ready.

碰巧的是，其中一位秘书有一间办公室，其位置使她无需离开办公桌就可以看到董事会开着的门。她是一个很有魅力的年轻人，其中一位程序员在等待工作被退回时碰巧打电话给她约会。他们谈了一会儿后，她说他肯定有工作要回去，但他回答说他还是在等工作。“哦，”她天真地说，“多少号？我从这里可以看到牌子。” 随着这句话开始了一项服务，它的存在逐渐为所有外围程序员所知。事实上，这是一项非常好的服务，以至于秘书很快就难以履行她的其他职责。就这样，这个非正式机制终于引起了行政当局的注意。

As it happened, one of the secretaries had an office whose placement permitted her to see the board out the open door, without moving from her desk. She was an attractive young thing, and one of the programmers happened to call her for a date at a time when he was waiting for a job to be returned. When they had talked for a while, she commented that he must have work to return to, but he replied that he was waiting for a job anyway. "Oh," she said innocently, "what number is it? I can see the board from here." With that remark began a service whose existence gradually became known to all the outlying programmers. It was such a good service, in fact, that the secretary soon had difficulty carrying out her other duties. In this way, this informal mechanism finally came to the attention of the administration.

明智地承认服务不能被切断，政府决定启用一个特殊的查询号码，人们可以通过该号码听到最新发布号码的录音。管理层甚至明智地使用了秘书的旧分机——尽管电话公司在这之前进行了一些抵制。因此，相当顺利地取代了效率低下但有用的非正式服务——伴随而来的是秘书时间的增加，可以从事更传统的职责。

Wisely acknowledging that the service could not just be cut off, the administration decided to inaugurate a special inquiry number over which one could hear a tape recording of the latest number posted. The management was even wise enough to use the secretary's old extension—although the telephone company gave some resistance before this was accomplished. Thus, a rather smooth replacement of a rather inefficient, but useful, informal service was made—with the concomitant gain in secretarial time for more conventional duties.

然而，应该指出的是，新的正式系统从未完全取代旧的、非正式的系统。录音大约每隔 30 分钟进行一次，因此有可能在电话记录之前将号码张贴在黑板上长达半小时。在一般情况下，这已经足够了——但在计算中心，总有人有不同寻常的要求。于是，当一个程序员真的急着找工作的时候，他会回到原来的系统，给秘书打电话。不过现在她的工作量已经减少到足以不影响其他工作的地步，所以这个系统大概一直到现在都没有变化。此外，她喜欢和所有这些聪明的年轻程序员交谈——我们承认，他们也喜欢和她交谈。

It should be noted, however, that the new formal system never completely replaced the old, informal one. The recordings were made more or less at intervals of thirty minutes, so that it was possible for a number to be posted on the board as much as half an hour before being noted on the telephone. For ordinary circumstances, this proved sufficient—but in a computing center, somebody always has extraordinary requirements. Thus, when a programmer was really in a hurry for a job, he would revert to the old system and call the secretary. Now, however, her workload was sufficiently decreased so as not to affect her other work, and so the system has remained unchanged, in all probability, to this day. Besides, she enjoyed talking to all these bright young programmers—and they, let us admit, enjoyed talking to her.

并非所有正式和非正式之间的冲突都有如此美好的结局。在这种情况下，计算中心的管理承认非正式组织所服务的功能；但在其他情况下，他们甚至可能不知道该功能的存在。一个典型的例子发生在一个大型大学计算中心。因为很多程序员都是没有办公室的学生，所以在返回窗口附近提供了一个很大的公共空间，这样学生和其他用户就可以解决他们的编程问题。在隔壁的房间里，中心提供疑难问题的咨询服务，配备了两名研究生助理。

Not all conflicts between the formal and informal have such happy endings. In this case, the administration of the computing center recognized the function that the informal organization was serving; but in other cases, they might not even be aware of the existence of the function. A case in point occurred at a large university computing center. Because so many of the programmers were students who had no offices, a large common space was provided near the return window, so that the students and other users could work on their programming problems. In the adjoining room, the center provided a consulting service for difficult problems, staffed by two graduate assistants.

公共休息室的一端是一组自动售货机——咖啡、可乐、糖果和你有什么。虽然房间很大，但聚集在机器前的狂欢者发出的噪音常常让一些工人无法忍受。最后，一对认真的学生任命自己为委员会成员，并找到了计算中心经理。他，当然，从来没有亲自去过公共休息室，所以当他去调查他们的投诉时，他对远端发生的事情感到震惊。没有超过 15 秒的观察和考虑，他就回到自己的办公室并开始行动，将机器移到某个偏远的地方。

At one end of the common room was a collection of vending machines —coffee, coke, candy, and what-have-you. Although the room was quite large, the noise from the revelers congregating at the machines often became more than some of the workers could bear. Finally, a pair of serious-minded students appointed themselves as a committee and went to the computing center manager. He, of course, had never personally gone into the common room, so when he went to investigate their complaint, he was appalled at the goings-on at the far end. Without more than fifteen seconds of observation and consideration, he went back to his office and inaugurated action to have the machines removed to some remote spot.

机器被拆除后的一周——周围张贴了敦促安静的标志——经理接待了另一个代表团。这个更大，组织得更好。他们是来抱怨缺乏咨询服务的；的确，当他去找自己的时候，他看到两条长长的队伍从咨询室延伸到公共休息室。他与顾问交谈，询问他们为什么在为客户提供服务时突然变得如此缓慢，但他们告诉他，他们的工作速度和以往一样快——如果不是更快的话。他们说，出于某种原因，需要建议的人比过去多了很多。

The week after the machines had been removed—and signs urging quiet had been posted all around—-the manager received another delegation. This one was much larger and much better organized. They had come to complain about the lack of consulting service; and, indeed, when he went to look for himself, he saw two long lines extending out of the consulting room into the common room. He spoke to the consultants to ask them why they were suddenly so slow in servicing their clients, but they told him that they were working as fast as they had ever done—if not faster. For some reason, they said, there were just a lot more people needing advice than there used to be.

经理花了两周时间检查负载增加的可能来源，但所有课程和其他用户都在正常进行。

The manager spent two weeks checking for a possible source of the increased load, but all courses and other users were carrying on normally.

尽管如此，负担依然存在，学生们抱怨他们无法完成作业。最后，他安排了一名社会学研究生去采访排队咨询的学生。一段时间后，他发现了问题的根源。这是自动售货机！

Still, the load remained, and students were complaining that they were not able to finish their assignments. Finally, he set a graduate student in sociology to interviewing the students queued up in the consulting lines. After some time, he discovered the source of the problem. It was the vending machines!

当自动售货机出现在公共休息室时，一大群人总是在它们周围徘徊——但并不是像经理很快假设的那样特别是为了打闹。没错，他们是在喝咖啡聊天，但他们是在谈论他们的节目。学生到达计算中心时的典型行为是拿起他的输出并走向咖啡机。在那里，他一边喝着咖啡，一边可以先看一下程序，还可以向可能站在一旁的伙伴们展示一下。由于大多数学生的问题都是相似的，他很有可能在自动售货机旁找到知道他的程序出了什么问题的人。通过这种非正式的组织，正式的咨询机制被分流，其负荷降低到可以合理处理的水平。

When the vending machines had been in the common room, a large crowd always hovered around them—but not particularly for fol-de-rol, as the manager had so quickly assumed. True, they were drinking coffee and chatting, but they were chatting about their programs. The typical behavior of a student when he arrived at the computing center was to pick up his output and head for the coffee machine. There, while sipping coffee, he could have a first look at the program and also show it to his buddies who might be standing around. Since most of the student problems were similar, the chances were very high that he could find someone who knew what was wrong with his program right there at the vending machines. Through this informal organization, the formal consulting mechanism was shunted, and its load was reduced to a level it could reasonably handle.

通过搬出自动售货机，经理打破了这种非正式结构的重点，并将由此产生的负担推给了他的顾问。不幸的是，他不能轻易相信这是超载的原因，所以他没有恢复机器，而是尝试增加顾问的数量。然而，顾问们抱怨他们不得不处理的琐事；最终，由于缺乏愿意这样做的人，咨询服务被完全放弃了。最后一次观察时，这个计算中心正在通过非正式渠道提供咨询服务——学生们从一个办公室跑到另一个办公室，直到他们找到一名程序员来回答他们的琐碎问题。这一切会在哪里结束，这很难说；

By moving out the vending machines, the manager had broken up the focus of this informal structure and put the resulting load on his consultants. Unhappily, he could not easily believe that this was the cause of the overload, so instead of restoring the machines, he tried increasing the number of consultants. The consultants, however, complained of the trivia they were having to deal with; and eventually the consulting service was abandoned altogether, for lack of people willing to do it. When last observed, this computing center was furnishing consulting through informal channels—with students scurrying around from office to office until they could find one of the staff programmers to answer their trivial questions. Where it will all end, it's hard to say; but we can be sure that the students will always get their questions answered—at whatever the cost.

这些故事的要点是，非正式机制始终存在，在不了解它们的情况下进行更改是很危险的，以免扰乱一些您无法以类似成本更换的平稳运行的操作系统。许多这样的混乱是通过事物的物理布局的变化而发生的——这种变化在计算中心周围非常普遍，以至于我们值得花一些时间来讨论物理结构和社会结构之间的关系。

The point of these stories is that informal mechanisms always exist and it is dangerous to change things without understanding them, lest you derange some smoothly operating system which you will not be able to replace at similar cost. Many such derangements occur through a change in the physical layout of things—a change which is so common around computing centers that it will pay us to spend a few words on the relationship between physical structure and social structure.

自然环境与社会组织

PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT AND SOCIAL ORGANIZATION

我们都知道物理环境会影响我们工作的质量和数量。然而，我们在这里所指的不是噪声、光、热和其他因素的影响，工业心理学家已经对这些因素进行了大量研究。毫无疑问，遵循在将程序员的工作区放在一起时制定的设计标准可以获得重要的好处。（绝对应该有人研究一下非常常见的半分区对程序员生产力的压抑影响。他们设法切断所有有用的通信，同时允许所有令人不安的声音和移动渗透。）我们关心的是布局如何工作空间的大小会影响社交互动的模式，而社交互动又会影响完成的工作。

We all know that physical surroundings affect the quality and quantity of our work. What we are alluding to here, however, is not the effects of noise, light, heat, and other factors, which have been much studied by industrial psychologists. No doubt there are important benefits to be gained from following the design criteria developed in putting together programmers' working quarters. (Someone should definitely study the depressing effect that the all-too-common half partitions have on programmer productivity. They manage to cut off all useful communication while permitting all disturbing sound and movement to penetrate.) What we are concerned with is how the layout of work space affects the pattern of social interaction which in turn influences the work that is done.

举个简单的例子，考虑一下用崭新的自动电梯取代旧电梯的机构。这对程序员来说是最不幸的，因为老电梯操作员在编程层——第八层——和机房——地下室之间为他们提供了非正式的接送服务。当然，没有人会因为从八楼到地下室就雇用一个信使，所以程序员们浪费了很多生产时间。该操作员的另一个功能是寻找失踪人员。机房在一层，打孔机室在另一层，程序员办公室在第三层，你在第一个地方找到失踪程序员的几率不到五十分。然而，电梯操作员 可以依靠它立即知道可以在哪一层找到给定的人。由于这两项损失——加上其他服务的损失，例如错误投递邮件的重新路由和重要消息的转发——新的自动电梯被证明是一个净损失，尽管电梯服务本身似乎有点快。

As a simple example, consider the establishment which replaced its ancient elevators with spanking new automatic ones. This was most unfortunate for the programmers, for the old elevator operator had run an informal pickup and delivery service for them between the programming floor—the eighth—and the machine room—the basement. Of course, nobody could justify hiring a messenger just for going from the eighth floor to the basement, so the programmers lost a lot of productive time. Another function this operator served was locator of missing persons. With the machine room on one floor, keypunch room on another, and programmers' offices on a third, chances of finding a missing programmer in the first place you looked were less than fifty-fifty. The elevator operator, however, could be relied upon to know immediately on which floor a given person could be found. With these two losses—plus the loss of other services such as rerouting of mis-delivered mail and relaying of important messages—the new automatic elevators proved to be a net loss, even though the elevator service itself seemed a bit faster.

尽管改用自动电梯的情况可能更为罕见，但办公室搬迁在一些商店几乎每天都会发生。只要程序员都在一起，这通常会产生有益的效果，让两个人意识到彼此的存在。在过去，这个功能通常是在机房的接待室完成的，我们都在那里排队进行十五分钟的在线调试。一次典型的谈话——大约在 1956 年——是这样的：

Although the switch to automatic elevators is perhaps more rare, the moving of offices is an almost daily occurrence in some shops. As long as the programmers all remain together, this often has the salutary effect of making two people aware of each other's existence. In the old days, this function was often accomplished in the anteroom of the machine room, where we all queued up to take our fifteen minutes of on-line debugging. A typical conversation—circa 1956—went like this:

“他在里面干什么这么久？我有一些非常重要的工作要做——但还有一个虫子。”

"What's he doing in there so long? I've got some really important work to do—but there's just one more bug."

“他正在调试 FORTRAN。”

"He's debugging FORTRAN."

“为了什么？”

"FOR-what?"

“FORTRAN。代表公式翻译。他们声称您将能够将程序编写为数学公式，并且该程序会自动将它们翻译成机器代码。”

"FORTRAN. Stands for Formula Translation. They claim you'll be able to write programs as mathematical formulas and this program will translate them into machine code automatically."

“来吧。你在开玩笑吗？”

"Come on. You're kidding?"

“他们是这么说的。至于我，我想可以做到，但效率不如手工编码。它卖不出去。”

"That's what they say. As for me, I suppose it can be done, but it can't be as efficient as hand coding. It won't sell."

“好吧，这肯定会占用大量机器时间。他看起来像是在弹奏风琴，上下弹奏那些琴键。应该有更好的方法。”

"Well, it's sure using a lot of machine time. He looks like he's playing the organ there, flipping those keys up and down. There ought to be a better way."

“有。”

"There is."

“是吗？那是什么？”

"Yeah? What's that?"

“我现在正在研究它。我们正在西海岸进行，但唯一的机器在这里，所以我们必须来这里调试。它叫做监控系统。”

"I'm working on it right now. We're doing it on the West Coast, but the only machine is here, so we have to come here to debug. It's called a Monitor System."

“监控系统？”

"Monitor System?"

“是的，它有点像自动操作员。让程序员离开机器。例如，我这里有三十个工作，我要在十五分钟内完成。”

"Yes, it's sort of an automatic operator. Takes the programmer away from the machine. For example, I've got thirty jobs here which I'm going to run in my fifteen minute shot."

“三十？你这是在耍我！”

"Thirty? You're pulling my leg!"

“不，我是认真的。通过消除操作员，我们实现了惊人的加速——同时也消除了设置和拆卸时间。”

"No, I mean it. By eliminating the operator, we achieve a fantastic speedup—and eliminate set-up and tear-down time, too."

“好吧，祝你好运。但如果我不能在控制台前，我不知道如何调试我的程序。事实上，我正在疯狂地等待这些——那个名字是什么？——FORTRAN伙计们。回头见。我现在起来了。”

"Well, good luck. But I don't see how I'm going to debug my programs if I can't be at the console. As it is I'm going crazy waiting for these—what was that name?—FORTRAN guys. See you later. I'm up now."

以这种方式传输了数量惊人的有用信息。操作系统消除了这种社会结构，就像自动电梯消除了另一种社会结构一样。不过，如果在返回计算机输出的地方旁边有一个公共房间，则可以在那里进行有用的混合。然而，个性化的交付服务倾向于将程序员与这种类型的交互隔离开来，而用于远程作业进入和退出的终端系统可能会使他的隔离变得更糟。终端操作的这一方面可能会成为诅咒，而不是祝福。

A surprising amount of useful information was transmitted in this way. Operating systems eliminated this social structure in the same way as automatic elevators eliminated the other. Still, if there is a common room right next to the place where computer output is returned, useful mixing can take place there. Personalized delivery services, however, tend to isolate the programmer from this type of interaction, and terminal systems for remote-job-entry and exit may make his isolation worse. This aspect of terminal operations is probably going to be a curse, not a blessing.

错误与自我

ERROR AND EGO

许多读到这里的程序员会对强调程序员之间的社交互动感到惊讶。编程——也许比任何其他职业更重要——是一种个人活动，取决于程序员自己的能力，而不是其他人。它会让你在白天遇到多少其他程序员有什么不同？如果被问到，大多数程序员可能会说他们更喜欢在一个不会被其他人打扰的地方独自工作。

Many programmers who have read this far will be surprised at the emphasis placed on the social interaction among programmers. Programming—perhaps more than any other profession—is an individual activity, depending on the abilities of the programmer himself, and not upon others. What difference can it make how many other programmers you run into during the day? If asked, most programmers would probably say they preferred to work alone in a place where they wouldn't be disturbed by other people.

前一段中表达的想法可能是我们将遇到的改进编程的最强大障碍。首先，如果这确实是编程行业的普遍形象，那么人们会根据自己喜欢单独工作还是与他人一起工作来吸引或排斥进入该行业。社会心理学家告诉我们，有不同的人格类型——这是我们都知道的，但能有权威印记是件好事。在一般人格特质中，有一个是从三个“维度”来衡量的——一个人是“顺从”、“好斗”还是“超然”。顺从型的特点是喜欢“与人共事，乐于助人”的态度。攻击型想要“

The ideas expressed in the preceding paragraph are possibly the most formidable barrier to improved programming that we shall encounter. First of all, if this is indeed the image generally held of the programming profession, then people will be attracted to, or repelled from, entering the profession according to their preference for working alone or working with others. Social psychologists tell us that there are different personality types—something we all knew, but which is nice to have stamped with authority. Among the general personality traits is one which is measured along three "dimensions"—whether a person is "compliant," "aggressive," or "detached." The compliant type is characterized by the attitude of liking to "work with people and be helpful." The aggressive type wants to "earn money and prestige," and the detached type wants to "be left to myself to be creative."

现在，每个人都包含这些态度的混合体，但大多数人比其他人更倾向于一个方向。毫无疑问，当今编程中的大多数人都倾向于“超然”的方向，这既是出于个人选择，也是因为程序员的招聘政策通常是为了寻找这样的人。并且，在很大程度上，这是一个不错的选择，因为大量的编程工作是“单独和创造性的”。

Now, every person contains a mixture of these attitudes, but most people lean more heavily in one direction than the others. There is no doubt that the majority of people in programming today lean in the "detached" direction, both by personal choice and because hiring policies for programmers are often directed toward finding such people. And, to a great extent, this is a good choice, because a great deal of programming work is "alone and creative."

然而，与大多数美好事物一样，程序员的“超然”常常被过度开发。虽然他们脱离了人，但他们依附于他们的程序。事实上，他们的程序经常成为他们自己的扩展——这一事实在将一个人的名字附加到程序本身的可恶做法中得到了证实——就像朱尔斯自己的 Algol 版本，更为人所知的是 JOVIAL。但即使程序没有正式冠以其创建者的名字，程序员也知道它是谁的程序。

Like most good things, however, the "detachment" of programmers is often overdeveloped. Although they are detached from people, they are attached to their programs. Indeed, their programs often become extensions of themselves—a fact which is verified in the abominable practice of attaching one's name to the program itself—as in Jules' Own Version of Algol, better known as JOVIAL. But even when the program is not officially blessed with the name of its creator, programmers know whose program it is.

那么，“拥有”程序有什么问题呢？艺术家“拥有”绘画；作者“自己”的书；建筑师“拥有”建筑物。这些归因难道不会导致下等人对优秀员工的钦佩和效仿吗？在一本书上写上作者的名字不是很有用，这样我们就可以更好地了解阅读时的期望吗？难道这不也适用于程序吗？也许它会——如果 people.read 程序，但我们知道他们不会。因此，对个别程序员的钦佩不会导致对他们工作的效仿，而只会导致他们的举止矫揉造作。这与我们在“艺术殖民地”中看到的现象相同，每个人都知道如何看起来像艺术家，但很少有人知道如何像艺术家一样作画。

Well, what is wrong with "owning" programs? Artists "own" paintings; authors "own" books; architects "own" buildings. Don't these attributions lead to admiration and emulation of good workers by lesser ones? Isn't it useful to have an author's name on a book so we have a better idea of what to expect when we read it? And wouldn't the same apply to programs? Perhaps it would—if people.read programs, but we know that they do not. Thus, the admiration of individual programmers cannot lead to an emulation of their work, but only to an affectation of their mannerisms. This is the same phenomenon we see in "art colonies," where everyone knows how to look like an artist, but few, if any, know how to paint like one.

“面向属性”编程的真正困难来自另一个来源。当我们认为一幅画、一部小说或一座建筑低劣时，那是一种品味问题。当我们认为一个程序较差时——尽管我们知道“好的程序”问题背后隐藏着困难——这至少是一个可能容易受到客观证明或反证的问题。至少，我们可以把程序放到机器上，看看会出现什么。如果评论家不喜欢他，艺术家可以不理会评论家的意见，但是程序员可以不理会计算机的判断吗？

The real difficulty with "property-oriented" programming arises from another source. When we think a painting or a novel or a building is inferior, that is a matter of taste. When we think a program is inferior—in spite of the difficulties we know lurk behind the question of "good programming"—that is a matter at least potentially susceptible to objective proof or disproof. At the very least, we can put the program on the machine and see what comes out. An artist can dismiss the opinions of a critic if they do not please him, but can a programmer dismiss the judgment of the computer?

从表面上看，计算机的判断似乎是无可争辩的，如果真是这样，程序员对他的程序的依恋会对他的自我形象产生严重的后果。当计算机在他的程序中发现一个错误时，程序员必须这样推理：

On the surface, it would seem that the judgment of the computer is indisputable, and if this were truly so, the attachment of a programmer to his programs would have serious consequences for his self-image. When the computer revealed a bug in his program, the programmer would have to reason something like this:

“这个程序有缺陷。这个程序是我的一部分，是我自己的延伸，甚至带有我的名字。我有缺陷。”

"This program is defective. This program is part of me, an extension of myself, even carrying my name. I am defective."

 

但这种自我判断的严厉性意味着它很少被执行。从社会心理学家 Festinger 的工作开始，已经进行了许多有趣的实验来确定一种称为“认知失调”的心理现象的真实性。认知失调的经典实验是这样的：

But the very harshness of this self-judgment means that it is seldom carried out. Starting with the work of the social psychologist Festinger, a number of interesting experiments have been performed to establish the reality of a psychological phenomenon called "cognitive dissonance." A classical experiment in cognitive dissonance goes something like this:

两组受试者被要求写一篇文章，对他们强烈反对的观点进行辩论。一组写出反对自己观点的论点每人一美元，另一组每人二十美元。在实验结束时，受试者将根据他们对此事的看法进行重新测试。鉴于“常识”会说二十美元的受试者——因为他们改变想法而获得更多报酬——更有可能改变他们的观点，认知失调理论预测，改变最多的将是另一组。数十个实验证实了该理论的预测。

Two groups of.subjects are asked to write an essay arguing in favor of some point with which they feel strong disagreement. One group is paid one dollar apiece to write this argument against their own opinions, the other is paid twenty dollars apiece. At the end of the experiment, the subjects are retested on their opinions of the matter. Whereas "common sense" would say that the twenty dollar subjects—having been paid more to change their minds—would be more likely to change their opinions, cognitive dissonance theory predicts that it will be the other group which will change the most. Dozens of experiments have confirmed the predictions of the theory.

认知失调理论背后的论点非常简单。在刚刚概述的实验中，两组受试者都必须执行一项操作——根据自己的观点写一篇文章——这是他们在一般情况下不愿意做的事情。争论一个人不相信的事情被归类为“不真诚”或“虚伪”，这两种行为在我们的社会中都不受高度重视。因此，产生了不和谐的情况。受试者作为一个真诚的人的自我形象受到他写这篇文章这一客观事实的挑战。根据该理论，失调是人类一种不舒服和不稳定的状态，并且；因此，必须以一种或另一种方式迅速解决。要解决不和谐，必须让一个或另一个促成它的因素屈服。哪个因素取决于情况，但是，一般来说，不会是这个人的自我形象。通过最神奇的争论设法保留了这一点。

The argument behind cognitive dissonance theory is quite simple. In the experiment just outlined, both groups of subjects have had to perform an act—writing an essay against their own opinions—which they would not under ordinary circumstances like to do. Arguing for what one does not believe is classed as "insincerity" or "hypocrisy," neither of which is highly valued in our society. Therefore, a dissonance situation is created. The subject's self-image as a sincere person is challenged by the objective fact of his having written the essay. Dissonance, according to the theory, is an uncomfortable and unstable state for human beings, and; must therefore be quickly resolved in one way or another. To resolve a dissonance, one factor or another contributing to it must be made to yield. Which factor depends on the situation, but, generally speaking, it will not be the person's self-image. That manages to be preserved through the most miraculous arguments.

现在，在引用的实验中，二十美元的受试者很容易解决他们的失调。“当然，”他们可以对自己或任何可能会问的人说，“我真的不相信那些论点。我只是为了钱才这么做的。” 虽然拿钱来提出这样的论点并不完全是最令人钦佩的品质，但这比实际持有质疑的信念要好得多。但看看美元集团的窘境。即使对于贫困大学生——心理实验的对象几乎都是贫困大学生——一美元也不是什么大数目。因此，另一组的论点对他们来说没有说服力，必须在别处解决不和谐。至少对于很多人来说，

Now, in the experiments cited, the twenty-dollar subjects have an easy resolution of their dissonance. "Of course," they can say to themselves or to anyone who might ask, "I didn't really believe those arguments. I just did it for the money." Although taking money to make such arguments is not altogether the most admirable trait, it is much better than actually holding the beliefs in question. But look at the quandary of the dollar group. Even for poor college students—and subjects in psychological experiments are almost always poor college students—one dollar is not a significant amount of money. Thus, the argument of the other group does not carry the ring of conviction for them, and the dissonance must be resolved elsewhere. For many, at least, the easiest resolution is to come to admit that there is really something to the other side of the argument after all, so that writing the essay was not hypocrisy, but simply an exercise in developing a fair and honest mind, one which is capable of seeing both sides of a question.

认知失调理论的另一个应用是预测当人们做出一些重大承诺时会发生什么，例如购买汽车。如果一个刚买了福特汽车的人被要求阅读一堆汽车广告，他会花大部分时间阅读有关福特汽车的信息。如果他购买的是雪佛兰，那么雪佛兰广告就会引起他的注意。这是一个预测不和谐的可能性并避免可能造成不和谐的信息的例子。如果他刚买了一辆福特，他不想发现雪佛兰是更好的车，最好的办法就是避免阅读雪佛兰的广告。在福特的广告中，他不太可能找到任何能让他相信自己不是最聪明的消费者的东西。

Another application of the theory of cognitive dissonance predicts what will happen when people have made some large commitment, such as the purchase of a car. If a man who has just purchased a Ford is given a bunch of auto advertisements to read, he spends the majority of his time reading about Fords. If it was a Chevrolet he purchased, then the Chevrolet ads capture his attention. This is an example of anticipating the possibility of dissonance and avoiding information that might create it. If he has just purchased a Ford, he doesn't want to find out that Chevrolet is the better car, and the best way to do that is to avoid reading the Chevrolet ads. In the Ford ads, he is not likely to find anything that will convince him that he is anything but the wisest of consumers.

现在，认知失调与我们的编程冲突有什么关系应该非常清楚了。一个真正将他的程序视为他自我的延伸的程序员不会试图找出该程序中的所有错误。相反，他将试图证明该程序是正确的——即使这意味着要疏忽在另一只眼中是可怕的错误。所有程序员都熟悉这种不协调解决方案的症状——当然，在其他人中也是如此。程序员带着他的输出清单来到大厅，它非常薄。如果他无法掩饰他跑步的失败，他会发表一些评论，例如

Now, what cognitive dissonance has to do with our programming conflict should be vividly clear. A programmer who truly sees his program as an extension of his own ego is not going to be trying to find all the errors in that program. On the contrary, he is going to be trying to prove that the program is correct—even if this means the oversight of errors which are monstrous to another eye. All programmers are familiar with the symptoms of this dissonance resolution—-in others, of course. The programmer comes down the hall with his output listing and it is very thin. If he is unable to conceal the failure of his run, he makes some remark such as

“那些按键操作员又做了一次。”

"Those keypunch operators did it again."

“接线员把我的卡按顺序放错了。”

"The operator put my cards in out of sequence."

“我们什么时候才能修好那个冲头，让它能正确复制？”

"When are we going to get that punch fixed so it duplicates properly?"

这些抱怨有成千上万种变化，但我们似乎从来没有听到的一件事是一个简单的

There are thousands of variations to these plaints, but the one thing we never seem to hear is a simple

“我又犯傻了。”

"I goofed again."

 

当然，如果错误比完全无法获得输出更微妙——这几乎不能被忽略——仅仅没有看到有错误就可以更简单地解决不协调。请不要误会：人眼几乎有无限的能力看不到它不想看到的东西。专门调试别人程序的人可以用成千上万的案例来验证这个断言。程序员，如果留给他们自己的设备，将忽略他们输出中最明显的错误——其他人可以立即看到的错误。因此，如果我们要解决制作好的程序的问题，如果我们要从满足规范的基本层面开始，

Of course, where the error is more subtle than a complete failure to get output—which can hardly be ignored—the resolution of the dissonance can be made even simpler by merely failing to see that there is an error. And let there be no mistake about it: the human eye has an almost infinite capacity for not seeing what it does not want to see. People who have specialized in debugging other people's programs can verify this assertion with literally thousands of cases. Programmers, if left to their own devices, will ignore the most glaring errors in their output—errors that anyone else can see in an instant. Thus, if we are going to attack the problem of making good programs, and if we are going to start at the fundamental level of meeting specifications, we are going to have to do something about the perfectly normal human tendency to believe that ones "own" program is correct in the face of hard physical evidence to the contrary.

无私编程

EGOLESS PROGRAMMING

如何解决编程中的自我问题？一篇关于管理的典型文章会说，经理应该劝告他所有的程序员加倍努力，找出他们的错误。也许他会四处走动，要求他们每天向他指出他们的错误。然而，这种方法会失败，因为它恰恰与我们的心理学知识所指示的方向相反，因为普通人会将这种调查视为个人审判。此外，并非所有程序员都有经理——或者即使看到红色轮廓的错误也会知道错误的经理。

What is to be done about the problem of the ego in programming? A typical text on management would say that the manager should exhort all his programmers to redouble their efforts to find their errors. Perhaps he would go around asking them to show him their errors each day. This method, however, would fail by going precisely in the opposite direction to what our knowledge of psychology would dictate, for the average person is going to view such an investigation as a personal trial. Besides, not all programmers have managers—or managers who would know an error even if they saw one outlined in red.

不，解决这个问题的方法不在于直接攻击——因为攻击只能导致防御，而防御是我们要消除的。相反，必须通过社会环境的重构来克服自我问题，并通过这种方式重构该环境中程序员的价值体系。在我们讨论如何做到这一点之前，让我们先看一些例子，说明完成后发生了什么——它如何影响程序员和他们的程序。

No, the solution to this problem lies not in a direct attack—for attack can only lead to defense, and defense is what we are trying to eliminate. Instead, the problem of the ego must be overcome by a restructuring of the social environment and, through this means, a restructuring of the value system of the programmers in that environment. Before we discuss how this might be done, let us look at some examples of what has happened when it has been done—how it affects the programmers and their programs.

首先，不要让任何人认为这样的重组是社会理论家的象牙塔梦。克服了自我问题的编程团队确实存在，并且从计算的早期就已经存在。John von Neumann 本人可能是第一个认识到自己在检查自己的工作方面存在不足的程序员。认识他的人都说他一直在断言自己是一个多么糟糕的程序员，并且不断地强迫其他人阅读他的程序以找出错误和笨拙的地方。然而，如今冯·诺依曼的普遍形象是无与伦比的计算天才——他的一举一动都完美无瑕。事实上，冯诺依曼的天才是毋庸置疑的。他意识到自己的人性局限性的能力使他远远高于当今的普通程序员。

First of all, let no one imagine that such restructuring is the ivory tower dream of social theorists. Programming groups who have conquered the ego problem do exist and have existed from the earliest days of computing. John von Neumann himself was perhaps the first programmer to recognize his inadequacies with respect to examination of his own work. Those who knew him have said that he was constantly asserting what a lousy programmer he was, and that he incessantly pushed his programs on other people to read for errors and clumsiness. Yet the common image today of von Neumann is of the unparalleled computing genius—flawless in his every action. And indeed, there can be no doubt of von Neumann's genius. His very ability to realize his human limitations put him head and shoulders above the average programmer today.

可以训练普通人接受他们的人性——他们无法像机器一样运作——并重视它并与他人合作，以便在编程成功时将其置于所需的控制之下。考虑 Bill G. 的案例，他在早期的空间跟踪系统之一工作。他的工作是编写一个模拟器来模拟整个跟踪站网络和其他实时输入。他的系统必须实时检查系统的其余部分，而无需全球网络在线。模拟器的核心是一个非常小且非常紧凑的循环，实际上只包含 13 条机器指令。比尔在这个循环上工作了一段时间，当他终于对它有了一些信心时，

Average people can be trained to accept their humanity—their inability to function like a machine—and to value it and work with others so as to keep it under the kind of control needed if programming is to be successful. Consider the case of Bill G. who was working in one of the early space tracking systems. His job was to write a simulator which would simulate the entire network of tracking stations and other real-time inputs. His system had to check out the rest of the system in real-time without having to have the worldwide network on-line. The heart of the simulator was to be a very small and very tight loop, consisting, in fact, of just thirteen machine instructions. Bill had worked for some time on this loop and when he finally reached the point of some confidence in it, he began looking for a critic—the standard practice in this programming group.

Bill 发现 Marilyn B. 愿意细读他的代码以换取他的回报。这在这个群体中并不罕见。事实上，如果没有第二方的这种审查，没有人会想到继续使用机器。只要有可能，就会进行交流，因此没有人会感到被别人批评。但是对于精通这种方法的比尔来说，交易所的保护是没有必要的。当涉及到编程时，他的价值体系表明秘密的、占有性的编程是不好的，而开放的、共享的编程是好的。可能在他编写的代码中发现的错误——不是“他的”代码，因为这里没有使用术语——只是为了未来的改进而暴露在调查中的事实，而不是对他个人的攻击。

Bill found Marilyn B. willing to peruse his code in exchange for his returning the favor. This was nothing unusual in this group; indeed, nobody would have thought of going on the machine without such scrutiny by a second party. Whenever possible an exchange was made, so nobody would feel in the position of being criticized by someone else. But for Bill, who was well schooled in this method, the protection of an exchange was not necessary. His value system, when it came to programming, dictated that secretive, possessive programming was bad and that open, shared programming was good. Errors that might be found in code he had written—not "his" code, for that, terminology was not used here—were simply facts to be exposed to investigation with an eye to future improvement, not attacks on his person.

在这个特定的例子中，Bill 经历了他的“编程糟糕日子”之一。当 Marilyn 一遍又一遍地检查代码时——当她发现一个又一个错误时——他变得越来越有趣，而不是越来越防御，如果他像我们许多程序员一样接受过培训，他可能会这样做。最后，他从他们的会议中脱颖而出，向全世界宣布了一个惊人的事实，即 Marilyn 仅在 13 个语句中就发现了 17 个错误。他坚持要向所有愿意倾听的人展示这是如何可能的。事实上，由于这个练习本身已经向他证明，这不是他编写代码的日子，所以他只是用一天剩下的时间来讲述和复述这一集的所有搞笑细节。

In this particular instance, Bill had been having one of his "bad programming days." As Marilyn worked and worked over the code—as she found one error after another—he became more and more amused, rather than more and more defensive as he might have done had he been trained as so many of our programmers are. Finally, he emerged from their conference announcing to the world the startling fact that Marilyn had been able to find seventeen bugs in only thirteen statements. He insisted on showing everyone who would listen how this had been possible. In fact, since the very exercise had proved to him that this was not his day for coding, he simply spent the rest of the day telling and retelling the episode in all its hilarious details.

同时，玛丽莲对她自己在这个问题上的工作没有任何虚假的信心，因为——她的推理是正确的——在有十七个错误的地方，可能还有更多。特别是，她知道在编写代码一定时间后，她已经像 Bill 一样将它内化了，尽管最初并不是她写的。于是她又去找批评家；当比尔因为他的牺牲而让每个人都开怀大笑时，玛丽莲和其他人在一天结束之前设法又发现了三个错误。

Marilyn, at the same time, did not feel any false confidence in her own work on the problem, for—she reasoned correctly—-where there had been seventeen errors, there were probably a few more. In particular, she knew that after a certain amount of time working on the code, she had internalized it as much as had Bill, even though she had not written it originally. So she in turn went looking for a critic; and while Bill was giving everyone an enormous laugh at his expense, Marilyn and others managed to find three more errors before the day was over.

作为此事件的结尾，应该注意的是，当这段代码最终被放入计算机时，尽管进行了最残酷的测试，但没有发现更多错误。事实上，这个模拟器已经在十几个装置中投入使用进行实时操作，并且在至少九年的时间里没有发现任何其他错误。如果比尔觉得代码中发现的每一个错误都是他自尊心上的伤口——他愚蠢的广告，那么这个故事可能会有多么不同。

As an epilogue to this incident, it should be noted that when this code was finally put on the computer, no further errors were found, in spite of the most diabolical testing possible. In fact, this simulator was put into use in more than a dozen installations for real-time operations, and over a period of at least nine years no other errors were ever found. How different might have been the story had Bill felt that each error found in that code was a wound in his pride—an advertisement of his stupidity.

这起事件不是个案，这个群体也不是独一无二的。那么，为什么这样的群体不更引人注目呢？为什么“无自我编程”的实践没有得到更广泛的应用？可以援引许多因素来解释此类群体很少见的印象。首先，许多成功的软件公司都是基于这种类型的交互，尽管他们会在直接询问下承认这一点，但他们通常将这些知识视为有价值的专有信息。其次，以这种方式工作的团队往往非常满意和稳定，因此我们发现在安装和安装之间徘徊的程序员不太可能来自这样的团队。而且，

This incident is not an isolated case, and this group is not unique. Why, then, are such groups not more conspicuous? Why is the practice of "egoless programming" not more widespread? A number of factors might be invoked to account for the impression that such groups are rare. First of all, many of the successful software firms are based on this type of interaction, and though they will admit to it under direct questioning, they often regard this knowledge as valuable proprietary information. Secondly, groups working in this way tend to be remarkably satisfied and stable, so that the programmers we find wandering from installation to installation are not likely to have come from such a group. Moreover, these gypsy programmers—to achieve a constantly escalating salary range—must encourage the myth that the best programming is the product of genius, and nothing else.

这些方法不太为人所知的另一个原因是，没有人曾试验过这种方法和孤立的个体程序员的方法所产生的工作质量的差异。已经对影响程序员生产力的因素进行了一些实验，但这些实验首先受到强调编程的机械方面而非社会方面的影响。例如，将进行一项研究将分时与批处理或语言 A 与语言 B 进行比较，因为有人试图证明他应该被允许为语言 B 开发分时系统或编译器。运行这些实验似乎理所当然地认为编程工作的个体性质——因为这可能是他们一直运作的方式。此外，与个人合作的事情已经够复杂了。

Another reason these methods are not better known is that nobody has ever experimented on the difference in quality of work produced by this method and the method of isolated individual programmers. Some experiments have been performed on factors affecting programmer productivity, but these have suffered first of all from emphasis on the mechanical aspects of programming, not the social. For example, a study will be made comparing time-sharing with batch processing or language A with language B, because someone is trying to prove that he should be allowed to develop a time-sharing system or a compiler for language B. The people who run these experiments seem to take for granted the individual nature of programming effort—for that is probably the way they have always operated. Besides, things are complicated enough working with individuals. When you compare system X and system Y and find out that 90 percent of the variance in your experiment comes from individual programmer differences, who wants to add the complication and expense of studying group performance?

一个有趣的轶事——我们在关于方法的章节中简要提到过——可以讲述我们的一项研究，该研究试图评估当不同的程序员对他们要实现的目标的印象略有不同时所获得的编程结果的差异——高效编码或快速完成。像往常一样，个别科目被聘用，但其中一个科目——他们都是参加为期三个月的特殊课程的学生——恰好来自一个练习无私编程的小组。有一次，他来找我说他的工作到了需要有人检查他所做的事情的地步。由于实验的目的不是研究小组工作和个人工作之间的差异，我被迫——违背我自己的信念——要求受试者尝试在没有外部帮助的情况下继续进行，

An interesting anecdote—which we mentioned briefly in the chapter on methods—can be told about one of our studies that tried to assess the difference in programming results obtained when different programmers were given slightly different impressions of what they were to achieve—efficient coding or quick completion. As usual, individual subjects were employed, but one of these subjects—they were all students on a special three-month course—happened to come from a group that practiced egoless programming. At a certain point, he came to me and said that he had reached the point in his work where he needed someone to look over what he had done. As the object of the experiments was not to study differences between group work and individual work, I was forced—against my own beliefs—to request that the subject try to proceed without outside assistance, which would only add to the variance of the experiment.

作为这一事件的旁观者，应该注意的是，在评估人员看来，与解决同一问题的其他四位程序员相比，这位程序员的工作组织得更好，执行得也更好。在与他讨论这个问题时，他提出了一个观点，即他一直在努力工作，就像他在自己的团队中所做的那样——始终着眼于使最终必须阅读它的人或人们清楚和理解该程序。这种洞察力表明，无自我编程的所有优势并不局限于错误检测，尽管这可能是采用该技术的最早和最强烈的动机。事实上，根据这种方法会对它们产生什么影响，检查我们在良好编程中的四个因素可能是有用的。

As a sidelight to this incident, it should be noted that this programmer's work seemed to the evaluators to be better organized and better executed than the other four programmers working on the same problem. In discussing this question with him, he raised the point that he had worked throughout as he always did in his own group—always with an eye to making the program clear and understandable to the person or people who would ultimately have to read it. This insight indicates that all the advantages of egoless programming are not confined to the detection of errors, though that was perhaps the earliest and strongest motivation for adopting the technique. In fact, it might be useful to examine our four factors in good programming in the light of what effect this method would have on them.

对于满足规范，价值是相当明确的。在调度问题上，对完成程序的平均时间的影响不是立即显而易见的，但从我们的错误模拟器示例中应该可以清楚地看出对变化的影响。如果程序员真的有糟糕的编码日——而且这似乎得到了很多来源的支持——那么在这些日子里写的一段代码将有一个额外长的调试周期。就 Bill G. 的程序而言，这 20 个错误可能需要数周时间才能根除。此外，似乎其中至少有一个可能在该部分与其他部分集成之后在系统中幸存下来——在这种情况下，其他部分的时间表可能会受到不利影响，或者至少不可预测地受到影响。

For meeting specifications, the value is quite clear. On the matter of scheduling, the effect on the mean time to complete programs is not immediately evident, but the effect on the variation should be clear from our example of the bugged simulator. If it is true that programmers have bad coding days—and this seems supported from a number of sources—then a piece of code written on one of these days is going to have an extra long debugging cycle. In the case of Bill G.'s program, the twenty bugs might have taken several weeks to root out. Moreover, it seems likely that at least one of them might have survived in the system past the time when this piece was integrated with other pieces—in which case the schedule of other parts would have been adversely, or at least unpredictably, affected.

不仅减少了调试时间的变化，而且由于有不止一个人熟悉该程序，因此更容易对已取得的实际进展量做出切合实际的估计。没有必要依赖单一的判断——而且是最不可能没有偏见的人的判断。程序的适应性也提高了，因为我们确信至少有两个人能够理解程序。在某些编程环境下，这代表了无限的改进。此外，如果其中一位程序员碰巧生病、怀孕或失踪，整个工作也不太容易受到干扰，而程序员通常会这样。这不仅减少了时间表的变化，而且更有可能在将来的某个时间必须修改代码时，

Not only is the variation in debugging time reduced, but since there is more than one person familiar with the program, it is easier to get realistic estimates on the amount of real progress that has been made. It is not necessary to rely on a single judgment—and of the person least likely to be unbiased, at that. The adaptability of programs is also improved, for we are assured that at least two people are capable of understanding the program. Under certain programming circumstances, this represents an infinite improvement. Also, the entire work is less susceptible to being disturbed if one of the involved programmers happens to be sick, or pregnant, or otherwise missing, as programmers are wont to be. This not only reduces variations in schedule, but also makes it more likely that at some time in the future, when the code must be modified, someone will be around who knows something about it.

关于效率问题，我们不能一概而论。以这种方式开发的程序似乎没有理由比其他程序效率低。通过让第二方查看该程序，我们似乎增加了至少消除最明显效率低下区域的可能性，尽管总体效率通常主要受所选原始结构的影响。

On the question of efficiency, we can make no hard and fast statements. There certainly seems to be no reason why programs developed in this way should be less efficient than other programs. By having a second party look at the program, it would seem that we increase the possibility of eliminating at least the most obviously inefficient areas, although overall efficiency is usually going to be primarily influenced by the original structure chosen.

这种方法的最后一个优势在于它对阅读其他人程序的人的影响，因为，如果我们正确评估阅读程序的价值，他将不得不成为一个更好的程序员。我们将在程序员培训的标题下对这个主题进行更多讨论，但即使没有具体的教育措施，这样一个群体的总体能力水平似乎也有可能提高。

One final advantage of this method lies in the effect it has on the person reading the program of someone else, for, if we are correct in assessing the value of reading programs, he cannot help but become a better programmer for the exercise. We shall have more to say on this subject under the heading of programmer training, but it does seem that the general level of competence of such a group is likely to raise itself even in the absence of specific measures for education.

创建和维护编程环境

CREATING AND MAINTAINING THE PROGRAMMING ENVIRONMENT

创造我们所描述的这种理想环境的问题不同于在这种环境存在后维持这种环境的问题。维持是迄今为止更容易的任务，因为将现有群体转变为这种哲学通常会与社会结构的“锁定”或“固定”现象发生冲突。只要情况创造了有利于维持该情况的环境，就会发生固定。例如，FM 调谐器可以设计为以调谐旋钮附近最强的信号为中心。一旦一个电台被这个设备捕捉到，只有非常强烈的变化才能让它消失，因为每一个微小的变化趋势都会被调谐器的补偿动作所满足。这种锁定发生在各种系统中——生理的、电子的、生物的、

The question of creating such a desirable environment as we have described is different from the question of maintaining such an environment once it exists. Maintenance is by far the easier task, for converting an existing group to this philosophy will usually run against the phenomenon of "locking" or "fixation" of social structures. Fixation occurs whenever a situation creates an environment favorable for maintaining that situation. For example, an FM tuner can be designed to center itself on the strongest signal in the vicinity of the tuning knob. Once a station is captured by this device, only a very strong change can get it off, because every small tendency to change is met by a compensating action by the tuner. Such locking occurs in all sorts of systems—physiological, electronic, biological, but especially for our immediate purposes, social.

社会固定的一个典型计算示例是安装采用一种编程语言。一旦语言被采用，新语言就更难进入，因为大多数人都使用旧语言，循规蹈矩会带来优势。如果需要建议，更容易找到。如果一个人需要子程序，它们就更有可能存在。计算机运行的调度可能有利于常用的语言，键盘输入器在输入熟悉的编码时会出现更少的错误，并且使用旧语言的程序会更顺畅，开发得更好。

One typical computing example of social fixation is the adoption of one programming language by an installation. Once the language has been adopted, a new language has more difficulty making an entry, because with most of the people using the old language, advantages accrue to following the beaten path. If one needs advice, it is more easily found. If one needs subroutines, they are more likely to exist. Scheduling of computer runs may favor the commonly used language, keypunchers will make fewer errors punching familiar coding, and procedures for using the old language will be smoother and better developed.

就像安装固定在编程语言上一样，它可以建立一个鼓励或阻止无私编程的一般社会环境。当一个新程序员进入环境时，他的态度可能会受到已经在场的其他人的反应的影响。如果他向某人寻求建议而他因愚蠢的错误而被嘲笑，他下次就不太可能寻求帮助。然而，如果有人来找他寻求帮助以查看程序，他会因为对他的能力的隐含赞美而受宠若惊，并且在他不得不寻求建议时可能不会感到如此威胁。在很大程度上，我们的行为方式与我们看到周围人的行为方式相同，因此一个正常运作的编程团队会倾向于让新成员融入其编程哲学。

In the same way that an installation fixates on a programming language, it can establish a general social environment which either encourages or discourages egoless programming. When a new programmer enters the milieu, his attitudes may be shaped by the reactions of the others already there. If he goes to somebody for advice and he is ridiculed for the stupidity of his errors, he is less likely to seek assistance the next time. If, however, someone comes to him and asks for help in looking over a program, he is flattered by the implied compliment to his ability and may not feel so threatened when he has to seek advice. To a large extent, we behave the way we see people behaving around us, so a functioning programming group will tend to socialize new members to its philosophy of programming.

有时，面对比引入一两个新成员更大的威胁，团队可能不得不保持其理念。无私编程哲学的拥护者经常受到组织中高层管理人员的威胁性举动。管理者倾向于从社会的“攻击性”部分中选择自己，并且难以理解其他人并不完全认同他们的金钱和声望目标这一事实。他们尤其不知所措，无法理解基于相互尊重个人才能和在共同事业中合作的编程团队的顺利运作。相反，他们倾向于将人们视为为金钱而工作或面临威胁——正如他们自己所做的那样。

Sometimes the group may have to maintain its philosophy in the face of a larger threat than the introduction of a new member or two. Adherents of the egoless programming philosophy are frequently subjected to threatening moves on the part of managers from higher levels in their organization. Managers tend to select themselves from the "aggressive" component of society and have difficulty appreciating the fact that other people do not completely share their goals of money and prestige. They are especially at a loss to understand the smooth functioning of a programming group based on mutual respect for individual talent and cooperation in the common cause. Instead, they tend to view people as working for money or under threat—as they themselves do.

在一家计算机制造商的软件部门中，发生了积极管理与顺从分离编程组之间冲突的一个特别相关的例子。该部门的一个小组作为一个团队，在生产一个全新的系统方面特别成功，该系统有望具有巨大的市场潜力。这群人的成就是如此明显，以至于公司管理层决定给他们现金奖励。按照典型的管理方式，他们将奖项颁发给被指定为集团经理的人。想象一下，当他告诉他们除非将奖项颁发给所有人，否则他无法接受该奖项时，他们会感到困惑。

A particularly pertinent example of the clash between aggressive management and a compliant-detached programming group occurred in a software section of one of the computer manufacturers. One group in the section, acting as a team, had been particularly successful at producing an entirely new system, which promised to have much market potential. The achievement of this group was so evident that the management of the company decided to give them a cash award. In typical management fashion, they gave the award to the person who had been designated as the group's manager. Imagine their bewilderment when he told them that he could not accept the award unless it was given to all.

鉴于团队分享工作的方式，他的反应是完全正确的，但管理层并不理解。一些经理认为他是为了赚更多的钱。其他人则认为他试图建立一个“女主角”团体。不管怎么说，还是决定逼他领奖，还要解散这群人——这似乎是有不正之风的想法。他接过奖，并迅速平分给所有小组成员，之后小组成员集体离开公司，前往一家独立的软件公司工作。

His reaction, in view of the way the group shared its work, was perfectly correct, but was not understood by the management. Some managers thought that he was maneuvering for more money; others thought he was trying to set up a "prima donna" group. In any case, it was decided to force him to accept the award and also to break up the group—which seemed to have unhealthy ideas. He took the award and promptly split it equally among all the group members, after which the group left the company en masse and went to work for an independent software firm.

在这种情况下，该组织通过起身和离开来保护自己免受巨大的外部威胁。如果管理层更清楚这个小组必须提供什么，并且他们更灵活，他们可能会制定出一个解决方案，让这个小组以有利的方式影响其他小组的工作。但这对管理人员来说并不容易做到，他们往往认为工作完成后是某个能力出众的领导者的直接行动结果。即使当经理欣赏团队的工作时，将团队的生产力视为团队的财产，而不是个人成员贡献的总和，也不符合他自己的理念。

In this case, the group protected itself against a great outside threat by picking up and leaving. Had the management been more aware of what this group had to offer, and had they been more flexible, they might have worked out a solution that would have permitted this group to influence the work of other groups in a favorable way. But this is not easily done by managers, who tend to feel that when work gets done it is the direct result of the actions of some leader of outstanding ability. Even when the manager appreciates the work of the group, it is not consistent with his own philosophy to see the productivity of the group as a property of the group, not as a sum of the contributions of the individual members.

在一个有趣的案例中，一组十名程序员来到一家大型机身制造商的编程部门工作。他们在另一家公司一起工作了大约两年，但那家公司决定将其数据处理设施集中在该国的另一边。这些程序员一直不愿意搬家。在每个人都收到几家公司的有吸引力的报价后，他们决定选择能雇用他们所有人的那家。这类群体的大规模运动并不少见，尽管管理层倾向于将其视为某种阴谋，但他们通常更多的动机是希望继续获得共同工作的成就感，而不是任何巨大的物质收益的想法——例如真正包容的工作环境的强大影响力。

In one interesting case, a group of ten programmers had come to work in the programming section of a large airframe manufacturer. They had worked together in another firm for about two years, but that firm had decided to centralize its data-processing facilities on the other side of the country. These programmers had been unwilling to move. After each had received attractive offers from several firms, they decided to go with the one that would hire them all. Mass movements of groups of this type are not rare, and though management tends to see them as some sort of conspiracy, they are usually motivated more by the desire to continue receiving the fulfillment of working together than any idea of enormous material gain—such is the powerful influence of a truly receptive working environment.

在这群人搬到机身制造商几个月后，他们的新经理在一次计算机会议上碰巧遇到了他们的前任经理，并问他是否还有这样的人。在被告知他拥有整个团队后，他询问了用于找到这些人的秘密。他们的老经理想不出有什么特别的——一个女孩是大学刚毕业的意大利语专业，一个男人在高中教了七年数学，一个男人是专业工程师，一个女孩是商学院毕业生，曾担任执行秘书和会计师多年。他想知道，为什么另一位经理会问？

Some months after this group had moved to the airframe manufacturer, their new manager happened to meet their former manager at a computer conference and asked him if he had any more people like those. Upon being told that he had the entire group, he inquired about the secret that had been used in finding these people. Their old manager could think of nothing special—one girl had been a new college graduate majoring in Italian, one man had taught mathematics in a high school for seven years, one man was a professional engineer, one girl had been a business school graduate who had worked for several years as an executive secretary and accountant. Why, he wanted to know, had the other manager asked?

“我不知道那是什么，”老老实实地困惑地回答说，“但是自从那些人来到我们这里后，我发现每当有真正需要按时正确完成的工作时，我把它交给他们中的一个。我还有 300 名其他程序员，但如果我想把它做对，那就是我要求的人。他们一定是某种天才。” 他的感知明显受到了他期望看到的东西的影响，以至于他无法让自己明白，每当他把工作交给团队中的一个成员时，所有人都会以他们惯常的方式进行工作。当他们试图向他解释他们的方法时，他明白他们是在掩盖这样一个事实，即一些成员正在做所有的工作，而其他人则负责搬运。幸运的是，他不会僵化到仅仅因为不明白它是如何运作就不得不中断他唯一令人满意的手术。不幸的是，他无法看到他们成功的方法如何可以传播给他的团队中的其他人，所以这个团队一直是一个孤立的口袋，直到它再次作为一个团队移动到一个更理解的环境。

"I don't know what it is," came the honestly puzzled reply, "but since those people have come to our place, I've discovered that whenever there is a job that really has to be done right and on time, I give it to one of them. And I have 300 other programmers, but if I want it done right, that's who I ask to do it. They must be some kind of geniuses." His perception was so obviously colored by what he expected to see that he could not bring himself to understand that whenever he gave a job to one member of the group, it was worked on by all of them in their usual fashion. When they tried to explain their methods to him, he understood them to be covering up the fact that a few of the members were doing all the work and carrying the others. Fortunately, he was not so rigid that he had to break up the only satisfactory operation he had merely because he didn't understand how it functioned. Unfortunately, he was unable to see how their successful methods could be transmitted to others in his group, so the group remained an isolated pocket until the time it moved on—again as a group—to a more understanding environment.

当然，遵循个人主义编程学派的团队也有办法保护自己——这家机身制造商的编程部门的其他成员也是如此。一个新成员，甚至是这么大一个群体中的一个新群体，即使坚信自己的做法是正确的，也确实没有机会改造社会制度。如果他进入一个既定的群体，他可能最终会改变自己的方式来适应他们的方式，尽管在经历了比人们可能希望的更多的心理困难之后。然而，如果这个小组是新成立的，就像编程小组经常做的那样，并且如果它是由不同的元素组成的，他可能会努力按照他的形象塑造这个小组，如果不成功就离开。

Of course, groups that follow the individualistic school of programming also have a way of preserving themselves—as did the remainder of the programming section at this airframe manufacturer. A single new member, or even a single new group within so large a group, really has no chance of converting the social system, even if he is firmly convinced of the correctness of his way of doing things. If he comes into an established group, he will probably change his ways to theirs, eventually, though after experiencing more psychological hardship than one might like. If the group is newly forming, however, as programming groups often are, and if it is forming from disparate elements, he may struggle to shape the group to his image and then leave if unsuccessful.

一个典型的例子是 Jim A.，他从纽约的一个编程中心被带到芝加哥的一个新形成的项目中。他被分配到的小组由两个人领导，他们在无私的编程传统中坚定地成长起来，并决心在这个项目中传播这一传统。该小组由这两个人、吉姆和四名学员组成。在小组聚集的第一天，小组组长就开始向其他人灌输他们的工作方法。一开始就决定，每个小组成员在进入计算机处理任何工作之前，都必须在其运行请求上获得其他成员之一的签名。通过这种略显正式的方法，他们希望确保小组成员养成习惯，做他们以后会自发做的事情。

A case in point was Jim A., who was brought onto a newly forming project in Chicago from a programming center in New York. The group to which he was assigned was headed by two people who had been firmly brought up in the egoless programming tradition and who were determined to propagate that tradition in this project. The group consisted of these two, Jim, and four trainees. On the first day the group assembled, the group leaders began the indoctrination of the others into their method of working. It was decided at the beginning that each of the group members was to have the signature of one of the other members on his run request before going on the computer with any job. By this slightly formal method, they hoped to ensure that the group members would get in the habit of doing what they would come to do spontaneously later on.

会议期间，吉姆什么也没说，但在学员们离开后，他走近了组长。“这是一个有趣的想法，”他开始说，“帮助那些受训者掌握诀窍。”

During the meeting, Jim said nothing, but when the trainees had left, he approached the group leaders. "That's an interesting idea you have," he began, "to help those trainees learn the ropes."

“嗯，”有人耐心地向他解释道，“这不仅仅是为了受训者。它是为了我们所有人，所以我们不会开始养成坏习惯。”

"Well," it was patiently explained to him, "it's not just for the trainees. Jt's for all of us, so we don't start slipping into bad habits."

“你不可能是认真的，”吉姆笑道。“为什么我有两年多的经验，我的作品当然不需要任何人监督，那些实习生能教我什么？”

"You can't be serious," Jim laughed. "Why I have more than two years of experience. I certainly don't need anyone looking over my work. What could those trainees possibly teach me?"

像大多数预言一样，这个预言有一种实现自己的方式，吉姆设法通过这样或那样的装置避免了其他人的目光落在他神圣的程序上。不久之后，他在小组中的出现显然适得其反。当他看到学员们奋力前行，完成艰巨的任务，而他独自一人奋力前行时，他试图嘲笑他们缺乏独立性和独立思考的能力。他自己的节目达不到小组其他人制作的质量标准。当组长最终被迫将他的一个程序——Jim 声称已经调试过，或者“基本上调试过”——交给一名受训人员来清理时，Jim 无法接受并辞职了。

Like most prophecies, this one had a way of fulfilling itself, and Jim managed to evade the falling of other eyes upon his sacred programs through one device or another. Before very long, his presence in the group became clearly counterproductive. As he saw the trainees advancing to do difficult and challenging assignments while he struggled on alone, he tried ridiculing them for their lack of independence and ability to think for themselves. His own programs were not up to the standard of quality which the rest of the group was producing. When the group leader finally felt forced to turn over one of his programs—which Jim claimed was debugged, or "essentially debugged"—to one of the trainees to clear up, Jim had more than he could take and resigned.

在这种情况下，团体的社会环境已经足以塑造学员的行为；但这还不足以抵消吉姆“两年的经验”。由于他的个性不够强大，无法带领团队朝着他认为正确的方向前进，最终情况变得无法容忍。也许如果组长更聪明、更有经验，他们会从一开始就原谅他离开组，但“两年经验”的诱惑证明了他们的失败——就像在一个如此严重的企业中的许多其他人一样缺乏经验。

In this case, the social environment of the group had been strong enough to shape the behavior of the trainees; but it was not strong enough to counteract Jim's "two years of experience." As his personality was not strong enough to carry the group in the direction he felt was correct, the situation eventually became intolerable. Perhaps if the group leaders had been more wise and experienced, they would have excused him from the group from the beginning, but the temptation of "two years of experience" proved their undoing—as it has to many others in a business which so sorely lacks experience.

概括

SUMMARY

程序员工作的环境是一个丰富而复杂的环境，充满了人的参与、变化和误导的表象。要了解这种环境，就必须了解正式结构和非正式结构之间的区别，以及塑造它的许多因素，从物理环境到个人自我。在一个正在进行的编程工作室中，这种丰富的环境赋予它一种自我维持的品质，可以抵抗来自外部的变化——尤其是在不了解正式和非正式之间的区别的情况下施加的变化。这种自我维持表现在社会各个层面，没有本质上的好，也没有本质上的坏。这只是编程生活中的一个事实。

The environment in which programmers work is a rich and complex environment, full of human involvement, change, and misleading appearances. To understand that environment, one must understand the difference between formal and informal structures and the many factors that shape it, ranging from the physical surroundings to the individual ego. In an ongoing programming shop, the richness of this environment gives it a self-maintaining quality which resists changes imposed from the outside—especially changes imposed without an understanding of the difference between the formal and the informal. This self-maintenance is manifest on all social levels, and is neither inherently good nor inherently bad. It is merely a fact of programming life.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1. 你有组织结构图显示你下面和你周围的组织吗？尝试复制这张图表并标记——用波浪线——在你的组织中发生的互动。波浪线是否与直线相匹配？如果是这样，请离开你的办公桌后面，看看那里到底发生了什么。

1. Do you have an organization chart showing the organization below you and around you? Try taking a copy of this chart and marking—-with wiggly lines—interactions that occur in your organization. Do the wiggly lines match the straight lines? If so, get out from behind your desk and find out what is really happening out there.

2. 你最后一次搬家是什么时候？你能回忆起那次行动的任何改变的行为，而不是行动的直接意图的一部分吗？如果您现在计划搬家，您会采取哪些不同的做法？

2. When was the last time you moved peoples' work locations? Can you recall any changed behavior from that move which was not part of the direct intention of the move? What would you have done differently if you were planning the move now?

3. 回顾你与程序员的互动，你能想到你说过的话可能会迫使他们陷入不和谐的境地——他们必须捍卫自我的境地吗？在那些情况下，不协调的解决方案是否总是朝着您预期的方向发展，或者您是否经历过掩盖错误或进度延误等反应，而不是纠正它们？您如何处理这些情况以减少不协调，或将不协调的解决方案引向对您组织的总体目标更有用的方向？

3. Looking back over your interactions with programmers, can you think of things you have said that might have forced them into dissonant situations—situations in which their ego had to be defended? In those situations, was the resolution of the dissonance always in the direction you intended, or did you experience such reactions as covering up errors or schedule delays, rather than correcting for them? How could you have approached those situations so as to lessen the dissonance, or to direct the resolution of the dissonance in directions more useful to the overall goals of your organization?

4. 要将无自我编程引入您的商店，您需要做什么？你预计会遇到什么阻力，你将如何应对？你认为这需要多长时间，成功的机会有多大？

4. What would you have to do to introduce egoless programming into your shop? What resistance would you expect to meet, and how would you deal with it? How long do you think it would take, and what are the chances of success?

5. 对于那些不想在你的组织中“晋升”，但似乎对他们所做的工作类型和获得的金钱数额感到满意的人，你的诚实看法是什么？你的观点在多大程度上受到你对自己的感受的影响？

5. What is your honest opinion of people who are not trying to "move up" in your organization, but who seem satisfied with the kind of work they do and the amount of money they get? To what extent is your view influenced by your own feelings for yourself?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 如果一个计算中心有完全一致的周转时间，就不需要非正式组织来提供有关工作何时准备就绪的信息。编程的复杂性引起的变化还以哪些其他方式导致非正式社会结构的发展？举一些你自己经历的例子。

1. If a computing center had perfectly consistent turnaround, there would be no need for an informal organization to produce information on when jobs are ready. In what other ways do the variations induced by the complexity of programming lead to the growth of informal social structures? Give some examples from your own experience.

2.如果你经常使用终端系统，你如何与终端系统的其他用户交换信息？您的终端系统是否有使您能够与其他终端用户交换消息的操作？如果是这样，与您使用的其他方法相比，这种用于实际交流的工具有多大价值？

2. If you use a terminal system regularly, how do you exchange information with other users of the terminal system? Does your terminal system have an operation which enables you to exchange messages with other terminal users? If so, how valuable is this facility for real communication, as opposed to the other methods you use?

3. 你把你的作品称为“我的”程序吗？尝试在不使用人称所有格提及程序的情况下度过一周，并记下您观察到的效果。

3. Do you refer to your work as "my" program? Try passing one week without using the personal possessive in reference to programs, and take notes on the effects you observe.

4. 你有没有因为“你的”程序中的错误而责怪其他人？你有没有责怪过无生命的物体，比如按键或磁带？你有多少次责备这些人或事是对的？

4. Have you ever blamed other people for errors in "your" program? Have you ever blamed inanimate objects, such as keypunches or magnetic tapes? How many times were you right in blaming these people or things?

5. 你有没有把“你的”程序的错误归咎于“运气不好”？多常？其他程序员也和你一样倒霉吗？如果不是，你认为命运为什么要挑出你这样的虐待？你认为你可以遵循什么样的仪式来平息他们对你的愤怒？

5. Have you ever blamed "bad luck" for errors in "your" program? How often? Are other programmers as unlucky as you? If not, why do you think the fates have singled you out for such ill treatment? What sort of rituals do you think you might follow to appease their anger with you?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

林奇，凯文，城市形象，剑桥，MlT 出版社，1960 年。

Lynch, Kevin, The Image of the City, Cambridge, M.l.T. Press, 1960.

在这本小而有见地的书中，林奇探索了我们对周围环境的印象如何影响我们的生活。尽管是在城市的层面上进行的，但这本书为任何参与改变或保护人们​​工作的物理环境的人提供了丰富的信息。

In this small and Insightful book, Lynch explores the ways In which our image of our physical surroundings influences our lives. Although cast on the level of cities, the book contains a mine of information for anyone involved in changing or preserving the physical environment in which people work.

Wright, Frank Lloyd，有机建筑：民主建筑，伦敦，Percy Lund，Humphries & Co., Ltd.，1939 年。

Wright, Frank Lloyd, An Organic Architecture: The Architecture of Democracy, London, Percy Lund, Humphries & Co., Ltd., 1939.

赖特是美国最伟大的建筑师，他阐述了“形式追随功能”的理论——必须规划物理环境以适应在其中执行的任务，就像必须为穿着者量身定做西装一样。赖特的想法现在可能已经变得陈词滥调，但在这个成衣成衣和随时可用的建筑时代，这位敏感的经理会通过读一点赖特的作品来刷新他对物理环境的思考。

Wright, the greatest of all the American architects, expounded the theory that "form follows function"—that physical surroundings had to be planned to fit the tasks performed in them, just as a suit has to be tailored to fit its wearer. Wright's ideas may have become ossified into cliches by now, but in these times of ready-to-wear clothing and ready-to-work buildings, the sensitive manager will refresh his thinking about physical surroundings by reading a bit of Wright.

欧文戈夫曼，日常生活中的自我呈现，花园城，纽约，双日出版社，1959 年。

Goffman, Erving, The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life, Garden City, N.Y., Doubleday, 1959.

正如工人受其物理环境的影响一样，他们也受社会环境形象的影响。但工作团队也倾向于塑造他们的形象，这也是为什么管理者很难了解他们的真实结构的原因之一。戈夫曼探讨了个人和团体如何塑造他们将呈现给外人和新来者的形象——这是经理和程序员都应该知道的。

Just as workers are shaped by their physical surroundings, they are shaped by the image of the social surroundings. But working groups also tend to shape their image, which is one of the reasons why managers have such a hard time perceiving their true structure. Goffman explores the ways in which individuals and groups work at shaping the image they will present to outsiders and newcomers—something that managers and programmers alike should know.

Hall, Edward T., The Silent Language , Garden City, NY, 双日出版社, 1959 . Hall 的方法对程序员社会化的方式以及我们获得从未在课程或书籍中教授的特定编程实践的方式产生了许多见解。

Hall, Edward T., The Silent Language, Garden City, N.Y., Doubleday, 1959. Hall takes another point of view on the image of organizations and describes how we acquire our views of the formal and informal structure of the groups in which we live. Hall's approach yields many insights into the ways programmers are socialized, and also into the ways in which we acquire specific programming practices that are never taught in courses or books.

Festinger, LA,认知失调理论，Evanston, III., Row, Peterson, 1957。

Festinger, L. A., A Theory of Cognitive Dissonance, Evanston, III., Row, Peterson, 1957.

费斯廷格 (Festinger) 关于认知失调的工作源于一项早期研究，该研究探讨了当预言世界末日的一群人看到这一天到来而世界继续发展时会发生什么。（当预言失败时）。显然，对于那些每天都在预言失败的环境中工作的人来说，失调理论有很多话要说——尤其是关于程序这次肯定能工作的预言，既然最后一个错误已经被删除了。

Festinger's work on cognitive dissonance grew out of an earlier study of what happens when a group which prophesied the end of the world saw the day arrive and the world go on. (When Prophecy Fails). Obviously, dissonance theory has a lot to say to people who work in an environment where prophecy fails each and every day—especially the prophecy that the program is sure to work this time, now that the last bug has been removed.

Haire, Mason，《管理心理学》，第 2 版，纽约，McGraw-Hill，1964 年。Haire 这本精美的小书对于难以理解非经理人的动机如何的经理人来说是一个很好的起点。

Haire, Mason, Psychology in Management, 2nd ed., New York, McGraw-Hill, 1964. Haire's fine little book is a good starting place for managers who have a hard time understanding how non-managers are motivated.

Fano, R. M„ 和 Corbato, FJ，“计算机上的分时”，《科学美国人》，

Fano, R. M„ and Corbato, F. J., "Time-Sharing on Computers," Scientific American,

215 (1966)，第 128-140 页。在这篇受欢迎的文章中，作者允许自己放弃一些关于用户社会的诱人暗示，这是随着特定计算机系统的发展而发展起来的。然而，他们可能觉得这不是一个适合专业观众的话题，而且他们似乎从未跟进过。

215 (1966), pp. 128-140. In this popular article, the authors allow themselves the luxury of dropping some tantalizing hints about the society of users, which grows up with a particular computer system. They probably felt, however, that this was not a fit topic for a professional audience, and they never seem to have followed it up.

第 4 章评论：编程组

Comments on Chapter 4: The Programming Group

虽然批处理中心在很大程度上走的是雷龙的路子，但是普通物理中心的社会功能会一直存在。然而，今天，我们拥有无处不在的电子邮件——这在 25 年前是不存在的（我也没有预测到这一点）。然而，电子邮件并不能取代近距离接触的所有功能。电子邮件的优势之一是它的相对隐蔽性——缺乏安全感的管理者不会轻易破坏他们不了解的通信系统。尽管如此，他们中的一些人还是尝试使用精密的电子邮件流量监视系统（偏执狂的心理并没有太大改变）。或许这不是偏执狂，而是简单的窥阴癖。变态心理仍然不是我的专长。

Although the batch processing center has largely gone the way of the Brontosaurs, the social functions of a common physical center will always exist. Today, however, we have ubiquitous e-mail—something that didn't exist twenty-five years ago (I missed predicting that, too). E-mail, however, doesn't replace all functions of proximity. One advantage of e-mail is its relative invisibility—insecure managers can't so readily destroy a communication system they don't happen to understand. Still, some of them try—the psychology of paranoia hasn't changed much—using elaborate systems of spying on e-mail traffic. Or perhaps it's not paranoia, but simple voyeurism. Abnormal psychology still isn't my specialty.

如果有任何一件事证明心理学研究被工作经理所忽视，那就是继续使用半分区将工作空间划分为小隔间。我可能认为 DeMarco 和 Lister 的Peopleware会一劳永逸地解决这个问题。也就是说，如果我没有了解将社会地位置于生产力之上的管理心理学，我可能会这么想。

If any one thing proves that psychological research has been ignored by working managers, it's the continuing use of half-partitions to divide workspaces into cubicles. I might have thought that DeMarco and Lister's Peopleware would set that issue to rest once and for all. That is, I might have thought so if I hadn't learned about the managerial psychology that puts social status above productivity.

Brian Pioreck 评论了这一观察：

Brian Pioreck commented on this observation:

“我认为这个问题比社会地位更深。我不知道人件是如何成为畅销书的。我从来没有遇到过任何阅读过它的经理。除此之外，我几乎没有遇到过任何阅读过他们行业的经理，管理理论或心理学时期。我曾经认为他们对有关其工作细节的信息过多，但坦率地说，经理们仍然没有接受过或没有接受过自我教育来完成他们的工作。至于社会地位, IT 经理从开发人员的身份就在他们的组织中被剥夺了地位，因此地位对他们来说甚至比其他业务线的同行更重要。我对 CIO 为自己创建的一些角落办公王国感到惊讶。”

"I believe the issue is even deeper than social status. I don't know how Peopleware became a best seller. I never run into any managers who have read it. Beyond that, I hardly run into any managers who read about their industry, management theory, or psychology, period. I used to believe that they were overloaded with information regarding the specifics of their job, but frankly, managers still aren't trained, or do not educate themselves, to do their jobs. As for social status, IT managers have been status deprived in their organizations since they were developers, so status is even more important to them than their peers in other lines of business. I am amazed at some of the corner office kingdoms that CIO's create for themselves."

 

像许多国王一样，一些经理使用分而治之的策略来统治他们的臣民，但程序员需要与其他程序员接触。当我在 1971 年预测远程系统会加剧程序员的孤立时，我只猜对了一半。这种孤立发生在一些管理不善的组织中，但我大大低估了人类与同类接触的需求。程序员可能不想花太多时间在非程序员的陪伴下，但他们总能设法找到几十个借口与同行面对面地聚在一起。

Like many kings, some managers use divide-and-conquer tactics to rule their subjects, but programmers need contact with other programmers. When I predicted in 1971 that remote systems would worsen programmer isolation, I was only half correct. Such isolation happens in some poorly managed organizations, but I greatly underestimated the human need for contact with their own kind. Programmers may not want to spend much time in the company of non-programmers, but they can always manage to find dozens of excuses to get together face-to-face with their peers.

今天，我将对错误和自我提出与我在第一版心理学中提出的相同的论点，但不是根据相当具有判断力的“顺从-攻击-分离”人格描述系统。现在，我将使用更具描述性的迈尔斯-布里格斯人格量表 (MBTI)，这是一个 25 年前公众（我当然不知道）不为人知的系统。我发现 MBTI 最有助于理解程序员/经理行为的某些倾向，其中一些是我在质量软件管理系列中开发的。

Today, I would make the same arguments about error and ego I set forth in the first edition of Psychology, but not in terms of the rather judgmental "compliant-aggressive-detached" system of personality description. Now I would use the much more descriptive Myers-Briggs Personality Inventory (MBTI), a system that wasn't known to the public (certainly not to me) twenty-five years ago. I've found the MBTI most helpful in understanding certain tendencies in programmer/manager behavior, some of which I've developed in my Quality Software Management series.

本章首次描述的“无自我编程”概念可能是原始版本中表达的所有概念中引用最多、误解最多和否认最多的。我经常想知道我是否可以用更有说服力的力量来写这一部分。如果我使用“不那么自负的编程”这个术语，也许就不会有争议了。也许我需要更多的例子，或者更好的例子。也许我需要更多的实验证据。

The concept of "egoless programming," first described in this chapter, is probably the most cited, most misunderstood, and most denied of all concepts expressed in the original edition. I've often wondered if I could have written this section with more persuasive power. Perhaps there would have been no controversy had I used the term "less-ego programming." Perhaps I needed more examples, or better examples. Perhaps I needed more experimental evidence.

[或者我可能需要再等几年，直到敏捷编程运动开始兴起——基于它相当于“无私的团队”。]

[Or perhaps I needed to wait a few more years, until the Agile programming movement took off—based as it is on what amounts to "egoless teams."]

关于无自我编程，我说，“这些方法不为人所知的另一个原因是，从来没有人试验过这种方法和孤立的个体程序员的方法所产生的工作质量的差异。” 这是一个 25 年来纠正了这种情况的领域，现在不乏证据表明，例如，技术审查（检查或其他形式）导致以更便宜和一致的方式生产出更可靠的代码。事实上，如今越来越多的软件组织定期使用某种形式的技术审查作为流程的标准部分。但不是全部——无论如何都不是。

Writing about egoless programming, I said, "Another reason these methods are not better known is that nobody has ever experimented on the difference in quality of work produced by this method and the method of isolated individual programmers." Here's an area where twenty-five years have corrected the situation, and there is now no shortage of evidence that, for example, technical reviews (inspections or other forms) lead to more reliable code produced more cheaply and consistently. And, indeed, more software organizations today regularly use some form of technical review as a standard part of the process. But not all—not by any means.

所以，我学到了一些东西：如果你不想让你的代码被审查的原因不是基于逻辑，你永远不会被逻辑论证说服来改变你的方式。而且，如果你对你的职业生涯不使用逻辑，你的专业精神就会受到严重限制。
