So, I've learned something: If your reasons for not wanting your code reviewed are not based on logic, you'll never be convinced to change your ways by logical arguments. And, if you're not using logic about your professional life, your professionalism is severely limited.

不幸的是，关于创建和维护编程环境的已有数十年历史的材料似乎根本没有过时。一些经理仍然与有效的编程团队发生冲突，出于各种无关紧要的原因将其解散。一些经理仍然对团队的行为感到困惑，但有智慧让他们不要管。而且，当谈到团队在软件工作中的价值时，有些人仍然不明白。

Unfortunately, the decades-old material on creating and maintaining the programming environment doesn't seem to have become dated at all. Some managers still clash with effective programming teams, breaking them up for all sorts of irrelevant reasons. Some managers still are mystified by what teams do, but have the wisdom to leave them alone. And, when it comes to the value of teams in software work, some individuals still don't get it.

或者也许他们确实理解，但被一种自我延续的动力驱使朝着相反的方向前进。许多软件经理仍然主要根据可交付成果来评判，而不是他们创建可以交付的团队的能力或他们交付的质量。在这种压力下，管理者可能会使用多种不一致的应对方式来哄骗下属的短期结果。一下一代同样误入歧途的经理。

Or maybe they do understand, but are motivated in a contrary direction by a self-perpetuating dynamic. Many software managers are still judged largely on deliverables, not their ability to create teams that can deliver or the quality of what they deliver. Under this kind of pressure, managers may use any number of incongruent coping styles to cajole short-term results out of their subordinates. Some subordinates figure out the game and do the same thing on a smaller scale, all the while honing the skills to become another manager who doesn't believe in building teams, doesn't produce quality results, and creates still more subordinates who become the next generation of similarly misguided managers.

但我并不气馁。我将敏捷（和其他）编程团队的出现视为未来的巨大希望。那么，让我们回到过去，看看 40 年前我们对编程团队的了解，几乎所有这些在今天仍然有效和有用。

But I'm not discouraged. I see the emergence of Agile (and other) programming teams as the great hope for the future. So, let's go back in time and take a look at what we knew about programming teams forty years ago, virtually all of which is still valid and useful today.

第 5 章编程团队

Chapter 5. The Programming Team

 

随着要生产的系统规模的增加，编程经验的缺乏变得更加明显。尽管我们已经看到，理想情况下，即使问题很小，程序员也不会孤立地工作，但是小程序和大程序之间存在社会差异。只要整个团队的工作——从其目的和一般组织到最后的编码细节——都可以记在一个人的脑海中，就不需要协调编程工作。两个程序员查看一个他们中的任何一个都可以完成的程序的交互与两个程序员在一个整体的不同部分上工作的交互是完全不同的，这个整体对于任何一个人来说都太大了。不同之处在于解决冲突需求的方式。在第一种情况下，冲突的解决是一个人的思考过程——也许有其他人的帮助，但总是在那个人的控制之下。在第二种情况下，相互冲突的技术需求转化为潜在的人际冲突，必须形成一种社会机制来解决这些冲突。

The lack of experience in programming becomes more evident as the size of the system to be produced increases. Although we have seen that the programmer does not, ideally, work in isolation even when the problem is small, there is a social difference between small programs and large ones. As long as the work of the entire group—from its purpose and general organization to the last coding detail—can be held in the mind of one person, there is no need for coordination of programming effort. The interaction of two programmers looking over a program that either one of them could have worked out is entirely different from the interaction of two programmers working on separate parts of a whole which is too great for either one to produce. The difference lies in the way conflicting demands are resolved. In the first case, resolution of conflict is the thinking process of one person—aided perhaps by other people, but always under that one person's control. In the second case, conflicting technical demands are translated into potential interpersonal conflicts, and a social mechanism must be formed to resolve them.

团队如何形成

HOW A TEAM FORMS

那么，一个编程团队应该针对一个人无法满足的工作需求而组建。这种需求不仅与要完成的工作的规格有关，还与可用于完成工作的人员的能力以及分配给完成工作的时间量有关。这两个因素——团队成员的能力和可用时间——都具有要求最低限度以使工作可行的特征。例如，某些编程工作不能由受训人员的团队完成，无论人数有多大，因此将“暖体”（业内通常称为“暖体”）的数量增加一倍仍然无法完成工作。时间表同样有限——我们只需要引用一个伪造的实验，该实验试图让九名妇女作为一个团队在一个月内生孩子。

A programming team, then, should be formed in response to a work requirement that cannot be met by a single person. This need relates not simply to the specifications of the work to be done, but also to the abilities of the people available to do the work and the amount of time allotted to doing it. Both factors—ability of the team members and time available—have the characteristic of requiring minima in order that the work be feasible. For example, certain programming work cannot be done by a team of trainees, no matter how large, so that doubling the number of "warm bodies"—as they are so often called in the trade—still will not get the work done. Schedule is similarly limiting—we need only cite the apocryphal experiment which tried to make a baby in one month by putting nine women to work on the job as a team.

从概念上讲，生产给定系统所需的专业知识和时间最少。由于无法明确定义这些数量——并且由于项目估算中涉及的不确定性——管理人员经常组建一个团队，任何合理的判断都表明该团队无法在分配的时间内完成指定的任务。不可避免地，当达到时限并且必须面对现实时，团队将被延期。如果更早地面对它，工作可能会以不同的方式组织——考虑到更长的时间表——从而最终更快地完成工作。

Conceptually, there is a minimum expertise and a minimum time necessary to produce a given system. Because these quantities cannot be clearly defined—and because of the uncertainties involved in program estimation—managers often form a team which any reasonable judgment would indicate cannot perform the designated task in the allotted time. Inevitably, the team is given an extension when the time limit is reached and the reality must be faced. Had it been faced earlier, the work could probably have been organized differently—in recognition of the longer schedule—and thus produced, in the end, more quickly.

这种过于普遍的编程情况说明了能力和进度之间的互补关系。只有让最好的团队为项目工作才能实现最短的进度；只有当我们愿意让项目延长更长的时间时，才能使用最小工作团队。换句话说，几乎任何程序都可以用更少的编程人才来制作——如果我们愿意允许延长时间表，并且如果我们没有低于最低能力。

This far too common programming situation illustrates the complementary relationship between ability and schedule. The minimum schedule can only be achieved by putting the best team to work on the project; and the minimum work team can only be used if we are willing to let the project stretch out for a longer time. In other words, almost any program can be produced with less programming talent—if we are willing to allow a stretching of the schedule, and if we have not dropped below the minimum competence.

这种情况也说明了进度和工作结构之间的重要关系。尽管我们必须时刻警惕帕金森病（工作会扩大以填补分配的时间），但过于紧迫的日程将不可避免地导致走捷径的诱惑。这些捷径可能会成功地让系统按时运行——但前提是一切正常，而这种情况很少发生。许多未能按时完成编程的失败都可以追溯到最初的时间表和攻击计划，这些计划和计划假设了最乐观的条件——没有因疾病而损失的日子，没有机器故障，没有编译器问题，没有“不可能的”错误。因为我们每个人都有过这样的经历，比如说，

Such situations also illustrate an important relationship between schedule and work structure. Although we must always be on our toes against Parkinsonianism (work expands to fill the time allotted), too tight a schedule will inevitably lead to the temptation to take shortcuts. These shortcuts might succeed in getting the system working on time—but only if everything goes right, which it rarely does. So many failures to meet programming deadlines can be traced back to an initial schedule and plan of attack which assumed the most optimistic conditions—no days 'lost through illness, no machine trouble, no compiler problems, no "impossible" bugs. Because each of us has had the experience of, say, a six-month period in which everyone on the team was in top health or there was no machine trouble or there were no compiler problems or there were no "impossible" bugs, we can easily slip into imagining—if the price is right—that we can have a six-month period in which all of these fortunate circumstances happen at once.

另一方面，如果我们试图掩盖可能出现的麻烦，我们就必须用额外的成员来补充我们的团队。此外，如果必须将全部工作分摊给更多的人，那么相对于总工作量而言，协调工作量就会增加。作为一个粗略的规则，组织成一个团队的三个程序员只能完成相同能力的单个程序员的两倍的工作——因为在协调问题上花费了时间。此外，出于同样的原因，三组三名程序员只能完成单组工作的两倍——或四倍于单个程序员的工作。因此，如果我们愿意让三个人来工作，一个程序员需要八个月的项目可能会在四个月内完成，如果我们愿意分配九个人，则可能会在两个月内完成。

If, on the other hand, we try to cover for the possibility of trouble, we have to supplement our team with extra members. Also, if the total work must be divided among more people, the amount of coordinating effort is increased relative to the total work. As a rough rule, three programmers organized into a team can do only twice the work of a single programmer of the same ability—because of time spent on coordination problems. Moreover, three groups of three programmers can do only twice the work of a single group—or four times the work of a single programmer—for the same reason. Thus, an eight-month project for a single programmer might be done in four months if we are willing to put three people to work on it or in two months if we are willing to allocate nine.

请注意，两个月可能是用具有这种能力的程序员编写此程序的最短时间，因为考虑到他们组织起来所需的时间，九个程序员是否可以在不到两个月的时间内完成任何有用的事情值得怀疑. 如果我们必须更快地完成该计划，我们将不得不聘请更好的人来完成这项工作。

Notice that two months would probably be the minimum time for this program to be produced with programmers of this ability, for it is doubtful whether nine programmers can do anything useful in less than about two months, considering the time it will take them to get organized. If we have to have the program faster, we shall have to hire a better man for the job.

无论如何，编程团队规模和组成的基本规则似乎是这样的——为了以最低的成本进行最好的编程，给你能找到的最好的程序员足够的时间，这样你就需要最少的人。当你必须更快地工作，或者与经验不足的人一起工作时，成本和不确定性就会增加。无论如何，进行编程项目最糟糕的方式是雇用一大群受训人员，让他们在没有监督的情况下在压力下工作——尽管这是当今最常见的做法。

In any case, the basic rule for size and composition of programming teams would seem to be this—for the best programming at the least cost, give the best possible programmers you can find sufficient time so you need the smallest number of them. When you have to work faster, or with less experienced people, costs and uncertainties will rise. In any case, the worst way to do a programming project is to hire a horde of trainees and put them to work under pressure and without supervision—although this is the most common practice today.

当作为原始受训者陷入困境时，许多人并没有从他们的编程经验中尽可能有效地学习。即使是为最大当前产量而适当组织团队通常也不是产生最大长期产量的最佳方式，因为要实现这一目标，必须考虑培训。因此，我们可能希望在团队中安排一个或多个相对年轻的程序员，即使我们预计他们对当前的工作贡献不大。当团队有这样的成员时，团队的目标就变得多了——既有生产又有培训——工作的组织也会受到影响。

When thrown into the breach as raw trainees, many people do not learn as effectively as they could from their programming experiences. Even the proper organization of teams for the maximum current production is not usually the best way to produce maximum long-range production, for to accomplish that, training must be taken into account. Therefore, we may wish to place one or more relatively green programmers on a team, even though we anticipate that they will contribute little to the current effort. When the team has such members, the goal of the team becomes multiple—both production and training—and the organization of the work is affected.

在编程中，团队的工作组织方式主要由两个因素决定——目标系统的组织和团队的组成。因为通常有多种接近系统结构的方法，但很少有超过一组程序员可以完成这项工作，所以通常选择结构以适应团队成员的长处和短处。当然，理想情况下，选择会以相反的方式做出——计划理想的程序结构，然后组建一个能够以最佳方式处理这项工作的小组。但是，鉴于目前缺乏编程人才——甚至是“温暖的身体”——这样的计划在违反而不是在遵守方面更受尊重。

In programming, the way a team organizes for work is most strongly determined by two factors—the organization of the target system and the composition of the team. Because there are frequently several ways of approaching the structure of a system but rarely more than one group of programmers available to do the work, the structure is often chosen to accommodate the strengths and weaknesses of the team members. Ideally, of course, the choice would be made the other way around—the ideal program structure would be planned and then a group would be assembled who could handle this work in an optimal way. But, given the present shortage of programming talent—or even "warm bodies"—such planning is honored more in the breach than in the observance.

作为系统结构和团队组织之间关系的一个例子，首先考虑图 5-1，它显示了一个由一名经验丰富的程序员和四名相关受训人员组成的团队如何组织一个系统。a 部分展示了如何将该程序设置为一个相当大的主程序，该主程序调用相对较小的——可能是无输入输出的——子程序来提供它的一些功能。在这里，如 b 部分所示，有经验的程序员将充当团队的传统领导者，他自己编写主要部分并将子例程分配给受训者，其方式有望为每个人提供与其能力水平相适应的经验。

As an example of the relationship between system structure and team organization, consider first Figure 5-1, which shows how a team composed of one experienced programmer and four relative trainees might organize a system. Part a shows how the program might be set up as one fairly large main program which calls upon relatively small—perhaps input-output-free—subroutines to provide some of its functions. Here, as shown in part b, the experienced programmer would act as a conventional leader of the team, programming the main section himself and allocating the subroutines to the trainees in a manner hopefully calculated to give each the experience appropriate to his level of competence.

一个。程序结构

a. Program Structure

b. 团队组织

b. Team Organization

图 5-1。项目结构与团队组织

Figure 5-1. Program Structure vs. Team Organization

 

现在考虑由三个经验相对相等的程序员组成的团队如何组织相同的工作，如图 5-2 所示。在 a 部分，我们看到程序现在被组织成阶段，一个接着另一个，而不是子程序。当然，图 5-1 的主程序也可能按照程序员带队的理念组织成阶段，但我们可能会发现该版本的接口编码比第二版本少。另一方面，第二组也可以在阶段内甚至阶段之间使用子程序，但在这种情况下，我们可能会在成品中发现较少的界面材料。

Now consider how the same work might be organized by a team of three programmers of relatively equal experience, as shown in Figure 5-2. In part a, we see that the program is now organized into phases, one following the other, rather than into subroutines. Of course, the main program of Figure 5-1 might also have been organized into phases according to the conception of programmer leading the group, but we would probably find less interface coding in that version than in the second. On the other hand, the second group could also use subroutines within—and possibly even among—the phases, but in this situation we would be likely to find less interface material in the finished product.

一个。程序结构

a. Program Structure

b. 团队组织

b. Team Organization

图 5-2。程序结构与团队组织

Figure 5-2. Program structure vs. team organization

 

如图 b 部分所示，编程团队本身的结构更多地是平等沟通的问题，尽管由于他在另外两个之间的部分。在这种情况下，成员 II 实际上可能拥有最简单的编程工作，特别是如果第一和第三阶段负责系统的输入和输出。就他在结构中的位置而言，与其他人密切合作的能力可能比编程能力更重要，而且他实际上可能是团队中最没有天赋的程序员——作为程序员。

The structure of the programming team itself would be more a matter of communication among equals, as indicated in part b of the figure, though member II would probably spend more of his time in "teamwork" than either of the others because of the position of his section between the other two. Member II, in a situation like this, may actually have the easiest programming job, especially if the first and third phases take care of the input and the output for the system. In his position in the structure, ability to work closely with the others is probably more important than programming ability, and he might actually be the least talented programmer—as programmer—in the group.

当然，这些结构是理想化的。例如，它们不反映由于这些团队成员所属的更大群体的一般编程哲学而产生的任何内部结构。图 5-1 中的组织实际上可能没有那么多层次，如果这个团体实行无我的编程；而如果其成员不这样做，图 5-2 中的团队可能会远不平等。团队成员的地位以受多种因素影响的方式演变，谁批评谁的工作是最重要的因素之一。因此，如果使用无自我编程，小组中的每个人都会有机会在某个时间检查其他人的工作，从而往往会阻止强等级制度的建立。

These structures, of course, are idealizations. They do not reflect, for example, whatever inner structure comes about because of the general programming philosophy of the larger group to which these team members belong. The organization in Figure 5-1 might in practice be far less hierarchical if the group practices egoless programming; while the team in Figure 5-2 might be far less egalitarian if its members did not. Status of members of a team evolves in a manner influenced by a number of factors, and the factor of who criticizes the work of whom is one of the strongest. Thus, if egoless programming is used, everyone in the group will have the opportunity to examine the work of everyone else at some time, thereby tending to prevent the establishment of strong hierarchy.

在编程中，团队成员的地位通常受到其他人认为他的能力的强烈影响。当程序被传递以供共同批评时，“奶油”到达顶部的速度就会加快。另一方面，如果团队成员像僧侣一样在隐蔽的牢房里工作，那么之前建立的声誉更有可能继续作为团队声望的决定因素——至少在对错误评估采取任何措施都为时已晚之前是这样。

In programming, the status of a team member is usually strongly influenced by his abilities as perceived by the others. When programs are passed around for shared criticism, the speed at which the "cream" will come to the top is enhanced. On the other hand, if the team members work secluded in cells like monks, the reputations previously established are more likely to remain as determinants of prestige in the team—at least until it is too late to do anything about a misappraisal.

同样，分配的特定工作可能会增加团队成员的地位 - 或者剥夺它。编程工作似乎具有地位，就像办公室里的地毯一样，在组织团队时，必须在分配工作时小心翼翼地考虑成员的感受。编写辅助程序，例如测试数据生成器，在某些圈子里似乎声望不高，这可能是因为这项工作不会实际出现在最终系统中。子例程——尽管它们可能会带来更大的困难——通常被认为将编写者置于从属地位，让编写例程的程序员调用它们，也许通过类比，调用子例程本身的角色。这些拟人化不一定代表理性思维，才能成为决定团队对工作分配满意度的重要因素。它们可以是非常真实的——也许因为非理性而更是如此。

Again, the particular piece of work assigned may lend status to a team member—or take it away. Programming jobs seem to carry status just as do carpets in offices, and in organizing a team one must tread gingerly among the sensibilities of the members when passing out the work. Writing auxiliary programs, for example, such as test data generators, seems to carry low prestige in some circles, perhaps because the work will not be physically present in the final system. Subroutines—though they may present far greater difficulties—are often thought to place the writer in a subservient position to the programmer who writes the routine which calls them, perhaps by analogy, to the role of the subroutine itself. These anthropomorphisms do not have to represent rational thinking in order to be important factors in determining team satisfaction with work assignments. They can be quite real—perhaps all the more so for being irrational.

建立和接受目标

ESTABLISHING AND ACCEPTING GOALS

团队成员对自己的任务低人一等的压抑情绪可能会对团队努力造成惊人的损害。无私的编程往往会缓和这种感觉，因为每个程序员都觉得他在系统的更大部分中占有一席之地。尽管如此，如果一个团队在就项目结构和工作分工建立真正的共识之前就开始工作得太快，那么麻烦就会以这样或那样的方式表现出来。

Suppressed feelings by a team member about the inferiority of his assignment can be surprisingly damaging to a team effort. Egoless programming tends to moderate such feelings, since each programmer feels that he has a share in a larger part of the system. Still, if a team sets to work too quickly—before establishing a real consensus about the structure of the project and the division of work—trouble will manifest itself in one way or another.

社会心理学家已经在其他情况下证实，一个或多个成员未能分享群体目标会影响群体绩效——不仅通过该成员的份额，而且通过其他人的绩效下降，因为他们总是认为内部的分歧团体或成员之一的冷漠。图 5-3 所示的组织系统中出现了一个相当奇妙的例子，说明了仅实现表面共识的成本。从系统组织我们可以猜到，最初的团队由七个相对平等的程序员组成，其中一个被指定编写输入/输出包，为从一个阶段传递到另一个阶段的数据提供一个通用接口。

Social psychologists have verified in other contexts that failure of one or more members to share the group goals affects the group performance—not only through that member's share but through a reduced performance on the part of the others, for they invariably perceive the division within the group or the indifference of one of the members. A rather fantastic example of the cost of achieving only a surface consensus arose in a system that was organized as shown in Figure 5-3. As we might guess from the system organization, the original team had consisted of seven relatively equal programmers, one of whom was designated to write the input/output package to provide a common interface for data which were passed from one phase to another.

图 5-3。一个系统的组织。

Figure 5-3. Organization of a system.

 

当决定将 704 转换为 709 时，这个系统已经在 IBM 704 上存在了大约四年。从编程的角度来看，709 几乎与 704 兼容——除了输入输出，它完全不同了。由于该系统将所有输入输出都限制在一个部分，因此预计会进行简单的转换。输入输出例程被转换以便使用 709 系统，同时保留与各个阶段的接口。一旦新例程经过测试，它们就会与旧阶段相结合，一切顺利——直到系统在第五阶段崩溃。

This system had been in existence on the IBM 704 for about four years when it was decided to convert the 704 to a 709. From a programming point of view, the 709 was almost compatible with the 704—except for the input-output, which was entirely different. Since this system had all input-output confined to one section, a simple conversion was anticipated. The input-output routines were converted so as to use the 709 system while preserving the interface to the various phases. Once the new routines had been tested, they were mated with the old phases and all went well—until the system blew up in phase V.

对输入输出例程进行了双重检查，并检查了阶段 V 是否与标准接口有任何偏差。绝对没有发现。然后检查阶段 IV，看它传递给阶段 V 的数据是否被新系统以某种方式扭曲，但阶段 IV 的输出与之前的输出匹配，用于相同的测试位。人们追求其他理论，但几个星期过去了，不知道哪里出了问题。当然，与此同时，拆除 704 和停止支付两个系统租金的压力越来越大。

The input-output routines were double-checked, and phase V was checked for any deviations from the standard interface. Absolutely nothing was found. Then phase IV was checked to see if the data it had passed on to phase V had somehow been distorted by the new system, but the output of phase IV matched the previous output for the same test bit for bit. Other theories were pursued, but several weeks went by without a clue as to what had gone wrong. In the meantime, of course, pressure was building up to remove the 704 and stop paying rental on two systems.

该系统的原始程序员都已不在，因此请来了其中一位，看看他是否能提供有关问题的线索。经过一天毫无回报的猜测之后，他正在和一位新程序员喝啤酒，回忆起原班人马在一起的美好时光。有一次，他偶然想起乔 R. 没有得到编写输入输出例程的任务而感到非常不安，因为他认为自己比得到这份工作的人更有能力。

None of the original programmers of the system were still around, so one of them was brought in to see if he could provide a clue as to the trouble. After a day of unrewarding speculation, he was having a beer with one of the new programmers and reminiscing about the good old days when the original crew had been together. At one point, he chanced to recall that Joe R. had been very disturbed not to get the assignment of writing the input-output routines, as he thought he was much more capable than the one who got the job.

“乔真的痛了大约一个星期，”这位老前辈回忆道，“但后来他似乎从自尊心受伤中恢复过来了。最后他在他的部门也做得非常好。”

"Joe was really sore for about a week," the old-timer recalled, "but then he seemed to get over his hurt pride. He wound up doing a darn good job on his section, too."

“那是哪个部分？” 少年问道，心中隐隐有了一丝疑惑。

"And which section was that?" the youngster asked, beginning to sense a wisp of suspicion.

“第二节，如果我没记错的话。不过你问这个干什么？”

"Section II, if I remember correctly. But why do you ask?"

年轻的程序员说他只是有预感，然后就找借口回了计算中心。他得到了第二部分的清单——没有人看过，注意力一直集中在第四部分、第五部分和输入输出例程上——并开始逐步阅读。他没有看多远。就在一开始，程序从为输入输出例程保留的存储区域中取出一个字，这些例程在整个运行过程中都驻留在核心中。然后第二阶段用一个分支替换了那个词到它自己的部分代码，转移了输入输出例程的流程。在处理结束时，它返回保存的单词，将所有内容保留为输入时的状态。

The young programmer said he just had a hunch, and then excused himself to head back to the computing center. He got a listing of section II—which nobody had looked at, attention having been focused on sections IV, V, and the input-output routines—and started to go through it step by step. He didn't have far to look. Right at the beginning, the program fetched a word from the region of storage reserved for the input-output routines, which were resident in core throughout the entire run. Then phase II replaced that word with a branch to part of its own code, diverting the flow from input-output routines. At the end of its processing, it returned the saved word, leaving everything as it had been upon entry.

当然，发生的事情是乔——根本不接受团队的决定，只是停止公开反对它——编写了他自己的阶段所需的输入输出函数版本。他没有对任何人说这件事，只是在他的灵态运行时短路了部分标准程序。然而，当创建新的输入输出系统时，以前由分支占据的部分现在被用来保存一些变量，这些变量跟踪中间磁带的位置。由于这个“变量在执行阶段 II 的过程中发生了变化，但在结束时又变回了它的原始值，输入输出例程实际上失去了对磁带位置的跟踪。因为这个磁带上的值直到第五阶段，直到那时才发生爆炸。这种不一致的代价是缓慢的；但当时机成熟时，它得到了回报，而且回报丰厚。

What had happened, of course, was that Joe—not accepting the team decision at all but merely stopping his open opposition to it—-had written his own version of the input-output functions needed by his phase. He said nothing to anybody about this, but merely short-circuited part of the standard routines when his phase was in operation. When the new input-output system was created, however, the part formerly occupied by the branch was now being used to hold some variable which kept track of the position of an intermediate tape. Inasmuch as this "variable was changed in the course of executing phase II, but changed back to its original value at the end, the input-output routines effectively lost track of the tape's position. Since the values on this tape were not used again until phase V, it was only then that the blowup occurred. The cost of this non-consensus was slow in being exacted; but when its time came, it was paid, and paid handsomely.

我们应该在这里强调，我们所谈论的共识是关于集团的目标，而不是可以通过其他方式解决的事实问题。例如，考虑一个团队为银行开发在线系统的情况。在对这个双面系统进行最终验收测试时，他们突然看到每台联机打印机都在正常输出的中间打印一行绝对垃圾。这两条线路是相同的，尽管这两个系统的运行完全不受彼此影响——这是为了确保一个系统的故障不会影响另一个系统的正常运行。当然，两个系统使用的是同一个程序，种种迹象表明存在某种程序错误。的确，

We should stress here that the consensus we are talking about concerns the goals of the group, not such matters of fact as could be settled by other means. Consider, for example, the case of a team producing an on-line system for a bank. While undergoing final acceptance testing of this duplex system, they suddenly saw each on-line printer print a line of absolute garbage, right in the middle of the normal output. The two lines were identical, even though the two systems operated entirely free of influence from each other—in order to ensure that trouble in one would not affect the proper functioning of the other. Of course, the same program was used in the two systems, so all indications were that some sort of program bug existed. Indeed, it would be hard to attribute a probability to the occurrence of two machine errors in the two independent machines-—they even had separate power supplies—which would lead to the same line printed at the same time on both.

一名团队成员被赋予了追踪错误的工作，但在研究了一周的证据之后，他并没有比开始时更接近问题的根源另一名团队成员第二周加入了他，没有更好的结果。距离系统投入运行的预定日期只有一周的时间，而且由于系统似乎在所有其他方面都运行正常，因此召开了一次会议来决定如何解决这个棘手的错误。11 名队员讨论得很热烈，没有得出任何结论，尽管有一大群人在敦促小组同意将这起事件标记为怪胎——双机失误！对这种情况的统计数据再多的诉求也不会动摇这个群体的立场——因为尽管这在生理上是荒谬的，这是心理上的满足。他们希望系统按时准备就绪；在第二次会议上，他们成功说服了其他人在系统上签字。

One of the team members was given the job of tracing down the bug, but after a week of studying the evidence, he was no closer to the source of trouble than he had been at the start Another team member joined him for a second week, with no better results. The scheduled date for putting the system into operation was only a week away and, since the system seemed to be operating correctly in every other aspect, a meeting was called to decide what to do about this intractable bug. The discussion among the eleven members of the team was heated, and no conclusion was reached, although one large contingent was pressing for the group to agree to label the incident as a freak—a double machine error! No amount of appeal to the statistics of the situation would sway this group from their position—for although it was physically absurd, it was psychologically satisfying. They wanted the system to be ready on time; and in a second meeting, they succeeded in persuading the others to sign off on the system.

该系统按计划进行了切换，并在大约一周的时间里运行良好。然后，在一个银行工作日的中间，就在操作开始依赖它的时候，系统突然停止了——两台机器同时停止了。大约一个小时后，银行完全瘫痪，系统重新启动。没有人敢估计损失了多少业务，但审计重启影响的文件是一项耗时数月的庞大工作。与此同时，整个编程人员都在疯狂地工作，以便在可能发生另一次故障之前找到错误。

The system was cut over on schedule and functioned quite well for about a week. Then, in the middle of a banking day, and just when operations were beginning to rely on it, the system just stopped—both machines at once. After about an hour, during which the bank was completely paralyzed, the system was restarted. Nobody dared to estimate how much business had been lost, but auditing the files for the effects of the restart was a gargantuan labor which stretched out over several months. In the meantime, the entire programming crew worked frantically to locate the bug before another failure might occur.

毋庸置疑，当最终发现该错误（预计大约每周发生一次的某种时间巧合）时，结果证明它与早先导致两条垃圾线的错误相同。在那种情况下，一个幸运——或不幸——的巧合让系统基本上没有受到损坏，但下一次发生时，事情变得相当糟糕。

Needless to say, when the bug—a certain timing coincidence which could be expected to occur about once every week or so—was finally found, it turned out to be the same bug which had earlier caused the two garbage lines. In that case, a fortunate—or unfortunate—coincidence had permitted the system to go on essentially undamaged, but the next time it happened, things turned out rather badly.

这个例子中的教训是错误共识的教训——也就是说，不像另一个案例那样是表面上的共识，而是对错误的真正共识。不加这种问题在编程中已经够糟了，但这是我们不得不面对的心理问题。我们将在“舆论和社会压力”的话题下对这个话题进行更多的讨论。目前，主要的教训是这种共识——它扼杀了对编程工作的公正评估所必需的健康分歧——和对团队目标的共识——这为生产性运作铺平了道路。

The lesson in this example is the lesson of false consensus—that is, not an apparent consensus as in the other case, but a true consensus on a falsehood. Things are bad enough in programming without adding this type of problem, but it is a psychological problem which we shall have to face. We shall have more to say on the subject under the topic of "opinions and social pressure." For the moment, the main lesson is the difference between this kind of consensus—which stifles the healthy disagreement essential to unbiased appraisal of programming work—and consensus on the goals of the team—which smooths the way for productive functioning.

要在团队目标上达成真正的共识，没有比让团队自己设定目标更好的方法了。一方面，参与设定目标可以确保目标得到更清楚的理解。另一方面，它让每个小组成员都有机会公开承诺实现小组的目标，而这种公开承诺——可能是由于认知失调——已被证明可以提高目标接受度。但是参与本身，完全独立于这些其他因素，似乎是决定个人是否真正接受团队的工作目标以及随之而来的生产力提高的重要决定因素。

To achieve true consensus on group goals, there is no better method than having the group set the goals itself. For one thing, participating in setting the goals ensures that the goals will be more clearly understood. For another, it gives each group member a chance to commit himself publicly to the group's goal, and this type of public commitment—perhaps because of cognitive dissonance—has been shown to enhance goal acceptance. But participation itself, quite independent of these other factors, seems to be an important determinant in whether an individual truly accepts the working goals of the team with the pursuant increase in productivity.

可以肯定的是，并不是每个编程团队都可以随时设定自己喜欢的目标。一个团队通常是为了完成一些任务而组建的，这些任务可能在团队组建之前就已经确定下来了。但是编程任务通常要到团队组建很久以后才会指定得过于精确，因此除非上层管理非常专横，否则很多有意义和有趣的目标设定可以由团队成员协同完成。最大的危险是经理，他是从编程队伍中升上来的，想要在团队甚至看到问题之前定义每一位和字节。没有什么比这更能挫伤团队的热情并让他们觉得自己“只是编码员”了。

To be sure, not every programming team can be permitted to set whatever goals it happens to fancy at any moment. A team is usually constituted to accomplish some task which has probably been set down before the team was even assembled. But programming tasks are not usually specified too precisely until much later than team formation, so that unless the upper management is very overbearing, much meaningful and interesting goal setting can be done by the team members in concert. The greatest danger is the manager who has come up through the programming ranks and wants to define every bit and byte before the team even sees the problem. Nothing is more sure to dampen the team enthusiasm and make them feel that they are "mere coders."

当一个团队根据这种“挑剔”的规范进行工作时，其他问题的出现仅仅是因为该团队试图完成的工作并不明确。精确度和清晰度是不一样的。要明确——目标清晰度是接受目标的最关键因素之一——概述的任务必须置于正在完成的事情的意义框架中。程序员想知道为什么，而不仅仅是什么。

When a team does work from this sort of "bit-picking" specification, other troubles arise simply because what the group is trying to accomplish is not clear. Precision and clarity are not the same. To be clear—and goal clarity is one of the most critical factors in goal acceptance—the task outlined must be placed in a framework of the meaning of what is being done. The programmer wants to know why, not just what.

当编程团队的工作不是为了生产特定的系统，而是为了向其他编程团队提供某种服务或支持功能时，目标不明确的问题会变得更加尖锐。至少当有一个包要生产时，您可以对要做什么有一个印象，即使您不明白为什么。但必须不断提醒支持小组他们的贡献，以免他们陷入做事更具体但效率更低的境地。

Problems of unclear goals become more acute when the programming team is working not to produce a specific system, but to provide some service or support function to other programming groups. At least when there is a package to produce, you can have an image of what is to be done, even if you don't understand why. But a support group must be constantly reminded of their contribution, lest they drift into doing things more concrete but less productive.

例如，许多设施都有一个系统编程团队。这样一个团队的任务相当多样化，由为安装的其他用户提供服务的共同线程结合在一起。我们知道，这样的团队经常只是因为对他们正在尝试做的事情缺乏清晰和持久的印象而陷入迷人但无用的小项目中。其他用户在系统事务中的无能加剧了这种趋势，因为他们觉得无法评估系统程序员所做的工作。在一个案例中——并非非典型——安装中的三个系统程序员着迷于产生改进的加载器的问题——在某些情况下可能有用，但绝对不是在他们的安装中。其他用户对某些服务的每个请求，例如创建一个新的编目程序或在图书馆中合并一个新系统，遇到了不能在他们的系统中完成的声明。事实上，有人断言，他们可以完成，但只有在这个新的装载机完成之后。

For example, many installations have a systems programming team. The tasks of such a team are rather diverse, held together by the common thread of service to the other users of the installation. We know how frequently such a team drifts off into fascinating but useless little projects simply for lack of a clear and persistent image of what they are trying to do. This tendency is exaggerated by incompetence of other users in systems matters, for they feel unable to evaluate the work being done by the systems programmers. In one case—not atypical—the three systems programmers in an installation were fascinated with the problem of producing an improved loader—possibly useful in some contexts, but definitely not in their installation. Each request from the other users for some service, such as creating a new cataloged procedure or incorporating a new system in the library, was met with the statement that it could not be done in their system. In fact, it was asserted, they could be done, but only after this new loader was finished.

这句话本身就足够了，因为只要整个团队都在研究装载机，就没有人有能力做这些其他工作。但是装载机本身与他们无关，除了吸走本可以更有利可图的劳动力。用户因自己对系统缺乏了解而感到害怕（他们中的大多数人甚至不确定加载程序是什么）而无法抱怨。最终，当有人鼓起勇气请来一位外部专家为他做一个小系统工作时，整个聚会就此破裂。装载机无论如何都没有工作，但是系统的变化给了团队他们需要的借口；他们通过声称他们的装载机无法在新系统下工作来挽回面子。

The statement itself was true enough, because as long as the entire team was working on the loader, there was nobody with the competence to do these other jobs. But the loader itself had nothing to do with them, other than sucking off the labor which could have been more gainfully employed. Users were too intimidated by their own lack of knowledge of the system (most of them were not even sure what a loader was) to complain. Eventually, the whole party was broken up when someone had the nerve to call in an outside expert to do a small systems job for him. The loader never worked anyway, but a change in the system gave the team the excuse they needed; they saved face by claiming that their loader could not work under the new system.

对于这种偏离团体目标的行为，没有任何补救措施，除非机构中有能力评估团体是否在按照他们的授权工作。当一个团队有相当明确的目标，但同时有多个目标时，可能会出现更困难的情况。除了前面提到的作为目标的生产和教育之间的潜在冲突外，还会出现其他冲突，例如，当一个团队有两个不同的项目要生产时。不知何故，这两个项目的相对重要性必须在一开始就明确，并且必须定期重新澄清，以免出现偏向其中一个的自然倾向。

There is no remedy for such drifting away from group goals unless there is competence in the installation to evaluate whether or not the group is working according to their mandate. Perhaps even more difficult situations arise when a group has reasonably clear goals, but has more than one at a time. In addition to the previously mentioned potential conflict between production and education as goals, other conflicts arise, for example, when a team has two distinct programs to produce. Somehow, the relative importance of the two projects must be made clear initially and must be re-clarified regularly, lest the quite natural drift in favor of one or the other should occur.

当然，最好每个团队都有一个明确定义的目标，但世界很少如此简单。即使目标是单个程序或子程序，也有可能在强调速度、空间或进度之间发生冲突。当一个团队没有完全了解要放在每个因素上的重点时，该团队的成员很可能会在交叉目的上工作。一个团队成员可能花费大部分精力试图节省时间，却发现这段时间被另一个团队成员浪费了，他试图将程序压缩到尽可能小的空间。当此类冲突公开出现时——尤其是在有关各方对一种或另一种方法进行了大量投资之后——肯定会导致严重的冲突。

Of course, it is best if each team can have a single clearly defined goal, but the world is seldom so simple. Even if the goal is a single program or subroutine, there is the possibility of conflict between emphasis on speed, space, or schedule. When a team is not fully apprised of the emphasis to be placed on each factor, the members of that team may very well be working at cross purposes. One team member may be spending most of his effort trying to save time, only to discover that this time has been squandered by another team member who was trying to compress the program into the smallest possible space. When such conflicts come out in the open—especially after the involved parties have a considerable investment in one approach or the other—serious conflicts are sure to result.

令人惊讶的是，当不同的观点几乎无法区分时，解决团队目标上的冲突想法往往是最关键的。格列佛 (Gulliver) 试图解决关于鸡蛋哪一头该吸的战争，这与人们经常花精力争论是使用一个有两个条目还是一个条目和一个额外参数的子程序相比，简直微不足道。团队成员之间这种争论的持续存在可以可靠地被视为一些更深层次冲突的迹象——也许是为了团队的“领导”——而不应该仅仅因为它的琐碎而被忽视。

The resolution of conflicting ideas on team goals is, surprisingly, often most critical when the differing views are almost indistinguishable. Gulliver's attempts to settle the wars over which end of the egg to suck are as nothing compared with the energies too often spent arguing over whether to use one subroutine with two entries or a single entry and an extra parameter. The persistence of this kind of argument among team members can reliably be taken as a sign of some deeper conflict—perhaps for "leadership" of the team—and should not be ignored simply on account of its triviality.

团队领导和团队领导者

TEAM LEADERSHIP AND TEAM LEADERS

对许多人来说，“领导者”这个词让人联想到阿道夫·希特勒 (Adolph Hitler) 微动一下他的小胡子就让数百万步履蹒跚的士兵送死的画面。事实上，希特勒是他的数百万人民的“元首”或领袖。但是理解像希特勒这样的现象在“追随”的标题下会比“领导”更容易，因为有一种特定类型的领导只是许多人共有的根深蒂固的欲望在一个人的个性上的结晶。

The word "leader," to many people, conjures up an image of Adolph Hitler sending millions of goose-stepping soldiers to their death with a tweak of his tiny mustache. And, indeed, Hitler was the "Fuhrer," or Leader, to millions of his people. But understanding such a phenomenon as Hitler would be easier under the title of "followership" than "leadership," for there is a certain type of leading which is only a crystallization of deep-seated desires shared by many onto the personality of one.

在编程中，这几乎不是需要的领导类型——或者通常是可以容忍的。试着想象一个典型的编程团队对一个拿着鞭子站在他们身边的主管或发出命令的反应，就像一个中尉带领他的小队冲向敌人的机枪阵地。无需想象对更温和形式的威权“领导”的反应，因为我们有无数例子表明，不开明的高管试图对程序员采用这种方法。一种典型的反应是“努力统治”。一个按规则工作的例子发生在一个项目中，该项目在其生命周期中途更换了经理。新经理看到一些程序员在十点三十分来上班时感到震惊——震惊到他没有

In programming, this is scarcely the type of leadership needed -—or which would usually be tolerated. Try to imagine the reaction of a typical programming team to a supervisor standing over them with a whip or issuing commands like a lieutenant leading his squad in a charge on the enemy machine-gun emplacement. The reaction to even milder forms of authoritarian "leadership" need not be imagined, for we have numerous examples of unenlightened executives trying this approach on programmers. One typical reaction is "working to rule." One instance of working to rule occurred in a project that had a change in manager halfway through its life. The new manager was appalled at seeing some of the programmers come in to work at ten-thirty—so appalled that he didn't bother to find out that they had been working on the machine until two the previous night.

下达了一项指令，指出必须严格遵守工作时间，并根据公司的正式规定强制执行打卡打卡。程序员们只是按照正常的工作时间工作——每天晚上 5 点 15 分准时清空办公室，并按时排队等待。由于该项目基本上是在交错班次的基础上运行，以适应有限的机器时间，生产率立即下降了一半。程序员白天无所事事等待机器运行，每天一班后机器立即关闭。

A directive was issued stating that working hours must be strictly observed, and that time-clock punching was to be enforced according to the official rules of the company. The programmers simply responded by working exactly the normal working hours—emptying the office precisely at five-fifteen every evening, and queueing up at the time-clock to do it. Since the project had been operating essentially on a staggered shift basis as an adaptation to limited machine time, productivity immediately fell by half. Programmers were idle during the day waiting for machine runs, and the machine closed down promptly after one shift each day.

一个类似的案例发生在一位经理发现供应品的消耗超出预算时。他立即下令给供应室上了锁，只有供应文员有钥匙。程序员的反应是整天一个接一个地去找供应文员，这样他就没有时间履行其他职责了。最后，经理发出指令，只能在十点到十点三十分或者三点到三点三十分之间领取物资。这种情况一直持续到他遇到一位盯着墙看的程序员并问他在做什么。

A similar case occurred when a manager discovered that the consumption of supplies was running over budget. He immediately ordered a lock put on the supply room, with only the supply clerk having a key. The programmers responded by coming one at a time to the supply clerk all through the day, so that he had no time to perform his other duties. Finally, the manager issued a directive that supplies could only be obtained between ten and ten-thirty or three and three-thirty. This continued until he came upon one programmer staring at the wall and asked what he was doing.

“我的笔用完了，”回答说，“所以我必须等到明天十点才能再写代码。”

"My pen ran out," was the reply, "so I have to wait until tomorrow at ten before I can write any more code."

经理明显脸红了。“你为什么不用铅笔？” 他要求。

The manager reddened noticeably. "Why don't you use a pencil?" he demanded.

“因为我总是用笔。打孔机操作员不会接受用铅笔写的作品。它会弄脏。”

"Because I always use a pen. The keypunch operators won't accept work written with a pencil. It smudges."

“那你为什么不借支笔？”

"Then why don't you borrow a pen?"

“但那样我们就不会准确跟踪耗材使用情况，对吗？”

"But then we wouldn't be keeping accurate track of supplies usage, would we?"

不用说，在经理被提升到更高级别的职位之前，这不是一个非常有效率的商店。当然，他可能会因为不服从命令或其他类似的军国主义指控而解雇了程序员，但他非常清楚，糟糕的经理比优秀的程序员更容易找到。事实上，程序员的长期短缺导致整个领域在编程领导力方面出现了一个有趣的情况。

Needless to say, this was not a very productive shop until the manager was promoted on to some more elevated position in the hierarchy. Of course, he might have fired the programmer for insubordination or some other such militaristic charge, but he knew very well that bad managers are easier to find than good programmers. Indeed, the chronic shortage of programmers has led to an interesting situation in the entire field with respect to programming leadership.

在研究影响工作组满意度的因素时，社会科学家分离出四个主要领域：

In studying the factors which go into the satisfaction of working groups, social scientists have isolated four major areas:

• 物质奖励和机会。

• The material rewards and opportunities.

• 挑战和工作本身的兴趣。

• The challenge and the interest of the work itself.

• 较大组织的一般情况，例如类似组织中的员工福利、工作条件和组织地位。

• The general conditions in the larger organization, such as employee benefits, working conditions, and organization status among similar organizations.

• 主管和领导者的能力。

• The competence of supervisors and leaders.

在当今的编程中，前三个需求的满足程度如此之高，以至于它们通常不会在决定程序员满意度方面发挥主要作用。可以肯定的是，在这个普遍高薪的职业中，存在工资过低的情况，也有乏味的工作，也有糟糕的公司。但这些都是例外，而糟糕的监督和领导比我们想象的更为普遍。因此，程序员对他的“上级”的态度更可能是他不满的原因——随之而来的生产力损失——可能比其他三个加起来还要多。

In programming as it is today, the first three of these wants are satisfied with such regularity that they ordinarily do not play a major role in determining programmer satisfaction. To be sure, there are instances of underpayment in this generally high-salaried profession, there are dull jobs, and there are bad companies. But these are exceptions, whereas bad supervision and leadership is more common than we would like to imagine. Thus, the attitude of a programmer toward his "superiors" is more likely to be the cause of his dissatisfaction—with consequent loss of productivity—than perhaps all the other three put together.

领导力，在社会科学家使用它的意义上，意味着影响人们的能力。程序员往往重视创造性工作和专业能力，他们倾向于把股票放在他们认为擅长做事的人身上。因此，通过成为一个说话温和的编程向导而不是成为世界上说话最快的推销员，更容易对程序员发挥领导作用。当非编程领导者被引入负责编程团队时，通常会出现麻烦，除非被任命的领导者明确或隐含地承认他在技术问题上的无能。他能做的最糟糕的事情——对于一个与该领域失去联系的前程序员来说也是如此——就是试图将编程智慧与团队的其他成员相匹配。

Leadership, in the sense that social scientists use it, means the ability to influence people. Programmers, being people who tend to value creative work and professional competence, tend to put their stock in people whom they perceive to be good at the things they do. Thus, it is easier to exert leadership over—to influence—-programmers by being a soft-spoken programming wizard than by being the world's fastest-talking salesman. When non-programming leaders are brought in to be in charge of programming teams, trouble usually brews unless the appointed leader explicitly and implicitly recognizes his incapacity on technical matters. The very worst he can do—and this goes also for a former programmer who has lost touch with the field—is to try to match programming wits with the other members of the team. Although a team might come to respect a leader who openly admitted his programming inexperience, they could only come to ridicule one whose pretense at knowledge was revealed to be a sham.

在一个案例中，Arnold C. 被任命为一个较大项目中的团队的晋升领导者。阿诺德的资历主要在数据处理销售领域，但他给人一种编程专业知识的感觉。他甚至提出了一种算法来解决该项目面临的关键问题，尽管他的两名最有经验的团队成员显然不知道他在说什么。当他私下向他们展示计划时，他们没有向他展示计划中的缺陷，而是鼓励阿诺德希望召集该项目的主要程序员来听他介绍他的想法。在会议上，他们给了他大约五分钟的时间让自己牢牢地陷入自己的圈套。然后他们开始拆散他的算法——在细节上和宏伟计划上。

In one case, Arnold C. was appointed to replace a promoted leader of a team within a larger project. Arnold's qualifications were mainly in the area of data-processing sales, but he affected an air of programming expertise. He even went so far as to suggest an algorithm to solve a crucial problem facing the project, although it was evident to his two most experienced team members that he didn't know what he was talking about. Instead of showing him the flaw in his scheme when he presented it to them in private, they encouraged Arnold's wish to assemble key programmers on the project to hear him present his idea. At the meeting, they gave him about five minutes to get himself solidly enmeshed in his own snare. Then they began to tear his algorithm apart —in detail as well as in grand plan. Arnold finally left the blackboard amidst the combined laughter of the assembled group, and within two months he received a requested transfer to another post.

此类问题经常出现，是因为外部力量任命的领导者无法在团队内部发挥所需的影响力。这位“正式”或“官方”领导者，因为他代表了外界的目标，所以总是处于不稳定的位置，尤其是当他认为自己的工作仅仅是“推销”或以其他方式将“管理观点”强加给团队时。由于这种观点假设管理层不可能妥协，因此管理层和团队之间的冲突唯一可能的解决方案是团队应该“让步”。

Such problems frequently arise because the leader who is designated as such by an outside force is not capable of exerting the influence required inside the team. This "formal" or "official" leader, because he represents the goals of the outside world, is always in a precarious position, especially if he sees his job as merely "selling" or otherwise imposing the "management view" on the team. Inasmuch as this view assumes that no compromise is possible with the management, the only possible resolution of a conflict between management and the team is that the team should "give in."

即使假设可以让团队屈服，也没有人会希望看到如此屈服的编程团队的表现。但是强迫劳动——在它确实起作用的小范围内——只能与不了解其他可能性的相对不成熟的程序员一起工作，或者与完全意识到其他可能性对他们不开放的相对不熟练的程序员一起工作。另一方面，典型的程序员知道其他可能性并知道他获得这些可能性的机会。如果把这种意识发挥到极致，就会导致编程类型的职业生涯是无休止的工作变动和很少的成就。然而，通常情况下，它会导致编程团队比许多其他领域的典型工作团队更民主地运作。

Even assuming that the team could be made to give in, nobody who has ever seen the performance of a programming group which has so knuckled under would desire this result. But forced labor—to the small extent that it does work—can only be made to work with relatively immature programmers who are not aware of other possibilities, or with relatively unskilled programmers who are quite aware that other possibilities are not open to them. The typical programmer, on the other hand, is aware of other possibilities and aware of his chances of getting them. Carried to an extreme, this awareness leads to the programming type whose career is an unending succession of job changes and very little accomplishment. Normally, however, it leads to programming teams which are run more democratically than typical work teams in many other fields.

在一个民主的团体中，领导力——或影响力——并不局限于一个人，而是随着需要与他的能力或想法相适应而在团队中从一个成员转移到另一个成员。然而，人并非生而相同——尽管他们生而平等。因此，民主团队中的领导权从来都不是均匀分布的，而是更多地落在某些成员身上。民主团体运作的重要因素不是每个成员都发挥平等的领导作用，而是领导力的决定因素是基于团队生活的内在现实，而不是从外部强加的。因此，当团队需要学习某些东西时，最了解该主题的团队成员可能会以其他人的老师的形式上升到领导者的位置。或者，当团队的工作进入调试阶段时，

In a democratic group, leadership—or influence—is not confined to a single person, but moves around the team from member to member as the needs become compatible with his abilities or ideas. People, however, are not all created the same—even though they may all be created equal. Thus, leadership in a democratic team is never spread uniformly, but falls more on some members than others. The important factor in democratic group functioning is not that every member exerts equal leadership, but that the determinants of leadership are based on the inner realities of team life, not imposed from outside. Thus, when the team is in need of learning something, that team member who knows most about the subject may rise to a position of leader in the form of teacher of the others. Or, when the team's work enters the debugging stage, one of the members may emerge as a frequent leader because he has a peculiar talent for debugging.

一个真正民主的团队能够适应不断变化的环境，因此在面对无法预料的困难时往往是一个更可靠的生产单位。然而，管理者往往不相信民主团队在危机中更胜一筹。作为证据，他们指出了一个集中组织的团队在聚集在一个领导者后面时可以聚集的速度和决心，而且他们是正确的——如果领导者恰好是适合这种情况的人。诚然，例如，希特勒的军队在这种指挥下取得了巨大的成功——但他的对手也是在同样的系统下组织起来的。也许希特勒是对的时间对的人——直到他输了。在一个民主组织的团体中——当然，给定的，有足够的才能和智慧可以利用——每次都能选到合适的人选。例如，瑞士人会在战争威胁时选举一位将军来领导他们的军队。当没有战争威胁时，就没有将军——但是根据领导的需要选出其他领导人。与某些其他国家不同，瑞士人在和平时期并没有被试图治理国家的将军们所累。

A truly democratic team is marvelously adaptable to changing circumstances, and thus tends to be a more reliable production unit in the face of unanticipated difficulties. Managers, however, tend not to believe that a democratic team is superior in a crisis. For evidence, they point to the speed and determination which a centrally organized group can muster when massed behind a single leader, and they are correct—if the leader happens to be the right one for the situation. It is true that Hitler's forces, for example, won great successes under this type of command—but then it is also true that his opponents were organized under the same type of system. Perhaps Hitler was the right man at the right time—until he lost. In a democratically organized group—given, of course, sufficient talent and intelligence to draw upon—the right man can be chosen for each time. The Swiss, for example, elect a general to head their armies when war threatens. When there is no war threat, there is no general—but there are other leaders chosen according to what needs there are for leadership. The Swiss, unlike certain other countries, are not burdened by generals trying to govern the country in peacetime.

不幸的是，从始终能够选择合适的人来领导他们的意义上说，没有一个编程团队是完全民主的。一方面，团队中可能不存在合适的人选。另一方面，个性因素可能会影响暂时选择合适的人选。最后，从外部侵入指定领导者的团体总是使团体偏离民主。

Unfortunately, no programming team can ever be completely democratic in the sense of always being able to choose the right man to lead them at each instant. For one thing, the right man may not exist in the team. For another, personality factors may intervene to preclude the selection of the correct man for the moment. Finally, the intrusion into the group of a designated leader from the outside always biases the group away from democracy.

指定的领导者是团队与外部力量之间的信息载体，它会影响团队追求的目标。理想情况下，他将是一个完全中立的携带者，但这从未发生过。他与外部团体的联系使他能够接触到其他人无法分享的特殊信息来源，他可以利用这些来源作为杠杆，将自己提升到更强大的领导地位。例如，如果管理层告诉他他们希望在十周内完成一个特定的项目，他可能会告诉团队管理层要求八周。然后，为了让团队感觉这项工作需要十二周，他似乎赢得了妥协，同意将时间改为十周。

The designated leader is a carrier of information between the team and outside forces which would like to influence the goals which the team pursues. Ideally, he would be a perfectly neutral carrier, but this never happens. His contact with the outside group gives him access to special sources of information which the others do not share, and he may use these sources as leverage to elevate himself to a stronger position of leadership. If, for example, he has been told by management that they wish a particular program to be completed in ten weeks, he might tell the group that the management has asked for eight weeks. Then, giving the appearance of winning a compromise in favor of the group's feeling that the work will take twelve weeks, he agrees to change the time to ten. The others have no way of finding out that he has used his special position to appear to be aiding the group, and his esteem as a leader may grow, even though he has been "management's boy" all along.

当然，如果团队成员发现他一直在歪曲来自管理层的信息传递以博取自己的好感，那么他作为该团队有效领导者的身份就完蛋了。但由于指定领导职位的不对称性，对团队成员不诚实或操纵的诱惑非常大。他的工作主要是在团队中，但他的奖惩来自上级管理层。通常，当一个程序员同意接受团队领导的任命时，他就已经有了从事管理职业的抱负。在那个职业上的进步不再取决于他的编程能力——这可能使他走到了这一步——而是取决于他取悦管理层的能力。

Of course, should the team members ever discover that he has been distorting the transmission of information from management in order to win favor for himself, he is finished as an effective leader of that team. But the temptation to be dishonest or manipulative with the team members is very great, because of the asymmetry of the designated leader's position. His work is primarily with the team, but his rewards and punishments come from the higher management. Usually, by the time a programmer consents to accept an appointment as team leader, he has acquired aspirations for a career in management. Advancement in that career is no longer dependent on his programming abilities—which have probably carried him this far—but on his ability to please management.

目光短浅或缺乏安全感的团队领导可能会觉得取悦管理层的最佳方式是无论他们要求什么都答应他们。但归根结底，管理层要的是信守诺言，而只有团队领导能够让团队接受诺言作为目标，才能获得这些。团队领导者必须学习的是

The shortsighted or insecure team leader may feel that the best way to please management is to promise them whatever they ask. But, ultimately, what the management wants is kept promises, and these can only be obtained if the team leader can win team acceptance of the promises as their goals. What the team leader must learn is that

• 经理们——无论他们多么努力地要求做出承诺——真正想要的是结果。

• Managers—no matter how hard they press for promises—really want results.

• 如果在全团队参与的情况下追求设定的目标，结果将更容易获得。

• Results will be far more easily obtained if they are obtained in the pursuit of goals set with full team participation.

牢记这些事实，指定的团队领导者可能能够克服被指定的障碍并成为自己的领导者。他可能会用“领导力”代替“领导力”。

Keeping these facts in mind, the designated team leader may be able to overcome the handicap of having been designated and become a leader in his own right. He may replace the "headship" with "leadership."

然而，如果我们不承认管理者并不总是意识到他们想要结果，我们就不会完全诚实。我们经常看到一位团队领导因拒绝承诺他的团队认为不可能的成就而被免职。然后，更换过程一直持续到管理层提出一位更愿意提升自己的候选人，而不是大脑来评估成功的真正机会。不幸的是，如果项目是一个长期项目，那么在项目达到管理层可以看到他的承诺不会兑现的地步之前，这位候选人可能会因为他的合作而得到提升。随之而来的是抢椅子游戏，其目的是在外界意识到项目失败时不让其承担责任。这个玩了一遍又一遍的游戏，

We would not be completely honest, however, if we failed to admit that managers are not always aware they want results. We frequently see a team leader removed from his post for refusing to promise achievements which his team believes are impossible. The process of replacement then goes on until management comes up with a candidate with more desire to advance himself than brains to assess the true chances of success. Unfortunately, if the project is a long one, this candidate may be promoted for his cooperativeness before the project has reached the point where management can see that his promises will not be kept. What ensues is a game of musical chairs, the object of which is not to be left in a position of responsibility at the moment the outside world becomes aware that the project has failed. This game, played over and over, has put more than one programming manager in the position he has today.

然而，指定的团队领导只能抵制强迫他接受他的团队无法实现的目标的企图。当然，他应该保持对可能改变情况的新信息的接受度——比如当管理层向他承诺增加人员或更好的机器调度时。他必须自己评估这些承诺被兑现的可能性，然而，一旦他向他的经理们承诺，他们很可能会忘记他向他们提出的条件。但当管理层的争论转向资源或工作规范以外的其他因素时，他绝不能动摇自己的判断。最典型的例子是承诺如果他成功了就会得到特别的奖励，但他不能让自己把奖励的价值和实现它的可能性混为一谈。

The designated team leader, however, can do no better than to resist attempts to coerce him into accepting goals his team cannot meet. Of course, he should remain receptive to new information which might change the situation—as when the management promises him additional people or a better machine schedule. He must assess for himself the chances of these promises being kept, however, for once he promises his managers, they are likely to forget the conditions he extracted from them. But when the management arguments turn to other factors besides the resources or the work specification, he must never let his judgment be swayed. The most typical case involves promises of special rewards if he succeeds, but he must not permit himself to confuse the value of the reward with the probability of achieving it.

讨论到悬赏的时候，leader真的没有办法了，只能抵制。他必须愿意根据自己的专业判断力担任指定领导者。如果他自己是一个优秀的程序员，那么他在这场斗争中会得到双倍的力量，因为他对自己的判断更有信心，而且他知道如果失去这个领导职位，他就不会挨饿。然而，如果他怀疑自己的能力，他将很容易成为隐藏在一团薄雾中的各种威胁的牺牲品。

When the discussions reach the stage of reward offering, there is really no strategy left to the leader but to resist. He must be willing to stake his position as designated leader on the strength of his professional judgment. If he is a good programmer himself, he is doubly strengthened in this struggle, for he has more confidence in his judgment and he knows that he will not be on the breadline if he loses this leadership post. If he doubts his own proficiency, however, he will fall easy prey to various sorts of threats veiled in a mist of wispy promises.

作为本节要点的说明，请考虑 Harold M. 的案例，他是一位杰出的程序员，他发现自己在竞争中处于指定领导者的位置。他接受了领导团队在特定日期前生产编译器的工作，但现在管理层希望在保持相同时间表的同时扩展规范。Harold 与他的团队讨论了此事，得出的结论是，除非他们获得三个月的延期，否则他们无法完成这项工作。当 Harold 将此信息带回给他的经理时，他发现没有被接受。当他坚持时，他的经理安排了哈罗德、他自己和他自己的经理之间的会面。

As an illustration of the major points of this section, consider the case of Harold M., an outstanding programmer who found himself in the position of designated leader in the squeeze. He had accepted the job of leading a team to produce a compiler by a certain date, but now management wanted to expand the specifications while retaining the same schedule. Harold discussed the matter with his team and the conclusion was reached that they could not do the work unless they got an extension of three months. When Harold carried this information back to his manager, he found that it was not accepted. When he insisted, his manager arranged a meeting among Harold, himself, and his own manager.

哈罗德从这次会议的构成中知道，这将是一次把他置于“热箱”的尝试。通过这种安排——方便私密——哈罗德应该在一种可以做出威胁和承诺但从未承认的气氛中感受到自己的重要性。但哈罗德已经多次经历过这种情况，足以预见每一个新动作，而且他对自己和团队的判断充满信心。会面持续了一段时间，每一次招架都被招架，气氛变得更加热烈。终于到了终极威胁的阶段。

Harold knew from the composition of this meeting that it would be an attempt to put him in the "hot box." With this arrangement—conveniently private—Harold was supposed to get the feeling of importance in an atmosphere where threats and promises could be made but never acknowledged. But Harold had already experienced this situation often enough to anticipate each new move, and he was armed with the confidence in his own and his team's judgment. The meeting went on for some time and, with each parried thrust, the atmosphere grew hotter. Finally, it reached the stage of the ultimate threat.

“哈罗德，”他的经理开始说，因为经理的工作是做肮脏的工作，而经理的经理的工作是扮演仁慈的父亲角色，用甜蜜的承诺来缓和经理的严厉威胁。“哈罗德，”他又开口了，因为他停下来将椅子向前拉了三英寸，“你没有与我们合作。要成为一名经理，你必须学会​​合作，学会妥协。也许你不我不具备成为一名经理所需的条件。”

"Harold," his manager began, for the manager's job was to do the dirty work and the manager's manager's job was to play the role of the benevolent father figure softening the manager's harsh threats with sweet promises. "Harold," he began again, because he had paused to pull his chair forward a significant three inches, "you're not cooperating with us. To be a manager, you have to learn to cooperate, to compromise. Perhaps you don't have what it takes to be a manager."

哈罗德明白了其中的含义，但没有让它过去，而是将其完全公开。“我认为你可能是对的。你为什么不找其他人来做这项工作——一个知道如何合作的人。”

Harold caught the implication, and instead of letting it pass, dragged it fully into the open. "I think you may be right. Why don't you get someone else to do this job—someone who knows how to cooperate."

经理的经理看到哈罗德已经被推到了他的极限，并试图回到积极的方向。“但是哈罗德，”他奉承道，“没有其他人了。你是唯一知道如何完成这项工作的人。我们要靠你了。”

The manager's manager saw that Harold had been pushed over his limit and tried to swing back onto the positive tack. "But Harold," he flattered, "there isn't anyone else. You're the only one who knows how to do this job. We're depending on you."

“那么，”哈罗德说，他的声音里带着假装得意的语气，“如果我是唯一能胜任这项工作的人，当我告诉你这是不可能完成的时候，你为什么不相信我呢？这么多时间？”

"Then," said Harold, with a note of mock triumph in his voice, "if I'm the only one who can do the job, why don't you believe me when I tell you it can.'t be done in that much time?"

“因为你并不真正了解问题所在，”他的经理反驳道，但哈罗德已经离开座位，站在门口。

"Because you don't really understand the problem," his manager shot back, but Harold was already out of his seat and at the door.

“看，”他说，就在离开陷入僵局的会议之前。“拿定主意，如果只有我一个人明白，那就只有我一个人真正明白，你就得按照我的方式去做，否则，你换我也没什么问题。” .这是你的问题，不是我的，所以如果你不介意的话，我会回去工作的。”

"Look," he said, just before leaving the deadlocked meeting. "Make up your minds. If I'm the only one who understands, then I'm the only one who really understands and you'll have to do it my way. If not, then you won't have any trouble replacing me. It's your problem, not mine, so if you'll excuse me, I'll get back to work."

哈罗德丢了工作吗？在这种情况下，他没有；但这并不重要，因为他知道他至少可以得到另一个同样好的。如果这很重要，他就不会做他所做的事。领导力的悖论之一就是：只有准备好下台的领导者才有真正的成功机会。

Did Harold lose his job? He didn't, in this case; but that wasn't really important, for he knew he could get another at least as good. If it had been important, he wouldn't have been able to do what he did. One of the paradoxes of leadership is simply this: only the leader who is ready to step down has a real chance of success.

危机中的团队

THE TEAM IN CRISIS

团队的生命周期从招募开始，通过目标设定和组织到完成工作，最后可能在工作完成或接受新目标时解散团队。然而，这条道路上充满了各种各样的危机，以至于一个典型的编程团队的生活故事会成为一部相当有趣——如果有点难以置信——小说的主题。事实上，将团队的工作分为两类是很有用的——旨在实现团队目标的工作和旨在在遇到危机时维持团队有效运作的工作。对于社会心理学家来说，这些活动被指定为“任务导向”和“维护导向”，并且已经成为许多研究的主题。

The life cycle of a team starts with recruitment, moves through goal setting and organizing to doing the work, and finally may end with a dissolution of the team when the work is finished or with the acceptance of new goals. This path, however, is so studded with crises of one sort or another that the life story of a typical programming team would make the subject of a fairly interesting—if slightly unbelievable—novel. Indeed, it is useful to consider the work of the team in two categories—work directed at accomplishing the team goals and work directed at maintaining the effective functioning of the team in the face of the crises it meets. To social psychologists, these activities are designated as "task-oriented" and "maintenance-oriented" and have been the subject of much research.

在某些类型的团队中，通常在编程团队中，团队倾向于选择两个互补的领导者——一个负责设置、分配和协调工作的任务专家；维护专家，负责解决团队成员之间或个人目标与团队目标之间的冲突。指定的领导者，由于他在将外部目标带入团队中的作用，通常处于任务专家的位置，尽管正如我们所知，如果他没有表现出必要的能力，他可能会被团队取代。维护专家——通常是团队中最受欢迎的人——可以来自任何地方。他可能不是一个特别优秀的程序员，尽管他很可能是。很多时候，他会是她。

In certain types of groups, and often in programming teams, the group tends to choose two complementary leaders—a task-specialist who sets, allocates, and coordinates the work; and a maintenance-specialist, who irons out conflicts among group members or between individual goals and group goals. The designated leader, because of his role in carrying external goals into the group, is most often in the task-specialist position, although, as we know, he may be replaced by the group if he does not display the necessary competence. The maintenance-specialist —who will more often be the best-liked person in the group—can come from anywhere. He may not be a particularly good programmer in his own right, though he may well be. Very often, he will be a she.

在一项关于核心家庭（父亲、母亲和他们的孩子）的跨文化研究中，通常至少在文化理想中发现了这种对任务和维持活动的划分。在大多数文化中，包括我们的文化，但并非在所有文化中，理想的父亲是任务专家，理想的母亲是维修专家。也许女性程序员的这一角色在我们的文化中是很自然的。无论如何，当编程团队中有女性时，她似乎经常扮演“团队母亲”的角色，尽管没有研究证实性别是选择维护专家的重要因素。至少有几支球队其中一名女性被公开称为“团队之母”或“巢穴之母”，计算界一直流传着一个笑话，将“软件”定义为“女程序员”。软性是用来描述维护任务的术语之一，而硬性似乎是描述必须指导工作的人的特征。

In one cross-cultural study of nuclear families—father, mother, and their children—this same division into task and maintenance activities was usually found at least in the cultural ideal. In most cultures, including ours, but not in all, the ideal father was the task-specialist and the ideal mother the maintenance-specialist. Perhaps this role for a female programmer is quite a natural one in our culture. In any case, it seems quite frequent that when there is a woman on a programming team, she assumes the role of "team-mother," although no studies have been made to verify sex as a significant factor in choosing the maintenance-specialist. There have been at least several teams where one of the women was openly referred to as the "team-mother" or "den-mother," and there is the persistent joke in computing circles which defines "software" as "a girl programmer." Softness is one of the terms which has been used to characterize the maintenance task, whereas hardness seems to characterize the one who must direct the work.

无论这种男女领导分工最终是否被证明具有社会心理有效性，有足够的轶事证据表明，在每个团队中至少安排一名女程序员是一项有价值的实验实践，尽管可能不担任指定的领导者。当然，在许多家庭中，女性没有理由不能担任任务专家的角色；但是经理们应该谨慎提拔女性担任领导，仅仅因为她似乎是团队中的二把手。事实上，没有必要将这一警告仅限于女性：如果可以确定团队中的维护专家，那么在进行晋升之前应该仔细考虑，因为其官方性质可能会损害该角色的领导绩效。

Whether or not this male-female division of leadership is ultimately shown to have social-psychological validity, there is sufficient anecdotal evidence to make it a worthwhile experimental practice to place at least one woman programmer on each team, though probably not in the role of designated leader. Of course, there is no reason why a woman, as in many families, cannot take the task-specialist role; but managers should be wary of promoting a woman to be designated leader simply because she seems to be second-in-command in a team. In fact, there is no need to limit this caveat to women: if it is possible to identify the maintenance specialist in a team, one should consider carefully before making a promotion which by its official nature may prejudice the leadership performance in that role.

领导者或任何团队成员的更换可能是团队生活中最常见和典型的危机。添加或删除成员的效果非常敏感地取决于团队结构，许多经理对由于删除或添加“无关紧要”的团队成员而导致的绩效变化感到不愉快。当然，当高层管理人员介入团队以罢免一名成员时，通常是因为该成员表现出的能力，因此如果他的离职影响团队绩效，也就不足为奇了。但并不是所有的绩效损失都可以归因于个人才能的损失——正如所有团队绩效不能归因于团队成员工作的简单总和一样。

The replacement of a leader—or any team member—is probably the most frequent and typical crisis in the life of a team. The effect of adding or removing a member depends quite sensitively on the group structure, and many a manager has been unpleasantly surprised at the change in performance resulting from the removal or addition of an "insignificant" group member. Of course, when higher management reaches into a team to remove a member, it is often by reason of that member's demonstrated competence, so it should not be surprising if his loss affects team performance. But not all lost performance can be attributed to the loss of individual talent—just as all team performance cannot be attributed to a simple sum of the team members' work.

“民主”组织的团队往往能够更好地承受失去团队成员的冲击——无论是晋升、辞职、疾病、死亡、怀孕还是被召回。由于工作是在成员之间分担的，并且由于他们之间有很多交流，所以当团队成员根据需要介入并应用他们在与离开的人一起工作时获得的知识时，离别留下的漏洞可能很难被注意到。相反，民主组织的团队可能更难接受新成员，因为在结构中没有明确划分的位置让他占据。矛盾的是，在某些人看来，民主组织的团队可能会向外人展示一个相当冷漠和不友好的外表，

The "democratically" organized team tends to be better able to withstand the shock of loss of a group member—whether by promotion, resignation, illness, death, pregnancy, or a call to the cloth. Since the work is shared among the members and since there is much communication among them, the hole left by the parting may hardly be noticed as team members step in as needed and apply the knowledge they had gained in working with the departed one. Conversely, it may prove more difficult for the democratically organized team to accept a new member, for there is no clearly delineated position in the structure for him to occupy. Paradoxically as it may seem to some, the democratically organized team may present to outsiders a rather cold and unfriendly facade, whereas the members of an authoritarian team may be most warm and friendly toward a newcomer.

在专制团队中，如果所有工作都由领导组织并由领导负责，那么当一个成员离开时就会留下漏洞。只有领导者拥有在其余成员之间进行新分工的必要信息。如果领导者很忙或不在，失去一名成员可能是一场灾难。

In the authoritarian team, to the extent that all work is organized through and guarded exclusively by the leader, holes are left when a member leaves. Only the leader has the necessary information to make the new division of labor among the remaining members. If the leader is busy or away, the loss of a member can be a disaster.

另一方面，获得一个成员可能相对简单，因为新成员只需要到领导那里被指派去做“这做那”——每一项任务都可能是从其他成员那里接过来的。如果新成员的能力与旧成员的能力非常接近，那么更换成员可能也更容易，因为所需要的只是将特定任务从一个人重新分配给另一个人。然而，我们很少能找到如此完美的一对一替代者，即使只是因为离职成员从他的工作中对该项目了解很多。在典型的不匹配中，民主团队可能会更好地重组工作以适应实际情况。

Gaining a member, on the other hand, can be relatively simple, for the new member merely has to go to the leader to be assigned to do "this and this and that"—each of which tasks is presumably taken from some other member. Replacement of a member is probably also easier, if the new member's abilities closely match those of the old, for all that is required is a reassignment of specific tasks from one to the other. Nevertheless, we seldom find such neat one-for-one replacements, if only because the departing member knows a great deal about the project from his work on it. In the typical mismatch, the democratic team will probably be better equipped to reorganize the work to fit the realities of the situation.

当团队成员开始意识到他们中的一个人无法承担他那份工作时，就会出现另一种危机。在民主团队中，最可能的结果是逐渐将工作从该成员转移到其他成员身上。如果团队的组织更加集中，只有一位强有力的领导者，那么该成员被解雇的可能性就更大。然而，这还不是全部，因为当发现问题时，移除可能无法解决任何问题，因为没有足够的时间来确保和培训替代者。然而，在民主团体中，无能不会长期被忽视，因为每个成员都有很多机会审查其他成员的工作。因此，只有当无能真的很明显时，专制方法才可能证明更有效。即使这样，

Another sort of crisis appears when the team members begin to be aware that one of their number is not able to carry his share of the load. In the democratic team, the most probable outcome is a gradual shifting of the work off of this member and onto the others. If the team is more centrally organized with a strong single leader, removal of the member is more likely. This is not the whole picture, however, for by the time the trouble is recognized, removal may not solve anything, since there is not sufficient time to secure and train a replacement. In the democratic group, however, incompetence is not likely to go long unnoticed, because each member has many opportunities to review the work of each other member. Thus, only if the incompetence is really glaring is the authoritarian approach likely to prove more effective. Even then, blunt removal of an incompetent member is not likely to have the most warming effect on the team morale, for even the most incompetent member may be well liked by the others.

一个有能力但与其他人相处不融洽的成员对民主团体来说可能是一个比彻头彻尾的无能更严重的问题。在一个专制的团体中，这样的成员无论如何也不会在工作上与其他人有太多接触，所以只要他与领导相处得很好，他就没有什么特别的问题。事实上，一些程序员更喜欢在一个强大的、集中的领导下工作，这样他们就不必与同事交往。但在民主团队中，反社会成员会切断沟通渠道，并且不断阻碍团队会议达成共识。

A member who is competent but who does not get along with the others can be an even more serious problem for the democratic group than an out-and-out incompetent. In an authoritarian group, such a member would not have much contact with others on a working basis anyway, so as long as he gets along adequately with the leader, he presents no particular problem. Indeed, some programmers prefer to work under a strong, centralized leader in order that they do not have to socialize with their fellow workers. But in a democratic team, an antisocial member cuts lines of communications and is a constant impediment to consensus in team meetings.

团队可以通过多种方式使其成员“社交”，就像反社会行为有多种可能的原因一样。这种行为的一个潜在来源是团队成员确实比其他人更有才华，因为他可能无法抑制自己的不耐烦。另一方面，他们可能无法理解或执行他提出的建议类型。编程可能太聪明了——如果这个人不够聪明，无法利用他的智慧来改变他的社交行为和交流方式。

There are many means by which a team can "socialize" one of its members, just as there are many possible reasons for antisocial behavior. One potential source of such behavior is a team member who is indeed much more talented than the others, for he may be unable to suppress his impatience. They, on the other hand, may be unable to appreciate or implement the types of suggestions he makes. It is possible to be too smart for programming—if the person is not smart enough to use his intelligence to modify his social behavior and methods of communication.

George G. 是一名被带入诊断编程组的实习生，所有迹象都表明他的编程生涯非常出色。他刚刚以优异的成绩获得数学硕士学位，而其他七名队员中只有两人上过大学。该团队正在为一台军用计算机进行实时诊断，而乔治被指派为高速鼓编写诊断程序，这是系统的关键部分。虽然这是他的第一个真正的程序，但他开发了一个巧妙的方案，其中程序在鼓上写入所有 1，然后通过分析回读的零模式，可以指出发生故障的确切电路。

George G. was a trainee who was brought into a diagnostic programming group with all signs pointing to an outstanding programming career. He had just received a Master's degree in Mathematics with honors, and only two of the other seven team members had even gone to a university. The team was working on real-time diagnostics for a military computer, and George was assigned to write the diagnostics for a high-speed drum, which was a critical part of the system. Although this was his first real program, he developed an ingenious scheme in which the program wrote all ones on the drum and then, by analyzing the patterns of zeros read back, could indicate the exact circuit that was failing.

George 因这项工作而受到高度赞扬，他并不需要这种赞扬，因为他完全意识到这比他的同事们缺乏想象力的工作要优越得多。事实上，乔治不失时机地告诉他们他们的缺点，这反映在他们的计划与他的优雅相比时显得笨拙。在很短的时间内，团队中酝酿着一场严重的危机，几位成员开始想方设法将乔治赶下台——而其他几位志趣相投的人则开始为自己谋求新的位置。然后命运以一些军方高层来访的形式进行了干预，以检查新硬件。

George received high praise for this work, praise that he didn't need because he was fully aware of how superior it was to the unimaginative work of his fellows. Indeed, George lost no opportunity of telling them about their shortcomings, as reflected in the clumsiness of their program when compared with the grace of his. In a very short time, a serious crisis was brewing in the team, and several members began to look for a way to push George out—while several others, of a different bent, began to seek new positions for themselves. Then fate intervened in the form of a visit from some military brass to inspect the new hardware.

为检查做了大量准备，但是当黄铜到达时，计算机无法运行。诊断都已成功运行，但其他软件根本无法运行。诊断程序重新运行，但它们再次起作用，而常规程序却没有。在这一点上，军方变得相当任性，管理层也越来越愤怒。然后，有人偶然走到主机架后面，发现一根电缆松动了。随口一问，问题迎刃而解。鼓没有连接到系统！

Great preparations were made for the inspection, but when the brass arrived, the computer could not be made to function. The diagnostics had all been run successfully, but the other software would not work at all. The diagnostics were rerun, but again they worked and the regular programs did not. At this point, the military was getting rather petulant, and management was growing furious. Then, somebody chanced to walk behind the main frame and noticed a cable lying loose. When he casually inquired what it was, the problem was solved. The drum had not been connected to the system!

鼓声响起，军方因精彩的示范和加了马提尼酒的午餐而感到安抚。然而，在他们离开很久之后，团队中的程序员仍在乔治那里找回他们的东西。当鼓不在线时，他没有考虑到鼓接口的行为。如果选择了未连接的设备，系统会发出中断信号，但乔治已将其屏蔽掉。如果中断被屏蔽，则写操作会被忽略，而读操作会产生一个全为 1 的字符串。因此，George 的奇妙程序只是简单地表明鼓的一切都很好，即使它甚至没有连接。

The drum was hooked on, and the military was soothed with a fine demonstration and a lunch well oiled with martinis. Long after they were gone, however, the programmers on the team were still getting theirs back at George. He had failed to take into account the behavior of the drum interface when the drum was not on-line. The system was designed to give an interrupt if an unattached device was selected, but George had masked that off. If the interrupt was masked, a write was simply ignored and a read produced a string of all ones. Thus, George's marvelous program had simply indicated that all was well with the drum, even though it was not even attached.

这是任何程序员都可能犯的错误，而且很容易修补。不是乔治的自负，因为其他程序员抓住一切可能的机会来取笑他。也许如果他没有声称自己绝对不会犯错，他从高处坠落可能就不会那么痛；但事实上，乔治无法接受。两周后，一个星期一早上他根本没出现，这是最后一次有人听说乔治 G。这很严厉，但很有效；团队很快回到了从前的快乐状态——产生缺乏想象力但可靠的诊断方法。

It was a blunder that any programmer could make, and it was easily patched up. Not so George's ego, for the other programmers took every possible opportunity ,to rib him. Perhaps if he hadn't claimed such infallibility, his fall from the heights might not have hurt so much; but as it was, George couldn't take it. After two weeks, he simply failed to show up one Monday morning, and that was the last that anyone ever heard of George G. It was harsh, but it was effective; and the group soon returned to its former happy state—producing unimaginative, but sound, diagnostics.

团队生活中的危机不一定与任何特定的人有关，但可能在团队生活的任何阶段出现，或多或少是正常的“成长阶段”，或者是对外部条件变化的反应。例如，我们可以预期团队的形成将是其生命中的一个关键点，因为它从无组织阶段过渡到有组织阶段。通常，团队结构是自上而下，自下而上的，就像盘子里的冰块。这是一个经验观察，但我们可以猜测可能是什么原因，因为团队中的极端能力将更容易从其他人中识别和分类。然而，也有一些时候，比如同一个团队中有两个潜在的强大领导者，而高层的阵型却长期没有解决。按说这种情况会适得其反，但只要选择合适的队伍，应该很容易避免。如果一个项目中有许多潜在的强大领导者，则可能有必要将更多的团队划分成几个团队——以避免这种形成冲突。

Crises in a team's life need not be associated with any particular person, but may emerge at any stage in the team life as more or less normal "growth stages" or in response to changed external conditions. For example, we can expect that the formation of the team will be a critical point in its life, for it passes from a stage of no organization to some organization. Ordinarily, the team structure develops down from the top and up from the bottom, like ice cubes in a tray. This is an empirical observation, but we can guess what might be the cause, since the extremes of ability in the team will be more easily recognized and sorted out from the rest. Nevertheless, there are times when, for instance, there are two potentially powerful leaders in the same team and the formation from the top goes unresolved for a long time. Ordinarily this situation will be counterproductive, but it should be easy to avoid by selecting teams properly. It may be necessary, if there are many potentially strong leaders in a project, to make more divisions into teams than when there are few—to avoid such formation conflicts.

谁是潜在的强大领导者？正如我们所见，这取决于对团队的工作要求。由于这些需求在团队的整个生命周期中都会发生变化，因此领导者可能会兴衰。如果性格上难以接受这种团队结构的变化，那么每当工作到一个新的阶段时，人际冲突就会产生。因此，团队架构的设置问题并没有在团队组建后就一劳永逸地解决。由于我们无法准确预测谁在什么时候成为天生的领导者，因此选择理想的团队时，人际交往能力和编程能力一样重要，但很少有人这样做。因此，我们通常会发现冲突以多种方式表现出来——但都会导致生产力暂时下降。

Who is a potentially strong leader? That depends, as we have seen, on the work demands placed on the team. Since these demands change throughout the life of the team, leaders may rise and fall. If there are personality difficulties in accepting such changes in team structure, interpersonal conflict will develop whenever a new stage of work is reached. Thus, the problems of setting the team structure are not solved once and for all soon after the formation of the team. Since we cannot predict exactly who will be the natural leader at which times, the ideal team would be chosen as much for interpersonal skills as programming skills, but this is rarely done. Thus, we usually find conflict manifested in numerous ways—but all leading to temporary decrease in productivity.

工作阶段到阶段的变化可能是渐进的，因此可以缓和因结构变化而产生的冲突，特别是如果团队成员之间有丰富的互动，可以提供许多解决冲突的小机会。然而，有时变化来得更快——可能是由某些外部机构或事件引发的。编程团队生活中典型的引发危机的事件是机器故障、机器过载、关键部分的顽固错误、两个单元测试程序的系统测试困难、进度变更、新设备到达、上级管理人员变动，以及规格的变化。难怪危机似乎是编程团队生活中的常态。

The change from phase to phase of work may be rather gradual and thus mollify the conflict arising from changing structure, especially if there is rich interaction among team members giving many small opportunities for conflict resolution. Sometimes, however, changes come more quickly—perhaps instigated by some outside agency or event. Typical crisis-provoking events in the life of a programming team are machine malperformance, machine overload, unyielding bugs in critical sections, difficulties in system testing of two unit-tested programs, schedule changes, arrival of new equipment, changes in higher-level management, and changes in specifications. No wonder it seems that crisis is the normal situation in the life of a programming team.

关于群体行为的两个一般社会心理学观察与危机四伏的编程团队特别相关。首先，据观察，在危机中，一个群体的成员更容易接受相对强势的领导尝试。然而，与此同时，如果他们的指导不能很快产生解决群体问题的有效解决方案，那么群体就会对未来的领导者缺乏耐心。因此，在一个可能处于持续危机中的编程团队中，领导模式可能会不断变化。由于这次改组，任务越艰巨，团队就越愿意追随那些真正能够最有效地引导团队的领导者。

Two general social-psychological observations about group behavior are especially relevant to the crisis-ridden programming team. First of all, it has been observed that in a crisis, members of a group more readily accept relatively strong leadership attempts. At the same time, however, the group becomes less patient with would-be leaders if their direction does not produce effective solutions to group problems rather quickly. Thus, in a programming team—which is possibly in a continual crisis—leadership patterns may be in constant flux. Because of this reshuffling, the more difficult the task is, the more the team comes to follow those leaders who can actually steer the team most effectively.

那么，我们可以看到为什么民主的——或者我们应该说“技术官僚的”——组织对于编程团队来说是如此自然。在为团队选择程序员时，我们应该尽量选择能够很好地适应这种自我转移结构的人——既不要太强势也不要太被动。在培训我们的程序员时，我们应该尽量教会他们如何跟随有能力的领导者，以及如何在他们自己是团队中最有资格的时候抓住领导机会。在团队的生命周期中，我们应该尽量——如果我们在外面——不要干涉那些民主过程，这些过程虽然对团队及其成员来说似乎是创伤性的，但从长远来看会导致最有效的团队运作。

We can see, then, why the democratic—or perhaps we should say "technocratic"—organization is such a natural one for a programming team. When selecting programmers for teams, we should try to choose people who will fit well within such a self-shifting structure—neither too dominant nor too passive. In training our programmers, we should try to teach them how to follow able leaders and how to grasp leadership opportunities when they themselves are the most qualified in the group. And during the life of a team, we should try—if we are on the outside—not to interfere in those democratic processes which, though seemingly traumatic for the team and its members, will in the long run lead to most effective team functioning.

的确，一旦团队被选定并运作起来，置于其之上的睿智管理者就会对其内部架构和架构变化采取“放手”的政策。就像经常发生的那样，当团队成员来找他就某个论点发表权威意见时，他最好效仿老拉比的做法，有一天他正坐在他的书房里，一个明显激动的人来了为了见他。男人给他讲了一个很长的故事，讲的是他和妻子刚刚结束的一场争吵。当他讲完他的故事后，他坚持要拉比告诉他他或他的妻子是否是对的。

Indeed, once the team is selected and operating, the wise manager placed above it will adopt a "hands-off" policy with regard to its internal structure and structure change.
