When, as so often happens, team members come to him to lend an authoritative opinion on their side of some argument, he would do well to follow the pattern of the old rabbi who was sitting in his study one day when an obviously agitated man came to see him. The man told him a long story about an argument just concluded with his wife. When he finished his story, he insisted that the rabbi tell him whether he or his wife had been right.

“你是对的，”拉比说，那人满脸笑容地离开了房子。然而，很快，男人的妻子出现了——甚至比男人更心烦意乱。

"You're right," said the rabbi, and the man left the house beaming. Soon, however, the man's wife appeared—even more distraught than the man had been.

“你是什么意思，”她坚持道，“说我丈夫是对的？你没听过我这边的故事。” 她继续讲述自己的立场，最后要求做出新的判断。

"What do you mean," she insisted, "saying that my husband was right? You haven't heard my side of the story." And she proceeded to relate her side, finishing with a demand for a new judgment.

“你是对的，”拉比说，妻子满意地离开了。然而，拉比自己的妻子并不满意，因为她无意中听到了这两个故事和两个答案。

"You're right," said the rabbi, and the wife left satisfied. The rabbi's own wife, however, was not satisfied, for she had overheard both stories and both answers.

“你怎么能那样做？” 她要求。“你告诉丈夫他是对的，告诉妻子她是对的。他们不可能都是对的。”

"How can you do that?" she demanded. "You told the husband that he was right and the wife that she was right. They can't both be right."

“你说得对，”拉比说。

"You're right," said the rabbi.

概括

SUMMARY

在许多编程情况下，主要工作单位是团队，而不是个人。尽管从社会心理学家那里继承了大量关于“小群体行为”的实验数据，但我们目前除了极富启发性的轶事材料外，还没有对编程团队进行真正的研究。当与社会心理学的结果联系起来时，这种轶事材料可以让我们对影响团队生活和绩效的因素产生强烈的印象，例如

In many programming situations, the primary working unit is a team, not an individual. Although a vast amount of experimental data about "small group behavior" has been inherited from the social psychologists, we at present have no real studies of programming teams other than highly suggestive anecdotal material. When linked with results from social psychology, this anecdotal material can give us strong impressions of the factors affecting the life and performance of a team, factors such

• 个人优势和劣势的差异。

• Variation in individual strengths and weakness.

• 设定目标的方式。

• The way in which goals are set.

• 正在制作的节目的结构。

• The structure of the program being produced.

• 外部强加的领导结构。

• The leadership structure imposed from the outside.

• 某些成员的性别，以及其他成员对该性别的态度。

• The gender of certain members, and the attitudes of other members about that gender.

• 团队与其环境的其余部分之间的沟通联系。

• The communication link between the team and the rest of its environment.

• 团队负责人的技术能力或不能力。

• The technical competence or incompetence of the team leader.

在观察轶事材料与实验情况的对比时，我们发现有一个差异应该使我们处于极度谨慎的状态。在编程情况下，时间跨度和所执行任务的复杂性与社会心理学家在实验中尝试过的任何事情都有数量级的不同。社会心理学实验中的任务需要一个小时、一天或一周的时间。如果人们知道时间会很短，他们可能会抑制强烈的感情；另一方面，他们可能认为压抑自己的感受并不重要，因为他们再也见不到团队中的人了。从陌生人组成的团队和同事组成的团队之间的比较，我们确实知道，短期团队行为会受到过去与团队成员的经验以及将来与他们共事的期望的影响。因此，对编程团队进行有意义的实验充其量将是一项困难的工作。

In viewing the anecdotal material in contrast to the experimental situations, we find there is one difference which should put us in a state of extreme caution. In the programming situations, the span of time and the complexity of the task performed are each orders of magnitude different from anything ever attempted in an experiment by social psychologists. Tasks in social psychological experiments take an hour or a day or a week. People may be able to suppress strong feelings if they know the time period will be short; on the other hand, they may not think it important to suppress what they feel, since they will never again see the people in their group. From comparisons between teams composed of strangers and teams composed of co-workers, we do know that short-term group behavior is influenced both by past experience with team members and the expectation of having to work with them in the future. Thus, meaningful experimentation on programming teams is going to be a difficult job, at best.

然而，即使是对其他领域正在进行的团队的观察，对编程的应用也是值得怀疑的，除非它们也涉及正在进行的非常复杂的智力工作，通常是在时间压力和奇怪的工作条件下进行的。在这里，我们有几个资源的优势，最近的工作已经完成——比如在医院和研究实验室中发现的团队。但即使在这里，我们也有他们所没有的东西——那台全能的机器像神一样坐在那儿评判我们的工作。病人痊愈，是医生的工作；当患者死亡时，这是上帝的作为。但是，当计算机程序不起作用时，每个人都知道——而且每个人都知道应该怪谁。

However, even the observations of ongoing teams in other areas will be of questionable application to programming unless they, too, involve ongoing intellectual work of great complexity, often under stress of time and strange working conditions. Here we have the advantage of several sources in which recent work has been done—such teams as are found in hospitals and research laboratories. But even here there is something that we have that they do not—that all-wise machine sitting there like a god in judgment of our work. When a patient recovers, it is the work of the doctor; when a patient dies, it is an act of God. But when a computer program doesn't work, everyone knows—and everyone knows who is to blame.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1. 你的招聘做法是否让你在团队中获得比你想要的更多的统一性？在组建团队时，您是试图看到每个团队中的人员“组合”良好，还是朝相反的方向努力？

1. Are your hiring practices such that you get more uniformity on teams than you would like? When making up teams, do you try to see that a good "mix" of people is on each team, or do you strive in the opposite direction?

2. 你对让女性加入团队有什么感受和做法？关于指定女性团队领导者？你能用任何经验证据来支持你的感受和做法吗？

2. What are your feelings and practices about putting women on teams? About making women designated team leaders? Can you back up your feelings and practices with any empirical evidence?

3. 在你的组织中，有多少决策权留给了工作团队成员？管理者有多少“挑剔”？靠你自己？

3. In your organization, how much decision making is left to the working team members? How much "bit-picking" is there by managers? By yourself?

4. 你有没有做过一些事情来试图在你的下属面前夸大你的技术能力？描述其中一些事件，以及一些发现您的技术能力至少在某一方面不如为您工作的人的事件。这一发现的后果是什么，它们是否证明试图掩盖事实是正当的？

4. Do you ever do things to try to inflate the appearance of your technical competence in front of the people who work for you? Describe some of these incidents, and also some incidents in which it was discovered that your technical competence was in at least one respect inferior to one of the people who work for you. What were the consequences of that discovery, and do they justify attempting to cover up?

5、在制定自己的工作目标时，哪些部分是由上面传下来的，哪些部分是由下面传下来的？你对这样的安排满意吗，或者你想在某些方面改变它？

5. In setting your own working goals, what part is set by what is passed down from above, and what part is set by what comes up from below? Are you satisfied with this arrangement, or would you like to alter it in some ways?

6、你有没有把一个团队的“二把手”提拔为组长？如果是这样，请解释您这样做的原因，并描述您之后注意到的任何效果？

6. Have you ever promoted the "second-in-command" of a team to be a team leader? If so, explain your reasoning in doing so, and describe any effects you noticed afterward?

7、你有没有被要求担任团队内部纠纷的裁判？如果是，请描述事件——你做了什么以及发生了什么。

7. Have you ever been asked to serve as judge in internal team disputes? If so, describe the incident—what you did and what happened.

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 你最擅长编程工作的哪一部分？你是否被允许将你工作中最好的部分贡献给你的团队，人们是否普遍认为这是你工作中最好的部分？

1. What part of programming work do you do best? Are you permitted to contribute that best part of your work to your team, and is it generally recognized that it is the best part of your work?

2. 你在设定团队目标方面扮演什么角色？你想扮演什么角色？你希望别人扮演什么角色？

2. What part do you play in setting the goals of your team? What part would you like to play? What part would you like others to play?

3. 你的经理有没有做过让你怀疑他诚实的事？如果是，请描述事件、您的疑虑最终发生了什么，以及您的工作受到了怎样的影响。

3. Has your manager ever done anything to make you doubt his honesty? If so, describe the incident, what ultimately happened to your doubt, and how your work was affected.

4. 您的团队是否有您可以识别的任务专家和维护专家？您的团队有“团队妈妈”吗？如果您是“团队之母”，请描述您担任该角色的经历。

4. Does your team have a task specialist and a maintenance specialist that you can identify? Does your team have a "team-mother?" If you are the "team-mother," describe your experiences in that role.

5. 画一张或多张代表你的团队结构的图表，包括正式的和非正式的。你能把这张图和你正在处理的程序的结构联系起来吗？你能把它和其他因素联系起来吗？

5. Draw a diagram or diagrams representing the structure of your team, both formally and informally. Can you relate this diagram to the structure of the program you are working on? Can you relate it to other factors?

6. 描述一个事件，其中：

6. Give an account of an incident in which:

   • 更换了团队负责人。

   • A team leader was changed.

   • 一名成员已添加到您的团队。

   • A member was added to your team.

   • 一名成员离开了您的团队。

   • A member left your team.

   • 一些危机开始在社交方面影响您的团队。

   • Some crisis began to affect your team socially.

7. 描述当变化或危机首次为人所知时以及随着时间的推移团队成员的反应。描述由于变化或危机而导致的团队行为的任何永久性变化——无论是好是坏。

7. Describe the reactions of the team members when the change or crisis first became known and as it happened through time. Describe any permanent changes in team behavior—either for better or worse—that came about as a result of the change or crisis.

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

有兴趣进一步探索社会心理学见解的读者可以查阅以下任何一本获益书籍：

The reader interested in further exploration for insights from social psychology could consult any of the following books with profit:

奥尔波特，FH，社会心理学，波士顿，霍顿·米夫林出版社，1924 年。

Allport, F. H., Social Psychology, Boston, Houghton Mifflin, 1924.

Asch, SE,社会心理学，Englewood Cliffs, NJ, Prentice-Hall, 1952。

Asch, S. E., Social Psychology, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., Prentice-Hall, 1952.

Lindzey, G., ed., Handbook of Social Psychology , Reading, Mass., Addison-Wesley, 1954.

Lindzey, G., ed., Handbook of Social Psychology, Reading, Mass., Addison-Wesley, 1954.

Krech, D.、RS Crutchfreld 和 EL Ballachey，《社会中的个体》，纽约，麦格劳希尔出版社，1962 年。

Krech, D., R. S. Crutchfreld, and E. L. Ballachey, Individual in Society, New York, McGraw-Hill, 1962.

Jones, EE 和 HB Gerard，社会心理学基础，纽约，Wiley，1967 年。

Jones, E. E. and H. B. Gerard, Foundations of Social Psychology, New York, Wiley, 1967.

Parkinson, C. Northcote，帕金森定律，波士顿，Houghton Mifflin，1957 年。

Parkinson, C. Northcote, Parkinson's Law, Boston, Houghton Mifflin, 1957.

帕金森经常被那些担心制定更长的时间表只会延长完成项目所需时间的人引用。那些为了他们的宠物想法而声称他的人应该花时间阅读整本书，看看还有什么可以从中学到的。

Parkinson is often cited by those who fear that making a longer schedule will simply lengthen the time it takes to do a project. Those who claim him for the benefit of their pet idea should take the time to read the entire book and see what else there is to learn from it.

Kohn, Hans，民族主义和自由：瑞士的例子，伦敦，George Allen and Unwin Ltd.，1956 年。

Kohn, Hans, Nationalism and Liberty: The Swiss Example, London, George Allen and Unwin Ltd., 1956.

为那些对民主的可能性不再抱有幻想的人、那些已经忘记民主的人，或者那些一开始就不知道民主的人的一些介绍。看完书，再教育的另一步就是去那里。

A little introduction for those who have become disillusioned with the possibilities of democracy, those who have forgotten them, or those who never knew them in the first place. After reading the book, another step in re-education is to go there.

Mills, HD，首席程序员团队：技术和程序，IBM 内部报告，1970 年 1 月。

Mills, H. D., Chief Programmer Teams: Techniques and Procedures, IBM Internal Report, January 1970.

希望 Mills 能在一般文献中发表他关于首席程序员团队的想法，这样就可以将它们与无自我编程的概念进行比较，并接受实验和观察测试。简而言之，首席程序员团队的模式类似于“外科手术团队”，主程序员取代了主外科医生，并由后备程序员、编程图书馆员以及可能的其他程序员、分析师、技术作家、技术人员或其他人员围绕和支持专家。米尔斯声称这样的组织“允许将新的管理标准和新的技术标准应用到编程项目中”，但人们对类比外科手术的有效性感到疑惑，外科手术被认为是落后国家中最落后的专业之一（技术）领域。

Hopefully, Mills will publish his ideas on Chief Programmer Teams in the general literature, so they can be compared, say, with the concept of egoless programming and also subject to experimental and observational tests. Briefly, the Chief Programmer Team is patterned after a "surgical team," with the master programmer replacing the master surgeon and surrounded and supported by a Backup Programmer, a Programming Librarian, and possibly additional programmers, analysts, technical writers, technicians, or other specialists. Mills claims that such an organization "permits the application of new management standards and new technical standards to programming projects," but one wonders at the validity of the analogy to surgery, which is acknowledged to be one of the most backward specialties in a backward (technologically) field. Also, anyone who has known a few surgeons personally may wonder about how great a social contribution such an organization would be—it may be fine for those who fancy themselves Chief Programmers, but what about the rest of the workers?

Mendelssohn, Kurt，“A Scientist Looks at the Pyramids”，美国科学家，V. 59, W 2（1971 年 3 月至 4 月）。

Mendelssohn, Kurt, "A Scientist Looks at the Pyramids," American Scientist, V. 59, W 2 (March-April 1971).

社会结构显然总是受到项目结构的影响，反之亦然。在这篇引人入胜的文章中，门德尔松探讨了 5000 年前金字塔的建造如何导致国家作为一种社会结构的发明，以及国家的发明如何导致金字塔的建造。所有项目经理都应注意此消息。

Social structure has evidently always been influenced by project structure, and vice versa. In this intriguing article, Mendelssohn explores how 5000 years ago the building of the pyramids led to the invention of the state as a social structure, and how the invention of the state led to building pyramids. All project managers should take note of this message.

第 5 章的评论。编程团队

Comments on Chapter 5. The Programming Team

“那么，一个编程团队应该针对一个人无法满足的工作需求而组建。” 我仍然同意我在黑暗时代所做的这句话，但我现在对“工作要求”的解释更广泛，包括团队和团队成员的能力发展。多年来，我观察到能力发展的要求不能由一个人充分满足。在他人的积极合作下，我们学得更快更好。

"A programming team, then, should be formed in response to a work requirement that cannot be met by a single person." I still agree with this statement I made back in the Dark Ages, but I now interpret "work requirement" more broadly, to include the development of capability in the team and team members. Over the years, I've observed that the requirement to develop capability cannot be met adequately by a single person. We learn much faster and much better with the active cooperation of others.

“这些捷径可能会成功地让系统按时运行——但前提是一切顺利，而这种情况很少发生。” 年龄的智慧使我对这种说法感到羞愧。“很少”是故步自封；事情总是出错。像我这样的作者的这种犹豫不决使“乐观”估计的神话长期存在——如果一切顺利，一个项目需要多长时间。这种“估计”也可能只是基于热力学定律将在项目期间被废除的假设。

"These shortcuts might succeed in getting the system working on time—but only if everything goes right, which it rarely does." The wisdom of age has made me ashamed of this statement. "Rarely" is pussyfooting; something always goes wrong. Shilly-shallying like this by authors like me has perpetuated the myth of the "optimistic" estimate—how long a project would take if everything went right. Such "estimating" might just as well be based on the assumption that the Laws of Thermodynamics would be repealed during the project.

“无论如何，编程团队规模和组成的基本规则似乎是这样的——为了以最低的成本进行最好的编程，给你能找到的最好的程序员足够的时间，这样你就需要最少的人。” 该规则的智慧得到了我后来所有经验的支持，并进行了三处修正：

"In any case, the basic rule for size and composition of programming teams would seem to be this—for the best programming at the least cost, give the best possible programmers you can find sufficient time so you need the smallest number of them." The wisdom of that rule has been supported by all my subsequent experience, with three amendments:

一个。最小的数字永远不是一个程序员。

a. The smallest number is never a single programmer.

b. “足够的时间”必须包括团队组建的时间。因此，选择具有良好记录的现有团队通常具有很大的优势。

b. "Sufficient time" must include time for team formation. Therefore, there is often a great advantage to choosing an existing team with a track record.

C。在你有一个真正关键的问题需要他们解决之前让你的团队开始工作通常是一个更大的优势。

c. It's often an even greater advantage to get your teams started before you have a really critical problem for them to work on.

“……做一个编程项目最糟糕的方式是雇用一大群受训者，让他们在没有监督的情况下在压力下工作——尽管这是当今最常见的做法。” 现在，周围有更多有经验的人，所以总培训项目并不常见。今天更常见的是进行编程项目的第二种最糟糕的方法：雇用各种各样的承包商（他们实际上可能是伪装的受训人员）并让他们在没有监督的情况下在压力下工作。或者过度监督。

"...the worst way to do a programming project is to hire a horde of trainees and put them to work under pressure and without supervision—although this is the most common practice today." Nowadays, there are more experienced people around, so the total-trainee project is not as common. More common today is the second worst way to do a programming project: Hire a miscellaneous horde of contractors (who may actually be trainees in disguise) and put them to work under pressure and without supervision. Or with over-supervision.

“在编程中，团队组织工作的方式主要由两个因素决定——目标系统的组织和团队的组成。” 这仍然和 25 年前一样真实，但我想我已经了解到，将产品与团队的组成相匹配并不像我当时认为的那样不合逻辑。我所说的团队构成，一般不是指个人的技能，而是指个人的性格。在一个真正的团队中，个人技能并不是那么重要，因为团队成员都在分享工作。即便如此，多年来我在团队组建中看到的第一个错误是根据某些假定的技能向团队添加成员，而不是根据新成员与团队其他成员的兼容性。技能可能很难获得，但它'

"In programming, the way a team organizes for work is most strongly determined by two factors—the organization of the target systems and the composition of the team." This is still as true as it was twenty-five years ago, but I think I have learned that matching the product to the composition of the team is not as illogical as I believed back then. By composition of the team, I don't generally mean the individual skills, but the individual personalities. Individual skills are not so important on a real team that shares work all around. Even so, the number one mistake I've seen in team formation over the years is adding members to a team based on some presumed skill, rather than on compatibility of the new members with the rest of the team members. Skill may be hard to come by, but it's always easier to buy or train than compatibility.

在从 IBM 704 到 IBM 709 的转换过程中，关于建立和接受目标的例子当然已经成为历史。然而，多年来，我听说过许多其他皈依的相同故事。1993 年，有人问我是否真的在写有关将应用程序从 Microsoft PC-DOS 转换为 Microsoft Windows™ 的文章。我的审讯者确信他参与了我所描述的项目，并且我已经替换了旧机器的名称以保护有罪的一方。

The example concerning establishing and accepting goals in the conversion from the IBM 704 to the IBM 709 is, of course, now ancient history. Nevertheless, over the years, I've heard the same story about many other conversions. In 1993, I was asked if I was really writing about conversion of an application from Microsoft PC-DOS to Microsoft Windows™. My interrogator was convinced he had been on the project I described, and that I had substituted the names of old machines to protect the guilty party.

就团队目标达成共识在 1996 年和 1971 年或 2021 年一样重要。这并不意味着每个人都必须与团队中的所有其他人拥有相同的目标，但重叠部分必须涵盖他们正在做的所有工作。

Achieving consensus on a team's goals is as essential in 1996 as it was in 1971, or will be in 2021. That doesn't mean that each person must have all the same goals as all other persons on the team, but that the overlapping portion must cover all the work they are doing.

我想我能提供的关于领导力部分重要性的最明确证据是成为技术领导者——我的书扩展了技术领导力的概念——在 25 年后继续畅销。或者，如果我告诉您，我们的问题解决领导力研讨会已经将我们的领导力概念与全世界数以千计的软件组织领导者进行了 35 年多的测试，也许证据会更清楚。

I guess the clearest proof I can offer about the importance of the leadership sections is that Becoming a Technical Leader—my book expanding on the concept of technical leadership—continues to sell well after a twenty-five years. Or perhaps the proof would be even clearer if I tell you that our Problem Solving Leadership Workshop has put our leadership concepts to the test with thousands of leaders in software organizations all over the world for more than thirty-five years.

然而，在关于团队领导力的部分，有一个特别令人震惊的、政治上不正确的陈述：“......在每个团队中至少安排一名女程序员......”为了正确看待这个听起来带有性别歧视的部分，我必须解释一下二十五年多以前，我对高级软件开发班的女程序员进行了调查。当我向这些学生询问她们与其他女性一起在团队中工作的经历时，他们都无法回答——因为没有人曾与其他女性程序员一起在团队中工作过。35 年前，我们典型的 PSL 班可能有 20 名参与者中有 4 名女性；今天，它更有可能是八到十二。

In the section on team leadership, however, there is one especially shocking, politically incorrect, statement: "...place at least one woman programmer on each team..." To put this sexist-sounding section in perspective, I must explain that more than twenty-five years ago I conducted a survey of the women programmers in my advanced software development class. When I asked these students about their experiences working on teams with other women, none of them could answer—because none had ever worked on a team with another woman programmer. Thirty-five years ago, our typical PSL class might have as many as four women out of twenty participants; today, it's more likely to be eight-to-twelve out of twenty.

我的一个学生对过渡时期做了这样一个生动的观察：“即使在 12 年前，编程团队基本上都是男性。我仍然记得第一个加入我工作的编程团队的女性开发人员。当时只有两三个男性团队甚至会和她说话的成员。一些男性开发人员抱怨说有一个女程序员在身边会影响他们的注意力。我后来得出结论，对于他们中的大多数人来说，在任何情况下都有一个女人在身边会影响他们的注意力并且他们不会与她，因为女人在初中就不再和她们说话了。”

One of my students made this telling observation about the transition period: "Even twelve years ago programming teams were largely all male. I can still remember the first woman developer who joined the programming team I worked on. There were only two or three male team members who would even talk to her. Some of the male developers complained that having a woman programmer around hurt their concentration. I later concluded that for most of them, having a woman around in any situation hurt their concentration and that they did not talk to her because women had stopped talking to them in junior high school."

当女性程序员很少见时，很容易对她们形成刻板印象。但是，一旦女性在编程团队中不再那么新鲜，她们就会发现自己能够担任任何合适的角色。有时，女性是任务负责人；有时，维护负责人；有时，主题专家。我仍然看到与这种以绩效为导向的安置理想的唯一偏差是经理为团队任命正式领导者。不幸的是，这里仍然至少存在对男性的二比一偏见，这种偏见使许多团队无法找到最佳结构。

When women programmers were rare, it was easy to make stereotypes of them. But once women became less of a novelty on programming teams, they found themselves able to take any role that fit. Sometimes a woman was task leader; sometimes, a maintenance leader; sometimes, a subject-matter expert. The only deviation that I still see from this ideal of merit-driven placement is when managers appoint official leaders for teams. Here, unfortunately, there still remains at least a two-to-one bias toward males, a bias that keeps many teams from finding their best possible structure.

那时，我对处理危机中的团队的了解还不如现在。向 Virginia Satir 等家庭治疗师学习对我来说是必不可少的一步，我在处理危机方面学到的大部分知识都包含在质量软件管理系列的第三卷中。尽管如此，最重要的教训是预防危机通常比处理危机要容易得多——这是我在第四卷中的主题。

Back then, I didn't know as much as I know now about handling teams in crisis. Studying with family therapists such as Virginia Satir was an essential step for me, and much of what I've learned about dealing with crisis is captured in the third volume of the Quality Software Management series. Still, the most important lesson is that preventing a crisis is generally a lot easier than handling one—my subject in the fourth volume.

第 6 章编程项目

Chapter 6. The Programming Project

 

当两个团队必须一起工作来完成某个编程目标时，协调功能就会出现，就像两个程序员必须一起工作时那样。新型的社会关系出现了，就像他们在团队由个人组成时所做的那样。例如，两个程序员现在既作为个人又作为不同团队的成员进行交互——因此现在他们的团队目标可能不同，即使他们的个人目标非常相似。一个团队成员的成功不仅是相对于他的团队的其他成员来衡量的，而且是作为他的团队的一部分相对于其他团队来衡量的。团队之间的协调现在需要二级或更高级别的领导，因此出现了领导者的现象，其下属不参与项目的基本工作，但自己是领导者。

When two teams must work together to accomplish some programming end, a coordination function emerges just as it did when two programmers had to work together. New types of social relations emerge, just as they did when teams were formed from individuals. For example, two programmers now interact both as individuals and as members of different teams—so that now their team goals may differ, even if their individual goals are very similar. The success of a team member is not only measured relative to other members of his team, but also as part of his team which is measured relative to other teams. Coordination among teams now requires a second level—or higher—of leadership, and so emerges the phenomenon of leaders whose followers are not engaged in the basic work of the project, but are leaders themselves.

从管理的角度来看，项目管理的许多方面已在已出版的书籍和文章中进行了讨论，我们不打算纵览整个领域。我们将在接下来的几节中讨论的是一些选定的方面——选择这些方面是因为它们有助于心理治疗，也许在某种程度上是为了纠正某些编程项目管理思想流派。

Many aspects of project management from a management point of view have been discussed in published books and articles, and we shall not attempt to survey the entire field. What we shall discuss in the next few sections are a few selected aspects—aspects selected for their amenity to psychological treatment and perhaps somewhat as a corrective to certain schools of programming project management thought.

通过变革实现稳定

STABILITY THROUGH CHANGE

大型组织最引人入胜的特征之一是它们能够在比任何一个成员留下的时间更长的时间内生存。这种特征在美利坚合众国这样的组织中很明显，因为没有人活过 200 岁。因此，美利坚合众国不能从某个人那里获得其持续的身份，无论这个人多么伟大。华盛顿、林肯、杰斐逊，甚至乔·麦卡锡都不能构成美利坚合众国的全部故事；然而，尽管这看起来很明显，但许多经理无法将相同的推理应用于他们的编程项目。

One of the most intriguing characteristics of large organizations is their ability to survive over periods of time longer than the time any one member remains. This characteristic is obvious in such organizations as the United States of America, for no person is known to have lived for 200 years. Thus, the United States of America cannot take its continuing identity from some person, no matter how great. Neither Washington, nor Lincoln, nor Jefferson, nor even Joe McCarthy make up the entire story of the United States of America; yet, as obvious as this seems, many managers are unable to apply the same reasoning to their programming project.

即使在一个编程团队中，我们有时也会看到当一个原始成员都没有留下时团队的生存。事实上，让其成员幸存下来的能力可能是团队组织的强项之一，因为如果一个人恰好被从现场带走，要做的工作并不会被搁置。这种能力当然来自团队成员之间的互动，因为这种互动可以将团队的目标和成就传递给新成员，并在老成员离开时保留下来。从某种意义上说，一个编程项目或团队就像一条河流，尽管它的水在不断变化，但它仍然是同一条河流。

Even in a programming team, we sometimes see the survival of the team when not a single original member remains. Indeed, the ability to survive its members can be one of the strong points of a team organization, for the work to be done is not set aside if one person happens to be removed from the scene. This ability comes, of course, from the interaction among team members, because this interaction permits the goals and accomplishments of the team to be transmitted to new members and so remain when old members depart. In a sense, a programming project or team is like a river which remains the same river even though its water is undergoing constant change.

许多项目经理无法掌握项目的这种观点。相反，他们对项目结构的看法很像房屋——如果拆除其中一根横梁，该结构可能会倒塌。他们对项目中的人——尤其是所谓的“关键”人——的行为反映了这种静态观点，通常会带来灾难性的后果。

Many project managers are unable to grasp this view of a project. Their view of the project's structure is, instead, much like that of a house—a structure that might collapse should one of the beams be removed. Their actions with respect to the people in the project—especially so-called "key" people—reflect this static view, often with disastrous consequences.

两个案例应该可以说明这种观点的一些后果。在一个例子中，Mark S. 为在线系统设计了控制程序来控制工业过程。然后他被要求留下来实施控制程序，因为他是唯一了解系统工作方式的人。马克对这项任务并不十分满意，因为对他来说，设计就等同于实施。他已经实施了两个这样的系统，并且认为实施第三个系统没有太大挑战。有足够的差异让他暂时保持适度的兴趣，但这种小兴趣被在一个相当偏远的地方工作的必要性进一步侵蚀——在工厂。

Two cases should illustrate some of the consequences of this view. In one instance, Mark S. had designed the control program for an on-line system to control an industrial process. He had then been asked to stay on to implement the control program, inasmuch as he was the only person who understood the way the system was to work. Mark was not terribly happy about this assignment, for to him the design was tantamount to the implementation. He had already implemented two systems like this and did not see much challenge in implementing a third. There were sufficient differences to keep him moderately interested for a while, but this small interest was further eroded by the necessity to work in a rather remote spot—at the plant.

马克是个城里人，但他开发的过程控制系统类型曾两次要求他长时间在偏远地区工作。很简单，他很无聊。当他开始要求将 Bob A.（一位经验相当丰富的程序员）从项目的另一部分（他正在编写某些分析例程）调到他的团队时，他的无聊症状就变得明显了，当时这个团队只包括他自己和两名实习生。Bob 表达了对控制程序的兴趣，这让 Mark 产生了训练 Bob 接管他的职能的想法，这样他就可以搬回城市。

Mark was a city boy, yet the type of process control system he was developing had twice before required him to work in a remote location for long periods. He was, quite simply, bored. The symptoms of his boredom became manifest when he began requesting that Bob A., a programmer of rather extensive experience, be transferred from another section of the project—where he was writing certain analytical routines—to his team, which then consisted of only himself and two trainees. Bob had expressed an interest in the control program, and this had given Mark the idea to train Bob to take over his functions so that he might move back to the city.

然而，项目经理对事情有不同的看法。他很难让有经验的人到野外参与这个项目，所以他不打算牺牲一位更有经验的程序员来满足马克对陪伴的明显渴望。他没有将 Bob A. 添加到控制程序团队，而是给了 Mark 另一个实习生。

The project manager, however, had a different view of things. He was having difficulty getting experienced people to come out in the wilds and work on the project, so he was not about to sacrifice one of his more experienced programmers to satisfy Mark's evident desire for company. Instead of adding Bob A. to the control program team, he gave Mark another trainee.

实习生可能是 Mark 最不想要的东西，因为他已经自己完成了大部分工作，并且把另外两个实习生当作多余的行李。他想快点完成工作或被替换，而新人似乎只会让他慢下来。他再次请求鲍勃 A.，鲍勃 A. 也对没有得到他想要的机会感到不满；但经理不打算让步。他承认马克是他项目中的“关键”人物，他很不高兴，但他不想麻烦找人代替鲍勃 A。为了为了让马克开心，有一天他给他打了电话，给他大幅加薪。但在马克有机会以新的汇率领取一周的工资之前，他已经辞职回城了。

The trainee was probably the last thing Mark wanted, for he was already doing most of the work himself and carrying the other two trainees as so much excess baggage. He wanted to get done in a hurry or get replaced, and the new man seemed only to slow him down. He renewed his request for Bob A., who was also unhappy about not getting the chance he desired; but the manager was not going to give in. He recognized that Mark was a "key" man in his project and that he was unhappy, but he didn't want to go to the trouble of finding someone to replace Bob A. In order to keep Mark happy, he called him in one day and gave him a substantial raise. But before Mark had a chance to draw a single week's pay at the new rate, he had quit and gone back to the city.

经理们经常惊讶地发现，程序员在获得稳定加薪后很快就退出了一个项目——有时是立即退出。令人惊讶的是，他们如此惊讶，因为至少有两个很好的心理原因导致这种行为。有时，程序员将加薪解释为给他增加了额外的责任，并不是每个人都希望承担额外的责任。程序员的理由是，如果他得到更多的钱，就会期望他做更多的工作。他已经比他想要的更努力地逼迫自己，而加薪象征着压断他脊背的稻草。

Managers are quite frequently surprised to find that a programmer quits a project very soon—sometimes immediately—after getting a solid raise. It is surprising that they should be so surprised, for there are at least two good psychological reasons for this behavior. Sometimes, the programmer interprets the raise as putting extra responsibility on him, and not everyone wants extra responsibility. The programmer reasons that if he is getting more money, more work is going to be expected of him. He is already pushing himself harder than he wants to, and the raise symbolizes the straw that would break his back.

然而，更常见的是，加薪被解释为试图用金钱来代替程序员真正想要的东西。也许程序员期望被任命为团队负责人，但加薪对他来说表明正在给予金钱奖励，以期将团队负责人的位置授予其他人。在马克 S. 的案例中，有一个正确的解释，即加薪是为了避免给他想要的合格助手，试图让他更紧密地参与项目。他已经觉得自己留下来是给经理人情，既然经理再次拒绝了他相当合理的要求——不是立即撤职，只是为了有机会培养一个替代者——他就放弃了。

More frequently, however, the raise is interpreted as an attempt to substitute money for something the programmer really wants. Perhaps the programmer was expecting to be named team leader, but the raise indicates to him that a money reward is being given in anticipation of the team leader spot being given to someone else. In the case of Mark S., there was a correct interpretation that the raise was an attempt to avoid giving him the qualified assistant he wanted, an attempt to bind him more closely to the project. He already felt he was staying on as a favor to the manager, and since the manager had once more refused his quite reasonable request—not for immediate removal, but merely for the chance to train a replacement—he gave up.

请注意在这种情况下，经理如何通过尝试将 Mark 绑定到项目中，只是成功地以比必要时更快、更昂贵的方式将他推出。马克离开后，鲍勃 A. 实际上被选中接替他；但由于他没有接受过这份工作的培训，也没有人有经验可以教他，所以这个项目失败了。最终，在预定完工日期一年多后，拼凑系统投入运行，但事实证明，由于控制程序效率低下，它无法控制所有可预见的变量。结果，系统没有实现预期的节省，在运行大约六个月后，整个系统停止运行。

Notice how the manager in this case, by trying to bind Mark to the project, only succeeded in pushing him out more quickly, and more expensively, than would have been necessary. After Mark left, Bob A. was in fact chosen to replace him; but as he had no training for the job, and nobody with experience to teach him, the project foundered. Finally, more than a year after the scheduled completion date, a patchwork system was put into operation, but it proved too slow to control all the variables which had been foreseen, due to inefficiencies in the control program. As a result, the anticipated savings from the system were not realized, and after about six months of operation, the entire system was discontinued.

具有不同结果的类似案例应该有助于说明通过不断变化实现稳定性的概念。Henry F，在与太空努力相关的项目中扮演了与 Mark S. 相似的角色。他设计了控制程序，并被任命为一个更大、更合格的团队的组长。当他开始厌倦实施工作时，他通过培训他的两名最合格的团队成员 Mary M. 和 Sid B. 来打发时间，这样他们就可以像他一样了解该系统。团队的民主组织和他们无私编程的实践使培训变得更简单，但高层管理人员并不鼓励这样做。

A similar case with a different outcome should be instructive as an illustration of the concept of stability through constant change. Henry F, played a similar role to Mark S. in a project connected with the space effort. He had designed the control program and had been made team leader of a somewhat larger and better qualified team. As he began to tire of the implementation work, he filled his time by training his two best qualified team members, Mary M. and Sid B., so that they would know as much about the system as he did. The training was made simpler by the democratic organization of the team and their practice of egoless programming, but it was not encouraged by higher management.

亨利经常要履行的职责之一是向来访的政要做报告，因为这是一个非常引人注目、声望很高的项目。亨利的演讲总是很受欢迎，管理层曾两次拒绝让玛丽·M. 代替他登上讲台。最后，他告诉玛丽准备一次谈话，然后安排在访问当天“生病”。管理层惊慌失措，但他们不得不尝试玛丽，她的表现非常出色。

One of the duties that Henry had often to perform was making presentations to visiting dignitaries, for this was a highly visible, high-prestige project. Henry's presentations were always well received, and the management had twice refused him to allow Mary M. to take his place on the rostrum. Finally, he told Mary to prepare a talk and then arranged to be "sick" on the day of the visit. Management was in a panic, but they had no choice but to try Mary, and she made a superb performance.

现在，经理们愿意接受玛丽作为替代领导——事实上，他们开始要求她提供演示服务——亨利决定是时候要求转移到其他职责了。然而，尽管玛丽显然很有能力，但亨利的经理对他离开的前景感到恐惧。她很好——他承认这一点——但亨利是控制程序概念的最初创造者。何况玛丽是个女人，虽然经理看过她的出色表现，但他不相信一个女人有能力领导这个团队。

Now the managers were willing to accept Mary as a substitute leader—in fact, they began to request her services for making presentations—and Henry decided it was time to ask for a transfer to other duties. In spite of Mary's evident competence, however, Henry's manager viewed the prospect of his leaving with horror. She was good—he acknowledged that—but Henry had been the original creator of the control program concept. Besides, Mary was a woman, and though the manager had seen her make outstanding presentations, he could not believe that a woman was capable of leading the group.

亨利或多或少对这种反应有所准备，所以他现在提到了席德 B 的名字。不幸的是，玛丽 M. 的成功让经理很难相信席德也有能力领导团队。亨利提议给希德一个做报告的机会，但现在经理坚持除了玛丽以外没有人可以做。于是，亨利安排玛丽“生病”，结果管理层终于看到了曙光。亨利准备离开，玛丽和席德都准备好——也愿意——接替他的位置。最终的提议是让 Henry 在项目中担任更高的管理职位，但他关注的是其他东西，挑战他编程想象力的东西，所以他离开了。但是，尽管管理层仍有一些担忧，该项目仍在继续，并取得了圆满成功。

Henry had been more or less prepared for this reaction, so he now brought up the name of Sid B. Unhappily, the very success of Mary M. had made it hard for the manager to believe that Sid was also competent to lead the group. Henry proposed that Sid be given a chance to make a presentation, but now the manager insisted that nobody but Mary would do. So, Henry arranged for Mary to be "sick," with the result that management finally saw the light. Henry was ready to go, and both Mary and Sid were ready—and willing—to step into his shoes. A final offer was made to give Henry a higher management position within the project, but he had his eye on something else, something which challenged his programming imagination, so he left. But, in spite of the residual fears of the management, the project went on, and to a successful conclusion.

这两个案例之间的差异很有启发性。没有任何单一因素可以解释第二个的成功与第一个的失败。亨利在与人打交道方面比马克更有经验。他很幸运拥有一支由非受训人员组成的团队，因此无需管理干预就可以自然继任；亨利项目中的经理们更加开明，不那么死板，也许成功的压力也更小；最后，Henry 更有耐心，也更能理解管理层所看到的问题。马克的经理要想成功，不仅要给马克他想要的助手，还要给马克一个他想要的助手；但他必须帮助马克对这位助手进行他需要的培训——因为马克更喜欢扮演不可或缺的角色。

The differences between these two cases are instructive. No single factor can account for the success of the second as against the failure of the first. Henry was more experienced in dealing with people than Mark; he was fortunate in having a team consisting of other than trainees so that a natural succession was possible without management intervention; the managers in Henry's project were more enlightened, less rigid, and perhaps under less pressure for success; and, finally, Henry was more patient and understanding of the problem as it would be seen by the management. For Mark's manager to have been successful, he would not only have had to give Mark the assistant he wanted; but he would have had to help Mark in giving that assistant the training he needed—for Mark rather enjoyed the role of indispensable man.

从这两个案例和其他数百起类似案例中吸取的教训是显而易见的。随着项目的推进，人们会了解到一些事情，这些事情使他们对有限的责任变得不那么满意，或者——让我们直言不讳——只是厌倦了他们认为不属于他们能力的职责。并不是每个程序员都想从事更具挑战性的工作——如果推进得太快，有些人会离开——但在大多数情况下，随着程序员的学习，他们会感到不满，除非他们能够应用他们的知识。因此，为了实现一个长期稳定的项目，经理必须鼓励该项目发挥某种程序员加工厂的作用——一方面提供新鲜的受训人员，另一方面提供一批经验丰富的领导者，中间的人被人流一次提升一个位置。

The lessons to be drawn from these two cases and hundreds of others like them are clear. As a project moves forward, people learn things that make them less content with limited responsibilities or—let us call a spade a spade—are simply bored with duties which they feel are beneath their capabilities. Not every programmer wants to advance to more challenging work—some will leave if pushed too fast—but for the most part, as programmers learn they become discontented unless they can apply their knowledge. Thus, to achieve a stable project over a long period of time, a manager must encourage the project to function as a sort of programmer processing plant—with a fresh supply of trainees coming in one end and a stream of experienced leaders coming out the other, with people in the middle being bumped up one position at a time by the flow.

需要明确吸取另一个教训。一个项目不是一个纸牌屋，当一个“关键”人物被移除时，它就会倒塌。至少，不应该是；但通常，当管理层认为是时，预言就会自我实现。这是 Mark 案例中的一个教训，因为如果对 Mark 的依赖程度降低一点，他的经理可能会在他的团队中配备实习生以外的人员。毕竟，即使“关键”人对自己的工作感到满足，人们有时也会对他们的经理不体贴，以至于生病、被征召入伍或死去。不，如果经理想要运行一个稳定的项目，他最好遵循这个简单的格言：

One other lesson needs to be drawn explicitly. A project is not a house of cards which collapses when a single "key" person is removed. At least, it should not be; but often, when management thinks it is, the prophecy becomes self-fulfilling. That was one of the lessons in Mark's case, for if a little less reliance had been placed upon Mark, his manager might have populated his team with other than trainees. After all, even if the "key" man is as contented as a cow with his work, people are sometimes inconsiderate enough of their managers to get sick, to get drafted, or to die. No, if a manager wants to run a stable project, he would do well to follow this simple maxim:

如果一个程序员是不可或缺的，就尽快把他干掉。

If a programmer is indispensable, get rid of him as quickly as possible.

 

衡量绩效

MEASURING PERFORMANCE

大型项目规模的一个后果是绩效变得更难衡量。这种困难部分源于事物的规模，这使得一个人不可能对所有部分做出判断。由于一个项目的进展是一个非常主观的事情，所以对于一个特定项目取得的进展量会有不同的看法，即使它不是为了其他影响。但是我们从来没有机会研究一个程序的不同观点。相反，我们将不同人对不同程序的看法进行比较，并将其组合成某种项目进度图。在进行这种组合时，存在许多心理恶作剧的可能性。

One consequence of the size of a large project is that performance becomes more difficult to measure. Part of this difficulty stems from the scale of things, which makes it impossible for a single mind to be making the judgment of all the parts. Since progress on a program is such a subjective matter, opinions would differ about the amount of progress a particular program had made, even if it were not for other effects. But we never get the opportunity to study the different views on one program. Instead, we compare and combine different people's views of different programs into some sort of picture of project progress. In making this combination, there are numerous possibilities for psychological mischief.

作为大型项目中过滤实践的结果，众多阶段可以产生有趣的效果。在一个军事项目中发现了一个极端的例子，该项目不仅涉及编程，还涉及全球通信网络的创建。编程项目本身由大约 75 名一级人员组成，分为 12 个小组，12 名小组长分为 3 个组，3 个组长向 1 个编程项目经理汇报。在进行编程的公司内部，还有设计和构建中央计算机和专用硬件的项目，因此这三个项目经理被组织成一个团队，由一个公司项目经理领导。

The numerous stages can produce interesting effects, as a result of filtering practices in a large project. An extreme example was found in a military project that involved not only programming but creation of a worldwide communication network. The programming project itself consisted of about 75 first-level people organized into twelve teams, with the twelve team leaders organized into three groups and the three group leaders reporting to one programming project manager. Within the company doing the programming, there were also projects to design and build the central computers and special hardware, so these three project managers were organized into a team under a single company project manager. The company project manager participated in a management team consisting of the project managers from the other companies and headed by an overall project manager.

每个月，根据合同的要求，必须向政府提交进度报告。当然，由于这是一项耗资巨大的项目，因此必须以令人印象深刻的全彩格式打印报告。这意味着报告的最终副本必须在报告截止日期前 12 天（即报告月份的下一个月的 10 号）交到印刷商手中。因此，例如，9 月的报告必须在 9 月 28 日之前交到印刷商手中——如果恰逢周末，则可能更早。

Each month, by the requirements of the contract, a progress report had to be submitted to the government. Naturally, since this was an expensive project, the report had to be printed in an impressive full-color format. This meant that the final copy for the report had to be in the hands of the printer twelve days before the report deadline—the tenth of the month following the month of the report. Thus, for example, the September report had to be in the hands of the printer by September 28th—and possibly earlier if this fell on a week-end.

为了让总项目经理有时间审查和修改报告，他不得不在印刷截止日期前五个工作日让每个公司报告。考虑到邮寄，这意味着 9 月份的公司报告必须在 20 日之前完成。在这个特定的公司中，公司经理需要四个工作日来审查他的三个项目经理的报告。因此，编程项目的报告必须在 15 号左右提交。

In order for the overall project manager to have time to review and amend the report, he had to have each company report five working days before the printer's deadline. Allowing for mailing, this meant that the September company report would have to be finished by, say, the 20th. In this particular company, the company manager needed four working days for review of his three project managers' reports. Thus, the report of the programming project had to be in by about the 15th.

像这样向后工作，我们最终到达了单独的编程团队，他们的报告必须在报告月份的前一个月月底前大约四天完成。因此，个别团队报告的不是当月的进展，而是对下个月的预测。然而，另一端出现的内容被标记为进度报告，似乎没有人担心其中的差异。

Working backwards like this, we eventually reach the individual programming team, whose report had to be made about four days before the end of the month preceding the month of the report. Therefore, what the individual team was reporting was not progress for the month, but a prediction for the coming month. What came out the other end, however, was labeled as progress reporting, and nobody seemed to worry about the difference.

到目前为止，这一切都不是特别心理上的，除了两个次要因素——人们愿意相信不可能是它假装的东西的意愿，以及审查报告所需的时间量与审查水平之间有趣的关系。审稿人，以及实际贡献的工作量。审稿人越“高”，他坚持必须拿到报告的时间就越长，而他实际对报告所做的事情就越少。并不是什么都没做——恰恰相反。在合并的每个阶段，无论报告的内容如何，​​都会进行一定程度的平滑处理。

So far, none of this is particularly psychological, except for two minor factors—the willingness of people to believe something that cannot possibly be what it pretends to be and the interesting relationship between the amount of time needed for reviewing reports, the level of the reviewer, and the amount of work actually contributed. The "higher" the reviewer, the longer he insisted he must have the reports and the less he actually did with them. Not that nothing was done—quite the contrary. At each stage of the consolidation, a certain smoothing-out was made, regardless of the content of the report.

每个阶段的推理都是这样的。如果一个子组报告了异常高的进度，审阅者会假设保留一点储备金以防万一他们下个月的运气发生变化，这不会有什么坏处，因此审阅者会削减一小部分。另一方面，如果报告的进展很少，审稿人会把它提高一两点——不想引起人们对任何弱点的注意，并决心在问题持续存在的情况下调查问题。同样，如果具体问题的清单太长，他会缩短一点，留下最不重要的。如果太短，他会将某个问题或其他问题放大为两个单独的问题。

The reasoning at each stage went something like this. If a subgroup reported an abnormally high amount of progress, the reviewer would shave the amount a trifle under the assumption that it wouldn't hurt to hold a little in reserve in case their luck changed next month. If, on the other hand, little progress was reported, the reviewer would step it up by a point or two—not wanting to call attention to any weakness and resolving to look into the trouble if things persisted. Similarly, if the list of specific problems was too long, he shortened it a bit, leaving out the least important. If it was too short, he amplified some problem or other into two separate problems.

这种筛选的六七个阶段的最终结果是一份报告，每月呈现一致的前进进展，一些领域略微落后或略微领先，一些问题从上个月解决，一些新问题，一些问题仍然悬而未决. 简而言之，底部报告的内容与顶部报告的内容之间没有可衡量的关系。

The net result of six or seven stages of such filtering was a report that monthly presented a consistent forward progress, a few areas slightly behind or slightly ahead, a few problems solved from last month, a few new problems, and a few problems still open. There was, in short, no measurable relationship between what had been reported at the bottom and what came out the top.

当然，无论如何，底部的东西只是对进展的预测，所以在向上的过程中对它做了什么可能并不重要，

Of course, what went in the bottom was only a prediction of progress anyway, so perhaps it didn't matter what was done to it on the way up,

事实上，当编程项目的一位团队负责人碰巧拿到一份最终报告时，他看到了他的信息发生了什么变化，并决定不再浪费时间去追求准确。从那时起，他不再用进度预测请求来打扰他的程序员，而是在五分钟内编出一组漂亮的数字并将其传递给生产线。几个月内，同样的做法传播到其他编程团队。因此，进度报告在与实际进度的干扰或关系最小的情况下继续进行。

In fact, when one of the team leaders in the programming project happened to get hold of a final report, he saw what had happened to his information and decided not to waste his time trying to be accurate. From that point on, instead of bothering his programmers with requests for progress predictions, he just made up a set of nice looking figures in five minutes and passed it on up the line. Within a few months, the same practice had spread to the other programming teams. And so, progress reporting went on with a minimum disturbance, or relation, to actual progress.

这个项目在进度报告中哪里出了问题？我们可以确定许多领域。首先，重点是报告，而不是衡量。即使将整个层级上升的过程加速到五天，仍然不会检查初始信息的意义。而且无论某些“管理信息系统”承诺什么，输入的垃圾总是会输出垃圾——尽管反之不一定正确。此外，提供初始信息的人——团队领导——可以看到，他们提供的信息的含义没有经过检查。事实上，唯一一次有人质疑他的预测是在他选择了一个非常大或非常小的数字时。为了尽量减少此类会话的数量，

Where did this project go wrong in its progress reporting? We can identify a number of areas. First, there is the emphasis on reporting, rather than on measuring. Even if the entire movement up the hierarchy had been speeded to five days, there still would have been no check on the meaningfulness of the initial information. And regardless of what some "management information systems" promise, garbage in always yields garbage out—though the converse is not necessarily true. Furthermore, the people who were supplying the initial information—the team leaders—could see that there was no check on the meaning of the information they gave. Indeed, the only time anyone ever was called to question on his predictions was when he chose some very large or small figure. In order to minimize the number of such sessions, the leaders learned to adjust their own figures to eliminate extremes.

众所周知的心理学原理是，为了最大限度地提高学习率，必须向受试者反馈他做得好坏的信息。可能不太为人所知的是，那些认为自己的表现受到评判但没有足够信息了解自己表现如何的人会通过尝试某些变化来测试系统。在这样的报告系统中，如果底层人员没有根据他们的输入反馈信息，他们将开始以任意方式改变输入以查看效果——以获得一些反馈，即使冒着被泄露的风险差评。

It is a well-known psychological principle that in order to maximize the rate of learning, the subject must be fed back information on how well or poorly he is doing. What is perhaps not so well known is that people who feel that their performance is being judged but who have no adequate information on how well they are doing will test the system by trying certain variations. In a reporting system like this, if the people at the bottom are not fed back information based on their input, they will start to vary the input in arbitrary ways to see the effect—to get some feedback, even at the risk of it being a poor evaluation.

在这种情况下，团队负责人已经很清楚他们的报告中唯一重要的因素是他们没有包含任何引人注目的内容。然后，他们中的一个人偶然看到了一份最终报告，它只是完成了整个报告计划徒劳无功的画面。一条额外的消息只是证实了一个已经存在的怀疑——而且至少可以为大家节省很多时间。

In this case, the team leaders were already well on the way to learning that the only important factor in their reports was that they contain nothing striking. Then, one of them chanced to see a final report, which only completed the picture that the entire reporting scheme was an exercise in futility. One additional piece of news only confirmed an already held suspicion—and at least had the advantage of saving everyone a lot of time.

从信息论的角度来看，这个报告系统可以看作是一系列过滤器——每个过滤器都有一定的延迟，每个都有一定的信息丢失。从这个意义上说，信息是由报告承载的，因为它承载了令人惊讶的消息。如果我们在报纸上读到太阳昨天升起，那传达的信息很少；但是如果我们读到太阳没有升起，那么很多信息就会因为事件的意外性而传递给我们。同样，在进度报告中，大部分信息都包含在那些表明进展非常大或非常小的项目中。但是这些物品会怎样？

From an information-theoretic point of view, this reporting system can be seen as a series of filters—each with a certain delay and each with a certain loss of information. Information, in this sense, is carried by a report to the extent that it carries surprising news. If we read in the paper that the sun came up yesterday, that conveys little information; but if we read that the sun did not come up, a lot of information is transmitted to us because of the unexpectedness of the event. Similarly, in a progress report, the most information is carried in those items which indicate very much or very little progress. But what happens to those items?

在心理测试中，当受试者被要求沿着某个线性尺度做出判断时，很少有受试者会选择尺度的终点。事实上，如果需要区分，比如说，五个级别，通常会使用七分或九分的量表，并且端点——如果它们被选中的话——与靠近中心的极端值集中在一起。这种效果可能与我们在每个阶段的报告过滤中看到的有关，每个编辑都会软化前任编辑留下的严酷极端。

In psychological testing, when subjects are asked to make judgments along some linear scale, very few subjects will ever choose the end points of the scale. In fact, if a discrimination of, say, five levels is desired, a seven or nine point scale will usually be used and the end points—if they are chosen at all—are lumped in with extremes closer to the center. This effect is probably related to what we see in the filtering of the report at each stage, with each editor softening the harsh extremes left over by the previous editor.

然而，在这种情况下，极端情况是相对于前任编辑留下的内容而言的，因此该报告在其每个数字中越来越向中心移动。然而，在这样做的过程中，它恰恰过滤掉了它本应旨在揭示的信息。没有什么方法可以打败这种过滤吗？

The extremes in this case, however, are relative to what has been left in by the previous editor, so the report moves more and more toward the center in each of its figures. In doing so, however, it is filtering out precisely the information it is supposedly designed to reveal. Is there not some way this filtering can be defeated?

要回答这个问题，我们必须确定将极端移向中间的趋势的心理来源。一种可能性是认知失调。就经理相信良好的管理创造平稳运行的运作而言，他可能会发现绩效波动与这种管理形象不一致。从那里迈出了一小步，相信波动只是那些“太了解情况而无法了解大局”的人的误判。

To answer that question, we must identify the psychological source of the tendency to move the extremes toward the middle. One possibility is cognitive dissonance. To the extent that a manager believes that good management creates a smoothly running operation, he is likely to find fluctuations in. performance inconsistent with this managerial image. From there it is a small step to believing that the fluctuations are simply misjudgments on the part of the people who are "too close to the situation to get the big picture".

另一种可能性——不排除认知失调的想法——是来自更高层的隐含或推断压力。来自上级的压力通常被管理手册视为完成工作的方式和破坏报告系统的方式。管理者必须学会做的是激励人们改变他们的工作方式或工作速度，而不是激励他们隐瞒他们正在做的事情。因此，他必须奖励对良好工作的准确报告。由于进行报告的人通常是对所报告工作负责的人，因此很难（如果不是不可能的话）在奖励他准确报告的同时又因表现不佳而受到谴责。由于组织的等级制度要求其管理者混淆目标，

Another possibility—not excluding the cognitive dissonance idea—is implied or inferred pressure from higher up. Pressure from higher up is classically recognized by management manuals as both the way to get work done and the way to destroy a reporting system. What a manager must learn to do is to motivate people to modify the way they work or the rate at which they work, not motivate them to conceal what they are doing. Therefore, he has to reward an accurate reporting of good work. Since the person doing the reporting is usually the one responsible for the work being reported, it is difficult, if not impossible, to reward him for accurate reporting at the same time he is being reprimanded for poor performance. Inasmuch as the hierarchical system of organization requires this confusion of goals for its managers, we generally see that reporting systems in this type of organization move further and further away from meaningfulness as time goes on.

即使项目不是按等级组织的，修改进度判断的压力也可能来自其他来源，尤其是来自同事。在一系列经典实验中，阿希展示了人们如何仅仅通过了解他人意见的压力就可以改变他们对两条线的相对长度的判断。在一个典型的实验中，六个“受试者”坐在桌子后面，被要求说出卡片上两条直线中哪一条更长。唯一真正的受试者可能坐在倒数第二个位置，其他人被秘密告知要给出什么答案。经过几轮答对后，所有真题前的“题”都说越短的线越长。这对主题造成了压力，

Even where the project is not organized hierarchically, pressure to modify judgments of progress can come from other sources, particularly from colleagues. In a classical series of experiments, Asch demonstrated how people could be made to modify their judgment of the relative lengths of two lines simply by the pressure of knowing the opinions of others. In a typical experiment, six "subjects" sit behind a table and are asked to state which of two straight lines on a card is the longer. The only true subject is seated perhaps in the second-to-last position, and the others are told secretly what answers to give. After a few rounds of correct answers, all the "subjects" preceding the true subject say that the shorter line is the longer. This creates a pressure on the subject, who can see that they are wrong but would have to contradict them all if he is to assert the facts of the matter.

人们发现，有些人从不屈服于这些压力，但大多数人会屈服。正如我们所预料的那样，当线条的长度接近时，收益会更高——但有些甚至会在较长的是较短的三倍时收益。此外，在接受采访时，他们相信自己所做的判断，正如我们从失调理论中所期望的那样。

Some people, it is found, never yield to these pressures, but most do. As we might expect, more yield when the lines are close in length—but some even yield when the longer is three times as long as the shorter. Moreover, when interviewed, they believe in the judgments they made, as we might expect from dissonance theory.

这些社会压力实验有很多变体，编程经理花钱研究它们。然而，就我们目前的目的而言，只要注意到对具体问题的意见如何容易受到他人发表的意见的影响，以及这种影响如何随着判断变得更加困难而变得更加有效就足够了。在这种情况下，很容易看出像编程项目的进展这样困难和主观的判断是如何受到同行的影响的——无论是在会议上还是通过阅读他们的报告。

There are many variants to these social pressure experiments, and it would pay the programming manager to study them. For our present purposes, however, it is sufficient to notice how opinions on concrete matters can be easily influenced by the announced opinions of others, and how the influence becomes more effective as the judgment becomes more difficult. Under the circumstances, it is easy to see how such a difficult and subjective judgment as the progress on a programming project could come under the influence of one's peers—either in a meeting or through reading their reports.

这些实验的另一个相关结果是当错误选择的压力不一致时对判断的影响。例如，如果第二个“受试者”被指示做出正确的选择，而其他所有人都选择了错误的选择，那么错误组对真正受试者的几乎所有影响都会消失。换句话说，即使是一个“盟友”的存在，也会让许多人有勇气看清事物的本来面目。

One other relevant result of these experiments is the effect on judgment when the pressure for the wrong selection is not unanimous. If, for example, the second "subject" is instructed to make the correct choice when all the others choose the wrong one, almost all influence of the wrong group on the true subject disappears. In other words, the presence of even a single "ally" gives many a man the courage to see things as they really are.

这种影响的一个显着例子发生在一个项目中，其中六个子系统的系统测试将在下周在位于全国各地的一台机器上开始——这样一来，八个人的工作人员将不得不在费用上得到支持，而测试正在进行中。在系统测试之前，六位团队领导与他们的经理举行了最后一次会议，对进展情况进行了审查。每个人都同意一切都在按计划进行，可以派出系统测试人员并在他们的酒店安顿下来。在讨论了各种技术细节和后勤问题后，经理准备结束会议。

A striking example of this effect occurred in one project where the system testing of six subsystems together was to begin the following week on a machine that was located across the country—so that a crew of eight people would have to be supported on expenses while the testing was going on. At the final meeting of the six team leaders with their manager before system testing, a review was made of progress. Everyone agreed that all was on schedule and that the system testing crew could be sent out and set up in their hotel. After discussing various technicalities and logistic problems, the manager prepared to wind up the meeting.

“再检查一次，”他说，“在我们休会之前。有没有人认为下周完成他的工作有任何延迟？”

"Just one more check," he said, "before we adjourn. Does anyone see any delay in having his part done by next week?"

一阵沉默，经理让沉默持续了整整六十秒。最后，其中之一。队长的手微微一动，好像不想被人注意到似的。但是经理捡到了它。“乔治。你有什么问题吗？”

There was a silence, which the manager allowed to prolong itself for a full sixty seconds. Finally, one of the. team leaders made a slight movement of his hand, almost as if he didn't wish it to be noticed. But the manager picked it up. "George. Do you have a problem?"

乔治蠕动着。“就一点点。”

George squirmed. "Just a little one."

“少到什么程度？”

"How little?"

“稍有延迟。”

"A slight delay."

“多久？”

"How long?"

“嗯。大概六个星期吧。”

"Umm. Maybe six weeks."

房间爆炸了。“六个星期？” 他们同时喊道。“当我们准备进行系统测试时，你怎么能在整个会议期间坐在那里什么都不说，而你已经落后了六周？”

The room exploded. "Six weeks?" they all shouted at once. "How can you sit there through the whole meeting and not say anything when we're getting ready for system test and you're six weeks behind schedule?"

经理让其他团队领导平静下来，并祝贺乔治在他们花钱在旅馆里设立系统测试人员之前勇于承认自己的困难。经过一番讨论，他说服乔治尝试在四个星期内准备好他的部分，并制定新的系统测试时间表。然后，经理再次准备休会，但他再次询问有什么问题。

The manager calmed down the other team leaders and congratulated George on having the courage to admit his difficulties before they had gone to the expense of setting up their system test crew in a hotel. After some discussion, he persuaded George to try and get his part ready in four weeks and set a new system test schedule. Then, the manager was about to adjourn once more, but once more he asked for any further problems.

“嗯，”其他领导之一不情愿地插话。“如果乔治多得到四个星期，我认为我的团队也应该如此。”

"Well," one of the other leaders put in reluctantly. "If George gets four extra weeks, I think my group should too."

“你的意思是，”经理问道，“你也没有准备好。”

"You mean," asked the manager, "that you're not ready either."

“不完全是。”

"Not exactly."

“不完全是多少？”

"How much not exactly?"

“我猜大约六个星期。但我们会尽量在四个星期内完成。”

"I guess about six weeks. But we'll try to do it in four."

最终，随着闸门的打开，六个部分中的每一个都落后于计划。然而，如果乔治没有迈出第一步，承认他们都知道的事情，会议可能会在没有任何问题迹象的情况下结束，而毫无结果的系统测试工作将以巨大的代价开始。

Eventually, with the floodgates thus opened, it turned out that every one of the six parts was behind schedule. And yet, if George hadn't taken the first step to admitting what they all knew, the meeting might have closed without a single hint of the trouble, and a fruitless system testing effort would have begun at enormous expense.

认识到即使是一个盟友也可以提供一个安全阀来释放产生一致意见的社会压力，一些编程项目已经为其管理会议建立了“魔鬼代言人”系统。在典型情况下，项目经理的技术人员助理会担任此角色。在每次会议上，他都有责任对所有其他人似乎都同意的观点提出所有可能的负面观点。通过以这种方式表达与该团体的不同意见，他为任何人提供了一个锚点，因为他们的潜伏怀疑因难以成为一个反对许多人而受到限制。

Recognizing that even a single ally can provide a safety valve to release the social pressure to produce conforming opinions, some programming projects have established a "devil's advocate" system for their management meetings. In a typical situation, a technical staff assistant to the project manager assumes this role. In every meeting, it is his duty to raise all possible negative points to opinions which all the others seem to share. By thus expressing disagreement with the group, he provides an anchor point for anyone whose lurking doubts were being restrained by the difficulty of being one against many.

因为魔鬼拥护者的角色是制度化的，所以他所承受的压力小于群体中任何其他首先表达不同意见的成员所承受的压力。然而，随着时间的推移，官方的魔鬼拥护者可能会发现自己承受着越来越大的社会压力，因为其他人将很难记住他是在官方行事，而不一定总是与他人作对。如果发生这种情况，他有效发挥作用的能力可能会在本应增强的时候减弱。一些项目试图通过将不同领导者的位置从一次会议或一份报告轮换到下一次来避免这种魔鬼代言人角色的个性化。这样，他们每个人都有机会了解到持消极观点不一定是消极行为。

Because the role of devil's advocate is institutionalized, the pressure on him is less than it is on any other member of the group who is first to express a dissenting opinion. Nevertheless, the official devil's advocate may find himself under increasing social pressure as time goes on, for the others will have difficulty in remembering that he is acting officially and is not necessarily against the others all the time. If this happens, his ability to play the role effectively may diminish just at the time when it should be increasing. Some projects attempt to avoid this personalizing of the devil's advocate role by rotating the position among the various leaders from one meeting or one report to the next. In this way, they each have the opportunity to learn that taking the negative point of view is not necessarily a negative activity.

项目结构

PROJECT STRUCTURE

如果一个编程项目要克服进度评估中固有的心理陷阱，那么在工作和评估之间进行某种分离是必不可少的。等级组织最严重的弱点可能在于它无法实现这种分离，因为完成工作的控制线只是进度报告线的倒转。正如我们所见，这样的系统通常会导致通过它传递的信息质量下降。为了对抗这种恶化，开始出现对简单等级结构的偏离。

If a programming project is going to overcome the psychological pitfalls inherent in progress evaluation, some sort of separation between doing the work and evaluating it is essential. Probably the most serious weakness of the hierarchical organization lies in its inability to achieve this separation, because the lines of control for doing the work are simply the lines of progress reporting run in reverse. Such a system, as we have seen, generally leads to a deterioration in the quality of information communicated through it. In order to combat this deterioration, deviations from a simple hierarchic structure begin to emerge.

许多项目都有一个标准小组，其主要职责不是生产，而是评估其他小组的生产。当到达测试阶段时，标准组（或其中的一部分）可能会负责系统测试，或者系统测试组可能从一开始就存在。除了评估进度之外，还出现了特殊的小组——图书馆小组、硬件小组、文档专家小组或负责项目使用的所有服务程序的系统编程小组。在高知名度的项目中特别有用的一类团体是公共关系团体，他们的活动保护其他团体免受好奇的外人的日常干扰。最后，可以针对期限有限的特殊项目成立各种小组。

Many projects have a standards group whose principal duty is not production, but evaluation of the production of other groups. When the testing stage is reached, the standards group—or part of it—may become responsible for system testing, or a system testing group may have existed from the beginning. Special groups also arise for functions other than the evaluation of progress—a library group, a hardware group, a group of documentation specialists, or a systems programming group responsible for all the service programs used by the project. One type of group, which is particularly useful in projects of a high degree of visibility, is the public relations group, whose activities shield the other groups from daily interference from inquisitive outsiders. Finally, various groups may be set up for special projects of limited duration.

例如，如果系统中存在普通方法无法发现的错误，则可能会成立一个专门的工作组来解决它。为了能够建立这样的临时小组，项目经理必须在项目中保留一定的“松弛”，以便抽出人员来填补漏洞。任何项目，无论计划得多么周密，都无法预见所有的突发事件并提前成立小组来应对。因此，典型的项目可能会在其整个生命周期中经历多次重组。

For instance, if there is a bug in the system which ordinary methods do not find, a special task force may be set up to root it out. To be able to establish such temporary groups, the project manager must preserve a certain amount of "slack" in the project, so that people can be extracted and used to plug the leak. No project, no matter how carefully planned, can anticipate all contingencies and set up groups in advance to meet them. Thus, the typical project may expect to experience several reorganizations throughout its lifetime.

当进行重组时，有时发现的虫子比举起一块扁平的大石头还多。人们拒绝从一个群体转移到另一个群体，拒绝与某个人一起工作或从事某项工作。其他人则坚持他们必须继续与某个人一起工作，或从事某项工作，或者他们必须去另一个小组。从本质上讲，所有这些问题都源于忠诚度的分裂，就像个人在团队中工作所产生的问题一样。

When a reorganization is made, it sometimes reveals more worms than lifting a large flat rock. People refuse to move from one group to another, to work with a certain person or on a certain job. Others insist that they must continue working with a certain person, or on a certain job, or that they must go to a different group. Essentially, all these problems stem from a division of loyalties, much like the problems arising from an individual going to work on a team.

在一个项目的团队中工作的每个人都已经接受了某些团队目标作为他自己的目标。但是当团队专业化时，它的目标不一定与项目的总体目标一致，或者与另一个团队的目标一致。这些冲突总是表现在某种社会关系中。例如，某些小组任务被认为不如其他任务有声望，更卑鄙。例如，一个文档组经常被工作编程团队的成员看不起——结果是文档编写者变得防御性和宗派化，尽可能避免与其他团队成员接触。但是，不幸的是，回避他人正是我们文档团队所不希望的。

Each person working on a team within a project has come to accept certain of the team goals as his own. But when the team is specialized, its goals do not necessarily coincide with the overall goals of the project, or with the goals of another team. These conflicts are invariably manifest in some sort of social relations. For example, certain group tasks are considered less prestigious, more menial, than others. A documentation group, for example, is often looked down upon by members of working programming teams—with the result that the documenters become defensive and clannish, avoiding contacts with other team members as much as possible. But, unfortunately, avoidance of others is precisely what we do not want in a documentation team.

管理人员在项目中鼓励这种类型的划分并非无罪。首先，他们可能只是有自己的偏见，并允许他们在项目结构中具体化。在一个大型项目中，经理向一些来访者介绍他们的培训计划，以证明他理解通过变革实现稳定的概念。他向来访者展示了一份按最终评估分数排列的新学员名单，并提醒他们注意他们“全部”取得的好成绩。

Managers are not guiltless in encouraging this type of division in a project. In the first place, they may simply have their own prejudices and permit them to become reified in the project structure. In one large project, the manager was telling some visitors about the training program they had, in order to demonstrate that he understood the concept of stability through change. He showed the visitors a list of the new trainees arranged by their final evaluation scores, and called their attention to the fine scores they "all" had achieved.

“可是，”其中一位参观者问道，“这三位垫底的呢？他们的分数好像比其他人低很多。”

"But," asked one of the visitors, "what about these three at the bottom? Their scores seem to be way below the others."

“哦，那个，”经理耸了耸肩。“那没什么。他们要去文档组了，所以没什么好担心的。”

"Oh, that," shrugged the manager. "That's nothing. They're going into the documentation group, so it's nothing to worry about."

如果其他团体对记录者的评价很低，不想与他们合作，我们会感到惊讶吗？

Can we be surprised if the other groups hold a low opinion of the documenters and do not want to cooperate with them?

任何测试组也会与其他组陷入困境，因为批评是他们的工作。我们的一名在程序测试小组工作的学生对她的小组成员与他们正在测试其程序的小组成员之间的社交互动进行了研究。虽然他们的办公室混杂在一起，但他们之间几乎没有社交互动。每个小组的成员都没有与另一组成员共进午餐或喝咖啡，甚至没有互相借铅笔或回形针这样简单的事情。在一个群体成员之间的对话中，另一个群体的成员通常被描述为愚蠢、不友好和不公平。

Any testing group is also put into a difficult relationship with other groups, because it is their job to criticize. One of our students who was working in a program testing group did a study of social interactions between members of her group and of the group whose programs they were testing. Although their offices were intermingled, there was almost no social interaction between them. Members of each group did not lunch or take coffee with members of the other, nor did they do even such simple things as borrow pencils or paper clips from one another. In conversations among members of a group, members of the other group were typically characterized as unintelligent, unfriendly, and unfair.

某种程度上，这种互相不喜欢的态度得到了管理层的鼓励，因为当这名学生试图为两个小组安排派对时，她遭到了管理层的强烈抵制，理由是这两个小组不“健康”变得非常亲密。当她解释说她想让聚会只是为了在她的计算机编程心理学课上测试这个假设时，她不情愿地得到了许可。该晚会是以庆祝该项目的主要部分测试成功完成为借口举行的。在聚会前一周，各组之间的社交活动增加了，聚会本身也取得了巨大的成功。后来，根据她的观察，

To some extent, this attitude of mutual dislike was encouraged by the management, for when this student tried to arrange a party for the two groups, she met with strong management resistance on the grounds that it was not "healthy" for these two groups to become very close. When she explained that she wanted the party just to test this assumption for her class in the psychology of computer programming, she was reluctantly given permission. The party was held under the pretext of a celebration of the successful completion of testing of a major piece of the project. In the week before the party, social contacts increased between the groups, and the party itself was a great success. Afterward, according to her observations, the two groups seemed to be able to carry out their mutual work with more personal contact and less traffic in recriminating memoranda.

我们无法衡量这种改善的社会氛围是否会导致这两个群体之间的工作变得更好或更糟。然而，根据我们在无私编程方面的经验，我们确实知道，没有什么特别的理由可以说明你的朋友不能成为你最严厉的批评者。我们当然可以在这个问题上使用对照实验。与此同时，项目经理最好不要在工作使他们陷入某种自然冲突的团队之间助长冲突。

We have no way of measuring whether or not this improved social climate led to better or worse work between these two groups. However, we do know through our experiences with egoless programming that there is no particular reason why your friend cannot also be your sternest critic. We could certainly use controlled experiments on this question. In the meantime, it probably is a good idea for a project manager not to foster conflict between groups whose work brings them into some sort of natural conflict.

项目中出现的另一个自然冲突是水平而不是垂直切割——倾向于将管理层与工作的程序员分开。这种冲突出现在目标的设定上，因为项目目标不仅仅是各个团队目标的总和。通常，目标是自上而下设定的，在大多数团队组建之前就已经做出了重大决定。这样的结构不鼓励团队内部的民主目标设定，因此可能很难让程序员忠于项目以及他们自己的团队。

Another natural conflict which arises in projects cuts horizontally instead of vertically—tending to separate the management from the working programmers. This conflict arises over the setting of goals, for project goals are not simply the sum of individual team goals. Typically, goals are set from the top down, with major decisions having been made before most of the teams have even been put together. Such a structure does not encourage democratic goal-setting within the teams, and it may therefore be difficult to get the programmers to have loyalty to the project as well as to their own group.

如果项目管理人员能够将运营视为完成项目的机器，而不是为满足个人抱负而攀登的金字塔，那么其中许多问题都可以克服。例如，在发动机中，气门不是汽缸的“老大”，曲轴也不是气门的“老大”。我们的许多项目似乎都效仿的等级组织，不是来自对成功的机器或自然系统的观察，而是来自 19 世纪奥地利军队的成功。然而，很难想象两个群体比一群士兵和一群程序员的差异更大。

Many of these problems can be overcome if the management of the project can see the operation as a machine for getting the project done, rather than as a pyramid to be climbed for the satisfaction of their personal ambitions. In an engine, for example, the valves are not the "boss" of the cylinders, nor is the crankshaft the "boss" of the valves. The hierarchical organization, which so many of our projects seem to emulate, comes to us not from the observation of successful machines or natural systems, but from the nineteenth century successes of the Austrian Army. Yet it would be difficult to imagine two groups which differ more than a bunch of privates and a bunch of programmers.

在军队中——老式的风格——每个步兵都被认为可以互换。因此，等级组织被认为是可以在这些可互换部分之间提供最快和最直接协调的结构。但编程项目不是战斗，不分表象。不需要在野外条件下所需的相当快的通信速度，要通信的内容也不需要简单到可以通过双向无线电咆哮，背景是炮弹爆炸。编程项目需要的是在执行非常不同、高度专业化任务的团队之间进行缓慢、仔细的沟通。此外，程序员不会被征召入职，如果他的程序不符合规范，他也不会受到军事法庭的审判。最后，

In the army—old-fashioned style—every foot-soldier was considered interchangeable with every other. The hierarchical organization, then, was conceived as the structure that could give the fastest and most direct coordination between these interchangeable parts. But a programming project is not a battle, regardless of appearances. There is no need for quite the speed of communication which is necessary under field conditions, nor are the things to be communicated so simple that they can be barked over a two-way radio with shells bursting in the background. What is needed in a programming project is slow, careful communication among teams of people doing very different, highly specialized tasks. Moreover, the programmer is not drafted into his job, and he is not subject to courts-martial if his program does not meet specifications. And finally, there is no danger to the officers of being hit by enemy fire or being shot in the back by their own men, so there is really no excuse for not getting down in the trenches once in a while with the troops.

大型项目的常见社会问题

COMMON SOCIAL PROBLEMS OF LARGE PROJECTS

项目领导远离工人是大型项目中许多社会问题的根源。在一个编程团队中，只有两个角色可以担任——程序员和程序员的领导者。然而，在项目中出现了第三个角色，领导者的领导者，或第 n 级经理。第一级和第 n 级经理之间的区别是显着的，因为第一级经理至少与正在完成的实际工作保持某种联系，而 n 级经理只能通过其他经理间接地看到工作。

The remoteness of the project leadership from the workers is the source of many social problems in large projects. There are, within a programming team, only two roles to fill—the programmer and the leader of programmers. Within the project, however, there emerges a third role, the leader of leaders, or nth-level manager. The differences between first-level and nth-level managers are significant, for the first-level manager maintains at least some contact with the actual work being done, and the nth-level manager only sees the work indirectly, through other managers.

尽管第 n 级经理可能最初是一名程序员，这种情况很少见，但几乎可以肯定，当他达到这些高度时，他已经失去了任何编程能力。鉴于编程技术和硬件的快速变化，更高级别的经理即使保留了他原来拥有的技能并不断磨练，也变得过时了，因为那些语言和那些机器已经不再使用了。在对在职程序员的小型调查中，只有 15% 的一线经理被认为与程序员本身一样熟练，而更高级别的经理则没有。一些程序员评论说，更高级别的经理有时会过来查看他们在做什么，但他试图表现出了解的样子对程序员来说是完全透明的。没有人，当然，

Even though the nth-level manager may have originally been a programmer, which is rare enough, he has almost certainly lost any programming ability by the time he reaches these heights. Given the rapid change of programming techniques and hardware, the higher-level manager becomes obsolete even if he retains the skills he originally had and keeps them sharply honed, for those languages and those machines are no longer in use. In a small survey of working programmers, only 15 percent of the first-line managers were thought to be as skillful as the programmers themselves, and none of the higher-level managers. Some of the programmers commented that a higher-level manager sometimes came around and looked at what they were doing, but that his attempts to look knowing were perfectly transparent to the programmers. Nobody, of course, was going to risk challenging his manager's manager, but after he left, all would have a good chuckle at his expense.

每当主管负责他不了解的工作时，他开始奖励工人不是因为工作，而是因为工作的表现。清晨到达的程序员被认为比那些在正式开始时间之后才到达的程序员更好。然而，工作到很晚的程序员可能得不到奖励，因为经理不太可能看到他们工作到很晚。被观察到与他人交谈的程序员不被认为是在工作，因为经理有这样一种印象，即编程工作涉及孤独的思考者，将秘密信息刮到计算机上。

Whenever a supervisor is responsible for work he does not understand, he begins to reward workers not for work, but for the appearance of work. Programmers who arrive early in the morning are thought to be better programmers than ones who are seen to arrive after official starting time. Programmers who work late, however, may not be rewarded because the manager is not likely to see that they are working late. Programmers who are observed talking to others are not considered to be working, because the manager has an image that programming work involves the solitary thinker scratching out secret messages to the computer.

但是经理还能做什么呢？由于编程工作的结果要好几个月才能得到，他不能等着看谁的程序能运行谁不能运行——即使他能分辨出其中的差别。经理能做的最好的事情可能就是依靠他的第一级经理，并坚持让他们实际观察工作——是的，甚至阅读程序。潜伏在程序员身边，给他们留下他正在观看的印象是骗不了任何人的。

But what else can a manager do? Since the results of programming work will not be available for many months, he cannot just wait to see whose programs run and whose don't—even if he could tell the difference. Probably the best thing the manager can do is to rely on his first-level managers, and to insist that they actually observe the work—yes, even going so far as reading the programs. Lurking around and dropping in on the programmers to give them the impression that he is watching isn't going to fool anybody.

我们采访的一位程序员告诉我们，他通过编写一个产生项目经理认为他理解的输出的程序而“赚”了一大笔钱。当项目经理走进他的办公室时，程序员拿出这个程序给他看，并询问他如何处理某种情况的建议。经理给了他一些建议——即使该程序是他们正在制作的系统的一部分，这些建议也毫无价值——然后他喜气洋洋地离开了。几天后，程序员特意在午餐室当着下级经理的面感谢经理；几天后，他得到了加薪。

One programmer we interviewed told us that he had "earned" a fat raise by preparing a program that produced some output that the project manager thought he understood. When the project manager dropped into his office, the programmer took out this program to show him, and asked his advice on how to handle a certain situation. The manager gave him some advice—which would have been worthless even if the program had been part of the system they were producing—and left beaming. A few days later, the programmer made a point of thanking the manager in the lunch room, in front of his lower-level managers; and a few days after that, he got his raise.

得到一些技术建议的感谢一定提高了项目经理在同事眼中的地位，因为这种直接的表现对于经理来说是很少见的。在工作层面，地位在很大程度上取决于执行技术任务的能力——例如传奇般的调试功绩。但是对于经理来说，这种获得地位的途径通常是不开放的，尽管他可能经常回忆过去的美好时光而让每个人感到厌烦。随着他在管理阶梯上的攀升，建立自己的技术优势变得越来越不容易，因此他越来越依赖地位的象征来赋予他权威。

Being thanked for some technical advice must have elevated the status of the project manager in the eyes of his fellows, for such direct performances are rare for managers. At the working level, status is largely determined by the ability to perform technical tasks—such as legendary feats of debugging. But for the manager, such avenues to earning status are not normally open, though he may often bore everybody by recalling the good old days when they were. As he climbs the management ladder, it becomes less and less easy for him to establish his technical superiority, so he comes to rely more and more on symbols of status to give him his authority.

地位象征总是很有趣——对体制外的任何人来说。在编程中，一些在其他职业中没有的特殊地位象征值得一提，尽管该主题在其他地方得到了很好的对待。例如，我们办公室有一个卡片文件夹。在某些低层次上，卡片文件是普通程序员的一种积极的身份象征，因为它意味着它的主人不能让他的重要程序无人看管。当然，在更高级别上，必须删除卡片文件，以免观察者认为它与实际编程太接近了。在运行封闭式机房的商店中，任何有权进入机房的人显然比任何没有进入机房的人更重要——尽管通常最安全的做法是只给那些足够高的人，这样他们就真的没必要在那里了. 在进入机房不是问题的情况下，运行作业的优先级可能是问题，尤其是当每个人的优先级都列在醒目位置时（按降序排列）。项目经理知道他的工作将领先于其他人，这一定是一种极大的满足——如果他曾经有过的话。

Status symbols are always amusing—to anyone outside the system. Within programming, some special status symbols not found in other professions are worth mentioning even though the subject is well-treated elsewhere. For instance, we have a card file in the office. At certain low levels, the card file is a positive status symbol over ordinary programmers, because it implies that its owner cannot leave his important programs unguarded. At higher levels, of course, the card file must be removed, lest the observer should think that one was too close to the actual programming. In shops which run a closed machine room, anyone with permission to enter the machine room is obviously more important than anyone who does not—though usually it is safest to give such permission only to those high enough so that they really have no business being there. Where access to the machine room is not the issue, priority of running jobs may be, especially if each person's priority is listed—in descending order—in a conspicuous place. It must be tremendously satisfying to the project manager to know that his job would be run ahead of everyone else's—if he ever had one.

最近，终端已成为节目经理的第一身份象征。无论可怜的工人的终端设备多么短缺，项目经理都必须将他的终端设备放在身边，让所有客人都能看到。他用它做什么很少为人所知，或者至少是一个严守的秘密。根据终端的类型，临时访客通常看到的是热身演示或 Nim 或 Spacewar 游戏。此类演示中最漂亮的一个是在 CRT 上显示某个项目函数的 PERT 图。当经理按下按钮时，图表中的关键路径比其他路径更亮。然后，通过将光笔指向其中一个节点，进行删除并显示新图表。再按一次按钮，新的关键路径就会亮起。经理对他的项目拥有强大的控制力，这次演示总是给参观者留下深刻印象。当然，那是彻头彻尾的赝品——四种图案都是系统预存的，而且是只有四种模式可用。

Lately, the terminal has become the number one status symbol for programming managers. No matter how short of terminals the poor workers may be, the project manager must have his terminal by his side for all his guests to see. What he uses it for is rarely known, or at least is a well-guarded secret. What the casual visitor usually sees is a hoked-up demonstration or a game of Nim or Spacewar, depending on the type of terminal. One of the most beautiful of such demonstrations consisted of displaying a PERT chart of some project function on the CRT. When the manager pushed a button, the critical path in the chart was illuminated with greater brightness than the other paths. Then, by pointing the light pen at one of the nodes, a deletion was made and the new chart was displayed. One more button push and the new critical path was illuminated. This demonstration never failed to impress visitors with the great control the manager had over his project. Of course, it was a complete fake—all four patterns were pre-stored in the system, and they were the only four patterns available.

编程经理不能免除的经典身份标志之一是秘书或行政助理。这两个头衔的区别在于秘书总是女性，而行政助理可以是任何性别。最漂亮的秘书可能是身份的象征——虽然丑陋的秘书可能被认为表明一个人的地位如此之高，以至于有人认为是一位称职的秘书。

One of the classic status symbols from which programming managers are not exempt is the secretary or the administrative assistant. The difference between these two titles is that secretaries are always female, and administrative assistants may be of either gender. The prettiest secretary may be a status symbol—though an ugly one may be taken as indicating that one's status is so high that one rates a competent secretary.

这种将女性与办公室的琐碎工作联系起来，以及外表漂亮但头脑不佳的女性，是大型项目中更严重的社会问题之一——性问题的根源。我们班的一位女士在她的项目中着手研究男性对女性程序员的态度。从这项调查中得出的情况是，男性（尤其是年长的男性）通过贬低从事专业工作的女性来掩饰自己的不安全感。担任秘书的女性并没有受到这种虐待——大概是，她们“知道自己的位置”。但是女程序员所做的任何事情都被以最坏的方式解释。

This association of women with the menial tasks of an office and of good looks with poor brains is the source of one of the more serious social problems in large projects—the sex problem. One of the women in our class undertook to study the attitudes about women programmers of men in her project. The picture that emerged from this survey was of men (especially the older ones) who plastered over their insecurities by belittling the women who were involved in professional work. Women working as secretaries did not come in for this abuse—presumably, they "knew their place." But anything the women programmers did was interpreted in the worst possible light.

例如，如果看到一个女人和另一个女人说话，人们倾向于称其为“八卦”。如果一个女人和一个男人说话，那就是“调情”。但是当男人与男人交谈时，没有特别的名字——只是“生意”，即使生意是棒球、篮球或保龄球。在项目的一个工段，只有两名女性，并且被安排到同一个团队，因为经理认为她们会“喜欢彼此的陪伴”。经理每次见到组长，都会问“他们”怎么样了。每个人都明白“他们”是谁。

For example, if a woman was seen talking to another woman, the tendency was to call it "gossip." If a woman talked to a man, it was "flirting". But when men talked to men, there was no special name—it was just "business," even when the business was baseball, basketball, or bowling. In one section of the project, there were only two women, and they had been put into the same team because the manager thought they would "like each other's company."
