Whenever the manager saw the team leader, he would ask how "they" were doing. Everyone understood who "they" were.

当然，大多数男人会认为这些观察结果并不严肃而将其置之不理。“当然，男人会以那种方式谈论女人，但一点友好的玩笑不会伤害任何人。” 即使是没有专业参与的女性也倾向于通过抓住一切机会表示不相信其他女性可以“做如此复杂的事情”——意思是“与男性竞争”来支持该系统。但对于所涉及的女性来说，这件事是非常严重的——尽管她们不会让任何好奇的男性知道这件事。在许多项目中，女性被系统地排除在管理职位或第一级以上的管理职位之外。因此，有这种抱负的女性知道，只要她继续从事这个项目，她的前途就很有限——这不是一种鼓励参与的非常健康的方式。

Most men, of course, will dismiss these observations as not being serious. "Of course men talk about women in those ways, but a little friendly joking never hurt anybody." Even the women who are not professionally involved tend to support the system by taking every opportunity to express disbelief that other women could "do such complicated things"—meaning, "compete with men." But to the women involved, the matter is deadly serious—though they are not about to let any curious male know about it. In many projects, women are systematically excluded from management positions, or management positions above the first level. Thus, a woman who has such aspirations knows that her future is limited as long as she stays on this project—not a very healthy way to inspire participation.

可以肯定的是，男性管理者可以为这些政策提供各种合理化解释，但这种合理化伴随着任何偏见。可以要求个别案例来支持每个错误的信念，但任何偏见也是如此。任何认为苏格兰人很吝啬的人都可以举出一个苏格兰人保存小绳子的例子；任何认为西西里人是歹徒的人都可以给你看剪报来“证明”他的观点；任何不提拔女性的经理都可以举出这样一个案例：女性被提拔后离开去生孩子或跟随她的丈夫去他的新工作。当然，如果一个女人不生孩子，也不跟随她的丈夫，他会说，“她是什么样的女人？”

To be sure, male managers can offer all sorts of rationalizations for such policies, but such rationalizations accompany any prejudice. Individual cases can be called upon to support each erroneous belief, but that is true of any prejudice, too. Anybody who thinks Scotsmen are cheap can point to an example of a Scot who saved little pieces of string; anyone who thinks Sicilians are gangsters can show you a newspaper clipping to "prove" his case; and any manager who won't promote a woman can point to a case where a woman was promoted and then left to have a baby or to follow her husband to his new job. And, of course, if a woman doesn't have babies or follow her husband, he says, "What kind of a woman is she?"

每一种偏见都有它的代价。在一个编程项目中，除了缺乏能力之外，任何人在任何基础上被排除在任何职位之外都会剥夺项目的最佳性能。此外，一旦一个派系开始觉得他们受到的评价与其他派别不同，他们就会开始采取不同的行动。尽管对其他群体的偏见也可能是严重的问题，但对女性的偏见在节目中非常普遍，值得特别关注。缓解编程和编程管理人才短缺的最伟大的单一行动可能是开始真正平等地对待女性——如果她们真的只是那样的话。

Each prejudice has its price. In a programming project, the exclusion of anyone from any position on any basis besides lack of competence robs the project of the best possible performance. Moreover, once one faction begins to feel that they are being judged differently from others, they will begin to act differently. Although prejudices against other groups can also be serious matters, the prejudice against women is so common in programming that it merits special attention. Possibly the greatest single action to relieve the shortage of programming and programming management talent would be to start treating women as true equals—if indeed they are only that.

概括

SUMMARY

1969年底，召开了第二次北约软件工程会议，与前一年的会议基调已经大不相同。人们开始参与进来，原因不难从诉讼中找到。我们可以引用 Joel Aron 的评论来最清楚地说明问题：

At the end of 1969, the second NATO conference on Software Engineering was held, and the tone was already much changed from the one held the previous year. People were beginning to come into the picture, and the reason is not hard to find in the proceedings. We-may quote this comment from Joel Aron as most clearly representing the problem:

我们对大约十几个项目进行了研究，但不是以非常正式的方式进行的。然而，我们的结果足以说服我们开设一门编程系统管理课程。

We made a study of about a dozen projects, though not in a very formal manner. However, our results were convincing enough to us to set up a course on programming systems management.

 

研究的性质是“为什么我们的项目成功或失败？” 我们将在预算资金范围内按时满足其要求并使客户满意的项目视为“成功”。在此基础上，在我们检查的 10 或 12 个项目中，我们有一个成功，也有很多失败。

The nature of the study was "Why do our projects succeed or fail?" We took as "successful" a project that met its requirements on schedule within the budgeted dollars and satisfied the customer. On this basis, out of 10 or 12 projects that we examined, we had one success and a whole lot of failures.

 

我们分析了项目经理和之前对项目进行过评估的人员给我们的失败原因。他们给出了项目失败背后的各种原因，基本上都是管理上的失败。我们遇到问题是因为我们不知道如何管理我们拥有的东西，而不是因为我们本身缺乏技术。（强调已添加。）

We analyzed the reasons for failure, as given to us by the project managers, and by people who had performed previous evaluations of the projects. They gave various reasons behind the failure of the projects, virtually all of which were essentially management failures. We ran into problems because we didn't know how to manage what we had, not because we lacked the techniques themselves. (Emphasis added.)

 

多年来，我有机会与 Joel Aron 一起工作，因为他一直在努力让人们相信他对编程项目所说的话。可悲的是，大多数计算机界人士仍然不相信。在会议记录的下一页，C，AR Hoare，一个非常聪明的人，说：

Over the years, I have had the opportunity to work with Joel Aron as he has crusaded to get people to believe what he says about programming projects. The sad part of it is that most of the computing fraternity remains unconvinced. On the very next page of the proceedings, C, A. R. Hoare, a very brilliant man, says:

基本上所有的问题都是技术性的。如果您知道自己想做什么，并且拥有必要的技术背景，那么就没有必要从中解决重大的管理问题。显然，必须继续进行一定数量的资源控制和人员工作，但仅此而已。

Basically all problems are technical. If you know what you want to do and you have the necessary technical background, there is no point in making a great management problem out of it. Obviously a certain amount of resource control and personnel work have to go on but that's all.

 

从某种意义上说，霍尔是对的，但事实并非如此。人们试图应对他们不理解的问题，以及他们不知道自己不理解的问题——这本身就是管理的失败。我们试图展示一个项目如何即使具备技术能力也会付诸东流——因为如果人们像 Hoare 先生一样不服气，那么这方面的研究就不会富有成果。这幅图只是粗略勾勒出一些轶事细节，但它必须被填充，否则我们必须停止尝试做编程项目，直到它完成。

Hoare is right, in a certain sense, but it doesn't work out that way. People are trying to cope with problems they don't understand, and those they don't know they don't understand—in itself a failure of management. We have tried to show how a project can go down the drain even when it does have the technical capability—for if people remain as unconvinced as Mr. Hoare, there will be no fruitful study in this area. The picture is only sketched in broad outline with a few anecdotal details, but it must be filled in, or we must stop trying to do programming projects until it is.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1、你负责现在的团队多久了？原来的人还剩下多少？列出已离开的人员名单，并说明他们离开的原因。你对这种营业额有什么样的规定？

1. How long have you been in charge of your present group? How many of the original people remain? Make a list of the people who have left and give the reasons for their departure. What sort of provisions do you make for this kind of turnover?

2. 你遇到过有人在升职或加薪后不久就辞职的经历吗？晋升或加薪是否可以替代你不愿或不能给那个人的东西？退出的原因是什么，你认为真正的原因是什么？

2. Have you ever had someone quit soon after a promotion or a raise? Was the promotion or raise a substitute for something you would not or could not give that person? What reasons were given for quitting, and what do you think the real reasons were?

3. 你有不可缺少的女人或男人为你工作吗？如果是这样，如果她或他被杀或生病六个月，你会怎么做？

3. Do you have an indispensable woman or man working for you? If so, what would you do if she or he got killed or was sick for six months?

4. 当信息在您的组织中传递给您时，您以何种方式对其进行修改？你的经理会如何奖励或惩罚你提供准确的信息？

4. In what ways do you modify information as it passes you on its way up through your organization? What does your manager do to reward you or punish you for accurate information?

5. 你最喜欢哪一个，准确的信息还是令人愉快的信息？你的程序员知道你需要的信息是做什么用的吗？他们是否看到作为信息目的地的最终报告？如果不是，为什么不呢？

5. Which do you reward most, accurate information or pleasing information? Do your programmers know what the information you require is used for? Do they see the final reports which are the destination of their information? If not, why not?

6. 在你的下一次管理会议上，尝试在一些已经达成共识的问题上唱反调。记录下你感受到的压力，以及那些试图通过非理性论证让你遵守规则的人的反应。

6. At your next management meeting, try to play devil's advocate on some point on which there is otherwise common agreement. Record the pressures you feel, and the reactions of those trying to bring you into line by other than rational arguments.

7. 你认为你的某些团队更重要吗？你认为某些球队比其他球队更有声望吗？您的哪个团队的士气问题最大？

7. Do you favor certain of your teams as being more important? Do you see certain of the teams as more prestigious than others? Which of your teams have the greatest morale problems?

8. 你是否鼓励有利益冲突的群体之间的竞争以刺激生产？您如何衡量该策略是否有效？

8. Do you encourage competition between groups with conflicting interests in order to stimulate production? How can you measure whether or not this strategy is working?

9.环顾你的办公室，列出你在那里找到的地位象征。如果你找不到，去其他经理的办公室，列出他的身份象征。然后回到你的办公室，试着再列一份清单。

9. Look around your office and make a list of the status symbols you find there. If you can't find any, go to some other manager's office and make a list of his status symbols. Then go back to your office and try to make another list.

10. 在您的组织中，女性的待遇是否与男性不同？在什么情况下，出于什么原因？在您的组织中，女性的贡献是否低于男性，或者您不知道？

10. Are women in your organization treated any differently than men? In what situations, and for what reasons? Are the women in your organization contributing less than the men, or don't you know?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 你有没有觉得你被迫留在一个你想离开的位置？用什么手段逼你的？它如何影响你在那个职位上的工作？

1. Have you ever felt that you were being forced into staying in a position that you wanted to leave? What methods were used to force you? How did it affect your work in that position?

2. 你是否曾经得到金钱来代替你想要的其他东西，例如不同的工作、更多的帮助、更好地使用机器或不同的工作时间？钱是否让你满意，以至于你不再想要其他东西了？

2. Have you ever been given money as a substitute for something else you wanted, such as a different job, more help, better access to the machine, or different working hours? Did the money satisfy you so that you no longer wanted the other thing?

3.你在你的岗位上是不可或缺的吗？如果是这样，你在做什么，使自己或多或少变得不可或缺？

3. Are you indispensable in your position? If so, what are you doing about it, making yourself more, or less, indispensable?

4. 你知道你的进度报告或时间表会怎样吗？你有没有想过？你问过吗？

4. Do you know what happens to your progress reports or time sheets? Do you ever wonder? Do you ever ask?

5. 你有没有屈服于团队或管理压力，违背你最好的技术判断？描述情况和后果。

5. Have you ever yielded to group or managerial pressure against your best technical judgment? Describe the situation and the consequences.

6. 从声望的角度来看，您如何评价以下类型的任务，为什么？

6. From the point of view of prestige, how do you rate the following types of assignments, and why?

• 文档

• Documentation

• 程序库工作

• Program library work

• 系统测试

• System testing

• 进度报告

• Progress reporting

• 标准工作

• Standards work

• 诊断编程

• Diagnostic programming

• 教育

• Education

7. 你办公室里有什么身份象征？见经理的问题 9。

7. What status symbols do you have in your office? See Manager's question 9.

8. 你所在组织对女性的态度是什么？如果您是女性，这种态度对您和您的工作有何影响？

8. What is the attitude toward women in your organization? If you are a woman, what does that attitude do to you and your work?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

Naur、Peter 和 Brian Randell 合着“软件工程”，北约科学委员会报告，1969 年 1 月。

Naur, Peter, and Brian Randell, eds„ :Software Engineering", NATO Science Committee Report, January 1969.

Buxton, JN 和 Brian Randell 编着，“软件工程技术”，北约科学委员会报告，1970 年 4 月。这两个会议汇集了国际编程界的一些领导者，讨论控制软件项目的问题。虽然不能指望这些报告能够捕捉到会议的全部活力，但编辑们做得很好，可以从中收集到很多关于软件工程的信息——尽管从行为科学。

Buxton, J. N., and Brian Randell, eds., "Software Engineering Techniques," NATO Science Committee Report, April 1970. These two conferences brought together some of the leaders of the international programming community to discuss problems of controlling software projects. Although the reports cannot be expected to capture the full vitality of the conferences, the editors have done a fine job, and there is much information on software engineering to be gleaned from them—although there is not nearly enough from the point of view of the behavioral sciences.

Asch, S. E„独立性和服从群体压力的研究：I. 少数反对一致多数，心理学专着，7，系列第 416 号，1956 年。

Asch, S. E„ Studies of Independence and Submission to Group Pressure: I. A Minority of One Against a Unanimous Majority, Psychological Monographs, 7, Series No. 416, 1956.

这是一部关于舆论和社会压力的经典原创著作，值得所有技术人员阅读。

This is the classical and original work on opinions and social pressure, and it should be required reading for all technical people.

Kantowitz, Leo, Women and the Law: The Unfinished Revolution，阿尔伯克基，新墨西哥大学出版社，1969 年。

Kantowitz, Leo, Women and the Law: The Unfinished Revolution, Albuquerque, University of New Mexico Press, 1969.

对于那些认为在美国女性与男性平等对待的人来说，这是一个很好的解毒剂，正如随着时间的推移通过法律编纂所看到的那样。

A fine antidote for those who feel that women are treated equally with men in the United States, as seen through the codification of laws over time.

弗里丹，贝蒂，女性的奥秘，纽约，诺顿，1963 年。

Friedan, Betty, The Feminine Mystique, New York, Norton, 1963.

最早的“妇女解放”新书之一，让我们的世界以一个对自己有智慧、意识得到提升的女人为榜样。

One of the first of the new "women's liberation" books, giving the way our world looks to a woman who has her wits about her and her consciousness raised.

Gagne, Robert M., ed., Psychological Principles in System Development , New York, Holt, Rlnehart, and Winston, 1962.

Gagne, Robert M., ed., Psychological Principles in System Development, New York, Holt, Rlnehart, and Winston, 1962.

这本书很好地记录了 50 年代的“系统开发”运动，该运动主要是军方的产物，通过 RAND 和 SDC 等机构，一些大学也参与其中。除了从政府那里获得大笔拨款外，尚不清楚这场“运动”在完成任何事情方面是否非常成功，当然它对非军事工作的影响迄今为止相当小。馆藏作品层次参差不齐，从肤浅的陈词滥调到详细的系统图和照片，重叠的地方很多。“心理”方面主要关注如何将人视为复杂系统中的组成部分——人体工程学方法和人员方法。计算机编程本身真的没有任何价值，

This book is a good job documentation of the "Systems Development" movement of the fifties, which was largely a baby of the military, through such agencies as RAND and SDC, with some participation from the universities. It is not clear that the "movement" was ever very successful at accomplishing anything but getting large grants of money from the government, and certainly its influence on non-military work has so far been rather small. The level of work in the collection is uneven, ranging from superficial platitudes to detailed system diagrams and photographs, and there is much overlap. The "psychological" aspect is largely concerned with how to view people as components in complex system—the human engineering approach and the personnel approach. There is really nothing of value on computer programming as such, and the main interest in this book is discovering why this approach does not succeed in programming.

Meyer, Marshall W.，“自动化和官僚结构”，美国社会学杂志74, 3(1968)，第 256-264 页。

Meyer, Marshall W., "Automation and Bureaucratic Structure," American Journal of Sociology 74, 3(1968), pp. 256-264.

这项研究是对州、县和市各级 254 个财政部门的调查，显示了数据处理部门与组织其他部门之间的结构差异。别的不说，一线主管管的人多，级别高的管的人少，组织窄底宽。这种在最低层控制范围的扩大和层数的增加以达到最高层正是我们在计算机编程中所不需要的，一线管理人员已经对他们的员工了解得不够多这样做，树上的通信已经太慢且不可靠了。

This study, which is a survey of 254 departments of finance at state, county, and city levels, shows the differences in structure between the data-processing sections and the other parts of the organization. Among other things, first-line supervisors supervise more people, and higher-level ones fewer people, giving a narrow organization with a wide bottom. This expansion of the span of control at the lowest level and extension of the number of levels to reach the top is just what we don't need in computer programming, where first-line managers already don't know enough about what their people are doing, and communication up the tree is already too slow and unreliable.

第 6 章的评论。编程项目

Comments on Chapter 6. The Programming Project

25 年后，新一代的经理们仍然相信他们可以用金钱购买项目忠诚度——在他们不能或不愿用他们看重的其他东西奖励开发人员时给予薪水或奖金。可悲的是，这个想法仍然存在，因为在某种程度上它是真实的。但是项目持续的时间越长，资金的约束力就越小。而且，同样是可以被金钱束缚的人，可以被更多的金钱所释放。

After twenty-five years, a new generation of managers still believes they can buy project loyalty with money—giving salary or bonuses when they can't or won't reward developers with other things they value. Sadly, the idea persists because to some extent it's true. But the longer a project lasts, the less binding the money. Moreover, the same people who can be bound by money can be released by more money.

一些经理已经吸取了这一教训，现在正在寻找其他方式来奖励那些坚持完成项目的员工。有些人甚至将他们的项目构建成小的、可转移的工作单元，因此他们不需要束缚人们——或者不想束缚他们。多年来，经理们无数次感谢我为这部分敲响了警钟，今天仍然如此：

Some managers have learned this lesson, and now look for other ways of rewarding people for staying on their projects. Some even construct their projects in small, transferrable units of work, so they don't need to bind people—or want to. Over the years, I've been thanked countless times by managers for the wake-up call of this section, still true today:

如果一个程序员是不可或缺的，尽快摆脱他（/她）。

If a programmer is indispensable, get rid of him(/her) as quickly as possible.

 

我已将重要且及时的度量主题扩展到质量软件管理系列的第 2 卷中。测量心理学没有太大变化。人们仍在玩本章中描述的游戏——日程小说和日程鸡——因为人们仍然被迫给出管理层想要的答案，而不是提供有关项目真实状态的信息。

I've expanded the important and timely topic of measurement into Volume 2 of the Quality Software Management series. Not much has changed in the psychology of measurement. People still play the games described in this chapter—schedule fiction and schedule chicken—because people are still pressured to give the answers management wants, rather than giving information about the true state of their projects.

在又进行了四分之一个世纪的软件项目之后，我可以确认奥地利军队的模式仍然盛行——至少在大多数经理看来是这样。谁与谁交谈的现实可能完全不同，因为我敢肯定他们在奥地利军队中。尽管如此，令人鼓舞的是发现现在可以谈论或撰写其他模型，尤其是那些强调团队合作是成功项目的基本内核的模型。

After an additional quarter-century of doing software projects, I can confirm that the Austrian Army model still prevails—at least in most managers' minds. The realities of who-talks-to-whom may be quite different, as I'm sure they were in the Austrian Army. Still, it's encouraging to find that it's now permissible to speak or write about other models, especially those emphasizing teamwork as the essential kernel of a successful project.

项目来来去去，但同样的社会问题依然存在。我现在认识到，许多这些问题的根源是自卑。治愈的方法在于营造一种能够提升自尊的环境，而不是破坏自尊的环境。

Projects come and go, but the same social problems remain. I now recognize that the root of many of these problems is low self-esteem. The cure lies in an environment that boosts self-esteem, not one that destroys it.

一代之后，很多高层管理人员对软件的方方面面仍然一无所知。至少现在我们有一个蓬勃发展的软件行业，让软件开发人员有机会展示他们在高层管理中的能力。有些人做得很好，而另一些人则表明他们的管理问题并非缺乏软件经验。同时，这些年已经非常清楚地表明，没有软件经验的人也可以成功地管理大型软件项目。因此，似乎缺乏软件技能从来都不是问题。缺乏管理技能一直是个问题；缺乏软件技能只是那些缺乏尊重的经理们的一个方便的借口。

After a generation, many higher-level managers are still clueless about all aspects of software. At least now we have a thriving software industry that gives software developers a chance to show what they can do in upper management. Some are doing quite well, while others are demonstrating that their managerial problem is not lack of software experience. At the same time, these years have shown quite clearly that people with no software experience can successfully manage large software projects. So, it seems, the lack of software skill never was the problem. Lack of managerial skill was always the problem; lack of software skill was merely a convenient excuse for those managers who lacked esteem.

25 年前非常明显的特定身份象征已经随着硬件的变化而改变，但身份象征仍然存在。这表明重要的不是特定的象征，而是对地位象征的需要，这种需要也源于低自尊。

The particular status symbols that were so much in evidence twenty-five years ago have changed as hardware has changed, but there are still status symbols. This shows that it's not the particular symbols that matter, but, rather, the need for status symbols, a need that also arises from low self-esteem.

总的来说，项目中的职业女性不再被视为不同的物种，但她们似乎确实被某些人视为同一物种的劣等形式。我想这是一种进步，但经过一代人之后，你会认为我们本可以做得更好。如果不是有这么多人觉得自己不够格的话，我们或许也会这么做。

By and large, professional women in projects are no longer treated as a different species, but they do seem to be viewed by some as an inferior form of the same species. I suppose that's a kind of progress, but after a generation, you'd think we could have done better than that. Perhaps we would have, too, if so many men didn't feel so inadequate.

很久以前，我写道，“人们正在努力应对他们不了解的问题，以及他们不了解的问题——这本身就是管理的失败。......带有一些轶事细节的大纲，但必须填写，否则我们必须停止尝试进行编程项目，直到它完成。” 幸运的是，我们没有停下来等待研究，所以我们实际做项目的经验就成了我们的研究。今天，我们有许许多多成功的项目，也有许许多多不成功的项目——足够多的数据足以说明在软件领域取得成功所需具备的条件。

Way back then, I wrote, "People are trying to cope with problems they don't understand, and those they don't know they don't understand—in itself a failure of management. ... The picture is only sketched in broad outline with a few anecdotal details, but it must be filled in, or we must stop trying to do programming projects until it is." Fortunately, we didn't stop to wait for research, so our experience actually doing projects has become our research. Today, we have lots and lots of successful projects under our belts, and lots of unsuccessful ones—more than enough data to fill in the picture of what it takes to succeed in software.

对我自己来说，最大的遗漏细节是未能理解项目管理的情感维度。这些年来，我一直在填补这些维度，主要是在质量软件管理系列（现在是质量软件系列）中，现在我作为顾问的成功率要高得多。

For myself, the biggest missing detail was failure to understand the emotional dimensions of project management. I've spent these years filling in those dimensions, mostly in the Quality Software Management series, (now the Quality Software series)and now my success rate as a consultant is much, much higher.

第 3 部分。编程作为一项单独的活动

Part 3. Programming as an Individual Activity

 

我想到的是唯一配得上这个名字的自由，自由在于每个人潜在的所有物质、智力和道德力量的充分发展；一种不承认任何其他限制的自由，只承认那些由我们自己的本性法则所追溯的限制，准确地说，这等于说根本没有任何限制。. . .Mikhail Bakunin （经 ol Macmlllan 公司许可转载。来自巴枯宁的政治哲学，作者 MA Bakunin。版权所有 © 1953，1964 年由 Free Press 提供。）

I have in mind the only liberty worthy of that name, liberty consisting in the full development of all the material, intellectual, and moral powers latent in every man; a liberty which does not recognize any other restrictions but those which are traced by the laws of our own nature, which, properly speaking,is tantamount to saying that there is no restriction at all. . . .Mikhail Bakunin (Reprinted with the permission ol Macmlllan Company. from The Political Philosophy of Bakunin, by M. A. Bakunin. Copyright © 1953, 1964 by the Free Press.)

 

在本书的开头，我们开始考虑不同程序员在编程性能方面的一些差异。我们已经看到，这种差异在很大程度上可以由社会因素来解释——比我们从偶然的考虑中所相信的要多得多。但是，无论有多少差异可归因于社会因素，总会有残留。无论两个节目组的结构多么相似，他们都会制作出不同的成品。在本节中，我们将通过检查以个人为中心和围绕个人的因素来尝试解释其中的一些差异。

At the beginning of this book, we set out to account for some of the variation In programming performance among different programmers. We have seen that much of that variance can be accounted for by social factors—much more than we might have believed from casual considerations. But, no matter how much variance is attributable to social factors, there will always remain a residue. No matter how similar the structure of two programming groups might be, they will produce different finished products. In this section, we shall try to account for some of those differences by examining factors centering in and around the individual.

我们该如何进行？尽管很少有人直接对程序员进行编程进行心理学研究，但我们可以想象已经完成了一项心理学研究，并思考我们将如何分析它以解释不同受试者的表现差异。

How shall we proceed? Although little psychological research has been done directly on programmers doing programming, we could imagine that a psychological study had been done and think about how we would analyze it to account for differences in performance by different subjects.

实验心理学家会问的第一件事是“所有受试者都做同样的任务吗？” 即使在一个精心控制的实验中，也有许多差异可能会潜移默化地影响到受试者正在做的事情，或者认为他们正在做的事情。此外，如果我们要比较两个不同的实验，我们必须先寻找任务上的差异，然后才能得出有意义的结论。当然，在编程中，每个任务都以多种方式与其他任务不同，我们的第一个调查必须是任务差异。

The first thing an experimental psychologist would ask is "Did all subjects do the same task?" Even in a carefully controlled experiment, there are many differences that might creep into what the subjects were doing, or thought they were doing. Moreover, if we want to compare two different experiments, we are obliged to look first for any difference in task before we can draw meaningful conclusions. Certainly in programming, where every task is different from every other in a multitude of ways, our first investigations would have to be into task differences.

心理学家接下来要考虑的事情将取决于他的实验对象。如果他试图衡量个体差异，他会专注于使环境的所有方面尽可能保持不变，以便将它们排除在外。例如，他不会在空调房中对某些受试者进行测试，而在过热的房间中对其他受试者进行测试，因为室温很容易对性能产生比他试图测量的个体差异更主要的影响.

The next thing a psychologist would consider would depend on the object of his experiment. If he were trying to measure individual differences, he would concentrate on keeping all aspects of the environment as constant as possible so that they could be excluded from consideration. He would not, for example, give a test to some subjects in an air-conditioned room and others in a room that was overheated, for the room temperature could easily be a more dominant influence on performance than the individual differences he was trying to measure.

但如果心理学家试图衡量温度对表现的影响，他就会做出这种变化。他不会让环境变量保持不变，而是会尝试将个体差异降到最低。为此，他可能会尝试对同一个人进行多次相同的测试——尽管他随后将不得不应对学习效果，这是我们也必须考虑的问题。

But if the psychologist were trying to measure the effect of temperature on performance, he would make exactly this kind of variation. Instead of holding the environmental variables constant, he would try to hold individual differences down to a minimum. To do this, he might try giving the same test many times to the same individuals—although he would then have to contend with learning effects, something we, too, must consider.

无论如何，我们对环境的影响和个体之间的差异都感兴趣，所以我们考虑它们的顺序并不重要——只要我们给予它们应得的。

In any case, we are interested in both the effects of environment and the differences among individuals, so the order in which we consider them is not really important—as long as we give both their due.

在接下来的章节中，我们分解了构成心理学家所说的“个体差异”的因素。也就是说，如果两个人在相同的环境中执行相同的任务（我们都意识到这是不可能的，但这是必要的概念虚构），那么他们行为方式的差异可以归因于一个或多了这些因素。我们感兴趣的个体差异可以进一步细分为“个性”、“智力”和“训练”或“经验”等一般类别。

In the following chapters, we have broken down the factors which, in sum, constitute what psychologists call "individual variations." That is, if two people are given the identical task to perform in the identical environment (which is, we all realize, an impossibility—yet it is a necessary conceptual fiction), the differences in the way they behave can be attributed to one or more of these factors. The individual variations that interest us may be further subdivided into the general categories of "personality," "intelligence," and "training" or "experience."

第 3 部分的评论：作为一项单独活动的编程

Comments on Part 3: Programming as an Individual Activity

对我来说，原书的这一部分是最有希望的——所以这部分带来的失望也许是不可避免的。我的目标是激发对程序员如何工作的研究，这并不是我感到失望的地方。不，在过去的 25 年里，有趣的实验层出不穷，例如在马里兰大学 Ben Shneiderman 的实验室进行的实验。

For me, this part of the original book held the most hope—so perhaps it was inevitable that this part delivered the most disappointment. My goal was to stimulate the study of how programmers do their work, and that's not what I'm disappointed about. No, the past twenty-five years have seen a proliferation of interesting experiments, such as those conducted in Ben Shneiderman's laboratory at the University of Maryland.

我的问题，就像很多项目的问题一样，都是从错误的目标开始的。我的目标并不是真正激发大量实验，而是激发理解，从而在个体程序员的水平上实现更好的编程。在大多数情况下，这根本没有发生。四分之一个世纪之后，个体程序员并不比他们早期的同行更熟练。他们并没有更适合按个性编程，也没有更聪明、更有动力、没有接受过更好的培训、也没有更有经验。然而，他们的生产力要高得多。

My problem, like so many projects' problems, arose from starting with the wrong goal. My goal wasn't really to stimulate a lot of experiments, but to stimulate the understanding that would lead to better programming at the individual programmer's level. For the most part, that simply hasn't happened. A quarter-century later, individual programmers aren't any more adept than were their earlier counterparts. They are not better suited to programming by personality, nor more intelligent, nor better motivated, nor better trained, nor more experienced. They are, however, far more productive.

当然，我可能只是一个老头子，对我们年轻时的聪明才智有一种扭曲的看法。我不这么认为（当然！）有两个原因。首先，我们并不比现在的程序员聪明。我几乎每天都和程序员一起工作，他们看起来很像我年轻时的样子——非常聪明而且积极性很高。有时，他们看起来非常非常聪明；在其他时候，非常密集。啊，是的，我和二十五年前完全一样。

Of course, I may just be an old geezer with a distorted view of how clever we were when we were young geezers. I don't think so (of course!) for two reasons. First, we weren't smarter than the present day programmers. I work with programmers almost every day and they seem to be pretty much like I was when I was young—very smart and highly motivated. At times, the seem awfully, awfully clever; at other times, incredibly dense. Ah, yes, I was exactly the same, twenty-five years ago.

其次，我确实认为我可以通过其他方式来解释生产力的差异——更好的工具、更好的团队合作、更好的管理，以及更好地理解程序员试图完成的任务。

Second, I do think I can account for the differences in productivity in other ways—better tools, better teamwork, better management, and better understanding of what task programmers are trying to accomplish.

第 7 章编程任务的变化

Chapter 7. Variations In The Programming Task

 

“编程”——就像“爱”一样——是一个包含无限活动的词。摆弄 BASIC 终端的高中生是在编程，而试图为专用在线计算机编写尽可能紧凑的微程序的工程师也是。除了名称之外，这两个活动之间还有什么共同点吗？

"Programming"—like "loving"—is a single word that encompasses an infinitude of activities. A high school student fiddling around with a BASIC terminal is programming, but so is an engineer trying to produce the tightest possible microprogram for a special-purpose on-line computer. Is there anything in common between these two activities besides their name?

编程文献通常假设高中生和工程师的活动之间存在一些共同点，而且就目前而言，这个假设可能是正确的。但也许在尝试解释编程性能差异时的大部分困难来自我们对称为编程的活动的分类缺乏细化。毕竟，我们可以通过在 5000 米高空飞越美国上空来创建经济活动理论，但我们只能说“每个人都在四处飞驰”。为了解释更多的行为细节，我们必须更接近地面，如果我们想从编程中去除一些神秘感，这就是我们必须做的。

The programming literature usually assumes that there is something in common between the activities of the high-school student and the engineer, and this assumption is probably correct, as far as it goes. But perhaps much of the difficulty in trying to account for differences in programming performance arises from a lack of refinement in our classification of the activities called programming. After all, we could create a theory of economic activity by flying over the United States at 5000 meters, but we couldn't say much more than that "everybody is driving around in all directions." To account for more details of behavior, we would have to get closer to the ground, and this is what we shall have to do if we want to remove some of the mystery from programming.

专业编程与业余编程

PROFESSIONAL VERSUS AMATEUR PROGRAMMING

高中生和工程师代表了众多程序员的两端。这些目的可能有所不同，但没有什么比听到一个业余爱好者——刚刚用 BASIC 完成一个六语句程序来求二次方程的根——关于编程理论和实践的演讲更让专业程序员反感的了。当然，我们很清楚，这种激烈可能是这两种活动之间没有任何区别的症状，因为这种缺乏会使专业人员的地位大大降低。尽管一些专业程序员可能确实只不过是隐藏在深奥晦涩的知识中的黑客，而一些业余爱好者可能通过编写一个简短的程序就可以深入了解编程，但这是有区别的。

The high school student and the engineer represent two ends of a rich spectrum of programmers. These ends may or may not be different, but nothing antagonizes the professional programmer more than to hear an amateur—having just completed a six-statement program in BASIC to find roots of a quadratic equation—discourse on the theory and practice of programming. We know well, of course, that this vehemence could be a symptom of lack of any difference between the two activities, for such a lack would put the professional in a much diminished stature. Although some professional programmers may indeed be no more than hacks camouflaged by esoteric obscurities and some amateurs might be able to gain a deep appreciation of programming through the writing of a single short program, there is a difference.

也许最深刻的差异源于程序最终用户的差异。几乎一成不变的是，业余爱好者程序的唯一目标用户是业余爱好者自己，而专业人士编写的程序将被其他人使用。可以肯定的是，专业人士经常发现自己编写的程序供自己使用——生成测试数据或评估未尝试过的算法的性能，仅举两个例子。事实上，在从事此类工作时，专业人士通常会陷入业余实践。但她工作的主要目标是让其他人使用该程序，这个简单的事实以多种方式影响了她的工作。

Perhaps the deepest differences emanate from differences in the ultimate user of the program. Almost invariably, the sole intended user of an amateur's program is the amateur himself, whereas the professional is writing programs other people will use. To be sure, the professional oftentimes finds herself writing a program for her own use—to generate test data or to evaluate the performance of an untried algorithm, to name but two instances. And, indeed, when doing this kind of work, the professional commonly slips into amateurish practices. But the main thrust of her work is directed toward use of the program by other people, and this simple fact conditions her work in a number of ways.

因为业余爱好者将是他自己程序的用户，他可以选择在编程之前或之后进行思考。例如，考虑一个想要编写程序来求二次方程根的学生。理想情况下，他坐在终端前，因为终端非常适合编程后的思考。[注意：在短短几年内，“终端”变成了“个人电脑”，然后再过几年，又变成了“终端”——但这次一般连接到互联网，而不是一台专用的大型机。]他决定他可能需要一些意见。这需要他为变量选择一些名称。在这里，程序的小规模和与其他程序的完全隔离给了他很大的推动力——在他不知情的情况下，当然——因为他可能会选择第一个想到的名字，比如 a、b 和 c。简单地遵循高中代数的符号，他根本没有考虑与其他符号、必须遵守的标准甚至属性声明可能发生的冲突。不，他只是输入类似

Because the amateur will be the user of his own program, he has the choice of doing his thinking either before or after programming. Consider, for example, a student who wants to write a program to find roots of quadratic equations. Ideally, he is sitting at a terminal, for terminals are well suited to post-programming thought. [NOTE: In just a few years, "terminal" became become "personal computer," then in a few more years, became "terminal" again—but this time generally connected to the Internet, rather than a single dedicated mainframe.] He decides that he will probably need some input. This requires that he choose some names for variables. Here the small size of the program and its complete isolation from other programs give him a big boost—without his awareness, of course—for he may choose whatever names first come to mind, such as a, b, and c. In simply following the notation of high school algebra, he does not think at all about possible conflicts with other symbols, standards which must be observed, or even with declaration of attributes. No, he merely types something like

获取列表（A、B、C）；

GET LIST (A, B, C);

以类似的方式添加一些其他程序部分后，他就可以尝试他的程序了。处理开始后，终端将暂停数据请求。由于是自己的程序，此时需要什么数据不需要任何提示，所以他至少保存了这样的编码作为预备

After adding some other program parts in a similar way, he will be ready to try his program. Upon initiation of processing, the terminal will pause in request for data. Since it is his own program, he does not need any prompting about what data are expected at this time, so he has saved at least such coding as a preliminary

PUT LIST（'输入 A、B 和 C'）；

PUT LIST ('ENTER A, B, AND C');

他也知道需要的东西的顺序，他的语言的简化输入系统允许他以多种形式输入他的数据，例如

He also knows the order in which things are required, and the simplified input system of his language permits him to enter his data in such diverse forms as

1 2 3

1 2 3

1,2,3

1,2,3

1.0、2.0、3.0

1.0, 2.0, 3.0

1E0, 2.0E+0, 0.3E+1

1E0, 2.0E+0, 0.3E+1

此外，如果他不小心滑倒并进入

Moreover, if he should happen to slip and enter

1A, 2, 3

1A, 2, 3

系统将拒绝第一个值，而他不必编写错误处理例程或记录拒绝此类数据项的原因。他知道期望是什么，因为他编写了程序。

the system will reject the first value without his having had to program an error-handling routine or document the reasons why such a data item is rejected. He knows what is expected, for he wrote the program.

甚至更细微的问题都可以帮他处理，因为他可以在编程之后思考。当他输入 1、2、3 这样的情况时，他可能会发现后面的一些语句会吐出数据，因为他将尝试对负数求平方根：

Even more subtle problems can be handled for him because he can think after programming. When he enters such a case as 1, 2, 3, he will probably find that some later statement coughs up the data because he will be trying to take a square root of a negative number:

(b**2 - 4ac) = 2**2 - 4*1*3 = 4 -12 = -8

(b**2 - 4ac) = 2**2 - 4*1*3 = 4 -12 = -8

他自动获得诊断——无需任何预先考虑或预先编程——并且可能很快意识到问题是什么。然后他可能会简单地决定他无论如何都不想要复杂的根，在这种情况下，问题根据定义就消失了。只有当程序员自己定义问题时，这种简化才有可能，因为专业程序员至少必须离开终端（或撰写电子邮件）才能找到授权更改或澄清规范的人。

He gets the diagnostic automatically—without any forethought or fore-programming—and probably realizes rather quickly what the problem is. He may then simply decide that he doesn't want complex roots anyway, in which case the problem disappears by definition. Only when the programmer himself is defining the problem is this sort of simplification possible, for the professional programmer would at least have had to leave the terminal (or compose an email) to find someone to authorize a change or clarification of specifications.

如果业余爱好者确实决定他需要复杂的根，他的任务在进行必要的修改方面仍然比专业人士简单得多。即使他完成了程序，他的工作仍然简单，因为当他完成时，他只需要忘记它。另一方面，专业人士必须将它放入一个整洁的包裹中，然后将其发送到寒冷的世界——从那里它可能会带着刻薄的评论返回给他，这些评论的意义必须被考虑用于随后的修改。

If the amateur does decide that he needs complex roots, his task is still much simpler than that of the professional in making the necessary modifications. Even when he has finished the program, his job remains simpler, for when he is finished, he merely has to forget about it. The professional, on the other hand, has to put it into a neat package and send it out into the cold world—from which it may return to him bearing caustic comments, comments whose sense has to be considered for subsequent modifications.

当然，真正的专业人士会以不会过度涉及修改的方式构建程序，但这是她在编写时必须考虑的另一件事。即使这个程序根本不是为了其他人的眼睛而设计的，专业人士也不能像业余爱好者一样完全忘记它。例如，如果程序刚刚存储在终端系统中，用户最终会收到清理其存储的通知。专业人士必须回忆她图书馆中的每一个程序，因为有些程序仍然需要。然而，业余爱好者可能只有一个程序，因此他指示系统将其擦除——或者让擦除在默认情况下自动完成。但是让系统删除她的图书馆的专业人士有祸了！不，

A true professional, of course, would have constructed the program in such a way that modifications will not be overly involved—but that was another thing she had to think about when writing. Even if the program is not intended for other eyes at all, the professional cannot quite forget about it in the same way as the amateur. For instance, if the program is just stored in the terminal system, the user will eventually receive notification to clean up his storage. The professional has to recall each of the programs in her library, for some will still be needed. The amateur, however, probably has only one program, so he instructs the system to erase it—or lets the erasure be done automatically by default. But woe betide the professional who lets the system erase her library! No, she must drop what she is doing and check her long library list before the deadline comes around, or all her work will be gone with the wind.

许多年前，当编程系统还很初级时，专业人士和业余爱好者之间的区别还没有那么明显。然而，今天，业余爱好者想做的许多事情已经隐含在我们的系统中，以至于鸿沟越来越大。然而，矛盾的是，随着鸿沟的扩大，业余爱好者越来越没有意识到这一点，因为他们越来越没有意识到系统正在为他们做什么。正如一位优秀的经理面临员工不了解他的管理的问题一样，系统设计者也面临着同样的问题，因为她的系统工作得越好，用户对它的存在的了解就越少。

Many years ago, when programming systems were rudimentary, the difference between the professional and amateur was not nearly so pronounced. Today, however, so many of the things amateurs want to do have been made implicit in our systems that the gulf is a wide—and widening—one. Paradoxically, however, as the gulf has widened, the amateurs have become less and less aware of it, for they have become less and less aware of what the system is doing for them. Just as a good manager faces the problem that his employees are unaware of his management, so does the systems designer suffer because the better her system does its job, the less its users know of its existence.

说到经理，在编程方面，他们可能是业余爱好者中最业余的。几年前，一家公司决定尝试为其高管开设一门课程，让他们了解专业程序员所面临的问题。由于他们是高管，在课程期间，每个人都被指派了一名专业程序员作为“助手”，课程的高潮是每个高管必须“为自己”编程的问题。（我很遗憾地说，在这种情况下，那些创建课程的 [有吸引力的] 女性程序员会成为更好的“专业程序员”来协助男性高管。）

And speaking of managers, they can be the most amateur of amateurs when it comes to programming. A few years ago, one firm decided to try to give its executives a course that would make them appreciate the problems of their professional programmers. Inasmuch as these were executives, each was assigned a professional programmer as "assistant" for the duration of the course, the climax of which was a problem which each executive had to program "for himself." (I'm sad to say that those creating the course in this case [attractive] female programmers would make better "professional programmers" to assist the male executives.)

为了增强高管对程序员面临的问题的理解，这个工作会议被频繁的琐碎电话、会议和规范的小改动打断。高管们明白了这一点——高管们可以通过“庇护”他们的员工而不是成为干扰的主要来源来提高程序员的生产力。但他们也带走了另一个根深蒂固的想法。毕竟，尽管有这些干扰，他们还是设法让他们的程序运行起来，不是吗？当然，他们从“助手”那里得到了一点帮助，但真的不多。所以，如果他们能按时完成一个程序，为什么他们的程序员不能呢？如果他们能在一周内掌握编程，那么编程有什么难的呢？

To enhance the executives' appreciation for the problems faced by programmers, this work session was interrupted by frequent trivial phone calls, meetings, and small changes in specifications. The executives got the point—that executives could increase programmer productivity by "sheltering" their staff rather than being the major source of disturbance. But they also took away another—deeper rooted—idea. After all, in spite of all these disturbances, they had managed to get their program working, hadn't they? Sure, they had a little help from their "assistants," but not much, really. So, if they could get a program done on time, why couldn't their programmers? And what was so hard about programming, anyway, if they could master it in a week?

这整个印象是基于同一种错觉的结合，这种错觉使任何业余爱好者都无法理解将他与专业人士分开的深渊。首先，存在语义错觉，将他们编写的“程序”——一个涉及复利计算的微不足道的问题，使用对数表或计算尺可以更好地解决——等同于他们的员工编写的“程序”——操作系统，编译器、实用程序等。其次，他们有一种错觉，认为他们的助手“对他们帮助不大”。这种错觉是基于对编程的复杂性缺乏了解——正是助手们本应保护他们的复杂性，以免他们消除因无法完成他们的小问题而产生的对编程的不良感觉。因此，旨在让高管更好地理解程序员的问题的努力恰恰导致了相反的效果。

This entire impression was based on a combination of illusions of the same sort that make any amateur unable to appreciate the abyss which separates him from the professional. First, there was the semantic illusion which equates the "program" they wrote—a trivial problem involving compound interest calculation which could have been better solved using a log table or slide rule—with the "programs" written by their staff—operating systems, compilers, utilities, and the like. Second, there was the illusion that their assistants were "not helping them much." This illusion was based on a lack of understanding of the complexities of programming—the very complexities which the assistants were supposed to shield them from lest they take away a bad feeling about programming engendered by being unable to complete their teensy problem. And so, the very efforts directed at giving the executives a better appreciation for the problems of the programmer resulted in precisely the opposite effect.

管理者需要更好地理解编程：一个典型的例子是，管理者甚至可以开始相信他可以在一周内学会专业人士通过多年经验学到的东西。确实，专业程序员和业余程序员之间的区别在于专业程序员过去的卓越经验。但也可以争辩说，同样重要的区别不在于每个人以前编写的程序，而在于他将来编写的程序。业余爱好者为了自己的目的而致力于特定程序的结果，正在寻找完成工作的方法。如果他遇到困难，他只想克服它——这样做的方式无关紧要。然而，对于专业人士而言并非如此。她可能很清楚解决手头问题的多种方法。她甚至可能为了完成工作而直接雇用其中一位。但她的工作并不止于此；它从那里开始。开始是因为她必须理解为什么她不理解，以便她可以为她有朝一日可能编写的需要这种理解的程序做好准备。

Better appreciation of programming by managers is needed: a case in point is the fact that a manager could even begin to believe he could learn in a week what the professional has learned through years of experience. Indeed, it is a homily that the difference between the professional and the amateur programmer lies in the superior past experience of the professional. But one could also contend that an equally important difference lies not in the programs each has previously written, but in those he will write in the future. The amateur, being committed to the results of the particular program for his own purposes, is looking for a way to get the job done. If he runs into difficulty, all he wants is to surmount it—the manner of doing so is of little consequence. Not so, however, for the professional. She may well be aware of numerous ways of circumnavigating the problem at hand. She may even employ one of them for the immediate purpose of getting the job done. But her work does not stop there; it begins there. It begins because she must understand why she did not understand, in order that she may prepare herself for the programs she may someday write which will require that understanding.

那么，业余爱好者正在了解他的问题，他所做的任何关于编程的学习都可能是一个很好的装饰，或者对他来说可能是一个讨厌的障碍。相反，专业人士正在学习她的专业——编程——而被编程的问题只是她发展过程中的一个偶然步骤。

The amateur, then, is learning about his problem, and any learning about programming he does may be a nice frill or may be a nasty impediment to him. The professional, conversely, is learning about her profession—programming—and the problem being programmed is only one incidental step in her process of development.

这种观察的另一方面是，专业人士从来没有像业余爱好者那样认真对待任何问题。她以前有过虫子，以后还会有。这种态度上的差异是这两种类型之间不断摩擦的根源：专业人士非常疲倦，并且对源源不断的业余爱好者在她面前挥舞着他们的打印输出并谴责机器、操作员、系统、按键打孔器感到有点恼火，语言，或政府。另一方面，业余爱好者可以看到，专业人士甚至不关心他的均值和标准差不会及时准备好以包含在会议记录中。

The other side of this observation is that the professional never quite takes any problem as seriously as does the amateur. She has had bugs before, and she will have them again. This difference in attitude is a source of constant friction between the two types: the professional is very tired and a bit irritated by the unending stream of amateurs waving their printouts in her face and condemning the machine, the operator, the system, the keypuncher, the language, or the government. The amateur, on the other hand, can see that the professional does not even care that his means and standard deviations are not going to be ready in time for inclusion in the proceedings of the conference.

程序员想要做什么

WHAT THE PROGRAMMER IS TRYING TO DO

业余程序员和专业程序员之间的关系存在不对称性，因为一个人无法理解另一个人所面临的复杂性。尽管如此，专业人士经常会犯这样的错误，即嘲笑业余爱好者的工作不够专业；这个错误比业余爱好者低估自己与专业人士之间的距离所犯的错误更不可原谅。专业人士，如果她是真正的专业人士，应该知道得更多，而业余爱好者则不能。业余爱好者可能无法编写出详细的错误处理例程，因为他不知道错误处理例程是如何做的，甚至不知道错误处理例程是什么。但是，如果他不需要的话，他为什么要知道呢？是不是

There is an asymmetry in the relationship between amateur and professional programmers, because the one cannot appreciate the complexities that the other faces. Nonetheless, the professional often commits the error of deriding the work of the amateur for not being sufficiently professional; and this error is much less excusable than that made by the amateur in underestimating the distance between himself and the professional. The professional, if she is truly professional, should know better, whereas the amateur cannot. The amateur may fail to program an elaborate error-handling routine because he doesn't know how or doesn't even know what an error-handling routine is. But then, why should he know, if he doesn't need one? Isn't it much worse for the professional to insist on treating a tiny one-time program for personal use as if it were an operating system intended to be used by thousands of people for five or ten years?

与任何其他人造物体一样，程序在设计时（或应该在设计时）考虑到明确的生命周期和应用范围。就像“执事的杰作”一样，它“以如此合乎逻辑的方式构建，至今运行了一百年”，一个程序不应该有过度设计或设计不足的部分。然而，由于某种原因，将更多时间花在那些呈现出最大智力挑战的程序部分而不是那些需要最多工作的程序部分上，这是程序员的一种职业病。

Programs, like any other human-made objects, are designed—or should be designed—with a definite lifespan and scope of application in mind. Like the "Deacon's Masterpiece," which was "built in such a logical way it ran a hundred years to the day," a program should have neither over-designed or under-designed parts. Yet it is an occupational disease of programmers to spend more time on those program parts that present, for some reason, the most intellectual challenge rather than on those that require the most work.

一个典型的例子是一位半专业的程序员，他受一位物理学教授的委托编写一个程序来求一些矩阵的逆。由于一次存储的矩阵太多，他需要一个例程来一次一个地从磁带中读取它们以进行处理。他在输入输出编程方面几乎没有经验，所以他认为这是学习一些东西的好机会，于是他开始寻求一些建议。

A case in point is the semi-professional programmer who was commissioned by a physics professor to write a program to find the inverses of some matrices. As there were too many matrices to keep in storage at once, he needed a routine for reading them from tape one at a time for processing. He had little experience with input-output programming, so he decided that this would be a good chance to learn something, and he set out to get some advice.

“我如何对来自磁带的输入进行编程，以便缓冲来自处理的输入？” 他问了一位更专业的同事。由于比较专业，这位同事没有回答问题，而是提出了自己的问题。

"How can l program the input from tape so as to buffer the input from processing?" he asked a somewhat more professional colleague. Being somewhat more professional, the colleague didn't answer the question, but put one of his own.

“为什么要缓冲输入？”

"Why do you want to buffer the input?"

“当然是为了节省时间。”

"To save time, of course."

“你估计过你会节省多少时间吗？”

"Have you estimated how much time you will save?"

“不完全是，但会很多，因为有很多矩阵。”

"Not exactly, but it will be a lot, because there are a lot of matrices."

“多少？”

"How many?"

“我不太清楚。很多。”

"I don't know exactly. A lot."

“大概有多少？”

"Approximately how many?"

“也许一百。”

"Maybe a hundred."

“很好。它们有多大？”

"Good. And how large are they?"

“十个十个。”

"Ten by ten."

这位同事在黑板上快速计算了一下，结果显示这些矩阵大约需要一分钟才能读完。

The colleague did a quick calculation on the blackboard which showed that these matrices would require about one minute to read.

“看，”半职业选手得意地说。“那是很多时间。”

"See," said the semi-pro, in triumph. "That's a lot of time."

“也许——也许不是。你要运行这个程序多少次？”

"Perhaps—or perhaps not. How many times will you run this program?"

“你是什么意思？”

"What do you mean?"

“我的意思是，如果你写了一个缓冲例程，你将不得不测试它，我怀疑你是否可以用不到一分钟的机器时间来做到这一点。所以如果你只有一组矩阵，我'我劝你还是算了吧。光是测试计算机的时间就比你节省的时间还要多——更不用说你的时间了。”

"I mean, if you write a buffering routine, you're going to have to test it, and I doubt if you can do that with less than one minute of machine time. So if you only have one set of matrices, I'd advise you to forget it. Just the computer time in testing will cost more than you could possibly save—not to speak of your time."

“但你不明白，”半职业选手说，他不愿意看到自己编写一个有趣的新程序的机会溜走。“这一定是一个高效的程序！”

"But you don't-understand," said the semi-pro, who was not willing to see his chance of writing a new and interesting program slip away. "This has got to be an efficient program!"

他的同事应该对这种反应感到沮丧，但无法阻止自己试图重新表述这些论点。但是，唉，这一切都是徒劳的，下次他有机会见到他的朋友时——那是下个学期——他仍然无法让他的缓冲例程发挥作用。可怜的物理学教授还在等待他的矩阵，完全不知道发生了什么——但对他的编程问题被证明如此复杂感到有点受宠若惊。

His colleague should have been discouraged by this response, but could not stop himself from trying to rephrase the arguments. But, alas, it was all in vain, and the next time he chanced to see his friend—which was the next semester—he was still having problems getting his buffering routines working. The poor physics professor, still waiting for his matrices, was completely unaware of what was going on—but was mildly flattered that his programming problem had proved so complex.

这个故事——以及其他一百个类似的故事——的寓意是，每个程序都有适当的关注和复杂程度，这取决于它的用途。在某种程度上，在该级别以上工作甚至不如在该级别以下工作。如果我们要知道一个程序员是否做得很好，我们就必须知道他是否在适当的水平上工作以解决他的问题。使一个人成为优秀的业余程序员的相同才能或个性可能使他非常不适合成为专业程序员；但缺乏根据手头的问题调整工作行为的能力，总是让他不适应。

The moral of this tale—and a hundred others like it—is that each program has an appropriate level of care and sophistication dependent on the uses to which it will be put. Working above that level is, in a way, even less professional than working below it. If we are to know whether an individual programmer is doing a good job, we shall have to know whether or not he is working on the proper level for his problem. The same talents or personality that make a person an excellent amateur programmer may make him singularly unsuited for being a professional one; but the lack of ability to adjust his working behavior to the problem at hand will always make him unsuited.

但是，程序员通常无法根据手头的问题调整他的活动，因为他不知道手头的问题是什么。也就是说，他假设某些东西是他想要的——也许是基于他知道如何做的事情，或者是基于他之前编写的工作中想要的东西——但他永远不会发现需要什么，直到工作被完成。完成的。为缓冲工作本身并不是一件坏事，但仅就特定程序的用途而言。如果矩阵是 100 x 100，并且有数千个，那么我们之前故事中的山羊可能就是英雄了。

Usually, though, the programmer fails to adjust his activities to the problem at hand because he does not know what the problem at hand is. That is, he assumes that certain things are wanted—perhaps on the basis of what he knows how to do, or on the basis of what was wanted in the previous job he programmed—but he never finds out what was wanted until the job is finished. Working for buffering is not a bad thing in itself, but only in terms of what a particular program is going to be used for. If the matrices were 100 by 100, and if there were going to be thousands of them, the goat of our previous tale could have been a hero.

对编程性能的研究非常少，但似乎所有的研究都因缺乏对模糊编程目标问题的认识而受到影响。给一群精心挑选的程序员解决同样的问题然后衡量他们的“表现”是不够的。任何心理学家都知道，必须向受试者明确说明他们要努力达到什么目标，但在大多数情况下，即使这样还不够。例如，如果给我们一个单词列表来匹配它们的同义词，我们应该努力提高速度还是提高准确性？如果心理学家告诉我们要尽可能快，我们是否真的会冒犯真正粗心错误的风险遵循该指示？出色地，这取决于许多因素——因为有些人天生就比其他人更一丝不苟。心理学家为此类问题失眠了很多个晚上，也许程序员和他们的经理应该分享一点这种担忧。

There have been very few studies of programming performance, but what few there have been all seem to have suffered from a lack of appreciation for the problem of ambiguous programming objectives. It is not enough to give a carefully selected bunch of programmers the same problem to work on and then measure their "performance." Any psychologist knows that subjects must be given explicit instructions on what they are to try to achieve, and that even that is not enough in most cases. For instance, if we are given a list of words to match with their synonyms, are we supposed to work for speed or for accuracy? And if the psychologist tells us to be as fast as we can, do we really follow that instruction at the risk of making truly careless errors? Well, that depends on a number of factors—because some people are inherently more meticulous than others. Psychologists lose many nights of sleep over such questions, and perhaps programmers and their managers should share a bit of that concern.

为了测试假设目标对编程性能的影响，我们进行了一个小实验。四名程序员被要求解决同一个问题——一个非常重要的问题，可能会花费他们五分之一的时间，持续十周。尽管问题说明在其他方面与复印机一样完全相同，但其中两个程序员得到的最后一页与其他两个程序员的最后一页不同。对于一对，最后一页内容如下：

In order to test for the influence of assumed goals on programming performance, we conducted a small experiment. Four programmers were asked to work on the same problem—a nontrivial one which would take perhaps one-fifth of their time for ten weeks. Although the problem specifications were otherwise as identical as a copier could make them, two of the programmers were given a last page which differed from the last page given to the other two. For one pair, the last page read as follows:

你在这个项目上的目标应该是获得一个完全调试的程序，它尽可能高效，尽可能使用最少的 CPU 时间。您可以根据需要使用尽可能多的核心存储，最多 128K。虽然你不是为了快速完成项目而努力，但你应该计划在第九周结束时达到最终测试水平。

Your objective on this project should be to get a fully debugged program which is as efficient as possible, in the sense of using the least CPU time possible. You may use as much core storage as needed, up to 128K. Although you are not working for fast completion of the project, you should plan to reach the final test level by the end of the ninth week.

对于另一对，最后一页内容如下：

For the other pair, the last page read as follows:

你在这个项目上的目标应该是在尽可能短的时间内获得一个完全调试的程序，而不考虑程序的速度或空间效率，因为这些因素会减慢程序的完成。但是，您在项目上花费的时间不应超过分配的正常工作量（五分之一）。但是，您必须保持程序大小小于 128K。

Your objective on this project should be to get a fully debugged program in as short a time as possible without considering the efficiency in speed or space of the program insofar as those factors will slow down the completion of the program. However, you should not spend any more time on the project than the normal work load allotted (one-fifth time). You must, however, keep the program size less than 128K.

通过明确说明，我们希望衡量由于对项目目标的不同理解而导致的变化类型。没有一个程序员知道其他人正在朝着不同的目标努力。然而，在项目结束时，两人之间的表现差异是惊人的。那些被要求尽快完成程序的人平均只使用了机器时间的五分之二和另一组个人时间的三分之一。另一方面，他们完成的程序平均要慢十倍！（参见图 7-1，“索引问题”。）

By making the instructions explicit, we hoped to measure the type of variation attributable to different understandings of the objectives of the project. None of the programmers knew that the others were working toward different objectives. At the end of the project, however, the difference in performance between the pairs was striking. Those who were asked to complete the program as quickly as possible used, on the average, only two-fifths of the machine time and one-third of the individual time used by the other group. Their finished programs, on the other hand, were, on the average, about ten times slower! (See Figure 7-1, "Index Problem.")

 

 

 

图 7-1 环境对性能的影响。

Figure 7-1 Effect of environment on performance.

 

对另一组程序员和不同类型的程序重复了这个实验，但设计的程序同样复杂。在这里，节省大量资金的可能性并不大，但“快速完成”组的平均机器时间是另一组的五分之二，是另一组个人使用时间的三分之一。在这种情况下，“效率”组的程序速度提高了大约 50%。（参见图 7-1，“文件问题”。）

This experiment was repeated with another group of programmers and a different type of program, but one designed to be about equally complex. Here the possibilities for spectacular savings were not so great, but again the "fast-completion" group averaged two-fifths the machine time and one-third the individual time used by the other group. The "efficiency" group, in this case, achieved about 50 percent more speed in their programs. (See Figure 7-1, "File Problem.")

这对实验给出了一个很好的对比，因为它表明，努力提高效率所获得的收益取决于问题的类型以及其他任何因素。因此，即使我们对所有问题的效率同样感兴趣，我们也永远无法就为提高效率付出多少努力是合理的做出一般性陈述。但实验的重要结果是，在任何工作中，程序员之间的很大一部分差异都可以归因于对要完成的工作的不同概念。

This pair of experiments gives a nice contrast, for it shows that the gains to be had from striving for efficiency depend on the type of problem as much as anything else. Thus, we could never make a general statement about how much effort toward efficiency is justified, even if we were equally interested in efficiency on all problems. But the important result from the experiments is that a large proportion of the variance between programmers on any job can be attributed to a different conception of what is to be done.

当我们更详细地调查“效率”组增加的机器时间和程序员时间的来源时，我们发现其中大部分可以归因于程序员对意外困难的反应方式。在“快速完成”组中，当某些方法行不通时，就简单地丢弃它并用另一种方法代替；但是当“效率”程序员遇到麻烦时，他们不愿意改变他们的方法，因为他们将不得不牺牲一些效率。因此，尽管不同组中的两个程序员可能在开始时想到了相同的方法，但“快速完成”的程序员最终却采用了截然不同的方法——但他确实在另一个还在挣扎的时候完成了。

When we investigated in more detail the source of added machine time and programmer time for the "efficiency" groups, we found that much of it could be accounted for in the way the programmers reacted to unanticipated difficulties. In the "fast-completion" group, when some method was not working out, it was simply dropped and another one was substituted; but when the "efficiency" programmers had trouble, they were loath to change their approach because they would then have to sacrifice some efficiency. Thus, though two programmers in different groups might have started out with the same method in mind, the "fast-completion" programmer wound up with something rather different—but he did finish while the other was still struggling.

同样重要的是要注意困难的来源或多或少与这个结果无关。例如，在一个案例中，一个编译器错误导致某个功能出现问题，而该功能对于解决问题的一种可能方法至关重要。尽管两个小组都遇到了同样的错误并且都无能为力，但“快速完成”小组在发现这是一个编译器错误之前很久就放弃了这种方法。其他人一直坚持到最后，直到发现困难的根源才不得不放弃它。尽管这一事件对这个群体来说可能是“不公平的”，但在世界各地的计算中心每天都会发生数千次，这并不是什么大不了的事。从心理学的角度来看，教训是显而易见的。相同的客观事件（编译器错误，一个困难的算法，或者你有什么）根据项目的目标（即使它们没有说明）以不同的方式影响项目。因此，如果我们要衡量程序员的性能、语言性能、操作系统性能或其他任何东西，我们必须确保每个人都真正在处理同一个问题。

It is also important to notice that the source of the difficulty is more or less irrelevant to this result. In one case, for instance, a compiler bug caused trouble with a feature that was critical to one of the possible approaches to a problem. Although both groups encountered the same bug and neither could do anything about it, the "fast-completion" group dropped the approach long before they ever found out that it was a compiler bug. The others stuck with it until the bitter end, only to have to drop it when the source of the difficulty was uncovered. Although this turn of events may have been "unfair" to this group, it was nothing that does not happen thousands of times a day in computing centers all over the world. From a psychological point of view, the lesson is clear. The same objective event (a compiler bug, a difficult algorithm, or what-have-you) affects a project in different ways according to the objectives—even though they be unstated—of the project. Therefore, if we are to measure programmer performance, or language performance, or operating system performance, or anything else, we must be sure that everybody is truly working on the same problem.

当然，在现实生活中，我们通常不会同时有多个小组在“同一个”程序上工作。因此，我们可能不知道该团队正在朝着一组不同的目标努力，而不是他们的经理认为他们拥有的目标。因此，除非我们采取预防措施确保所有目标都已传达——并保持传达——否则当程序不符合时间表或运行效率低下、使用过多存储或诸如此类的情况时，我们不应该感到惊讶。

In real life, of course, we do not usually have more than one group working on "the same" program at a time. Thus, we may not be aware that the group is working toward a different set of objectives than, say, their manager thinks they have. Consequently, unless we take precautions to see that all the objectives are communicated—and remain communicated —we should not be surprised when the program does not meet schedules or runs inefficiently, or uses too much storage, or what-have-you.

但是让我们退后一步，因为“现实生活”从来都不是那么简单。传达目标有一定的危险：目标可以改变估计！在我们的实验中，在发现指令对性能的影响后，我们回过头来检查每个程序员给出的估计。程序员估计了完成每个项目的批处理运行次数和运行天数，他们的实际运行和估计运行和天数的比较如图 7-2 所示。很容易看出发生了什么。那些被要求尽快完成的人在他们对完成时间的估计上要保守得多，他们实际上比他们的估计要好得多，也比另一组好得多——尽管另一组已经完成了很多他们的估计更加乐观。

But let's back off a moment, for "real life" is never so simple. There is a certain danger in communicating objectives: objectives can change estimates! In our experiment, after we had found the effect of instructions on performance, we went back and checked the estimates given by each programmer. The programmers had estimated number of batch runs and number of elapsed days to complete each project, and the comparison of their actual and estimated runs and days is shown in Figure 7-2. It is easy to see what happened. Those who were instructed to finish as fast as possible were motivated to be far more conservative in their estimates of time to completion, and they actually performed much better than their estimates and much better than the other group—even though the other group had been much more optimistic in their estimating.

 

图 7-2 环境对估计的影响。

Figure 7-2 Effect of environment on estimating.

 

一个有趣的小插曲是，有一个人绝对拒绝做出时间估算，而他在小组中被要求尽快完成这项工作。他也是唯一一个在项目中途得了阑尾炎的人（幸运的是他是该组中的第五个人）。编程经理在为他们的下一个项目设定目标之前，应该仔细研究这个数字。如果明确设定了目标，则会产生两种影响：程序员以可能牺牲另一个目标为代价来实现该目标，并且程序员在估计他们将如何实现目标时会更加保守（或准确）。对没有强调的目标的估计可能是完全不可靠的，这既是因为它们没有仔细制定，也因为它们不够重要，无法抵制为其他目标而牺牲。

One interesting sidelight is that there was one person who absolutely refused to make a time estimate, and he was in the group asked to do the job as quickly as possible. He was also the only one who got appendicitis in the middle of the project (though fortunately he was a fifth person in that group). Programming managers should take a long, hard look at this figure before they set down the goals for their next project. If a goal is set explicitly, there are two effects: programmers work toward that goal at the possible expense of another goal, and programmers will be far more conservative (or accurate) in estimating how well they will meet the goal. Estimates on goals not emphasized will probably be completely unreliable, both because they are not made carefully and because they are not important enough to resist being sacrificed to other goals. Unfortunately, this modification of estimates was not anticipated by the experimenters, so we neglected to ask the programmers to estimate the efficiency of their programs, but it seems reasonable that the same type of result would have obtained—but reversed for the two groups.

如果这个结果被证明是普遍的，它将在一定程度上澄清帕金森定律的奥秘，从而可能解除无数经理人的噩梦。当帕金森说“工作会增加以填补分配的时间”时，他是在让我们意识到，日程目标的存在本身就会影响工作的速度。但现在我们看到，作为目标的日程表的存在可以影响“分配的时间”。工作可以扩展以填补分配的时间的原因是存在其他目标，这些目标相对于日程安排的重要性尚未明确。或许我们可以沿着这条推理线开始理解在编程项目永远无法按时完成这一普遍接受的结论背后存在哪些谬误。

Should this result prove general, it would clarify somewhat the mysteries of Parkinson's Law and might thereby relieve the nightmares of numerous managers. When Parkinson said that "work expands to fill the time allotted," he was making us aware that the very existence of schedule goals can influence the rate of work. But now we see that the very existence of schedule as a goal can influence "the time allotted." The reason work can expand to fill the time allotted is the existence of other goals whose importance relative to scheduling is not made clear. Perhaps we might follow this line of reasoning and begin to understand what fallacies underly the generally accepted conclusion that programming projects can never be done on time.

编程工作的阶段

STAGES OF PROGRAMMING WORK

我们必须摒弃的另一个谬论是，“编程”是某种统一的工作，需要一组统一的才能。至少对于专业人士来说，从规范到交付程序的工作需要各种各样的工作，而这反过来又需要各种各样的人才。

Another fallacy we shall have to lay to rest is that "programming" is some sort of uniform effort requiring a set of uniform talents. For the professional, at least, the job of getting from specifications to delivered program demands various kinds of work, which, in turn, demand various talents.

在一个组织得当的项目中，并不是每个程序员都需要具备制作完整程序所需的所有才能，因为工作可能会根据个人能力分配。事实上，可能在编程的一个阶段适合工作会使一个人或多或少不适合在另一个阶段工作。系统设计的工作需要一双不放过森林的眼睛，而调试的工作可能需要把每一棵树——甚至每一根树枝或叶子——都看得一清二楚。编码工作通常需要挤出每一滴冗余，而文档工作可能需要将简单的句子增加到段落大小。

In a properly organized project, not every programmer need have all of the talents required to produce complete programs, since work may be allocated according to individual abilities. Indeed, it may be that suitability for work in one stage of programming makes one more or less unsuited for work in another. The job of system design calls for an eye which never loses sight of the forest, whereas the job of debugging may require that every tree—even every branch or leaf—be seen with utmost clarity. The job of coding often requires squeezing out every drop of redundancy, and the job of documentation may require that simple sentences be plumped up to paragraph size.

正如一个成功的程序员在调到管理职位时可能会失败一样，一个成功的设计师在调试系统时也可能成为障碍。另一方面，在调试中可能对我们帮助最大的人可能在设计阶段就被排除在项目之外，因为当时既不需要也不欣赏他的特殊才能。如果我们要确保在需要时提供合适的人才，我们就必须将程序员所做的工作分类为比简单术语“编程”所涵盖的更精细的类别。

Just as a successful programmer may become a failure when moved into a management position, so may a successful designer become a handicap when the time comes to debug a system. On the other hand, the man who might have helped us most in debugging may have been pushed out of the project during the design phase because his peculiar talents were neither needed nor appreciated at that time. If we are to ensure that the proper talents are available when needed, we shall have to classify the work that programmers do into somewhat more refined categories than the simple term "programming" covers.

编程通常被描述为一个过程，从问题定义到分析再到流程图绘制，然后是编码，然后是测试，最后是文档。尽管这种粗略的看法包含一些事实，但它在几个方面歪曲了事实。首先，实际顺序并不是那么固定，因为，例如，文档可能先于测试、编码、流程图甚至分析。其次，当我们为新机器或新语言重新编写程序时，并非所有步骤都需要存在。第三，它根本不需要是一个序列——而且在实际操作中，很少是。谁没有经历过随着分析、流程图、编码、测试、和文档？或者谁见过在整个编码过程中保持不变的流程图或在整个测试过程中保持不变的代码？

Programming is often described as a process moving from problem definition through analysis to flow diagramming, then coding, followed by testing, and finishing with documentation. Although this rough view contains some truth, it distorts the truth in several ways. First of all, the actual sequence is not so fixed, because, for example, documentation may precede testing, coding, flow diagramming, and even analysis. Secondly, not all steps need be present, as when we are recoding a program for a new machine or language. Thirdly, it need not be a sequence at all—and, in actual practice, rarely is. Who has not experienced a problem definition that changes as discoveries are made in analysis, flow diagramming, coding, testing, and documentation? Or who has ever seen a flow diagram that remains unmodified throughout the coding—or code that remains unmodified throughout testing?

如果我们要从心理学的角度研究编程，我们必须将这些复杂的活动分解为我们已经建立的更简单的活动。然而，由于编程过程的循环或迭代性质，即使我们上面所做的这种分解也过于精细。这些划分没有明确的界限，或者可能根本没有界限。可以肯定的是，如果我们问一个程序员他在做什么，他会毫不犹豫地说“编码”或“调试”。此外，在大多数设施中有效的“进度报告”系统往往会迫使人们将他们的工作归入比实际存在的更严格的类别。这样，人们就会相信他们每周在时间表上写下的类别的真实性。

If we are to study programming from a psychological point of view, we must decompose these complex activities into simpler ones—that we have established. And yet, because of the cyclic, or iterative, nature of the programming process, even such a decomposition as we have made above is too refined. These divisions lack sharp boundaries, or perhaps have no boundaries at all. To be sure, if we ask a programmer what he is doing, he will say "coding" or "debugging" without any hesitation. Moreover, the system of "progress reporting," which is in effect in most installations, tends to force people to put their work in sharper categories than really exist. In this way, people are led to believe in the reality of the categories they write on their time sheets each week.

举一个具体的例子，考虑一个项目，它有一个完成每项活动的设定日期。随着问题定义日期的临近，“问题定义”的准备工作显得非常仓促。在规定的日期，所有的定义都在项目经理的手中——但这并不意味着项目已经定义好了。这意味着定义掌握在项目经理手中。

To take a specific example, consider a project which has a set date when each of the activities will be completed. As the date for problem definition approaches, great haste is evident in the preparation of "problem definitions." At the required date, all the definitions are in the hands of the project manager—but that does not mean that the project is defined. All it means is that the definitions are in the hands of the project manager.

现在定义正式完成，分析开始。如果，也许是因为仓促的定义过程，此时在定义中发现了一些缺陷，就会发生以下两种情况之一。首先——也是最糟糕的——缺陷可能会被掩盖，因为相信定义现在是固定的。其次，定义可能会改变——在大多数情况下可能是非正式的，但需要花费时间和精力来对付“分析”。就这样，项目继续进行，从一个类别到另一个类别，没有任何后退——至少在项目经理看来是这样。他关于如何完成编程项目的模型已经叠加在项目本身上，他永远不会意识到事情并没有那么简单。这一切都造就了一个非常整洁的会计系统，

Now that definition is formally finished, analysis starts. If, perhaps because of the hasty definition process, some flaw is discovered in the definition at this point, one of two things will happen. First—and worst—the flaw may be covered up, under the belief that the definition is now fixed. Second, the definition may be changed—probably informally in most cases, but with the time and effort required being charged against "analysis." And so the project goes on, from category to category without ever a backward step—or so it seems to the project manager. His model of how a programming project is done has been superimposed on the project itself, and he never becomes aware that things are not so simple. It all makes for a very neat accounting system, but it will never do for an understanding of the psychological processes underlying success or failure of the project.

即使真的有可能将一个编程项目强制进入明确定义的阶段，这样做也可能不是一个好主意。一个项目的程序员构成混合人才，其中一些人比另一种更适合一种类型的工作。如果一次只做一种类型的工作，那一刻某些人才将得不到充分利用。此外，即使对于单独工作的个体程序员来说，故意将工作分解成不同的部分在任何时候都处于不同的阶段可能是个好主意。为什么？因为工作的进展可能会更加统一，并且更少依赖于编程环境或程序员自身气质的日常变化。

Even if it really were possible to force a programming project into sharply defined stages, it might not be a good idea to do so. The programmers on a project constitute mixed talents, some of which are better suited for one type of work than another. If only one type of work is being done at a time, certain talents are going to be underexploited at that moment. Moreover, even for the individual programmer working alone, it may be a good idea deliberately to break up the work so that different parts are in different stages at any one time. Why? Because the progress of the work is likely to be more uniform and less dependent on day-to-day variations in the programming environment or in the programmer's own temperament.

例如，考虑一下并非每一天都适合编码的想法。如果我们正在编码并意识到我们在糊涂——每前进三步后退四步——最好把编码放在一边，去做一些其他需要不同技能和可能需要不同心态的活动，例如文档。但是，如果目前唯一要做的工作是编码，那么除了完全脱离程序之外，就没有办法脱离编码。由于我们很少能够完全放弃工作——或者至少被人看到完全放弃工作——因此我们无论如何都必须尝试编码，尽管我们最了解自己。

Consider, for example, the idea that not every day is a good one for coding. If we are coding and become aware that we are muddling about—taking four steps backward for each three forward—it would be a good idea to put aside the coding for some other activity requiring a different set of skills and perhaps a different frame of mind, such as documentation. But if the only work being done at the moment is coding, there is no escape from coding except by escape from the program altogether. Since we can seldom afford to drop work altogether—or at least to be seen dropping work altogether—we would then have to try coding anyway, in spite of our best knowledge of ourselves.

外部环境也每天都在变化。例如，如果计算机因安装某些新设备或修复某些硬件错误而停机，则机器测试必须完全停止，如果此时正在进行的所有事情都是机器测试，那么进度就会令人沮丧地停止。如果同时进行多个阶段，我们只需转向其他活动。

The external environment also varies from day to day. If, for instance, the computer is down for installation of some new equipment or for fixing some hardware bug, machine testing must cease altogether, if all that is going on at the moment is machine testing, then progress grinds to a frustrating halt. If there are a number of phases in progress at once, we merely turn to some other activity.

“锁步”编程的另一个结果是，在任何给定时刻，某些设施可能会超载，而其他设施却处于闲置状态，程序测试对机器时间的需求最大，如果每个人都在测试同时，机器可能超载。文档给秘书人员带来了很大的负担。那些在机器超负荷运行测试时无所事事地等待工作的秘书现在发现自己被打字淹没了，比如每个人都同时开始记录。而且因为项目中的某些人是编程某些阶段的专家，所以他们也时而空闲时而忙得不可开交。

Another consequence of "lock-step" programming is that, at any given moment, certain facilities are likely to be overloaded at the same time others are lying fallow, Program testing makes the biggest demands on machine time, and if everyone is testing at the same time, the machine may be overloaded. Documentation puts a big load on the secretarial staff. The same secretaries who were idly waiting for work while the machine was overloaded with testing runs now find themselves swamped with typing and such as everyone starts to document at the same time. And because certain people in the project are specialists in certain phases of programming, they, too, are alternately idle and swamped.

因此，理想的项目设计应避免所有部分同时处于同一编程阶段。然而，如果人们相信典型的管理文本，就会得到恰恰相反的印象。拯救我们的往往是这些阶段之间缺乏真正的界限，因此在问题定义过程中已经进行了一些调试，而在调试过程中仍在进行一些问题定义。优秀的程序员也会有意识或无意识地进行同样的“抹黑”，因此当他在一个活动领域遇到障碍时，他会切换到另一个活动领域。事实上，一个糟糕的程序员的一个标志是，当机器出现故障并且他无法运行他的程序时，人们会发现他无所事事。如果他不能完成今天安排的一件事，

The ideal project design, then, would avoid having all its parts in the same stage of programming at the same time. However, if one were to believe typical management texts, one would get precisely the opposite impression. What saves us, more often than not, is the lack of true boundaries between these stages, so a little debugging is already going on during problem definition and a little problem definition is still going on during debugging. The same kind of "smearing" is done by the good programmer—whether consciously or unconsciously—so that when he runs into an obstacle in one area of activity he switches to another. Indeed, one mark of a poor programmer is that he can be found sitting around doing nothing whenever there is machine trouble and he cannot get his programs run. If he can't do the one thing scheduled for today, he is lost.

当然，并不是每个人在所有事情上都同样擅长，我们喜欢做我们最擅长的事情。例如，普遍无法书写简单的英语，无疑解释了为什么文档是一种普遍的溃烂疮。即使没有别的事可做，做文档也绝不是自愿的选择。我们可以尝试安排我们项目的工作，让每个人都专注于他最擅长的事情，但这种方法至少有两个缺点。首先，我们可能会发现没有人做文档工作；其次，没有人会学到很多东西。

Of course, not everybody is equally good at all things, and we like to work on the things we do best. The widespread inability to write plain English, for instance, no doubt explains why documentation is a universal festering sore. Even when there is nothing else to do, doing documentation is never a voluntary alternative. We can try to arrange the work of our project so each person specializes in what he does best, but this approach has at least two drawbacks. First of all, we probably will find nobody to do the documentation work; and, second, nobody will learn very much.

另一方面，我们可以通过分配每个程序员成为他最不擅长的那部分工作的专家来最大化学习率。通过这种方式，我们也可以确保每个人在遇到障碍时都会抓住机会切换到其他任务。

We can, on the other hand, maximize the rate of learning by assigning each programmer to be a specialist in that part of the work he does least well. In this way, also, we can ensure that each one will jump at the opportunity to switch to some other task when he runs into a snag.

在“编程”的标题下，不同类型工作的多样性也导致了编程心理学研究中的某种夸大。如果我们测试一个小型编程项目的性能，那么结果很可能受工作某个阶段的性能支配。例如，在一个强调对细节的细致关注的问题中，某些程序员会表现出明显优于其他人的优势。如果所提出的问题需要能够坐下来并从广泛的角度看待事物，情况可能会自行逆转。因此，我们很可能有两项研究显示出 30 比 1 的性能差异。

The multiplicity of different types of work under the rubric of "programming" also accounts for a certain exaggeration in psychological studies of programming. If we test for performance on a small programming project, the results are likely to be dominated by performance on one phase of the work. For instance, in a problem which emphasizes painstaking attention to detail, certain programmers will show a marked superiority to others. The situation might reverse itself if the problem posed required the ability to sit back and take the broad view of things. Therefore we could well have two studies which showed thirty-to-one differences in performance.

然而，当我们让这些相同的程序员解决一个更大的问题时，我们可能会发现这些极端差异减少了，因为现在每种类型的程序员都会发现一些适合他的部分，而一些部分不适合他。对于更大的问题——比如我们在上一节中报告的——我们更有可能发现二比一或三比一的差异。而且，在许多情况下，甚至这些差异也不再归因于程序员之间的差异，而是某些外部因素。并不是说程序员没有差异，只是这些差异在一个需要各种态度和技能的项目中得到了平均。

When we put these same programmers on a somewhat larger problem, however, we may see these extreme differences reduced, for each type of programmer now finds some parts that are suited to him and some parts not. With larger problems then—such as we reported in the previous section—we will more likely find differences of two-or three-to-one. Even these differences, moreover, are no longer attributable to differences among the programmers, but to certain external factors, in many cases. Not that the programmers do not differ, but simply that these differences average out over a project requiring all sorts of attitudes and skills.

尽管如此，如果我们知道如何利用它，那么 30 比 1 的比例还是有一定道理的。这个比例可能代表了程序员在编程工作的不同阶段的能力差异。因此，一个项目不是将工作量划分为程序而是划分为工作类型可能会实现如此巨大的生产力收益。请注意，这正是练习无私编程时发生的情况；只要程序员“拥有”程序而不是“拥有”编程阶段，我们就不会实现这些潜在收益。

All the same, there is a certain truth in the thirty-to-one ratio, if we but knew how to exploit it. This ratio is probably representative of the differences in ability among programmers—in different stages of programming work. Thus, a project dividing the effort not into programs but into types of work might realize gains in productivity of this magnitude. Notice this is precisely what happens when egoless programming is practiced; and as long as programmers "own" programs rather than, possibly, "owning" programming stages, we are not going to realize these potential gains.

有了这个论点，我们又回到了原点，回到试图区分程序员所做的真正不同类型的活动的尝试。即使承认经典划分之间的模糊界限，我们也能够在进行过程中进行一些富有成效的细分。例如，考虑测试阶段。我们可以立即分离出至少三种不同的活动（从心理学的角度来看），它们集中在这个单一的标题下：

With this argument, then, we come the full circle, back to the attempt to isolate the truly different kinds of activity programmers do. Even acknowledging the fuzzy boundaries between the classical divisions, we will be able to do some fruitful subdividing as we go along. For example, consider the testing stage. We can immediately isolate at least three different activities (from a psychological point of view), which are lumped under this single title:

• 检测错误的存在。

• Detecting the presence of errors.

• 定位已知存在的错误。

• Locating errors which are known to exist.

• 更正我们发现的错误。

• Correcting errors we have found.

从广义上讲，这三种活动可能需要不同的技能和性格特征组合。要检测错误，程序员必须有一种纵容的头脑，一种乐于发现曾经被认为是美丽和完美所在的缺陷的头脑。也许有点偏执狂会有所帮助——那种自动联想到最坏情况的想法。

In a very broad way, these three activities could require different combinations of skills and personality traits. To detect errors, the programmer must have a conniving mind, one that delights in uncovering flaws where beauty and perfection were once thought to lie. Perhaps a touch of paranoia helps—the kind of thinking that automatically conjures up the worst imaginable case.

然而，对于定位错误，我们需要一个具有婆婆的坚持和一群老鼠的收集本能的人。例如，在一个项目中，操作系统中的一个错误已知存在了六个月，直到一位程序员最终找到它，他保存了那段时间的所有垃圾——三叠九英尺高的纸！深夜时分，人们会发现他在仔细检查自己的垃圾——寻找、摸索、翻找一些可能逃过夏洛克·福尔摩斯眼睛的细微线索。几个月过去了，然后，在一次垃圾堆中，他注意到一点似乎不太对劲。回来后，他翻遍了所有其他垃圾场，直到他又翻出了两起案件，然后是五起，然后是数百起案件中的一打。他把这十二个案子摆在一张大桌子上，先是一种模式，然后是另一种模式，

For locating errors, however, we want a person who has the persistence of a mother-in-law and the collecting instincts of a pack rat. In one project, for instance, a bug in the operating system was known to exist for six months before it was finally tracked down by one programmer who had saved every dump taken in that period—three nine-foot stacks of paper! Late at night he could be found poring over his dumps—searching, groping, rummaging about for some slight clue that would have escaped the eye of a Sherlock Holmes. Months went by, and then, in one dump, he noticed a single bit which didn't seem quite right. Back he went through all the other dumps, until he had ferreted out two more cases, then five, then a dozen out of the hundreds. These twelve cases he arranged on a large table, first in one pattern, then another, until some threads of connection became visible.

到这个时候，他的头脑已经非常专注于手头的案例，以至于他试图向其他人解释他的假设是徒劳的。在他看来，其中一个数据通道——当某些条件恰到好处时——正在其地址寄存器的一个位置上拾取一个位，从而导致单个字符被存储在其规则序列之外。由于此错误通常发生在大数据块的中间，因此杂散字符通常会被块中的后续字符擦除，但在少数情况下（十二个），该字符恰好在块末尾之后被发现。他试图说服工程师，但他们不听。程序员总是说有机器错误。所以，最后，他构建了一个程序，以更高的频率迫使频道进入正确的环境。然后，当他使错误更规律地发生时，他能够足够精确地定义环境，从而在原理图上准确地找到肯定有错误的电路卡。工程师们对他的勤奋印象深刻，所以他们最终准许他对卡片进行测试——结果发现他是对的！

By this time, his mind was so specialized to the cases at hand it was fruitless for him to try to explain his hypothesis to anyone else. It seemed to him that one of the data channels—when certain conditions were just right—was picking up a bit in one of the positions of its address register, thus causing a single character to be stored out of its regular sequence. Since this error usually occurred in the middle of a large data block, the stray character was usually wiped out by subsequent characters in the block, but in a few cases—the twelve—the character was found just past the end of the block. He tried to convince the engineers, but they would not listen. Programmers always say there are machine errors. So, finally, he constructed a program that would force the channel into just the right circumstances with an increased frequency. Then, when he made the error occur with more regularity, he was able to define the circumstances with enough precision to find on the schematic exactly the circuit card that must be in error. The engineers were impressed with his diligence, so they finally granted him a test of the card—and found that he was right!

这样的编程侦探不会因为他们的发现而获得巴斯德或索尔克的名声。尽管如此，他们对工作本身感到满意——超出普通人的理解。然而，这样一个发现错误的天才在发现错误后可能会相当无能为力——事实上，发现的错误对他来说已经失去了兴趣。如果被迫进行更正，他通常会在原处引入一个更粗糙的错误，或者创建一个笨拙且低效的补丁。对于以某种优雅的方式适合程序的更正，需要另一种类型的程序员。
