Anyone who has ever tried proofreading is aware of this type of set phenomenon, and anyone who has ever tried to locate a mistyped word in a computer program is more than just aware—he is scarred. In such tasks as proofreading, it is hard to measure the difficulty in overcoming the effects of set, for texts sufficiently perfect to serve as standards and sufficiently difficult to simulate actual conditions are difficult to obtain. Not so in computer programs, for the computer provides an automatic testing ground for the efficacy of proofreading.

计算机可以针对其自身程序中的此类错误进行的测试具有相当微妙和强大的范围。在范围的最简单端是对无法识别的语法、拼写错误的关键字和格式错误的常量的测试。符号表、交叉引用列表和流分析提供的交叉检查类型更深入了一步，但本质上仍然是静态的。未初始化变量的动态检查、流跟踪和子例程调用跟踪有助于清除可能已经通过其他级别筛选的印刷错误。然而，没有任何自动系统可以保证定位所有这些错误，我们可以期望在编写程序或设计语言时通过注意心理事实来取得一定的改进。

The testing a computer can provide for this type of error in its own programs has quite a range of subtlety and power. On the simple end of the range lie the tests for unrecognizable syntax, misspelled keywords, and ill-formed constants. The type of cross-checking provided by symbol tables, cross-reference lists, and flow analyses go one step deeper, but are still essentially static. Dynamic checking for uninitialized variables, flow-tracing, and subroutine call-tracing contribute to cleaning up such typographical errors as may have sifted through the other levels. Nevertheless, no automatic system can be guaranteed to locate all such errors, and we may expect certain improvements by attention to psychological facts when the programs are written or languages are designed.

与“集合”的概念相关的是“距离”的概念。并非所有的误读都同样可能发生，不管读者的情况如何。因此，与“dack”相比，“daxk”更不容易被误认为“duck”，因为读者将不得不进行两个字母转换，而不是一个。在信息论中，两个“消息”——可以被认为是比特串——有一个“距离”，可以通过计算它们不同的比特位置的数量来获得。该度量的重要性在于它指示将一条消息转换为另一条消息必须更改的位数——如果传输中存在噪声，可能会发生这种情况。

Related to the concept of "set" is the concept of "distance." Not all misreadings are equally likely, regardless of the set of the reader. Thus, "daxk" is less likely to be mistaken for "duck" than was "dack," because the reader will have to make two letter transformations instead of one. In information theory, two "messages"—which may be taken to be strings of bits—-have a "distance" that can be obtained by counting the number of bit positions in which they differ. The importance of this measure is that it indicates the number of bits that would have to be changed to transform the one message into the other—as might happen if noise were present in the transmission.

对于编程语言的符号，就像自然语言中的单词一样，这种简单的“距离”度量只能作为一个符号不会被误认为另一个符号的可能性的第一近似值。例如，心理测试表明，首字母和末尾字母在区分时更为重要。因此，与“daxk”相比，“gucr”被视为“duck”的可能性要小得多，即使它们与“duck”的区别恰好有两个字母。此外，不能假定每对符号与其他对之间的距离相同。尽管确切的关系必须取决于所使用的打字稿，但“x”和“k”等字母对似乎比“x”这样的字母对更容易混淆

For the symbols of a programming language, just as for the words in a natural language, such a simple measure of "distance" can only be taken as a first approximation to the likelihood that one symbol will not be mistaken for another. For instance, psychological tests have shown a tendency for initial and final letters to be more significant in making distinctions. Thus, "gucr" would be much less likely to be seen as "duck" than would "daxk," even though they each differ in exactly two letters from "duck." Moreover, each pair of symbols cannot be assumed to be the same distance apart as each other pair. Although the exact relationship must depend upon the typescript used, letter pairs such as "x" and "k" would seem to be more readily confounded than such pairs as "x" and "o."

新手程序员学到的第一课就是仔细区分他手写的“零”和“哦”，如果其他人正在键入他的程序。这种谨慎在计算机出现之前就存在了，当时排版是使用活字块手工完成的。一个特别常见的错误是选择字母的镜像——d 代表 b，b 代表 d。从这个实践中，我们得出了这样的表达：“注意你的 p 和 q！”

One of the first lessons the novice programmer learns is to make careful distinction between his handwritten "zero" and "oh," if someone else is keying his program. This sort of caution existed before computers, when typesetting was done by hand using slugs of movable type. One particularly common error was to pick a letter's mirror image—d for b, and b for d. From this practice, we derived the expression: "Mind your p's and q's!"

不幸的是，大多数程序员在养成有助于克服编程风险的集合的习惯方面，从未超越这一点。例如，无论一个人在符号“ST0P”中写得多么仔细，它都会被误认为整行都是“哦”。“STOP”和“ST0P”之间的心理距离是如此之小——因为零和 oh 的相似性，单个不同字母的中间位置，以及符号内的集合使我们强烈偏向英语单词——习惯性地做出如此糟糕的符号选择的程序员将走向某些灾难。

Most programmers, unfortunately, never advance much beyond this point in developing habits that will facilitate the conquest of set as a programming hazard. For example, no matter how carefully one writes the zero in the symbol "ST0P," it will be mistaken for an "oh" all along the line. The psychological distance between "STOP" and "ST0P" is so slight—because of the similarity of the zero and oh, the middle position of the single differing letter, and the set within the symbol which strongly biases us toward the English word—the programmer who habitually makes such poor symbol choices is headed for certain disaster.

毫无疑问，检测此类错误的自动方法取得的广泛成功使许多程序员在选择符号时变得粗心大意。尽管如此，总会有一些情况，编译器或解释器无法做出错误的明智结论。在一个案例中，一位程序员在同一代码中同时使用了符号“SYSTSTS”和“SYSSTSTS”，并且在运行了数百小时的错误模拟后才发现一个被另一个替换了，出版了一本书包含这些结果，以及一些系统基于它们的错误而被错误设计。如果他采用在他的符号之间保持两个（不同的）字符的最小距离的做法，所有这一切都是可以避免的，

No doubt, the rather extensive success of automatic methods of detecting such errors has lulled many programmers into carelessness when choosing symbols. Nonetheless, there will always be some situations in which the compiler or interpreter cannot make a sensible conclusion that there is an error. In one case, a programmer had used both the symbols "SYSTSTS" and "SYSSTSTS" in the same code and only discovered that one had been substituted for the other after hundreds of hours of erroneous simulations had been run, a book had been published containing these results, and several systems had been mis-designed on the basis of their errors. All this could have been avoided if he had adopted the practice of keeping a minimum distance of two (dissimilar) characters between his symbols, and perhaps ensuring that at least one of these differences was at the beginning or end.

助记符特别容易引起程序阅读器的迟钝。由于以下几个原因，助记符号使我们容易被误读：

Mnemonic symbols are particularly susceptible of inducing a torpor in the program reader. Mnemonic symbols expose us to misreading for several reasons:

• 他们倾向于使程序看起来“明智”，因为他们满足于我们对理智而不是胡说八道的普遍看法。

• They tend to make programs seem "sensible" by their satisfaction of our general set toward sense over nonsense.

• 他们利用我们相信名字的倾向，而不是名字的含义。谁会相信符号“五”表示值 4？但它确实发生了，在一个情况下，程序员不得不修改他的代码并且没有时间将所有引用更改为“五”。然而，他确实有时间重新运行程序——在花了很多时间找到困难的根源之后。

• They play upon our tendency to believe in the name, rather than the denotation of the name. Who would believe that the symbol "FIVE" denoted a value of 4? But it did, in one case where the programmer had to modify his code and didn't have time to change all references to "FIVE." He did, however, have time to rerun the program—after having taken much time to locate the source of difficulty.

• 他们倾向于给出一些不符合最佳“距离”模式的东西。例如，英语单词不是字母的随机集合。一些模式，如辅音-元音-辅音，或辅音-元音-元音-辅音，往往出现得更频繁。更糟糕的是，“LEAD”和“LEAD”等同形异义词可能会从两个不同的来源出现在同一程序中。

• They tend to give something less than an optimal "distance" pattern. English words, for example, are not random collections of letters. Some patterns such as consonant-vowel-consonant, or consonant-vowel-vowel-consonant, tend to occur more frequently. Even worse, there are homographs such as "LEAD" and "LEAD," which might pop up in the same program from two different origins.

由于我们缩写方式的规律性，最佳距离进一步缩短，导致诸如“PEND”（表示处于待定状态的记录）和“PEND”（“P 部分结尾”的缩写）等歧义。

Optimal distance is further reduced because of regularities in the way we abbreviate, leading to such ambiguities as "PEND," for a record that is held in pending status, and "PEND," short for "end of part P."

我们不能在不评论评论的情况下放弃设置错误的主题。评论的整个想法是让读者做好准备，以便正确解释评论所附的说明或陈述。如果注释所引用的代码是正确的，那么注释可能以这种方式有用；但如果它碰巧不正确，注释借出的集合只会降低检测到错误的可能性。

We cannot abandon the subject of set errors without a comment on comments. The whole idea of a comment is to prepare the mind of the reader for a proper interpretation of the instruction or statement to which it is appended. If the code to which the comment refers is correct, the comment could be useful in this way; but if it happens to be incorrect, the set which the comment lends will only make it less likely that the error will be detected.

注释对解释错误代码的这种影响可以在一个实验中很好地测量，在这个实验中，产生了相同代码的多个版本，一个有正确的注释，一个有一两个错误的注释，一个可能根本没有注释（冲本，1970）。至少对于某些类型的代码，可以更可靠、更快速地获得对程序所做的正确解释，而无需任何注释。与使用不正确或误导性注释的情况相比，正确的注释如果构造得当，可以减少错误。尽管如此，许多有经验的程序员在仔细检查程序列表中的错误时养成了覆盖所有注释的习惯，从而减少了集合，虽然这有助于理解正确的程序，但只会使本已不可能完成的调试工作变得更加复杂。

This effect of comments on interpretation of erroneous code can be measured quite nicely in an experiment in which several versions of the same code are produced, one with correct comments, one with one or two incorrect comments, and one with perhaps no comments at all (Okimoto, 1970). For certain types of code, at least, correct interpretation of what the program does can be obtained more reliably and faster without any comments at all. Correct comments, if well constructed, reduce errors when compared with cases in which incorrect or misleading comments are used. Nevertheless, many experienced programmers make a habit of covering all comments when scrutinizing a program listing for errors, thus reducing set which, though helpful to understanding a correct program, only complicates the already impossible job of debugging.

问题解决的一些维度

SOME DIMENSIONS OF PROBLEM SOLVING

在心理学中，“集合”通常被认为是“知觉”研究的一部分，而不是“智力”的一部分。然而，从前面的部分应该清楚，集合现象可以影响我们肯定会标记为“解决问题”的行为。当然，在解决问题之前，还有回避问题的问题。正如我们所看到的，有许多技术可以让程序员在某些情况下完全避免 set 的问题。抽象地考虑，完全避免问题的程序员比自己解决问题的程序员更“聪明”，无论他最终是否“解决”了问题。

In psychology, "set" is usually considered part of the study of "perception" rather than part of "intelligence." Yet it should be clear from the preceding section that set phenomena can influence behavior which we would surely label "problem solving." Of course, even before the question of problem solving comes the question of problem avoiding. As we saw, numerous techniques exist whereby a programmer can avoid the problems of set altogether in certain situations. Considered in the abstract, a programmer who avoids a problem altogether is more "intelligent" than one who brings it upon himself, whether or not he ultimately "solves" it.

然而，关于智力的抽象概念很少符合我们对具体情况的看法。由于缺乏任何客观的衡量标准，我们通常会根据程序员的工作努力程度来判断程序的难度。使用这种衡量标准，我们很容易相信最差的程序员是最好的——因为他们工作如此努力。一个恰当的例子是一名程序员，他每周工作 7 天，每天工作 14 小时，持续八周，以使一个小程序在新安装中运行。由于他的努力，他的公司授予他卓越服务奖。此后不久，另一位程序员（因为第一个被提升为管理职位作为额外奖励）被赋予了对该程序进行一些更改的工作。

However, abstract ideas about intelligence rarely fall into accord with our beliefs about concrete situations. Lacking any objective measure, we often judge how difficult a program is by how hard a programmer works on it. Using this sort of measure, we can easily fall into believing that the worst programmers are the best—because they work so hard at it. A case in point was a programmer who worked 14 hours a day, seven days a week, for eight weeks to get a small program running in a new installation. For his efforts, his company gave him an award for exceptional service. Shortly thereafter, another programmer (for the first had been promoted to a management position as an additional reward) was given the job of making some changes to this program. He found the program to be such a confusing mess it was easier to rewrite it than to try and modify it.

重写和调试只用了一个星期，正常工作时间。即使考虑到第二次编写程序比第一次编写程序要容易得多，差异还是很大的。此外，新程序的运行速度比旧程序快八倍，占用的存储空间减少一半，代码行数减少一半。显然，第一个程序员因小题大做了而获得了奖励。这种滥用管理慷慨的发现导致该编程组的士气严重下降。

The rewriting and debugging took exactly one week, working normal hours. Even considering that writing a program for the second time is far easier than writing it the first, the difference is significant. Moreover, the new program ran eight times faster than the old, took half the storage, and was half as many lines of coding. Clearly, the first programmer had been rewarded for making a mountain out of a molehill. The discovery of this misapplication of management largesse then led to a severe drop in morale in this programming group.

因此，回避问题的行为是最高的智能行为，尽管如果一个人试图吸引训练有素的经理的眼球，它就不是很智能。总是很难理解我们没有遇到多少麻烦。

Problem-avoiding behavior, then, is intelligent behavior at its highest, although not very intelligent if one is trying to attract the eye of a poorly trained manager. It will always be difficult to appreciate how much trouble we are not having.

同样，总是很难欣赏真正出色的解决问题工作。一旦显示了问题的解决方案，就很容易忘记解决问题之前存在的困惑。一方面，问题困难的最常见原因之一是忽略了某些因素。一旦我们发现或被告知这个因素很重要，找出解决方案就很简单了。如果我们将问题呈现给其他人，我们通常会将那个因素呈现给他，这会立即为他解决十分之九的问题。他无法想象我们为什么会遇到这样的麻烦，很快我们就开始怀疑自己。

Similarly, it will always be difficult to appreciate a really good job of problem solving. Once the problem solution has been shown, it is easy to forget the puzzlement that existed before it was solved. For one thing, one of the most common reasons for problem difficulty is overlooking some factor. Once we have discovered or been told that this factor is significant, working out the solution is trivial. If we present the problem to someone else, we will usually present him with that factor, which immediately solves nine-tenths of the problem for him. He cannot imagine why we had such trouble, and soon we begin to wonder ourselves.

忽略问题中的一个因素只是导致我们误入歧途的假设的一个特例。我们假设某个因素并不重要——可能甚至没有以任何有意识的方式思考它。我们同样误入歧途，假设某个因素对手头的问题没有意义，但它很重要。花很多时间调试别人程序的人很快就会学会在解决问题之前不要听解释。这样的解释往往会使听众陷入同样的​​错误假设轨道，从而阻止演讲者自己找到错误。

Overlooking a factor in a problem is just one special case of assumptions leading us astray. We assume that a certain factor is not important—probably without even thinking about it in any conscious manner. We are led similarly astray by assuming that a certain factor is important, when it has no significance for the problem at hand. People who spend much time debugging other people's programs soon learn not to listen to explanations before tackling the problem. Such explanations tend to put the listener on the same false track of assumptions that prevented the speaker from finding the bug for himself.

当然，心理定势是做出假设的另一种形式。虽然在这种情况下假设可能被埋得更深，但它们对解决问题的作用是一样的。那么，难道我们不能说解决问题的首要规则是“不要做假设”吗？

Psychological set, of course, is another form of making assumptions. Although the assumptions may be buried more deeply in this case, they have the same effect on problem solving. Could we not say, then, that the first rule of problem solving is "don't make assumptions"?

我们可以这么说，但我们完全错了。如果我们要成功地解决问题，我们必须做出假设。如果我们真的把每个问题都当作全新的来面对，就不可能提高我们解决问题的能力。例如，我们拥有的这套书使我们能够像阅读错误一样阅读错误，就好像它是正确的一样，在大多数情况下都是最有价值的资产。只有当我们进行校对时，我们中很少有人花很多时间去做，这组特定内容才会引起麻烦。因此，智能行为并不在于回避假设，而是在于足够灵活以根据场合需要操纵假设。换句话说，聪明并不是拥有可以应用于所有问题的神奇公式。相反，它有许多“公式”，而不是太爱一个，以至于不能放弃另一个。

We could say that, but we would be precisely wrong. If we are to be successful at solving problems, we must make assumptions. If we really faced each problem as entirely new, it would be impossible to improve our problem-solving performance. The set we have, for example, which enables us to read a misprint as if it were correct, is a most valuable asset—in most situations. Only when we are proofreading, something few of us spend much time doing, does this particular set cause trouble. Intelligent behavior, then, does not consist in eschewing assumptions, but in being sufficiently flexible to manipulate assumptions as the occasion demands. In other words, being intelligent is not having some magic formula which one can apply to every problem. It is, rather, having a number of "formulas" and not being so much in love with one that it cannot be dropped for another.

在我们离开解决问题的适应性主题，仔细研究成功的问题解决者有选择地应用的一些“公式”之前，我们必须消除另一个关于智力的谬误。智能，无论最终如何定义，充其量只是一个统计概念。我们永远不能希望通过在一个特定问题上的表现来衡量智力，因为获得“正确”解决方案的非智能原因与获得“错误”解决方案的智能原因一样多。事实上，一些程序员对成功的解释让人想起了中了每月彩票的村里白痴的故事。当被要求解释他是如何选择中奖号码时，他说，“嗯，我的幸运号码是七，这是今年的第七次彩票，

Before we leave the topic of adaptability in problem solving for closer examination of some of the "formulas" selectively applied by the successful problem solver, we must lay to rest one more fallacy about intelligence. Intelligence, however it is ultimately defined, is, at best, a statistical concept. We cannot ever hope to measure intelligence by performance on one particular problem, for there are as many non-intelligent reasons for getting the "right" solution as there are intelligent reasons for getting the "wrong" solution. Indeed, the explanations for success given by some programmers bring to mind the story of the village idiot who won the monthly lottery. When asked to explain how he picked the winning number, he said, "Well, my lucky number is seven, and this was the seventh lottery this year, so I multiplied seven times seven and got the winning number—63."

而且，当有人试图告诉他七乘以七等于四十九时，他只是不屑地回答，“哦，你只是嫉妒”——当然，这是真的。

And, when someone tried to tell him that seven times seven was forty-nine, he merely answered with disdain, "Oh, you're just jealous"—which, of course, was true.

编程智能的各个方面

FACETS OF PROGRAMMING INTELLIGENCE

因此，适应性是各种智能行为所必需的。尽管是智力行为，但只需要执行一组固定规则的行为就不能被恰当地认为是智能的。由机器执行比由人执行可能更好。并不是说执行一套固定的规则就不能成为智能行为的重要组成部分。相反，如果一个程序员不费吹灰之力就不能将两个数字相加，那么他在解决问题的竞赛中就处于严重障碍，当然，除非他通过开发绕过他无法完成的算术运算的捷径来将他的障碍转化为资产。

Adaptability, then, is required for all sorts of intelligent behavior. Behavior which, though mental, only requires carrying out a set of fixed rules is not properly considered intelligent. It might better be carried out by machines than by people. Not that carrying out a set of fixed rules cannot be an important part of intelligent behavior. On the contrary, a programmer who cannot add two numbers together without extraordinary difficulty is heavily handicapped in the race for better problem solving, unless, of course, he turns his handicap into an asset by developing shortcuts that bypass the arithmetic he cannot do.

在很大程度上，解决问题的技巧是特殊的，即使只是因为某些人在某些事情上比其他人做得更好。每个人，如果他是聪明的，都倾向于寻找解决方法，这些方法取决于他最好的品质并避免最弱的品质。作为这种品质的具体示例，请考虑内存方面。

To a great extent, problem-solving technique is idiosyncratic, if only because certain people can do certain things better than others. Each person, if he is intelligent, tends to look for methods of solution that depend on his best qualities and avoid his weakest. As a specific example of such a quality, consider the facet of memory.

毫无疑问，记忆力是程序员最重要的智力方面之一——如果他能利用它的话。记忆力以多种方式帮助程序员，其中最重要的一点是，当他面前没有所有论文时，记忆力可以帮助他“解决”问题。想想一个程序员讲述的关于他如何躺在床上解决问题的轶事：

There is no doubt that memory is one of the most important aspects of intelligence for a programmer—if he can but harness it. Memory helps a programmer in many ways, not the least of which is by enabling him to "work" on problems when he does not have all his papers in front of him. Consider this anecdote related by a programmer about how he solved a problem while lying in bed:

这个问题是我昨天早上在计算中心遇到的一个程序员给我的。他说他从去年四月（现在是一月）就遇到了问题。问题不是很严重，但从那以后就断断续续地困扰着他，他试过所有方法都没有用。这是一个 PL/I 程序，问题出在输出格式上。他建立了一个 ON ENDPAGE 单元，但它只在第一页的末尾和由 SIGNAL 引发时起作用。在第一页之后，列表只是一页一页地继续，而没有产生他想要的标题。

The problem was given to me by a programmer I encountered yesterday morning at the computing center. He said he had the problem since last April (it is now January). The problem was not very serious, but it had puzzled him on and off since then, and everything he tried failed to work. It was a PL/I program, and the trouble was in the format of the output. He had established an ON ENDPAGE unit, but it only worked at the end of the first page and when it was raised by SIGNAL. After the first page, the listing just went on from page to page without producing the headings he wanted.

 

我检查了他使用的 PAGESIZE 和他的作业控制卡——看他是否有一些奇怪的回车控制情况。我检查了 ON-unit 的位置，但显然它正在执行一次。里面有开关吗？没有什么。我发现的唯一不寻常的事情是他使用了 PUT SKIP 来打印标题，而不是像我通常那样使用 PUT PAGE。我向他指出，这就解释了为什么他打印的标题未能出现在页面顶部。但是，在测试了许多其他假设之后，我知道我不会找到主要问题。我向他展示了他如何获得正确的输出，使用 LINENO 测试来提高 ENDPAGE。这让他很满意，但我知道在我弄清楚发生了什么之前我无法安心。

I checked the PAGESIZE he was using, and his job control cards—to see if he had some strange carriage control situation. I checked the position of the ON-unit, but obviously it was executing once. Were there any switches in it? Nothing. The only unusual thing I found was that he had used a PUT SKIP to print the heading, not a PUT PAGE as I ordinarily do. I pointed out to him that this explained why the heading he had printed failed to go on the top of the page. But, after testing a number of other hypotheses, I knew I wasn't going to find the major trouble. I showed him how he could get the right output, using a test of LINENO to raise ENDPAGE. That satisfied him, but l knew l couldn't put my mind at rest until I understood what was happening.

 

我把这个问题抛诸脑后，但昨晚睡觉时，我的思绪似乎很清晰，所以我决定躺在那里继续研究它。我在心里重建了整个情况——编码和输出。当我闭上眼睛，在一个安静的地方时，我可以调出我正在处理的任何程序的图片——即使是像这样的，我只看过一次的程序。我在脑海中扫描输出并试图想象什么样的程序会产生这个输出。在回顾了我早上的假设并在仔细考虑的基础上拒绝了每一个假设之后，我决定寻找新的东西。

I put the problem out of my mind, but when I went to bed last night, my mind seemed clear, so I decided to work on it as I lay there. I reconstructed the whole situation mentally—the coding and the output. When my eyes are closed and I am in a quiet place, I can call up the picture of any program I am currently working on—even one like this, which I had seen only once. I scanned the output in my mind and tried to imagine what kind of program would produce this output. After reviewing my hypotheses from the morning and rejecting each on carefully considered grounds, I decided to look for something new.

 

奇怪的元素，我在扫描程序时感觉到，是 ON 单元中的 PUT SKIP。我越频繁地扫描它，它在我的图像中越突出，因为我从来没有这样做过。绝不？在那种情况下，也许是造成差异的原因。但是为什么以不同的方式开始一个页面会导致错过页面的结尾呢？那么，如何检测页面的结尾呢？从顶部开始有这么多行。但是top是怎么确定的呢？我意识到我不知道确切的答案，所以我推测了可能的替代方案。到这个时候，我知道我走在了正确的道路上，我只是依次考虑了每个备选方案，想象每个方案在这个程序中会产生的行动。

The strange element, I felt in scanning over the program, was the PUT SKIP in the ON-unit.This stood out in my image the more frequently I scanned it, for I never did that. Never? In that case, perhaps it was causing the difference. But why would starting a page in a different way cause the end of the page to be missed? Well, how is the end of a page detected? By being so many lines from the top. But how is the top determined? I realized I didn't know that answer precisely, so I speculated on possible alternatives. By this time, I knew I was on the right path, and I simply considered each alternative in turn, imagining the action each would produce in this program.

 

最后，当我在假设只有 PAGE（或者可能是 LINE，在本例中不适用）可以开始一个新页面的假设下完成操作时，我意识到了这个问题。ON 单元中的 PUT SKIP 并没有开始新的页面——行号只是不断增加并且没有到达新的页面末尾，因为没有开始新的页面。心满意足地解决了问题，我马上就去睡觉了。今天早上，我做了这个测试用例来证明我的猜想，你看，果然如我所说。

Finally, when I worked through the action under the hypothesis that only PAGE (or possibly LINE, which did not apply in this case) could start a new page, I realized the problem. PUT SKIP in the ON-unit did not start a new page—the line number simply kept increasing and no new end of page was ever reached because no new page had ever been started. Satisfied that I had solved the problem, I went immediately to sleep. This morning, I made this test case to demonstrate my conjecture, and you can see that it is precisely as I say.

 

如果没有良好的记忆力，这个程序员可能永远也解决不了这个问题——也学不到新东西——因为他可能再也不会看到这个程序了。另一方面，如果他没有这种记忆力，他可能永远不会尝试用这种方法来解决问题。相反，他可能会利用他在创建关键测试用例方面的聪明才智来使用计算机解决问题。由于他的记忆力不足，他会用问题程序的实际副本来代替——这没什么好丢脸的。

Without the aid of a fine memory, this programmer might never have solved this problem—and learned something new—because he might never have seen this program again. On the other hand, if he did not have this kind of memory, he probably never would have attempted this approach to the problem. He might, instead, utilize his cleverness at creating critical test cases to solve the problem using the computer. For his inadequate memory, he would substitute an actual copy of the problem program—which is nothing to be ashamed of.

事实上，通过在机器上解决问题，这个记忆力差的程序员可能在回家之前就找到了问题的解决方案，让他的睡眠不受错误影响。哪种方法更优？我们确实不能孤立地给出答案。例如，如果机器访问很差，第二个程序员就会处于劣势。另一方面，如果每个人都在加班加点，几乎没有时间睡觉，更不用说安静的反思，第一个程序员将​​永远无法展现自己的才华。自然地，最好是两种能力同等程度地具备，并因地制宜、因地制宜地加以运用。除此之外，我们必须充分利用我们所拥有的。

Indeed, by attacking the problem on the machine, this poor-memory programmer might have the solution to the problem before going home, leaving his sleep untroubled by bugs. Which method is superior? We really cannot give an answer in isolation. If, for example, machine access is poor, the second programmer will be at a disadvantage. If, on the other hand, everyone is working overtime and barely has time for sleep, let alone quiet reflection, the first programmer will never get to show his brilliance. Naturally, it would be best to have both abilities to an equal extent and to apply each as is appropriate to the problem and the overall situation. Short of that, we must make the best of what we have.

正如不同的工作条件有利于应用不同形式的智能行为一样，不同的编程阶段也给了不同的程序员大放异彩的机会。例如，我们在进行程序的总体设计时，最需要的是能够创造出新的编程思想，并根据大的原则进行筛选。这种筛选思路的例子有结构的对称性和功能的通用性——一个导致困难问题的简单编码，另一个导致困难问题的简单编码解决。尽管如此，如果缺乏应用它们的想法，这些关键能力就毫无用处。“无”不能批评。因此，缺乏创造力或选择性的程序员将无法尝试设计程序。

Just as different working conditions favor the application of different forms of intelligent behavior, so do different programming phases give different programmers a chance to shine. For example, when we are making the overall design of a program, what we most need is the ability to create new programming ideas and to screen them on the basis of broad principles. Examples of such screening ideas are symmetry of structure and generality of function—one leads to simple coding of difficult problems and the other leads to the solution of difficult problems with simple coding. Still, these critical abilities are useless if there is a paucity of ideas to which to apply them. "Nothing" cannot be criticized. Thus, a programmer lacking in either ability—creativity or selectivity—will be handicapped in attempting to design programs.

然而，在编码时，不同的能力脱颖而出。现在，精通小事的头脑不再是宽广的头脑。然后，在测试时，程序员必须切换到另一组天赋——尤其是完整性之眼，或格式塔。考虑以下故事：

When coding, however, different abilities come to the fore. Instead of the broad, sweeping mind, the mind which is clever at small things now excels. Then, when testing, the programmer must switch to yet another group of gifts—particularly the eye for wholeness, or gestalt. Consider the following tale:

我一边吃早餐，一边阅读斯蒂芬·斯彭德 (Stephen Spender) 的一篇文章，名为“诗歌的创作”。在第 120 页，我读到一节的末尾，放下书，在我的麦片粥上加了些糖。当我再次拿起书开始阅读“记忆”这一节时，我顿时觉得开头的第一句话有问题：

I was eating breakfast and reading an article by Stephen Spender called "The Making of a Poem." On page 120, I reached the end of one section and set the book down to put some more sugar on my cereal. When I picked the book up again to start reading a section called "Memory," I immediately had a feeling that there was something wrong in the first sentence which started:

 

“如果以特定方式集中注意力的艺术……”

"If the art of concentrating in a particular way ..."

 

我或多或少同时感到，问题出在“特别”这个词上，而且它涉及到一个印刷错误。然而，印刷错误相当令人困惑，因为我感觉到这是一个字母倒置，但我也感觉到——虽然稍微弱一点，但我对此有明确的印象——少了一个字母。我检查了“particular”这个词——顺便说一句，我经常把它误打成“particluar”——首先是为了倒置，但没有找到，为了省略的字母。我花了相当长的时间寻找错误——我可以测量到这个错误，因为我在这个过程中吃了五六勺麦片，这是我通常在两口水之间吃的量。但我找不到任何不妥，当我伸手去拿水杯时，我有些糊涂了。

I felt, more or less simultaneously, that the trouble was in the word "particular" and that it involved a misprint. The misprint, however, was rather confusing for I sensed that it was a letter inversion but I also sensed—a little bit more weakly, though, I have a definite impression of that—that there was a letter missing. I examined the word "particular"—which, by the way, I often mistype as "particluar"—first for the inversion and, failing to find that, for the omitted letter. I spent a rather long time looking for the error—I could measure that because I ate five or six spoonfuls of cereal in the process, the amount I ordinarily eat between sips of water. But I could not find anything wrong, and when l reached for the water glass, I was rather confused.

 

水杯是空的，我放下书，走到水槽边倒水。回来后，我喝了点水，拿起书开始看。我毫不费力地读完了这一段，但当我开始阅读下一段时，我立即看到了这行：

The water glass was empty, so I set down the book and went to the sink to fill it. Upon returning, I drank some water, picked up the book, and started to read. I finished the paragraph without further difficulty, but when I commenced reading the next, I immediately saw that the line:

 

“所有的诗人都有这种高度发达的敏感器官……”

"All poets have this highly devolped sensitive apparatus ..."

 

包含“devolped”一词的印刷错误，该词在该句中的位置与“特定”在前一段第一句中的位置相同。我有正确的印象，但我错误地“聚焦”了。

contained the misprint of the word "devolped," which stood in the same position in that sentence as "particular" had stood in the first sentence of the preceding paragraph. I had the right impression, but I had "focused" wrongly.

 

虽然这个错误是在打印时出现的，但它的发现和定位非常接近于发现许多编程错误的过程。首先，只有格式塔，一种没有任何特定定位的东西不合适的一般感觉。然后是摆脱不屈不挠的局面的能力——改变观点的能力，甚至可以使用外部设备，例如去喝杯水。然后，然而，必须从一般到特殊——“聚焦”，就像这里所说的那样。虽然通过详细搜索每一行、每个单词或每个字符并不能有效地发现错误，但归根结底，掌握细节的能力是必不可少的。因此，为了调试，需要一组几乎互补的智力。难怪好的调试器如此稀有！

Although this error was in printing, its discovery and location followed very closely the process by which many programming errors are found. First, there is only the gestalt, a general feeling that something is out of place without any particular localization. Then follows the ability to shake loose from an unyielding situation—the ability to change one's point of view, even by employing external devices such as going for a glass of water. Then, however, one must go from the general to the particular—"focusing," as it was called here. Although one does not find errors efficiently by a detailed search of each line, or word, or character, the ability to get down to details is essential in the end. Thus, for debugging, an almost complementary set of mental powers is needed. No wonder good debuggers are so rare!

更罕见的是良好的记录文档困难来自许多来源。首先，如果程序写得不好，文档也无能为力。由于程序员通常会记录他们自己的作品，因此优秀的文档编写者首先必须是一名优秀的程序员——然后他必须增加口头和图形表达自己的能力。最后，他必须有耐心解决文档中最后的几个歧义——因为最后 5% 的工作使文档 100% 变得更好。

Even more of a rarity is the good documented Documentation difficulties come from many sources. In the first place, if the program is not well written, there is not much that documentation can do to resuscitate it. Since programmers usually document their own productions, the good documenter has to be a good programmer to begin with—and then he must add the capacity to express himself verbally and graphically. Finally, he must have the patience to work out those last few ambiguities in his documentation—for the last 5 percent of the work makes the document 100 percent better.

能力测试

APTITUDE TESTS

如果智力对于编程的成功如此重要，那么如何选择那些具备完成这项工作所需的人才呢？对选定的程序员进行测试的可能性长期以来一直让编程经理着迷，但多年来，没有人能够证明各种“程序员能力”测试中的任何一个都物有所值。然而，如果我们不尝试探索造成这种普遍失败的原因，那我们就是失职了。

If intelligence is so important for programming success, what can be done to select those people who have what it takes to do the job? The possibility of administering tests to select programmers had long bewitched programming managers, but over the years nobody has ever been able to demonstrate that any of the various "programmer's aptitude" tests was worth the money it cost for printing. We should be remiss, however, if we did not attempt to explore the reasons for this universal failure.

首先，当然，编程是一项多样化的活动，任何给出单一“等级”的测试都不足以衡量所需的能力。一些测试被设计为给出多个分数，但即使这些测试具有单独有效的措施，它们也很难明智地应用，而普通的人事经理根本不会费心。而且，正因为多维性，一个人在某一方面极度不足的人可能在另一方面很突出——前提是有机会发挥他的长处。另一方面，有时一个在所有可能的量表上都得分很高的人表现不佳是因为他缺少一些“次要”能力，比如与同事相处的能力。

In the first place, of course, programming is a diverse activity, and any test that gives a single "grade" is hardly adequate to measure the aptitudes required. Some tests have been designed to give multiple scores, but even if these had individually valid measures, they would be difficult to apply sensibly, and the average personnel manager simply would not bother. Moreover, just because of the multidimensionality, someone who is sorely deficient in one area may turn out to be outstanding in another—provided that the opportunity to use his strong points exists. On the other hand, sometimes a person who scores high on every possible scale performs poorly because he is missing some "minor" ability, such as the ability to get along with the people he has to work with.

然而，这些都是理论上的推测，因为还没有人组织过具有任何可衡量有效性的测试。与验证程序员的能力倾向测试最接近的是研究表明，在测试中得分高的人在随后的程序员培训中是更好的学生。然而，当它深入到实际编程的本质时，测试分数和额定性能之间没有相关性——甚至是轻微的负相关性。

These are theoretical conjectures, however, because nobody has put together a test with any measurable validity. The closest thing we have to a validation of a programmer's aptitude test are studies which show that people who scored high on the test were better students in the ensuing programmers' training. When it got down to the nitty-gritty of actual programming, however, there was no correlation—or even a slight negative correlation—between test scores and rated performance.

这张遗憾的图片并不是编程独有的。一般来说，智力测试——比如著名的 IQ 测试——能够预测学校类情况下的成功——而在其他情况下则无济于事。事实上，正如一位智者所说，智力测试衡量的是参加考试的能力。我们有理由相信，这一评价与事实相去不远。例如，在智商测试中，速度是一个非常重要的因素，就像在学校一般情况下一样。但是，在办公室里，一小时和一小时十分钟的区别只是十分钟——而不是 A 和 C 之间的区别。缓慢和稳定可能不会赢得比赛，但编程不是比赛。

This sorry picture is not unique to programming. Intelligence tests generally—such as the famous IQ tests—are able to predict success in school-type situations—and in nothing else. In fact, as one wit put it, intelligence tests measure the ability to take tests. We have reason to believe that this appraisal is not far from the truth. For example, in IQ tests, speed is very much a factor, as it is in school situations generally. But, in the office, the difference between one hour and one hour and ten minutes is only ten minutes—not the difference between an A and a C. Slow and steady may not win the race, but programming is not a race.

智力测验的另一个典型的扭曲是他们强调短期——而不是长期——记忆。考虑到必须对其进行管理的限制，很难指望它们会做其他事情。在智商测试中，要求一个人记住无意义的单词或任意列表。但在“现实生活”中，选择性记忆是有回报的——忘记不重要的事情并长期记住重要的事情的能力。然而，在学校不是这样，所以我们有智商测试和学校成绩齐头并进——与我们感兴趣的任何事情都朝着不同的方向发展。

Another typical distortion of intelligence tests is in the emphasis they place on short-term—rather than long-term—memory. They could hardly be expected to do otherwise, given the constraints under which they must be administered. In an IQ test, one is asked to memorize nonsense words or arbitrary lists. But in "real life," it is selective memory which pays—the ability to forget the unimportant and retain the important over long periods. Not so in school, however, and so we have the IQ test and the school grades going hand in hand—off in a different direction from anything we are interested in.

最后，这直接进入了我们的下一个主题，IQ 分数和程序员的能力倾向分数显然与某些形式的培训相关。在大城市里，热心的家长可以带孩子找一位专门的家教，保证他的智商提高那么多点，花那么多钱。某些编程学校使用相同的技术来帮助他们的毕业生在那些严重依赖能力倾向测试的公司找到工作。因此，无论我们多么希望拥有一根能指出最佳程序员前景的魔杖，我们都将不得不学会没有它。

Finally, and this leads right into our next topic, IQ scores, and programmer's aptitude scores, are demonstrably correlated with certain forms of training. In big cities, an eager parent can take his child to a special tutor who guarantees to raise his IQ by so many points for so many dollars. The same techniques are used 'by certain programming schools to help their graduates get jobs with those companies that rely heavily on aptitude testing. So, no matter how much we would like to have a magic wand which would point out the best programmer prospects, we are just going to have to learn to do without.

编程能力测试

APTITUDE TESTS FOR PROGRAMMING

所有这些都导致了特定的测试，这些测试已被用于衡量编程能力的重大尝试。其中最重要的可能是所谓的 PAT，即程序员能力测试。实际上，这不是一个单一的测试，而是 1956 年之前的某个时候，IBM 纽约科学计算中心的一组程序员在一个空闲的下午组成的原始测试的未知数量的变体，并在那里对所有求职者和感兴趣的访客进行了管理. 出现大量变体的原因之一是该测试被广泛使用并且没有受到保护，以至于没有人知道有多少人接受了它，或者特别是哪些人接受了它。

All of this leads up to specific tests that have been used in a grand attempt to measure aptitude for programming. Probably the foremost among these is the so-called PAT, or Programmer's Aptitude Test. Actually, this is not a single test, but an unknown number of variants on an original test made up one idle afternoon by a group of programmers in IBM's New York Scientific Computing Center sometime before 1956, and administered there to all job applicants and interested visitors. One of the reasons for the profusion of variants is that the test has been so widely used and so unprotected that nobody knows how many people have taken it, or, in particular, which people have taken it.

并不是说变体提供了很多保护，因为从一种变体到另一种变体的学习有相当大的转移。在涉及 IBM 和其他程序员的一系列课程中，我要求人们报告他们参加 PAT 变体的次数以及他们的分数。由于这是一个“安全”的情况——没有人的工作受到威胁——所以有理由相信这些答复并不太不准确。在不止一次参加过 PAT 的 27 人中，有 23 人在他们最后一次参加考试时获得了 A——他们都是在将 A 视为重要招聘标准的公司工作的受雇程序员。其中，12 人第一次获得 A，7 人获得 B，4 人获得 C。上次没有人比第一次做得更糟。

Not that the variations give much protection, since there is considerable transfer of learning from one variant to another. Over a series of classes involving IBM and other programmers, I asked people to report the number of times they had taken a variant of the PAT and what their scores had been. Since this was a "safe" situation—with nobody's job at stake—there is reason to believe that the replies are not too inaccurate. Out of 27 people who had taken the PAT more than once, 23 received A's the last time they took the test—they were all employed programmers working for companies which regarded A's as an important hiring criterion. Of these, 12 had A's the first time they took it, 7 had B's, and 4 had C's. Nobody had done worse the last time than the first.

一个典型的案例是一位在 IBM 工作的女性程序员，她大学毕业时主修数学，并申请了 RCA 的编程工作。他们给了她 PAT，她得了一个“低”B。她没有得到这份工作，所以她接受了 IBM 的面试，IBM 进行了一个略有不同的测试版本，她得到了一个明确的 A。她有人问她以前是否参加过 PAT，她（聪明地）说“没有”，于是她被录用了。

A typical case was a woman working for IBM as a programmer who had graduated from college with a Math major and applied to RCA for a programming job. They had given her the PAT, and she had scored a "low" B. She didn't get the job, so she interviewed with IBM, who administered a slightly different version of the test, on which she scored a clear A. She was asked whether she had ever taken the PAT before, and she (intelligently) said "no," whereupon she was hired.

以前使用 PAT 的经验可能是研究人员无法将 PAT 绩效与工作绩效相关联的原因之一。已经报道了一些相关性（参见 Reinstedt，1964 年），但我们必须谨慎对待在这些情况下我们认为“重要”的东西。例如，在这些研究中发现的最佳相关性是 PAT 与主管排名之间的 0.7。0.7 相关性意味着什么？

This previous experience with the PAT may be one reason researchers have been unable to correlate PAT performance with job performance. A few correlations have been reported (see Reinstedt, 1964), but we must be careful as to what we regard as "significant" in these cases. For example, the best correlation found in these studies was 0.7 between the PAT and supervisor's ranking. What does 0.7 correlation mean?

对于一项研究，两个变量之间的 0.7 相关性意味着 (0.7)**2 —0.49，或一个变量中 49% 的变异可以由另一个变量解释——尽管它没有说明哪个是哪个。即使相关系数是一种“解释”，仍然有超过一半的变化需要解释。相关系数流行的原因之一是它似乎夸大了情况，因为使用的数字总是大于它的平方。

For a single study, a 0.7 correlation between two variables means that (0.7)**2 —0.49, or 49 percent of the variation in one variable can be accounted for by the other—although it doesn't say which is which. This still leaves more than half of the variation to be explained, even if the correlation coefficient were an "explanation." One of the reasons for the popularity of the correlation coefficient is the way it seems to overstate the case, since the number used is always larger than its square.

这种相关性的第二个问题是分数——足够确定——与主管的排名相关，至少可以说，这是衡量程序员绩效的一个不确定指标。今天确实没有任何工具可以衡量程序员的表现——或者将它简化为一个数字，无论如何。因此，没有真正可靠的东西可以关联 PAT。PAT 甚至可能是程序员性能的一个了不起的预测器，但主管们本身并没有经过足够的培训来了解它。

The second problem with such correlations is that the score—which is definite enough—is correlated with the supervisor's ranking, which is an uncertain measure of programmer performance, to say the least. There really is no instrument today for measuring programmer performance—or reducing it to a single number, in any case. Consequently, there is nothing really reliable with which to correlate the PAT. It may even be that the PAT is a marvelous predictor of programmer performance, but the supervisors are not themselves sufficiently trained to know it.

在使用这种相关性时，我们还必须警惕另一件事。没有人知道人们曾多少次尝试将 PAT 与工作绩效相关联。那些尝试过但没有获得“显着”结果的人往往不会发表他们的试验。我们知道有类似的试验，因为在考试成绩和学校成绩之间发现了相关性（Biamonte，1964 年，Gotterer，1964 年）。但是，你看，如果有足够的机会进行关联，如果数据是随机的，我们最终会得到一些高于我们想要的水平的相关系数。因此，我们可以说 0.56 的相关性偶然会出现，不超过一百次，但如果我们不知道已经进行了多少次试验但没有报告，我们就无法评估这样的说法。然而，我们确实知道，

We must also be wary of one other thing in using such correlations. Nobody knows how many times people have tried to correlate the PAT with job performance. Those who did try and did not obtain "significant" results more often than not would not publish their trial. We know of similar trials because correlations have been found between test scores and school grades (Biamonte, 1964, Gotterer, 1964). But, you see, if given sufficient chances to correlate, we will eventually get some correlation coefficient above any level we desire, if the data are random. Thus, we could say that a correlation of 0.56 will arise, by chance, no more than one time in a hundred, but if we do not know how many trials have been made and not reported, we have no way of evaluating the significance of such a statement. We do know, however, that the PAT is used in hundreds of places.

此外，即使试验只进行了几次，但 0.56 的相关性 100 次偶然出现一次也假定真正的相关性为零。如果有一个小的正相关，比如 0.1，那么 0.56 的虚假测量值将比一百次更频繁地出现。但是 0.1 的相关性意味着 1% 的变化是由相关性引起的，这几乎不是我们可以用来做出人事决策的信息类型。

Furthermore, even if the trials have only been made a few times, a correlation of 0.56 occurring one time in a hundred by chance assumes that the true correlation is zero. If there is a small positive correlation, say of 0.1, then a spurious measure of 0.56 will occur more frequently than one time in a hundred. But a correlation of 0.1 means that 1 percent of the variation is accounted for by the correlation, and this is hardly the type of information we can use to make personnel decisions.

假设相关性是可靠的，根据记录的文献，我们没有比 PAT 更好的工具。不可否认，它确实可以很好地预测编程课程的分数，但这并不是我们在雇用程序员时所购买的。正如 Mayer (1968) 所说的那样，

Assuming that the correlations were reliable, we have, on the basis of the recorded literature, no instrument any better than the PAT. Admittedly, it does predict scores in programming classes fairly well, but that is not what we are buying when we hire a programmer. As Mayer (1968) puts it so well,

如果您使用所有测试来选择一个人，您很有可能 [原文如此] 找到一个很有可能成功完成您的培训计划的人。这个人是否会喜欢编程，或者是否有动力让他在工作现场接受成功的培训，这是一个尚未回答的问题。

Very probably if you would use all of the tests to select an individual, you can [sic.] obtain a person who has a high probability of successfully completing your training program. Whether this individual is going to like programming or will possess the motivation that will allow him to take the successful training onto the job site is a question that is not yet answered.

 

即使是这种谴责也意味着测试就目前而言可能还不错，但其他因素在工作中可能比纯粹的“能力”更重要。虽然我们不能对这个结论有异议，但我们认为可能忽略了一种可能性——即这些测试对于程序员能力来说并不是很好的测试。鉴于 PAT 的历史，人们想知道为什么有数百家公司年复一年地盲目地使用它。对测试本身的结构进行一些检查可能会给我们一些关于它有什么问题的提示，既然我们知道它有很多问题。

Even this condemnation implies that the tests may be all right as far as they go, but that other factors may be more important on the job than pure "aptitude." Although we can not quarrel with the conclusion, we think a possibility may have been overlooked—namely, that the tests are just not good ones for programmer aptitude. Given the history of the PAT, one wonders why so many hundreds of firms use it slavishly, year after year. A little examination into the structure of the test itself might give us some hints as to what is wrong with it, now that we know that much is wrong with it.

最初的 PAT 包含三个部分：几何图形的关系规则（很像标准 IQ 系列）、算术推理和数字系列。前两个在 PAT 的几乎所有变体中都得到了保留，尽管数字系列经常被字母系列所取代。只是想知道可能出了什么问题，请考虑字母或数字系列问题，其中一个典型的问题可能是 (1 4 7...)，要求考生提供系列中的下一个数字。回答“10”需要一点智力当然是合理的，但这真的是我们最需要程序员的能力吗？

The original PAT had three sections: relationship rules for geometric figures (much like standard IQ series), arithmetic reasoning, and number series. The first two have been retained in almost all of the variants of the PAT, although the number series has often been replaced by letter series. Just to get an idea of what might be wrong, consider the letter or number series problems, a typical one of which might be (1 4 7...) where the examinee is asked to supply the next number in the series. It is certainly plausible that a modicum of intelligence is required to answer "10", but is this really the ability we most need in a programmer?

让我举一个例子，说明一个优秀的程序员是如何处理这样一个系列的。一个 FORTRAN 程序是用语句编写的

Let me give an example of what a good programmer did with such a series. A FORTRAN program had been written with the statement

DO 15 I = 10000, 30000, 10000 程序进入了一个奇怪的循环，这个循环最终结束了，但产生了没人能破译的输出。当它被带到这个程序员面前时，他想了想，然后问自己在什么情况下这个特定的 DO 不会产生系列 10000 20000 30000 。. .

DO 15 I = 10000, 30000, 10000 The program went into a strange loop which finally ended but produced output that nobody could decipher. When it was brought to this programmer, he thought for a while and then asked himself under what circumstances this particular DO would not produce the series 10000 20000 30000 . . .

突然他意识到，如果将数字保存在 15 位寄存器中，则系列中的下一个数字将是 7232，系列将如下所示：

Suddenly he realized that if the numbers were being kept in a 15-bit register, the next number in the series would be 7232, and the series would look something like this:

10000 20000 30000 7232 17232 27232 。. . 这准确地解释了该程序的问题所在。

10000 20000 30000 7232 17232 27232 . . . which explained precisely what was wrong with the program.

换句话说，PAT 测试的是在一系列数字或字母中看到常规模式的能力，但程序员，尤其是在调试时，必须精确地寻找非常规模式——偏差。对于程序员能力来说，更好的问题类型可能是这样的：

In other words, the PAT tests for the ability to see the conventional pattern in a series of numbers or letters, but the programmer, especially when debugging, has to look precisely for the unconventional pattern—the deviations. Possibly a much better type of question for programmer aptitude would be something like this:

“给定数列 (1 4 7...) 说出通常预期的下一个数字是什么，然后描述至少三个其他可能正确的选择，并给出每个选择的理由。”

"Given the series (1 4 7...) tell what might normally be expected as the next number, and then describe at least three other choices which might be correct, giving reasons for each choice."

 

PAT 的另一部分是算术推理，但我从来没有人能够向我解释为什么程序员必须擅长算术。也许在 1956 年之前算术更为重要，当时大多数编程都比今天更接近机器语言。如果您使用的是一种相对粗糙的语言，那么能够将两个或三个十六进制数相加以便您可以在转储中找到一个地址是很有用的，但是今天有多少程序员这样做呢？难道我们没有电脑只是为了不用做算术吗？我自己从来没有能够快速地添加 7 和 5，但我不认为这是阻碍我成为程序员的原因。事实上，我知道我不太擅长算术，我对我的程序和我的校验计算更加怀疑——这迫使我对它们进行更多测试。

Another section of the PAT is arithmetic reasoning, but I have never had anyone who has been able to explain to me why programmers have to be good at arithmetic. Perhaps before 1956 arithmetic was more important, when most programming was done much closer to machine language than it is today. If you are working in a relatively crude language, it is useful to be able to add two or three hexadecimal numbers so that you can find an address in a dump, but how many programmers do that today? Don't we have computers just so we don't have to do arithmetic? I myself have never been able to add 7 and 5 rapidly, but I don't think that is the thing holding me back as a programmer. In fact, knowing I am not very good at arithmetic, I am more suspicious of my programs, and of my check calculations—which forces me to do more testing of them. It would be rather easy to make an argument that poor arithmetic ability is an asset to a programmer.

PAT 的第三部分让我完全不知所措。即使在 1956 年，几何关系似乎也与编程能力没有多大关系，但也许我没有抓住要点。编程在当今世界似乎不存在的一件事是几何。我从来没有见过一个程序员被要求判断两个程序旋转 90 度后是否相同。（曾经有一篇关于回文程序的文章，前后读起来一样，但是对这个行业的贡献很小。）

The third part of the PAT leaves me entirely befuddled. Even in 1956, geometric relationships never seemed to have much to do with programming aptitude, but perhaps I missed the point. The one thing that programming doesn't seem to be in today's world is geometric. I've never met a programmer who was asked to tell whether two programs were the same if one was rotated 90 degrees. (There was once an article about palindromic programs, which read the same forward and backward, but its contribution to the profession was minor.)

如果人们要坚持使用这些能力测试，也许是时候对这些能力测试进行一些新思考了。他们会坚持下去，因为即使成功的希望不大，回报也很大。因此，让我提出一些可能对识别潜在的成功程序员更有意义的事情：

Perhaps it is time that some new thinking go into these aptitude tests, if people are going to persist in using them. And persist they will, since even if the promise of success is not great, the rewards are. So let me suggest a few things that might make more sense for identifying potentially successful programmers:

1. 给考生三十或四十张随机打印的试卷，让他分装在十个盒子里。一周后，让他找到写有“COMMODITY”字样的那张纸。为他的检索性能计时——给快速工作的高分。

1. Give the examinee thirty or forty papers with random printing on them and ask him to place them in ten boxes. One week later, ask him to find the paper with the word "COMMODITY" on it. Time his retrieval performance—giving high scores for fast work.

2. 给出上面建议的系列异常类型的问题。

2. Give the series-exception type question suggested above.

3. 告诉他你在想一个他必须解决的问题。除非他特别要求，否则不要给他更多信息，而是按字面意思回答他的所有问题。为他找出问题所在的程度打分。

3. Tell him you are thinking of a problem which he must solve. Don't give him any more information unless he specifically asks for it, but answer all his questions literally. Score him on how well he figures out what the problem is.

我真的对这样的测试不抱太大希望——要么它们会起作用，要么如果它们起作用就会被应用——但它们看起来肯定比我们目前使用的更有希望。

I don't really have much hope for such tests—either that they will work or that they will be applied if they do work—but they certainly seem more promising than what we have been using so far.

然而，一切并没有那么黯淡。当我们在经验丰富的程序员中进行选择时，情况可能会有所不同，尽管似乎很少有作者或员工意识到这一点。例如，在一项调查中使用 PAT 的 282 个组织中，有 138 个组织仍然使用它来选择有经验的程序员。为什么？因为他们觉得自己一无所有。由于缺乏更好的东西，他们尝试了可用的东西，徒劳地寻找难以捉摸的魔法测试。对于那些带着一揽子承诺而来的人来说，这样的公司就像坐着的鸭子——而且有很多坐着的鸭子，猎手还会落后吗？

Yet all is not quite so bleak. When we are selecting among experienced programmers, the situation is potentially different, although few authors or employees seem to realize it. For example, out of 282 organizations using the PAT in one survey, 138 of them still use it for selecting experienced programmers. Why? Because they feel they have nothing else. Lacking anything better, they try what is available in a vain search for the elusive magic test. Such companies are sitting ducks for anyone who comes along with a fancy package of promises—and with lots of sitting ducks, can the hunters be far behind?

不是很远——比我想象的还要近。写完上面的包后，我在一本行业杂志上看到了下面的广告：

Not very far—even closer than I thought. After writing the above package, I ran across the following ad in a trade magazine:

测试程序员的技能

TEST THE SKILLS OF YOUR PROGRAMMERS

 

称为 XYZ 的程序由旨在评估程序员技能的程序、软件、指令和问题组成。XYZ 衡量编写正确、紧凑和高效程序的能力，可用于测试有经验的程序员或评估非专业人士的编程能力程序员。使用的测试与语言无关，并根据问题的难度和解决问题所用的时间来加权。XYZ 程序将在 RST 系统上运行。它的售价为 5,000 美元……”

A program called XYZ consists of procedures, software, instructions and problems designed to evaluate programmer skills.XYZ measures the ability to write correct, compact, and efficient programs, and can be used to test experienced programmers or to evaluate the programming aptitude of non-programmers. The tests used are language independent, and are weighted in accordance with the difficulty of the problems and the time used to solve them. The XYZ program will run on a RST System. It is priced at $5,000 ..."

 

对这则广告的评估留给读者作为练习，但除了它声称要测试有经验或没有经验的程序员外，当它谈到“正确编写的能力，紧凑、高效的程序。” 这句话说明了什么？

An evaluation of this ad is left as an exercise for the reader, but aside from its claim to test experienced or inexperienced programmers alike, it does offer one clue as to the proper direction for testing when it speaks of the "ability to write correct, compact, and efficient programs." What does this phrase suggest?

正如一位作者评论的那样，如果我们为管弦乐队聘请双簧管演奏者，我们将能够进行试镜，这将在几分钟内确定他的资格，至少在拒绝明显不合适的情况下。经过较长时间的表演后，我们将对双簧管演奏者的能力有一个比较好的衡量标准。然后他继续感叹，“没有相当于试镜的编程”。但是为什么没有呢？对于没有经验的人来说当然没有，但是对于申请双簧管演奏培训的孩子来说也没有多少。

As one author comments, if we were hiring an oboe player for an orchestra, we would be able to give an audition, which would determine in a matter of a few minutes what his qualifications were, at least insofar as rejecting an obvious misfit. After a longer performance, we would have a moderately good measure of the oboist's abilities. He then goes on to lament, "There is no equivalent of an audition" for programming. But why isn't there? Certainly there is not for a person without experience, but neither is there much for a child who is applying for a traineeship in oboe playing.

对于一个声称有经验的程序员，为什么不让他坐下来写一个小程序，或者阅读和解释一组规范，勾画出他的实现方法呢？为什么不呢？也许是因为我们很少阅读程序，所以我们从来没有想过这个动作，或者也许是因为当我们打算雇用一个“有经验”的程序员时，即使只有一个申请人出现，我们也认为自己很幸运。测试单身申请人就像测试你的妻子——如果她失败了，你打算怎么办？

For a programmer who claims to have experience, why not just have him sit down and write a small program or read and interpret a set of specifications, sketching out his approach to implementing them? Why not, indeed? Perhaps it is because we so rarely read programs that this action never occurs to us, or perhaps it is because when we intend to hire an "experienced" programmer, we deem ourselves lucky if even a single applicant shows up. Testing a single applicant is like testing your wife—if she fails, what are you going to do about it?

概括

SUMMARY

每个参与招聘程序员的人都对优秀程序员的基本素质有自己的看法——尽管我们知道编程不是一项单一的活动。如前所述，Mayer 认为他的“X 因素”与能力有关。然而，他们中的一些人像 EW Dijkstra 一样明确地说明了他们的 X 因素，他说：

Everybody involved in hiring programmers has an opinion about what qualities are essential to a good programmer—even though we know that programming is no one single activity. Mayer, as cited previously, believes that his "X-factor" is related to aptitude." He speaks wisely, with the caution of one heavily involved in psychological testing. People more involved in programming are more confident of their impressionistic view. Not all of them, however, are as explicit about their X-factors as E. W. Dijkstra, who said:

我从事研究生阶段的教学，培养一种“数学工程师”。我所知道的对申请者成为我的学生之一的最有力的测试是他对他的母语有绝对的掌握：你只需要听他说。

I am engaged In teaching, at graduate level, in producing one variety of "mathematical engineer." The most powerful test that I know of for an applicant to be one of my students is that he have an absolute mastery of his native tongue: you just need to listen to him.

 

由于 Dijkstra “从事教学”，我们不能太受他的话的影响，因为他可能确实像其他几位工作者一样孤立了学术成功的一个因素。“口头表达能力”与我们在编程方面的学术成功一样是一个很好的衡量标准，因此 Dijkstra 的直觉可能是一个很好的直觉。但是对于实际的编程性能，在商业程序而不是“玩具”程序上，我们根本缺乏任何能力测度，除了一般智能。就我自己而言，我认为与性格、工作习惯和训练无关的是智力。与智力不同，这些东西可以通过以后的生活经验来改变，这将问题从选择程序员变成了创造他们。换句话说，优秀的程序员是后天培养出来的，而不是天生的；

Since Dijkstra is "engaged in teaching," we cannot be too swayed by his remarks, for he may indeed have isolated a factor in academic success, as have several other workers. "Verbal ability" is as good a measure as we have of academic success in programming, so Dijkstra's intuition is probably a good one. But for actual programming performance, on commercial programs rather than "toy" programs, we lack any aptitude measure at all, except perhaps for general intelligence. For myself, I believe that intelligence has less to do with the matter than personality, work habits, and training. These things, unlike intelligence, can be changed by experience later in life, which turns the problem from one of selecting programmers to creating them. In other words, good programmers are made, not born; therefore we should turn our attention to the manufacturing, or training process.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1. 你现在在选择程序员时是否使用任何能力倾向测试，或者你的人事部门是否使用它们？如果是这样，您对它们的有效性了解多少？

1. Do you use any aptitude tests now in choosing programmers, or does your personnel department use them? If so, what do you know about their validity?

2. 你是否努力通过在工作一段时间后评估程序员来验证它们？您使用什么方法进行此评估？您对它们的有效性有多确信？

2. Do you make any effort to validate them by evaluating programmers after a period of time on the job? What methods do you use for this evaluation? How convinced are you of their effectiveness?

3. 你发现你的程序员最常缺乏的重要能力是什么？您认为什么样的测试会发现这种能力缺失？

3. What single important aptitude do you find most often lacking in your programmers? What kind of test do you think would discover that such an aptitude was missing?

4. 你会花 5000 美元购买广告中的包裹吗？还是每次测试 100 美元？如果不是，为什么不呢？如果是这样，你读过这本书吗？

4. Would you spend $5000 for the package in the ad? Or $100 per test? If not, why not? If so, have you been reading this book?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1、你应聘现在的工作时，是否进行了能力测验？如果是这样，您认为测试相关吗？您知道您的组织是否仍在使用这些测试吗？如果他们这样做，并且您认为它们不相关，那么您在做什么？

1. Were you tested for aptitude when you applied for your present job? If so, did you find the test relevant? Do you know if your organization still uses these tests? If they do, and if you feel they are not relevant, what are you doing about it?

2. 你觉得至少可以测试编程能力的某些关键方面吗？列出您认为是编程能力的关键方面的列表，以及关于如何测试它们的建议列表。

2. Do you feel it is possible to test for at least certain crucial aspects of programming aptitude? Make a list of what you consider to be crucial aspects of programming aptitude, and a list of suggestions as to how they could be tested.

3. 本章是否向您指出了您在解决问题的能力或习惯方面可能存在的不足？如果是这样，你有什么计划来做些什么？

3. Has this chapter indicated to you any areas of problem-solving ability or habit in which you may be deficient? If so, what plan do you have for doing something about it?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

Mayer、David B. 和 AW Stalnaker，在选择计算机人员时使用心理测试，SHARE/GUIDE Presentation，1968 年 10 月。

Mayer, David B., and A. W. Stalnaker, Use of Psychological Tests in the Selection of Computer Personnel, SHARE/GUIDE Presentation, October, 1968.

Reinstedt, RN, et a/., Computer Personnel Research Group Programmer Performance Prediction Study, The RAND Corporation (RM-4033-PR), Santa Monica, California, 1964 年 3 月。

Reinstedt, R. N., et a/., Computer Personnel Research Group Programmer Performance Prediction Study, The RAND Corporation (RM-4033-PR), Santa Monica, California, March 1964.

Biamonte, AJ，预测程序员培训的成功，第二届年度计算机人员研究会议论文集，计算机协会，纽约，1964 年。

Biamonte, A. J., Predicting Success in Programmer Training, Proceedings ot the Second Annual Computer Personnel Research Conference, Association for Computing Machinery, New York, 1964.

Gotterer, M. 和 AW Stalnaker，预测非预选受训人员群体中的程序员表现，第二届年度计算机人员研究会议论文集，计算机协会，纽约，1964 年。

Gotterer, M., and A. W. Stalnaker, Predicting Programmer Performance Among Non-preselected Trainee Groups, Proceedings of the Second Annual Computer Personnel Research Conference, Association for Computing Machinery, New York, 1964.

Okimoto, G. H„ The Effectiveness of Comments: A Pilot Study，IBM SDD 技术报告 TR 01.1347，1970 年 7 月 27 日。

Okimoto, G. H„ The Effectiveness of Comments: A Pilot Study, IBM SDD Technical Report TR 01.1347, July 27, 1970.

Luria, AR，《助记者的心智》，纽约，雅芳图书公司，1968 年。

Luria, A. R., The Mind of a Mnemonist, New York, Avon Books, 1968.

一个有趣的例子，说明一个人如何利用他特殊的能力或残疾来取得出色的表现——在这个例子中是涉及记忆的任务。

A fascinating example of how an individual can use his peculiar abilities or disabilities to achieve fantastic performance-—in this case on tasks involving memory.

亨特，JM，情报和经验，纽约，罗纳德，1961 年。

Hunt, J. M., Intelligence and Experience, New York, Ronald, 1961.

亨特回顾了智力发展的过程，最终看到可以做些什么来影响智力。不幸的是，当一个人到了可以成为程序员的年龄时，似乎已经失去了大部分修改的机会。也许我们应该从更年轻的时候开始。现在越来越多的编程爸爸妈妈家里都有电脑了，难道我们出一个编程莫扎特还需要很久吗？

Hunt reviews the process by which the intellect develops, with an end to seeing what can be done to influence intelligence. Unfortunately, it seems that by the time one is old enough to become a programmer, most of the opportunity for modification has been lost. Perhaps we should start younger. Now that more and more programming fathers and mothers have computers at home, can it be long before we produce a programming Mozart?

Wertheimer, M„富有成效的思维，修订版。纽约，哈珀出版社，1945 年。

Wertheimer, M„ Productive Thinking, revised ed. New York, Harper, 1945.

韦特海默是格式塔心理学派的主要创始人，在这本书中，根据他对幼儿的经验和实验，他给出了教人们如何更有效地思考的处方。很多想法似乎不太可能直接应用于教程序员更好地编程，但是这本书确实提供了关于尝试哪些事情和避免哪些事情的丰富建议。

Wertheimer is the main founder of the Gestalt school of psychology, and in this book gave his prescription—based upon his experiences and experiments with young children—for teaching people how to think more productively. It seems unlikely that many of the ideas can be applied directly to teaching programmers to program better, but the book certainly is rich in suggestions as to which things to try and which to avoid.

Polya, George，How to Solve It，普林斯顿，普林斯顿大学出版社，1946 年。

Polya, George, How to Solve It, Princeton, Princeton University Press, 1946.

波利亚是我们这个时代最伟大的数学家之一，他对解决数学问题和谜题的技术进行了通俗介绍。同样，这部作品对编程很有启发性，但没有人直接测试它，尽管许多程序员都读过它。

Polya, one of the great mathematicians of our time, gives a popular version of his work on techniques of solving mathematical problems and puzzles. Again, the work is highly suggestive for programming, but nobody has put it to a direct test, though many programmers have read it.

Ghiselin, Brewster, The Creative Process，加州伯克利，加州大学出版社，1952 年。

Ghiselin, Brewster, The Creative Process, Berkeley, California, University of California Press, 1952.

人们长期以来一直在研究“创造性过程”——至少从柏拉图和亚里士多德开始——而我们离理解它还有很长的路要走。我们甚至不知道编程是否真的需要创造力，或者莫扎特或爱因斯坦水平的创造力，或者甚至是否存在不同水平的创造力，或者只是不同水平的创造。但是对于那些怀疑编程中可能存在一些创造性元素的人来说，这一系列原创作品和摘录肯定会助​​长他们的热情。即使对于那些不相信编程创造力的人来说，他们也可能会错过阅读爱因斯坦、莫扎特、梵高、华兹华斯、柯勒律治、叶芝、尼采、荣格和斯宾塞——仅举几例——不得不说的内容的机会关于这个主题。除了，

People have been studying the "creative process" for a long time—since Plato and Aristotle, at least—and we are a long way from understanding it. We don't know, even, if programming really requires creativity, or creativity on the level of a Mozart or an Einstein, or even if there are different levels of creativity, or just different levels of creations. But for those who suspect that there may be some element of creativity in programming, this collection of original works and excerpts will certainly add fuel to their flame. Even for those who don't believe in creativity in programming, who could miss a chance to read what Einstein, Mozart, van Gogh, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Yeats, Nietzsche, Jung, and Spencer—to name but a sample—have to say about the subject. Besides, this is the source of the Stephen Spender misprint (in the paper edition).

Sackman, Harold，《人机问题解决》，普林斯顿，奥尔巴赫，1970 年。

Sackman, Harold, Man-Computer Problem Solving, Princeton, Auerbach, 1970.

Sackman 的研究不仅仅涉及编程，还涉及更一般的问题解决行为类别。他的书中包含许多关于使用计算机工作对解决问题行为的影响和缺乏影响的有用见解，但在某种程度上，他错过了编程作为解决问题的要点。萨克曼本人不是程序员，而是心理学家，他在学习中似乎从未做过的一件事就是阅读制作的程序。与大多数心理学家一样，他显然假设，同一问题的所有完整解决方案都是等价的，只有未能完成程序并获得正确结果才需要仔细考虑。但是正如我们所知，所有提供相同输出的程序都不相同，直到心理学家认识到这一点，

Sackman's studies are not concerned solely with programming, but with the more general category of problem-solving behavior. His book contains many useful insights into the effects and lack of effects that working with a computer has on problem-solving behavior, but in a certain way he misses the point on programming as problem solving. Sackman himself is not a programmer, but a psychologist, and the one thing he never seems to have done in his studies was to read the programs produced. Like most psychologists, he apparently assumes, that all completed solutions to the same problem are equivalent, and that only failures to complete a program and get the correct results need be considered carefully. But all programs that give the same output are not alike, as we know, and until psychologists recognize this, most of programming/problem-solving behavior will remain a fog.

Weinberg，GM，解决问题的实验（博士论文），安阿伯，大学缩微胶卷，1965 年。

Weinberg, G. M., Experiments in Problem Solving (Doctoral Thesis), Ann Arbor, University Microfilms, 1965.

推荐给不理解前面引文中的评论的心理学家。这项研究表明，在观察解决问题的任务时有足够的分辨率，以及根据个体主体的强弱特征来描述任务的能力如何导致对问题解决的深刻见解。如果分辨率水平仍然太高，或者如果个人被平均在一起以获得“具有统计意义的结果”，那么这样的见解将永远不可用。

Recommended for the psychologist who does not understand the commentary in the previous citation. This study shows how sufficient resolution in the observation of the problem-solving task and the ability to characterize the task in terms of the individual subject's strong and weak characteristics lead to striking insights into problem solving. Such insights will never be available if the level of resolution remains too high, or if individuals are averaged together to get "statistically significant results."

第九章：智力，或解决问题的能力的评论

Comments on Chapter 9: Intelligence, or Problem-Solving Ability

本章有一个有趣的“现在可以讲述”的历史。多年来，人们一直在问我为什么要花那么多篇幅来进行程序员能力测试，结果却得出结论说这全是胡说八道。事实上，原稿谨慎地忽略了这个主题，但手稿的两位审稿人恰好从事销售此类测试的业务。自然地，他们坚持认为这本书解决了“计算机编程中最重要的主题”。为了让我的原始出版商满意，我编写了本章中有关能力测试的部分。

This chapter has an interesting "now-it-can-be-told" history. Over the years, people have asked why I devoted so much space to programmer aptitude testing, only to conclude that it was all nonsense. The truth is the original manuscript discreetly ignored this subject but two reviewers of the manuscript happened to be in the business of selling such tests. Naturally, they insisted that the book address "the most crucial subject in computer programming." To satisfy my original publisher, I wrote the parts of this chapter addressing aptitude testing.

如今，程序员能力测试已成为一个死题（我希望如此）。如果本章在消除这种荒谬做法方面有任何作用，那么我为完成了我的工作而感到自豪。是的，智力是编程成功的一个因素——智商低于 50 的人可能不会创建操作系统（尽管他们可能会设计新的语言——魔鬼让我这么说）。

Today, programmer aptitude testing is a dead issue (or so I hope). If this chapter had any part in killing this ridiculous practice, then I take pride in having done my job. Yes, intelligence is a factor in programming success—people with an IQ less than 50 are probably not going to create operating systems (although they might design new languages—the Devil made me say that).

除了智力之外，还有许多因素会影响编程的成功（或失败）。我认识一些相当迟钝的人，他们始终能够编写出优秀、有用的代码，而一些相当聪明的人却从来没有编写过任何有用的代码。简而言之，我坚持我 25 岁的立场：“……智力与性格、工作习惯和训练的关系不大。这些东西与智力不同，可以通过经验改变在以后的生活中，这将问题从选择程序员变成了创造他们。”

There are many factors besides intelligence that contribute to programming success (or failure). I've known some rather dull people who consistently turn out fine, useful code and some rather brilliant people who never turn out any useful code at all. In short, I'm sticking with my twenty-five-year-old position: "... intelligence has less to do with the matter than personality, work habits, and training. These things, unlike intelligence, can be changed by experience later in life, which turns the problem from one of selecting programmers to creating them."

我所说的“创造他们”并不是强迫他们遵循某种“最佳”思维方式。我自己的博士论文非常清楚地表明，解决问题的方式因人而异。因此，任何迫使程序员以他人的方式思考的事情都会降低程序员解决问题的能力。因此，最大的挑战不是创造性思维，而是创造性沟通：以其他人（每个人都有独特的风格）可以理解的方式表达我们的想法。

By the words "creating them," I don't mean forcing them to follow some "best" style of thinking. My own doctoral thesis showed quite clearly that problem solving style was unique to the individual. Thus, anything that forces a programmer to think in another person's style reduces that programmer's ability to solve problems. The greatest challenge, then, is not creative thinking, but creative communicating: representing our thoughts in a way that other persons—each with a unique style—can understand.

第 10 章动机、训练和经验

Chapter 10. Motivation, Training, and Experience

 

心理学家知道，人类在给定任务上的表现是任务本身以及主体对任务的理解的函数。他们还知道，绩效会受到个性和智力等方面的个体差异的影响。但是，虽然性格可以改变，智力可以有所提高，但真正的成绩提升还得靠训练和经验。

Psychologists know that human performance on a given task is a function of the task itself as well as the task as understood by the subject. They also know that performance will be influenced by individual differences in such areas as personality and intelligence. But even though personality can be changed, and intelligence can be raised somewhat, real improvement in performance has to come from training and experience.

然而，心理学不是一门精确的科学，也不可能是。一旦心理学家考虑了任务和受试者对任务的理解，一旦他考虑了所有可测量的个体差异，一旦他考虑了所有的训练和经验，他仍然留下无法解释的表现残余. 例如，同一个人在一天后执行基本相同的任务可能会比他以前做的更糟。既然推定他的智力和性格不是一天就变了，既然他对任务的理解和经验应该只是提高了，那么怎么解释这种下降呢？

However, psychology is not an exact science, nor can it ever be. Once the psychologist takes into account the task and the subject's understanding of the task, once he has taken into account all measurable individual differences, and once he has taken into account all the training and experience, he is still left with a residue of unexplained performance. For example, the same individual doing essentially the same task a day later may do a worse job than he did previously. Since his intelligence and personality are presumed not to have changed in one day, and since his understanding of and experience with the task should only have improved, how can such a decrease be explained?

在考虑了所有其他因素之后，这种残留被称为“动机”。关于这个主题已经写了很多卷，尽管心理学家仍然怀疑动机这样的东西是否真的存在。我们已经谈到了动机的某些方面，因为它们是通过群体或团队绩效的变化来观察的，从某种意义上说，我们最好不要再打开这个潘多拉魔盒，因为我们在这里很难对其进行充分的处理。但是，出于两个原因，我们必须先谈一谈动机，然后才能谈及有关教育和培训的任何有用信息。首先，如果有可归因于动机的绩效残留，那么这种残留物就无法进行培训和教育，并限制了我们希望通过这些方式取得的成就。其次，剩下的可能就是教育和培训的全部内容。很可能如果某人没有动力，就没有简单的方法让他学习，如果有人有上进心，可能没有办法阻止他学习。

This residue, after all the other factors are taken into account, is called "motivation." Volumes have been written on the subject, even though there is still doubt in psychologists' minds whether or not such a thing as motivation really exists. We have already spoken about some aspects of motivation as they are seen through variations in group or team performance, and in a certain sense we would be better off not opening this Pandora's box again, since we can hardly give it adequate treatment here. But we must say something about motivation before we can say anything useful about education and training, for two reasons. In the first place, if there is a residue of performance attributable to motivation, then this residue is inaccessible to training and education and sets limits on how much we can hope to accomplish by these means. Secondly, the residue might be all there is to education and training. It could very well be that if someone is not motivated, there is no easy way to make him learn, and if someone is motivated, there may be no way to stop him from learning.

动机

MOTIVATION

当我阅读标准心理学文本中关于动机的部分开头的以下段落时，可能是我想到什么动机的最好例证：

Probably the best illustration of what motivation is came to me when I was reading the following passage from the beginning of the section on Motivation from a standard psychology text:

即使是对人的行为最粗略的考察也会让人断言人不是环境的被动受害者。相反，我们都很容易断言，人似乎可以决定对哪些刺激做出反应，忽略哪些刺激，获取哪些信息，忽略哪些信息。这些观察结果构成了将某种内在“导向驱动力”或“内在动力”归因于人的基础。这种内在的指导力就是我们大多数人所说的“动机”。（Krech、Krutchfield 和 Livson，1969 年）

Even the most cursory examination of the behavior of man leads one to the assertion that man is not a passive victim of circumstances. Instead, we all easily assert that man seems to decide which stimuli to react to, which to ignore, and which information to learn, which to neglect. These observations form the basis for ascribing to man some sort of an inner "directing drive" or "inner spring." This inner directing force is what most of us mean by "motivation." (Krech, Krutchfield, and Livson, 1969)

 

这段话中有趣的一课是因为这不是一本新书，而是从大学书店买来的旧书。这本书的前任主人在这段文字中，用橙色铅笔小心翼翼地在不同单词的某些字母上圈了圈。显然，这是一种涂鸦，要么是在他应该学习的时候，要么是在他应该听课的时候。当这些字母被依次读出时，他们拼出了

Now the interesting lesson in this passage arose from the fact that this was not a new book, but had been bought used from the college bookstore. The previous owner of the book had, in this passage, meticulously circled in orange pencil certain letters in various words. Evidently, it was a form of doodling, either when he was supposed to be studying or when he was supposed to be listening to the lecture. When the letters were read off in sequence, they spelled

SALLYSALLY 对于“我们大多数人所说的动机”的“内在指导力”，我们还能提供什么更好的例证呢？

S-A-L-L-Y-S-A-L-L-Y What better illustration could we give of the "inner directing force" which "most of us mean by motivation."

当然没有必要指出，程序员也可能想知道 Sally 变成了什么，而他们的经理宁愿他们想知道一些理货器变成了什么。然而，管理者犯的一个错误是认为缺乏绩效就意味着缺乏动力。因此，他们可能会尝试用一点“外在驱动力”来弥补“内在驱动力”的不足，而此时程序员正遭受太多而不是太少的痛苦。

It is certainly unnecessary to point out that programmers, too, may be wondering what's become of Sally when their managers would rather they were wondering what's become of some tally. One error that managers make, however, is to assume that a lack of performance means a lack of motivation. Consequently, they may attempt to supplement the lack of "inner driving force" with a little "outer driving force," just when the programmer is suffering from too much, rather than from too little.

动机研究最著名和公认的结果之一是，增加“驱动力”将首先将绩效提高到最大值，超过此值，进一步增加驱动力将迅速使绩效降至零。性能的快速下降在复杂任务中尤其明显，这就是它对编程如此重要的原因。比方说，过于努力地寻找错误与根本不尝试一样糟糕，或者更糟，而且许多错误只有在程序员放弃并停止施压后才能消除。迫使程序员快速消除错误可能是最糟糕的策略——但这是迄今为止最常见的策略。

One of the best known and accepted results of motivation research is that increasing "driving force" will first increase performance to a maximum, beyond which addition of further driving forces will quickly drive performance to zero. The rapid fall-off in performance is especially observable in complex tasks, which is why it is so important for programming. Trying too hard, say, to find a bug, is as bad, or worse, than not trying at all, and many bugs have been exterminated only after the programmer had given up and stopped pressing. Pressing a programmer for rapid elimination of a bug may turn out to be the worst possible strategy—but it is by far the most common.

从编程经理或程序员自己的角度来看，关于动机的第一个重要问题是，程序员已经有多大的动机了？这个问题的答案告诉我们是想办法增加还是减少驱动力。总的来说，根据我的经验，程序员作为一个群体过于积极，这是许多编程项目随着压力的增加而分崩离析的主要原因。

From the point of view of a programming manager, or of the programmer himself, the first important question about motivation, then, is how motivated is the programmer already? The answer to this question tells whether to look for ways to increase or to decrease the driving force. Overall, it has been my experience that programmers as a group are over-motivated, which is a major reason why so many programming projects fall apart as the pressure grows.

但是一旦我们确定了是否必须增加或减少力，我们能做些什么呢？个人面临的问题很可能是无法解决的，因为如果他没有动力去改变他的内在驱动力，他怎么能改变呢？但实际上，他拥有与经理相同的策略——他必须改变外部环境，才能有机会改变内部环境。

But once we have established whether force has to be added or subtracted, what can we do about it? The problem facing an individual is probably insoluble, for how can he change his inner driving force unless he is motivated to do so? Actually, though, he has available the same kinds of strategies that a manager has—he must change something in his external environment in order to have a chance of changing something inside.

当然，特定的外部变化不会在每个人群中产生相同的内部变化。在门口炫耀一位裸体女士对男性和女性的影响肯定不同。男性或女性个体会受到不同程度的影响——正如偷拍电影“你对裸体女士说什么？” 表现得如此生动。但也许作为一个群体的程序员在对外部刺激的反应上有一些共同点，就像男人，无论多么不同，通常对裸体女人都有一些反应——至少是兴趣反应。

Of course, a particular external change will not produce the same internal change in each group of people. Parading a naked lady by the door will certainly affect men differently from women. And individual men or women will be differentially affected—as the Candid Camera movie, "What Do You Say to a Naked Lady?" showed so vividly. But perhaps programmers as a group have some commonalities in their reactions to external stimuli, just as men, no matter how different, generally share some reaction to a naked lady—the reaction of interest, at least.

我们进行了一些初步研究，试图深入了解哪些外部因素会激励程序员。我们没有进行实验，在实验中我们不得不让程序员接受不同的刺激，然后观察他们的工作模式。相反，我们调查了程序员和他们的经理，了解他们认为激励程序员的因素。我们之所以强调“思想”这个词，是因为一个人所说的他所做的或将要做的或将要做的与他实际所做的之间没有必然的关系。有了这个保留，我们可以报告一些更有趣的发现。

We have made some preliminary studies to try for some insight into what external factors motivate programmers. We did not run experiments, in which we would have had to subject programmers to different stimuli and then observe their work patterns. Instead, we surveyed programmers and their managers about what they thought motivated programmers. We emphasize the word "thought" because there is no necessary relationship between what a person says he does or will or would do and what he actually does. With that reservation, we can report some of the more interesting findings.

在一家大型商店的软件程序员中，我们发现“加薪和/或奖金”会“对我的经理看到的结果产生重大影响，让我以持续快速的速度工作或让我勤奋工作。 “ 正如我们已经从社会心理学中预期的那样，紧随其后的是“个人参与我们任务的计划”。然后，并列第三的是两项——“晋升”和“更多时间让我的工作具有个人品质”。

Among software programmers at one large shop, we found that "a salary increase and/or bonus" would "make a large effect on the results my manager would see in getting me to work at a sustained fast pace or keeping me diligently at work." A very close second, as we already expected from social psychology, was "personal involvement in planning of our task." Then, tied for third place were the two items—"a promotion" and "more time to give my work a personal touch of quality."

这四个人在十九个选择中名列前茅。排在最底部的是“缩小我的工作范围”，这似乎与更多参与整体规划的倾向相吻合。就在这个选择的上方是另外四个不太受欢迎的选择。第一个是“文档、复印等方面的协助”。这似乎与普遍厌恶文档工作的民间智慧相矛盾。但这样的结论可能为时过早——可能这些人已经达到了他们根本不做文档的状态，而这个因素并不重要。四个中的第二个是“安置在一个有声望的位置”，这似乎与“晋升”相矛盾。进一步调查发现，“晋升”本质上与“

These four topped the list of nineteen choices. At the very bottom of the list was "lessening the scope of my work," which is reasonable in that it seems to jibe with the favoring of more involvement in overall planning. Just above this choice were four other low-favored choices. The first was "assistance in documentation, copying, etc." which seems to contradict the folk-wisdom about the universal distaste for documentation work. But such a conclusion may be premature—it could be that these people had already reached a state where they were not doing documentation anyway and that -factor wasn't important. Next of the four was "placement in a prestige position," which seems to contradict "promotion." Further investigation revealed that "promotion" was essentially associated with "more money," rather than the acquisition of a new title—which goes to show the difficulty of taking opinion surveys.

四个中的最后两个似乎是矛盾的：“放宽目标日期”和“收紧目标日期”。如果我们观察到这与当时目标日期对这个群体不是很重要的观点一致，那么矛盾就解决了。此时——一个重要的预选赛。在调查时，项目截止日期不在六个月内。我们希望在几个月后再次检查，看看“目标日期”是否仍在列表的底部。

The last two of the four seemed to be contradictory: "relaxation of target dates" and "tightening of target dates." The contradiction is resolved if we observe that it is consistent with the view that target dates were not very important to this group at this time. At this time—an important qualifier. At the time of the survey, the project deadline was not within six months. We would have liked to check again in several months and see if "target dates" were still at the bottom of the list.

这给我们带来了动机研究的另一个主要困难。即使这些反应确实反映了外部力量的不同强度，它们也代表了特定时间特定情况下的这些强度。在项目接近尾声时，人们的动机与开始时不同，当时目标设定已近在咫尺，而目标日期还遥遥无期。在职业生涯的早期，人们的动机与后来的不同——例如，随着储蓄的增​​加、薪水的增加以及对自己的债务逐渐还清，金钱可能变得不那么重要，或者，在某些情况下，我们已经看到，额外的金钱可以实际上让一个人失业。

Which brings us to another major difficulty with motivation studies. Even if these responses truly reflect differential strengths of outside forces, they represent those strengths in a particular circumstance at a particular time. Toward the end of a project, people are motivated differently than at the beginning when the goal-setting is at hand and the target date is far off the horizon. Early in a career, one is motivated differently than later on—money, for example, may grow less important as savings grow, salary grows, and debts to oneself are progressively paid off, Or, in certain circumstances we have seen, additional money can actually drive a man off the job.

在这一点上很容易说金钱动机不如参与目标设定和工作质量那样真实，但是没有真正的理由相信程序员作为一个群体对金钱的关注程度更低比同等薪酬水平的任何其他群体都要高。当然，与普通民众相比，程序员往往具有相当高的规模，因此我们可能认为金钱对他们的激励作用不大。它可能是，但我们还没有通过研究证明这一点。话又说回来，金钱是一种模棱两可的动机。它激励一些人作为获得他们想要或需要的东西的一种方式，一些人它激励作为对他们工作的价值的象征。但这有什么区别呢？钱就是钱，不是吗？不完全是，因为如果钱的价值更多地作为一种象征，那么除了金钱之外，程序员可能会受到其他奖励的激励——比如额外的时间来为工作赋予个人风格，或者承担一部分计划责任。请注意，这不仅仅是为了节省公司资金，而是为了更有效地激励他们，因为加薪只能在短时间内激励他们。是加薪，而不是工资水平，是当前价值的象征。在任何较长的时间间隔内，连续的一系列加薪可能是不可能的，但持续参与和持续时间进行高质量的工作也不是不可能的。因为加薪只能在短时间内激励。是加薪，而不是工资水平，是当前价值的象征。在任何较长的时间间隔内，连续的一系列加薪可能是不可能的，但持续参与和持续时间进行高质量的工作也不是不可能的。因为加薪只能在短时间内激励。是加薪，而不是工资水平，是当前价值的象征。在任何较长的时间间隔内，连续的一系列加薪可能是不可能的，但持续参与和持续时间进行高质量的工作也不是不可能的。

It would be tempting at this point to say that the money motivation is not as real as the concern with participation in goal setting and quality of the work, but there is no real justification for believing that programmers as a group are any less concerned with money than any other group at a comparable pay scale. Of course, programmers tend to be on a rather high scale compared with the general populace, so we might expect that money would be less motivating for them. And it may be, but we haven't proved it by our studies. Then again, money is an ambiguous motivator. Some people it motivates as a means of obtaining what they want or need, some it motivates as a symbol of the value placed on their work. But what difference does that make? Money is money, isn't it? Not precisely, for if the money is valued more as a symbol, then programmers could be motivated with other rewards than money—such as extra time to give work a personal touch, or a piece of the planning responsibility. That's not just to save the company money, mind you, but to motivate them more effectively, for an increase in salary only motivates for a short time. It is the raise, not the salary level which is a symbol of current value. A continuing series of raises is probably out of the question over any long interval, but continuing participation and continuing time for quality work are not out of the question at all.

任何曾经在工作中见过程序员的人——任何曾试图因错误而中断终端会话或会议的程序员的妻子或丈夫——都知道编程本身，如果程序员有机会按照他的方式去做的话，是编程最大的动力。关于象棋，有一句老话是这样说的：

Anyone who has ever seen a programmer at work—any wife or husband of a programmer who has ever tried to interrupt a terminal session or a conference over a bug—knows that programming itself, if the programmer is given a chance to do it his way, is the biggest motivation in programming. There is an old saying about chess that goes like this:
