“国际象棋，就像女人和音乐一样，有使男人快乐的力量。”

"Chess, like women and music, has the power to make men happy."

 

我想我们可以有把握地说：

I think we could safely say:

“编程，就像国际象棋、女人和音乐一样，有让男人快乐的力量。”

"Programming, like chess, women, and music, has the power to make men happy."

 

总有一天，我想，我会拿起这本书的旧本，发现有人圈出了各种字母以形成

Someday, I suppose, I will pick up a used copy of this book and find that somebody has circled various letters to form

红宝石红宝石

R-U-B-Y-R-U-B-Y

——那可能不是女朋友的名字。

—and that's probably not the name of a girlfriend.

培训、学校和教育

TRAINING, SCHOOLING, AND EDUCATION

某些人声称他们可以把任何走进门的人训练成一个称职的程序员。虽然这是一个略微有偏见的观点——因为不是任何人都会走进计算中心的大门寻找工作——但至少有一点道理。有一次，在访问一家非常成功的软件公司时，我们有机会与他们的系统编程团队一起度过了一个下午。

Certain people claim they can take any person who walks in the door and train that person to be a competent programmer. Although this is a slightly biased view—because not just anyone walks in the door of a computing center looking for a job—there is at least a grain of truth in it. Once, on a visit to a highly successful software firm, we had the opportunity to spend the afternoon with their systems programming team.

该团队的五名成员具有以下背景，使他们有资格担任高级职务：

The five members of the team had the following backgrounds to qualify them for their positions of high responsibility:

• 一名 33 岁的男子在大二时被常春藤联盟学校开除，因为他只想打桥牌。

• A man of 33 who had been thrown out of an Ivy League school in his sophomore year because all he wanted to do was play bridge.

• 一位 28 岁的女士在南部的一所私立女子学院主修西班牙文学，然后开始狂欢，三年后她在一个麻醉品恢复计划中出现，在那里她学习了编程。

• A woman of 28 who had majored in Spanish literature at a private girls' college in the South, then went on a binge from which she emerged three years later in a narcotics recovery program where she learned programming.

• 一名前计算机维护工程师，也是 28 岁，他小学毕业后唯一的正规教育是在海军电子学校。

• A former computer maintenance engineer, also 28, whose only formal education past grade school was at a Navy electronics school.

• 一位 55 岁的母亲，有五个成年孩子，三十三年前获得了师范学院学位，但结婚后从未教过书，她决定从事编程以打发孩子离开后的时间离开。

• A 55-year-old mother of five grown children who had taken a Teachers' College degree thirty-three years ago, but had gotten married and never taught—and who decided to take up programming to occupy her time when her children had gone away.

• 一名 30 岁的男子直接（以优异成绩）读完大学，获得数学硕士学位，随后他进入了编程行业。他被认为是小组中的怪人。

• A 30-year-old man had gone straight through college (with honors) to the M.A. in mathematics, whereupon he entered the programming business. He was considered the odd-ball of the group.

尽管这个群体的异质性似乎反对计算机编程培训，但实际上它只是反对将“正常”教育过程作为培训基地。这个团队的成员的共同点是在一个人（软件公司的创始人之一）的带领下一起工作了四年，他把这段时间用在塑造他们自己的形象上。

Although the heterogeneity of this group might seem to argue against training for computer programming, it is actually only an argument against the "normal" educational process as a training ground. What the members of this group had in common was four years of working together under one man—one of the founders of the software firm—who devoted that time to shaping them in his own image.

这种情况并不像听起来那么不寻常。大多数在编程领域工作了一段时间的人都可以描述他们遇到的类似群体。引人注目的因素总是相同的——在一位强大的领导者的带领下，在实际项目上合作多年。但那些年代表着训练和经验——也许不是普通或传统的那种，但同样，对我们可能取得的成就抱有希望，但我们只能提取过程的本质。

Such a situation is not as unusual as it may sound. Most people who have been around the programming scene for a while can describe similar groups they have encountered. The striking factor is always the same—several years of working together on real projects under a formidable leader. But those years represent training and experience—not, perhaps, the common or conventional kind, but all the same, holding promise of what we might achieve could we but extract the essence of the process.

阻碍教育进步的困惑之一是学校教育与教育的混淆。另一个是教育和培训的混淆。为了说明这些困惑以及它们如何阻碍进步，我想展示一些关于我自己教学有效性的结果。在几年尝试教授操作系统概念的过程中，我发现如果没有操作系统的机器经验，这些概念似乎没有力量。也就是说，我会在学生离开学校一年左右后拜访他们的工作，发现他们没有应用他们在我的课堂上“学到”的东西。

One of the confusions standing in the way of educational progress is the confusion between schooling and education. Another is the confusion between education and training. To illustrate these confusions and how they impede progress, I would like to present some results concerning the effectiveness of my own teaching. In the course of several years of trying to teach operating systems concepts, I found that without machine experience with operating systems, the concepts seemed to have no force. That is, I would visit my students on the job a year or so after they left school and find that they were not applying what they had "learned" in my classroom.

由于我将这种学习损失归因于缺乏实践经验，因此我决定将课程更改为 OS/360 中的研讨会。但在工作坊模式下，我发现学生们很难看到细节的概念。特别是，工作控制语言的细节似乎阻碍了他们——这一观察结果与来自该领域的报告非常吻合。更具体地说，处理“无关紧要”的空白和连续卡片似乎是巨大麻烦的根源——如果抓握的数量是任何衡量标准的话。

Since I attributed this loss of learning to lack of practical experience, I decided to change the course into a workshop in OS/360. But in the workshop mode, I discovered that the students were having a terrible time seeing the concepts for the details. In particular, the details of the Job Control Language seemed to be standing in their way—an observation that corresponded well with reports coming in from the field. In more particular, the handling of "nonsignificant" blanks and continuation cards seemed to be the source of enormous trouble—if the amount of griping was any measure.

因此，我决定在讲座中强调这些琐碎的句法细节，并通过一些课堂问题记录学生的表现。这些问题涉及通过连续更困难的练习来创建、键入和测试一系列工作控制卡。如图 10-1 中的“Class #1”所示，结果相当令人沮丧。所有 JCL 错误中有 83% 是“空白”错误，即我在课堂上特别强调的错误类型。

I therefore decided to emphasize these petty syntactic details in the lectures and to keep records of the student performance through some class problems. The problems involved creating, keying, and testing a series of job control cards through successively more difficult exercises. The results were rather discouraging, as shown under "Class #1" in Figure 10-1. Eighty-three percent of all JCL errors were "blanks" errors—that is, the types of errors I had specifically emphasized in class.

图 10-1 JCL 初学者的错误。

Figure 10-1 Errors by JCL beginners.

 

然后，我决定将此行为与使用相同练习的另一堂课进行比较——但除了回答特定问题外，没有在“空白”错误主题上花费任何课堂时间。该类的行为在图 10-1 中显示为“Class #2”。

I then decided to compare this behavior with another class using the same exercises—but without spending any class time on the subject of "blanks" errors except to answer specific questions. The behavior of that class is shown as "Class #2" in Figure 10-1.

从这张图表可以看出，我通过讲授来教授 JCL 语法的艰苦尝试的最终效果是将相对错误率从 87% 降低到 83%。这肯定不是统计上显着的结果。然而，对于程序员教育的心理学来说，这是一个重要的结果，因为它表明学校教育——或在这种情况下的讲座——与教育几乎没有或根本没有关系。当然，也可能是其他一些讲师对这种行为产生了影响——我并不是说自己是世界上最好的讲师。但是，我可以谦虚地说，我也不是世界上最糟糕的，所以很多其他讲师在理解他们的“材料”时会遇到这个问题。

It appears from this chart that the net effect of my arduous attempt to teach JCL syntax by lecturing was a reduction of relative error rate from 87 to 83 percent. This is assuredly not a statistically significant result. It is a significant result, however, for the psychology of programmer education, for it shows that schooling—or lecturing, in this case—need have little or nothing to do with education. It may be, of course, that some other instructor could have had an influence on this behavior—-I don't claim to be the world's finest lecturer. But then, I can say in all modesty that l am not the world's worst, either, so a good many other lecturers would have had this problem getting across their "material."

现在，为什么了解这些琐碎的材料如此重要呢？不幸的是，尽管这些材料的知识含量并不高，但不学习它绝对会阻碍学习使用操作系统的进一步进步。这就引出了我们的第二个区别——教育与培训。粗略地说，“教育”是指获得一般原则和技能，而“培训”是指获得特定技能。因此，我们谈到“驾驶员培训”、“军事培训”、“成人教育”和“通识教育”。并不是说这些话一定能说明学校里发生的事情。军训当然教的是影响一生观点的大道理，

Now, why is it so important to get across such trivial material, anyway? Unfortunately, although the intellectual content of the material is not great, failure to learn it absolutely impedes further progress in learning to use the operating system. Which brings us to our second distinction—education versus training. Roughly speaking, by "education" we mean acquisition of general principles and skills, and by "training" we mean acquisition of specific skills. Thus, we speak of "driver training," "military training," "adult education," and "liberal education." Not that the words necessarily tell what is going on in the school. Military training certainly teaches general principles that affect one's point of view for a lifetime, and adult education is more often than not merely training in some specific skill.

但更重要的是，如果没有一定的培训作为先决条件，教育可能是不可能的。在我们的案例中，计算机方面的经验对于以持久的方式传授操作系统概念是必要的，而操纵 JCL 语法的能力对于获得操作系统经验是必要的。因此，未能接受 JCL 语法培训导致未能接受操作系统原理方面的教育。

But more important, education may be impossible without certain training as a prerequisite. In our case, experience on the computer was necessary to impart operating systems concepts in a lasting way, and ability to manipulate JCL syntax was necessary to get operating system experience. Thus, failure to train in JCL syntax led to failure to educate in operating systems principles.

或许我们应该说“JCL 语法学习失败”导致教育失败，因为最终 Class #2 确实接受了 JCL 语法培训，如图 10-2 所示。

Perhaps we should say "failure to school in JCL syntax" led to failure to educate, because eventually Class #2 did become trained in JCL syntax, as shown in Figure 10-2.

图 10-2 JCL 初学者在接受培训时犯的错误。

Figure 10-2 Errors by JCL beginners with training.

 

十次练习结束时，17 名学生中有 13 人掌握了制作 JCL 卡片的技巧，没有“空白”错误（尽管其中两人在问题 #11 上略有退步，该问题比其他人大一点）。然而，其他四名学生在这项技能上并没有表现出任何明显的提高，这一失败仍然阻碍了他们在操作系统概念方面的进步。毫无疑问，他们最终会学会这项技能，但课程在那一刻结束，他们被送回了自己的家乡。很可能，他们仍然远离操作系统，而其他 13 人现在可以自信地接近它以进一步学习。

By the end of ten exercises, 13 of the 17 students had mastered the skill of creating JCL cards without "blanks" errors (although two of them regressed slightly on problem #11, which was a bit larger than the others). The other four students did not show any marked increase in this skill, however, and this failure was still standing in the way of their progress in operating systems concepts. No doubt they would have learned the skill eventually, but the class terminated at that point and they were sent back to their home locations. Quite likely, they remained aloof from the operating system, whereas the other 13 could now approach it with confidence for further learning.

总之，在 JCL 语法中获得技能（培训）的困难造成了阻碍操作系统教育进一步发展的障碍（并且顺便创建了一个由 JCL“专家”组成的精英团队，其他程序员仍然依附于他们）。这个障碍不能通过讲授来消除，但是可以通过让学习者处于机器不断给他需要的经验的环境中来消除。毫无疑问，可以创建一个比 OS/360 本身更有效地完成这项工作的系统——例如，一个带有 JCL 语法检查功能的在线终端。但尽管 OS/360 很糟糕，但如果我们能让学生使用它，它就是一种教学机器。这是“学校”在这种情况下可以提供的服务——鼓励学生继续尝试面对 OS/360，或者正如一位学生所说的那样，“Obstacle System/360”。

In summary, then, the difficulty of acquiring skill—training—in JCL syntax creates a barrier that blocks further progress in operating system education (and incidentally creates an elite group of JCL "experts" upon whom other programmers remain slavishly dependent). This barrier cannot be removed by lecturing about it, but it can be removed by putting the learner in a situation where the machine keeps giving him the experience he needs. No doubt a system could be created which would do this job more efficiently and effectively than OS/360 itself—an on-line terminal with JCL syntax-checking facilities, for example. But bad as OS/360 is, it is a kind of teaching machine if we can but get the students to use it. This is the service the "school" can provide in this situation—encouraging the student to keep trying in face of OS/360, or as one student termed it, "Obstacle System/360."

反对学习的力量

FORCES AGAINST LEARNING

令人惊讶的是，我们唯一无法学习的时候是在有负面力量反对它的时候。我们说“令人惊讶”是因为教学非常强调通过使用各种巧妙的设备或技巧来激励人们学习。然而，如果我们能够观察孩子们的学习，我们就会发现任何一个真正任其自生自灭的孩子都会学到大量的东西——不一定是我们想让他学的东西，但数量是一样的。为了试图将他的学习塑造成我们希望他学习的东西的形式，我们建造了某些墙并打开了某些门。当他学习时，我们祝贺自己，但如果没有我们和我们的人为障碍，他会学得更好——可能更好。

To a surprising degree, the only time we fail to learn is when there are negative forces set up against it. We say "surprising" because so much emphasis in teaching is placed on motivating people to learn by using all sorts of clever devices or tricks. If we could observe children learning, however, we would see that any child really left to his own devices will learn vast numbers of things—not necessarily the things we want him to learn, but vast numbers all the same. In order to try to shape his learning into the form of the things we want him to learn, we build certain walls and open certain doors. When he learns, we congratulate ourselves, but he would have learned—possibly better—without us and our artificial barriers.

然而，对于成年人来说，学习的障碍通常已经内化了，如果任其自生自灭，普通成年人学得很少。首先也是最重要的是，为了学习，我们必须承认有些我们不知道的东西可能值得知道。对于一个专业的程序员来说，这种承认代表着地位的降低——除非他有足够的洞察力，看到一个真正的专业人士，一个真正有实力的人，承认自己的弱点不会有任何损失。

With adults, however, the barriers to learning have usually become internalized, and the average adult learns very little if left to his own devices. First and foremost, in order to learn we have to acknowledge that there is something we don't know that might be worth knowing. For a professional programmer, this acknowledgment represents a lowering of status—unless he is perceptive enough to see that a true professional, a person with true strength, loses nothing by admitting to weakness.

然而，有些人太愿意承认自己的弱点，但他们不会尝试学习，因为他们事先就确信自己会失败。这种对失败的恐惧可能是由于普遍缺乏信心而产生的，或者可能是由于早先在同类努力中失败的经历而产生的。然而，大多数情况下，恐惧与其说是失败本身，不如说是让其他人目睹失败。

Some people, however, are only too willing to admit weakness They however, will not try to learn because they are convinced in advance that they will fail. Such fear of failure may be engendered by a general lack of confidence, or may spring from the experience of earlier failures in the same kind of endeavor. Most often, however, the fear is not so much of failure itself, but of having other people witness the failure.

对于某些类型的材料，在一个小组中会抑制新的学习，但会促进使用已学材料的表现。要学习，我们必须愿意犯错误，这在有观众在场的情况下很难做到。事实上，当所使用的材料众所周知时，可能正是其他人的存在激励人们不犯错误。就此观察适用于编程技能学习的程度而言，我们可能期望在与终端隔离时最好进行新编程语言的初步学习，并且不保留任何错误记录。

For certain types of material, being in a group inhibits new learning but facilitates performance in using material already learned. To learn, we must be willing to make mistakes, and this is difficult to do when there is an audience present. Indeed, it is probably the presence of the others that gives the incentive not to make mistakes when the material being used is well known. To the extent that this observation applies to the learning of programming skills, we might expect that initial learning of, say, a new programming language would best be done when cloistered with a terminal—and when no record is kept of mistakes.

我们的观察倾向于以多种方式证实这一预测 在一项研究中，该研究试图确定使用 PL/I 时最常犯的错误并检查编译器检测和纠正错误的程度，我们试图收集由一组五十个初学者。制作这一系列的困难是惊人的。各种逃避都被用来掩盖错误的存在。尽管我们明确告诉小组我们不是将他们作为个体进行研究，并且研究的目的是衡量所有错误，但我们不断收到这样的回复：“......但你对这次运行不感兴趣；我离开了去掉那个愚蠢的分号。等待下一次运行；然后我会给你看一些好东西。”

Our observations have tended to confirm this prediction in several ways In one study, which was attempting to determine the most commonly made errors in using PL/I and to examine how well the compiler detected and corrected them, we attempted to collect all runs made by a group of fifty beginners. The difficulties in making this collection were astounding. Every sort of evasion was used in an attempt to cover up the very existence of errors. Although we had explicitly told the group that we were not studying them as individuals and that the purpose of the study was to measure all errors, we continually received this reply: ". . . but you're not interested in this run; I left off that silly semicolon. Wait for the next run; then I'll have something good to show you."

另一个指向这个方向的观察是初学者经常对终端系统产生的热情——这种热情在他们达到通过学习几乎消失了琐碎的句法错误的程度后往往会减弱。更有经验的程序员似乎对终端不太感兴趣，因为它是一种数据输入设备——可能具有温和的语法检查功能以帮助消除键入错误。对于初学者或业余爱好者来说，语法、键控和作业控制等辅助操作的困难通常远远超过可能由细微的语义点或问题本身引起的任何更深层次的困难。由于大多数涉及在线系统和批处理系统之间比较的心理测试都涉及初学者和/或相当微不足道的问题，他们未能为我们提供有关这两种方法不同优势的明确数据。如果我们要设计最适合初始学习和最适合以后使用的系统，则有必要仔细观察程序员在不同开发阶段和处理不同类型问题时的终端使用情况。

Another observation pointing in this direction is the enthusiasm beginners often generate for terminal systems—enthusiasm that often dampens after they reach the point where trivial syntactic errors have all but disappeared through learning. More experienced programmers seem less enthusiastic about the terminal as other than a data entry device —perhaps with mild syntax-checking features to help eradicate keying errors. For beginners, or amateurs, the difficulties with syntax, keying, and such auxiliary operations as job control usually far outweigh any deeper difficulties that might arise from subtle semantic points or from the problem itself. Since most psychological tests involving comparisons between on-line systems and batch systems have involved beginners and/or fairly trivial problems, they have failed to give us definitive data on the different strengths of these two approaches. Careful observation of terminal use by programmers in different stages of development and working on different types of problems will be necessary if we are to design systems that are best for initial learning and best for later use.

关于不同编程语言和系统的争论很少涉及易学性和易用性之间的区别。从长远来看，最容易学习的功能将最容易使用，这没有特别的原因。这里的重要概念是技术的可扩展性——它是否适用于不同于最初学习它的情况？当我们学习一般技术时，我们不会简单地添加到我们的事实库中。我们也倍增我们的表现力。

Precious little of the controversy over diverse programming languages and systems ever touches on the distinction between ease of learning and ease of use. There is no particular reason why a feature that is easiest to learn will be easiest to use in the long run. The important concept here is that of extensibility of a technique—is it applicable to situations other than the one for which it was first learned? When we learn a general technique, we do not simply add to our repertoire of facts. We also multiply our power of performance.

在通用技术的相反极端，可扩展技术就是我们所说的“死胡同”技术。例如，我们可以学习 Cramer 的通过行列式求解联立线性方程组的规则，以便我们可以求解具有三个或四个方程组的系统。事实上，这是高中代数教学的常规课程。但是 Cramer 规则——尽管在理论上完全通用——基本上不可能应用于大型方程组，因为行列式的计算在复杂性上增长得太快。尽管无法得出明确的终点，超过该终点使用 Cramer 规则是不切实际的，但它无疑是一种死胡同的技术。

At the opposite extreme of general, extensible techniques are what we might term "dead-end" techniques. We may, for example, learn Cramer's rule for solving simultaneous linear equations by means of determinants in order that we can solve systems of three or four equations. Indeed, this is the normal course of teaching high school algebra. But Cramer's rule—though in theory perfectly general—is essentially impossible to apply to large systems of equations, for the computation of determinants grows too rapidly in complexity. Although no definite end point can be drawn beyond which it is impractical to employ Cramer's rule, it is without a doubt a dead-end technique.

在编程中，我们经常会遇到一个程序员，他在解决一定规模的问题上取得了很大的成功，但始终无法超越这些问题。事实上，我们有时会遇到相反的情况——程序员直到他开始在更大的系统上工作才取得显着的成功。在第一种情况下，在小程序上运行良好的技术无法有效地应用于大型程序。其次，将强大的通用技术应用于简单问题可能会导致过多的开销。

In programming, we often encounter a programmer who has had much success working on problems of a certain size but has never been able to go beyond them. In fact, we sometimes encounter the converse situation—the programmer who was not notably successful until he began to work on bigger systems. In the first case, the techniques that worked so well on small programs just cannot be applied effectively to large ones. In the second, application of powerful and general techniques to simple problems may have resulted in excessive overhead.

例如，考虑二分搜索和顺序搜索之间的区别。如果我们正在编写一个必须搜索包含十个项目的表的程序，那么如果我们尝试应用二进制搜索，它可能会减慢编程甚至执行速度。不知道二分搜索概念的程序员在这个问题上可能会胜过知道它但不太了解其局限性的程序员。尽管如此，二分搜索可能不会超过一半的速度和两倍的工作——当应用于 1000 项的列表时，这对于线性搜索来说是不可能的。

Consider, for instance, the difference between a binary search and a sequential search. If we are writing a program which has to search through a table of ten items, it will probably slow down the programming and even the execution if we try to apply a binary search. The programmer who does not know of the binary search concept may, on this problem, outshine the programmer who does know it but doesn't quite have the sense to detect its limitations. All the same, the binary search will probably not be more than half the speed and twice the work—which cannot be said for the linear search when applied, say, to a list of 1000 items.

对于掌握了某些死胡同技术（或死胡同的编程语言）的程序员来说，新的学习要求他至少暂时放弃一些当前的满足感。他在新技术方面的早期成功可能不会很好。从某种意义上说，他是在让自己与新手平起平坐。当面对学习一门新的编程语言时，这种对损失的恐惧会特别大。任何一个在异国他乡生活过的人，都知道第一次真正尝试以自己微薄的语言知识去相处时那种无助的感觉。再次学习编程时的感觉几乎没有什么不同。就像旅行者对小孩子的法语说得比他好感到尴尬一样，

For the programmer who has mastered certain dead-end techniques (or dead-end programming languages), new learning requires him to give up, at least temporarily, some current satisfaction. His early success with the new techniques will probably not be great. He is, in a sense, putting himself back on a par with the novices. This fear of loss can be especially great when faced with the learning of a new programming language. Anyone who has ever lived in a foreign country knows the feeling of helplessness the first time he really tries to get along with his meager knowledge of the language. The feeling is hardly different when one learns to program again. Just as the traveler is embarrassed by the way little children speak better French than he, the experienced FORTRAN programmer feels his power slipping away when he has to ask one of the trainees about some simple syntactic point in PL/I.

对新事物的恐惧、对失败的期待以及不愿承认弱点都会对学习产生直接的阻碍作用，无论是在正式的课堂场合还是在工作中。其他问题是间接产生的，最常见的原因是对必须学习什么或如何着手学习的认识不足。在一门介绍性编程课程中，讲师注意到大多数学生在完成实验室作业时遇到困难，尽管它们的性质很简单。每个学生都应该使用连接到 APL 系统的终端解决两三个简单的问题，但第五周后，五十人中只有大约五个人交出了成绩。

The fear of new things, the expectation of failure, and the reluctance to admit weakness all have a direct retarding effect on learning, whether in a formal classroom situation or on the job. Other problems arise indirectly, most often from an inadequate perception of what has to be learned or how to go about learning it. In one introductory programming course, the instructor noticed that most of the students were having trouble with their laboratory assignments, although they were of a simple nature. Each student was supposed to solve two or three simple problems using a terminal connected to an APL system, but after the fifth week, only about five out of fifty had turned in results.

讲师决定参观实验室，他发现有两个不同的问题导致相同的最终结果——没有重要的学习。第一个问题涉及他在候机室发现的学生。通常，他们在知道如何开始打字的那一刻就登录了终端。比想象中更有信心，他们在终端时间里徘徊了好几个小时，却一无所获。然而，第二个问题涉及指导员在候机室没有找到的学生。在他们的例子中，因为他们习惯于手工解决问题，所以他们不敢在每个细节都解决之前来到终端。而且，如果没有终端本身的帮助，他们当然无法计算出每一个细节。

The instructor decided to visit the laboratory, and what he found there were two different problems leading to the same end result—no significant learning. The first problem involved the students he found in the terminal room. Typically, they had signed onto the terminal the moment they knew how and started typing away. With more confidence than thought, they blundered about for hours and hours of terminal time and got nowhere. The second problem, however, involved the students the instructor didn't find in the terminal room. In their case, because they were accustomed to working problems by hand, they were afraid to come to the terminal before having every last detail worked out. And, of course they were unable to work out every last detail without the aid of the terminal itself.

当面对由不熟悉的情况引起的问题时，我们可能会犯两种常见的错误——我们认为问题比实际情况更难，或者我们认为问题比实际情况更容易。一个差劲的老师通常不会因为缺乏对主题的掌握而变得差劲——主题通常在书本或其他资源中，学生可以自己细读。可怜的老师可能给他的学生留下事情太简单的印象，也许是因为准备得太顺利，以至于他们看不到他的例子背后的困难。或者，他可能会故意选择简单的例子来强调某些要点，这样做给人的印象是，在实际问题中，事情似乎总是水到渠成。

When faced with a problem arising out of some unfamiliar situation, there are two general errors we can make—either we think the problem is harder than it really is or we think it is easier than it really is. A poor teacher is not usually poor for lack of mastery of the subject matter—subject matter is commonly in books or other sources, which the students can peruse for themselves. The poor teacher may give his students the impression that things are too easy, perhaps by being too smoothly prepared so that they do not see the difficulties underlying his examples. Or, he may choose intentionally simple examples to highlight certain points and, in so doing, give the impression that in real problems things always seem to fall into place.

在我们的 APL 课上，讲师给出了一个程序，该程序可以找到一个字符串在另一个字符串中的位置——本质上是 PL/I 的 INDEX 函数。课堂上的例子只用了一行，非常优雅。不幸的是，这个解决方案在几个方面是不够的。如果其中一个字符串只有一个字符，或者没有，则解决方案将完全失败。如果所寻找的字符串恰好“环绕”在所寻找的字符串周围，例程就会错误地说它已找到——就像在“ABCX”中找到“XA”的情况一样。许多其他细节被排除在问题之外；但是当学生们在终端上遇到类似的问题时，他们不得不处理这样的细节，即使他们没有预料到。

In our APL class, the instructor had given a program which found the position of one character string in another—essentially the INDEX function of PL/I. The example presented in class took exactly one line, and was quite elegant. Unfortunately, this solution was inadequate in several ways. If either of the strings had only one character, or none, the solution failed entirely. If the sought-for string happened to be "wrapped around" the sought-in string, the routine incorrectly said that it was found-as in the case of 'XA' being found in "ABCX". Many other details had been left out of the problem; but when the students were given a similar problem to do on the terminal, they had to deal with such details even though they didn't expect them.

另一方面，同一位老师犯了让其他学生觉得事情太难的错误。在一次讲座结束时，他发现自己还有十分钟的时间，他试图向他们展示他在自己的研究中一直在研究的一个问题。解决方案完全超出了一些学生的范围，因为他们甚至没有理解问题的数学基础。这些学生甚至不敢尝试做家庭作业。

On the other hand, the same instructor had been guilty of making things seem too hard for other students. At the end of one lecture, finding himself with an extra ten minutes, he attempted to show them a problem he had been working on in his own research. The solution was completely beyond some of the students because they did not have the mathematical grounding even to understand the problem. These students were discouraged from even trying the homework.

当有老师时，我们希望他能够察觉到这种情况，并在必要时进行干预，让学生回到学习的轨道上。但是很多编程学习是在没有老师的情况下进行的，或者至少没有正式指定的老师。而且，很多编程学习是在没有某些其他基本要素的情况下进行的——教科书、参考资料、运行软件的软件或硬件、发布的研究新主题的时间，授权在生产问题上尝试新技术，或其他有一定经验的程序员。每一个这样缺失的成分都加剧了学习的问题，并使学习者更有可能在第一个令人沮丧的迹象时放弃。

When there is a teacher, we expect he will be able to perceive such situations and intervene as necessary to get the students back on the track to learning. But much of programming learning takes place without a teacher, or at least without someone formally designated as one Moreover, much of programming learning takes place without certain other essential elements-textbooks, reference material, software or hardware on which to run the software, released time to study new topics, authorization to try a new technique on a production problem, or other programmers who have some experience. Each such missing ingredient compounds the problem of learning and makes it more likely that the learner will give up at the first discouraging sign.

学校是应该提供这些基本元素的地方。我们无法知道一所学校的成功在多大程度上取决于这些因素，而不是取决于其教师——他们只是教学系统中最引人注目的部分。然而，尽管没有人会争辩说学校提供这些元素是不合适的，但学校的存在可能往往意味着它们在其他地方没有提供。一位经理的推理可能是这样的：“他要我提供一个会计准则，以便在做一些练习题时使用。他需要那个干什么？我们刚送他去学校上了四个星期——他们在那里教了他什么？”

The school is a place where these essential elements are supposed to be supplied. We have no way of knowing how much of the success of a school depends on these factors rather than on its teachers—who form only the most conspicuous part of the teaching system. And yet, although nobody would argue it is improper for a school to furnish these elements, the very existence of schools may tend to mean they are not furnished elsewhere. A manager's reasoning may go something like this: "He's asking me for an accounting code to use in running some practice problems. What does he need that for? We just sent him to school for four weeks—what did they teach him there?"

这种态度——“学校是你学习的地方；办公室是你工作的地方”——当然不仅限于编程行业。尽管如此，编程行业比其他任何行业都更依赖于无休止的学习，因此我们不必为我们对阻碍其发展的因素的关注而道歉。

This attitude—"school is where you learn; office is where you work"—is not, of course, confined to the programming business. Nevertheless, the programming business relies more than any other on unending learning, so we need not apologize for any attention we pay to factors that stand in its way.

如何学习编程

HOW TO LEARN PROGRAMMING

想要提升自己的程序员不能依靠正规培训和经理的恩典来获得他需要的教育。他也不能依赖纯粹的“经验”，因为经验不一定能教给我们任何东西。如果程序员要利用他的经验，他必须学会如何学习。

The programmer who wants to advance himself cannot afford to rely on formal training and the grace of his manager to get the education he needs. Neither can he depend on pure "experience," for experience doesn't necessarily teach anything. If a programmer is going to make something of his experience, he must learn how to learn.

学习如何学习任何东西的第一步是了解你自己的资产和负债——“认识你自己”。作为自己的老师的人比课堂上的学生有一个主要优势——他可以根据他唯一的学生的需要精确地调整课程。在上一节中，我们举了一个老师的例子，他的学生由于两个不同的原因未能学习 APL。原因不仅不同，而且是互补的。如果老师试图让事情看起来更难来帮助一个小组，他就会失去已经难以跟随他的榜样的小组。朝另一个方向移动也好不到哪里去，所以这位老师陷入了一个本质的悖论。摆脱这种困境的唯一方法是在它的喇叭之间：他将不得不单独处理每个学生的情况。

The first step in learning how to learn anything is to learn your own assets and liabilities—"know thyself." The person who is his own teacher has one major advantage over the classroom student—he can tailor the lessons precisely to the needs of his one and only student. In the previous section, we gave an example of a teacher whose students were failing to learn APL for two different reasons. Not only were the reasons different, they were complementary. If the teacher tried making things seem harder to help one group, he would lose the group that already was having difficulty in following his examples. Moving in the other direction would be no better, so the teacher was caught in an essential paradox. The only way out of this dilemma would have been between its horns: he would have to deal with each student's situation individually.

这种个人关注恰恰是自学成才的学生自动获得的，如果他有使用它的自我敏感性的话。例如，每一种现代教育理论都承认存在偏好的感知模式。例如，有些人在听到演讲时会更好地记住（学习）信息，例如在讲座中；其他人在看到所写信息时保留得最好。当讲师是一位优秀的演讲者时，第一类人可能在课堂上取得更大的成功，而当讲师拥有精心准备的视觉教具时，更倾向于视觉的人将处于优势地位。大多数人都知道他们是喜欢听觉还是视觉呈现来学习，但很少有人使用这些信息来制定他们自己的教育计划。

This individual attention is precisely what the self-taught student gets automatically, if he but has the self-sensitivity to use it. For instance, every modern theory of education recognizes the existence of favored modes of perception. For example, some people retain (learn) information better when they hear it spoken, as in a lecture; others retain best when they see the information written. People of the first type may have more success in a class when the lecturer is a fine speaker, whereas people of a more visual bent will be at an advantage when the lecturer has well-prepared visual aids. Most people have an awareness of whether they favor auditory or visual presentations for learning, but few use this information in charting their own educational plans.

喜欢听觉学习的人应该设法找到他可以从中学习的讲座，无论是现场的还是录音的。如果他能找到录制的讲座，他可能会有额外的优势，可以多次听同一个讲座——这是他在现场讲座中做不到的。事实上，录音有望让听觉学习者与视觉学习者处于同等地位，视觉学习者总是有优势，可以根据需要多次阅读一本书或调查一张图表。

The person who favors auditory learning should try to find lectures, either live or recorded, from which he can learn. If he can find recorded lectures, he may have the additional advantage of being able to listen to the same lecture several times—something he cannot do very easily with live lectures. In fact, the recording promises to give the auditory learner equal parity with the visual learner, who always had the advantage of being able to read a book or survey a diagram as many times as he thought necessary.

学习者的个性不仅体现在他被动地接受书籍或讲座中的信息，还体现在他使用这些媒体进行的活动中。例如，有些人如果不做笔记就无法从讲座中有效地学习，即使他们再也不会参考这些笔记。边听边写的行为增强了一些人的记忆力。然而，对于其他人来说，在讲座中做笔记只是一种分散注意力的方式，他们通过专注于所讲的讲座来保持最佳状态。这样的学习者由于被迫在课程中做笔记而受到阻碍，例如当教师要求每个学生在学期结束时上交笔记本时。然而，当单独学习时，不存在这种外部压力，但许多人继续做笔记，因为他们被迫或被教导，

The individuality of the learner is not only reflected in his passive acceptance of information from a book or lecture, but also in the activity he performs while using these media. For instance, some people cannot learn effectively from a lecture unless they take notes, even if they never refer to the notes again. The very act of writing while listening enhances retention for some. For-others, however, taking notes during a lecture is merely a distraction, and they retain best by concentrating on the lecture as it is given. Such learners are handicapped by being forced to take notes in a course, as when the instructor requires that each student turn in his notebook at the end of the term. When learning individually, however, no such outside pressure is present, yet many people continue to take notes because they were forced to, or taught to, when they were in a formal school situation.

另一个重要的二分法是在实践中学习最好的人——通过解决问题、编写程序等——和那些通过与他人讨论问题学习最好的人。当然，二分法不是遗传的，我们可以学会从一种互动形式中获益，即使我们偏爱另一种互动形式。事实上，我们可能以不同的模式最好地学习不同种类的材料——我们可能通过编写程序来学习一种新的编程语言，但我们可能通过在深入研究之前彻底讨论它来最好地理解一个问题。

Another important dichotomy is between people who learn best by doing—by working problems, writing programs, and so forth—and those who learn best by discussing problems with other people. Of course, the dichotomy is not a genetic one, and we can learn to profit from one form of interaction even if we favor the other. In fact, it may be that we learn different kinds of material best in different modes—we may learn a new programming language best by writing programs in it, but we may come to understand a problem best by discussing it thoroughly before plunging in.

应研究特殊学习方法的最后一个领域是工作习惯。有些人早上学得最好，而有些“夜猫子”则在难以逾越的迷雾中度过清晨时光。有些人坐在办公桌前的硬直背椅上学习效果最好，而有些享乐主义者在这种情况下无法将注意力从不适中移开足够长的时间来了解一加一等于二。有些人喜欢用硬铅笔写字，有些人喜欢用软铅笔写字。其他人必须有钢笔、圆珠笔或毡尖；还有一些人必须有键盘和特定型号才能启动。

One final area in which idiosyncratic learning methods should be studied is that of work habits. Some people learn best first thing in the morning, and some "night people" pass their early morning hours in an impenetrable fog. Some people learn best when seated in a hard straight-backed chair at a desk, whereas some hedonists in such a situation cannot take their mind off their discomfort long enough to learn that one plus one equals two. Some people like to write with a hard pencil, some with a soft one. Others must have a fountain pen, a ball-point, or a felt-tip; still others must have a keyboard—and a particular model, to boot.

有些人喜欢单线纸，有些人喜欢宽线，有些人喜欢窄线。还有一些人喜欢使用图格纸，至少在某些类型的工作中是这样。一个程序员必须在预印的编码表上编码，另一个必须使用普通纸，还有三分之一可能更喜欢在键盘上编写程序。即使使用键盘，有些人还是喜欢图形设备，而其他人则必须在他们眼前制作一份硬拷贝。偏爱图形设备的原因之一是有些人无法在嘈杂的环境中很好地工作，但我们知道其他人实际上需要大量的噪音才能学习——甚至需要玩游戏他们学习时收听广播。

Some people prefer unlined paper, some prefer wide-lined, some prefer narrow. Still others like to use graph-ruled paper, at least for some types of work. One programmer must code on a preprinted coding sheet, another must use plain paper, and yet a third might prefer composing his programs on a keyboard. Even when keyboards are used, some prefer a graphic device, and others must have a hard copy produced before their eyes. One of the reasons for preferring a graphic device is that some people cannot work well in a noisy environment, and yet we know that others actually need a substantial amount of noise in order to learn at all—even to the extent of having to play a radio while they study.

关于最佳学习条件的争论可能是无止境的，因为它本质上是对一个无法解决的问题的争论。当我们建立一所学校时，可能有必要接受一种运作模式作为对“典型”学生的最佳妥协，但为什么一个人单独工作必须与对他来说最佳的条件做出任何妥协？事实上，即使在学校里，对效率的追求也常常超出任何合理的需要。例如，为什么必须强迫所有学生使用相同类型的终端、相同类型的编码板，还是用相同类型的钢笔或铅笔？在学校情况下提供几种合理的选择应该鼓励学生思考他们自己的学习习惯——这样当他们离开学校时，他们会更好地准备继续学习，而不是觉得如果他们不学习另一件事，那就太过分了。很快。

The debate over the optimum conditions for learning is probably endless, for it is essentially a debate over an unresolvable problem. When we are establishing a school, it may be necessary to accept one mode of operation as the best compromise for the "typical" student, but why should an individual working alone have to make any compromise whatsoever with the conditions that will be optimal for him? Indeed, even in schools, the quest for efficiency is often carried beyond any reasonable need. Why, for instance, must all students be forced to work on the same type of terminal, the same type of coding pad, or with the same type of pen or pencil? Making several reasonable alternatives available in the school situation should encourage students to think about their own learning habits—so that when they leave the school they will be better prepared to continue learning, rather than feeling that if they never study another thing it will be too soon.

无论我们为学习创造了多么好的物理环境，如果我们不使用所有可用的信息来帮助我们学习，那么该环境对我们的成功影响不大。正如我们因忽视特殊需求而失去效率一样，当我们忽视信息来源或我们已经使用的来源中可用的信息片段时，我们也会失败。造成这种损失的最大原因可能是认为不“正确”的事情就是“错误”的观念。这种二元区别——这种亚里士多德的谬误在当今文化中普遍存在——导致无数信息丢失，如果恢复这些信息，可能会大大提高教育效率。

No matter how well we establish the best physical environment for learning, that environment will have little influence on our success if we do not use all the information available to help us learn. Just as we lose efficiency by ignoring our idiosyncratic needs, we lose when we ignore sources of information—or pieces of information lying available in sources we are already using. Probably the greatest cause of this type of loss is the concept that something that is not "right" is "wrong." This binary distinction—this Aristotelian fallacy which pervades our culture today—results in countless amounts of lost information, which, if recovered, could lead to a major increase in educational efficiency.

作为此类信息丢失的一个简单示例，请考虑两个学生在考试中尝试做算术题 25-16 的情况。如果一个学生的答案是“19”，而另一个学生的答案是“41”，则两个学生都被评为“错误”，但显然第一个学生遇到的问题与第二个学生不同。在一个大班里，这两个学生只是被归为“不会减法的小学生”。如果他们中的任何一个有幸拥有一位导师，他们答案中的额外信息将转化为良好的教学优势。

As a simple example of such loss of information, consider the case of two students trying to do the arithmetic problem, 25-16, on a test. If one student gets the answer "19" while the other gets "41," both are graded as being "wrong," yet the first is obviously suffering from a different problem than the second. In a large class, these two students are merely lumped together as "pupils who cannot subtract." If either were fortunate enough to have a tutor, the additional information in their answers would be turned to good teaching advantage.

当我们着手辅导自己时，我们必须学会注意所有这些信息。例如，当我们编写一个程序时，当该程序没有“正确”运行时，输出中通常会包含大量信息。很少，如果有的话，我们只是返回一个说“不正确”的程序，尽管许多程序员的操作就好像这就是他们必须处理的一切——也是他们关心的一切。另一方面，如果输出看起来是“正确的”，他们就把它放在一边，不加思索。

When we undertake to tutor ourselves, we must learn to pay attention to all such information. When we write a program, for instance, and when that program does not run "correctly," there is usually a plethora of information lying about in the output. Rarely, if ever, do we just get back a program which says "incorrect," although many programmers operate as if this were all they had to work with—and all they care about. If, on the other hand, the output seems to be "correct," they lay it aside without a further thought.

学习是一种积极的追求。学习编程时，有两个时候应该积极学习——程序运行时和不运行时。当它运行时，是时候后退三步，全面审视已取得的成就。当我们在看似相似的程序上遇到更多麻烦时，为什么这个程序会成功？为什么我们遇到这么多麻烦？如果我们从头开始，我们会做哪些不同的事情来使编程工作更容易，或者使程序更高效，或者使文档更好？我们现在可以做这些事情吗？“工作”的程序常常被误认为是已完成的程序，这通常是因为管理压力要求“生产”。但是想要学习的程序员必须要顶住这样的压力，花时间去回顾自己的成功。管理人员在项目“完成”后给程序员放一天假可能是一种很好的做法，与其说是奖励，不如说是一个获得一点观点的机会。

Learning is an active pursuit. When learning to program, there are two times when one should actively pursue learning—when the program runs and when it doesn't run. When it runs is the time to step back three paces and take a broad look at what has been accomplished. Why was this program successful when we have had more trouble with seemingly similar programs? Why did we have as much trouble as we did? If we were starting from scratch, what would we do differently to make the programming job easier, or to make the program more efficient, or to make the documentation better? Can we do any of these things now? All too often the program that "works" is mistaken for the program that is finished, frequently because of management pressure to "produce." But the programmer who wants to learn must resist such pressures and take the time to review his success. It might be a good practice for management to give the programmer a day off when his project is "finished," not so much as a reward but as a chance to get a little perspective.

当我们的程序不能正确运行时，我们就有机会吸取更具体的教训。很多时候，在生产压力下，程序员很想用他知道会起作用的“修复”来绕过问题点，因为它没有使用他试图掌握的一些新技术。例如，假设他刚刚学习了 PL/I 中的数组表达式，但在他的生产程序中使用数组表达式遇到了一些麻烦。如果他认为数组表达式太“复杂”并用自 FORTRAN 时代以来就一直使用的 DO 循环代替，他将错过学习的黄金机会。最适合学习的时间莫过于最强烈地感受到学习需求的时间——也就是我们发现错误的那一刻。

When our program does not run correctly, we have the opportunity to learn more specific lessons. Quite often, under the pressure of production, the programmer is tempted to bypass a trouble spot with a "fix" he knows will work, since it does not use some new technique he was trying to master. Suppose, for example, he has just been studying array expressions in PL/I, but he has some trouble with an array expression in his production program. If he decides that array expressions are too "complicated" and substitutes a DO loop such as he has been using since his FORTRAN days, he will have missed a golden opportunity for learning. No time will be more propitious for learning than that time at which the need for learning is felt most strongly—the very moment when we detect an error.

但要现实一点：在大多数环境中，生产工作先于学习，即使承诺在掌握新技术后会在更远的地方获得最终回报，经理们也不会容忍当前的大量延迟。面对工作和学习之间的这种冲突，程序员该怎么办？其实解决方法很简单。如果在尝试理解新技术失败的合理时间后，他没有成功，他应该继续他的“修复”，如果他有的话。同时，他应该构建一个测试用例，使他能够发现他原来的方法失败的原因。

But be realistic: production work comes before learning in most environments, and managers will not tolerate substantial current delays even when promised ultimate rewards in the great beyond when the new technique is mastered. What is the programmer to do when faced with this conflict between his job and his learning? Actually, the resolution is simple. If, after a reasonable amount of time trying to understand the failure of the new technique, he has had no success, he should proceed with his "fix," if he has one. At the same time, he should construct a test case that will enable him to discover why his original approach failed.

在我们的 PL/l 数组分配示例中，程序员可以在生产程序中写出 DO 循环并启动一个单独测试数组分配的作业。通过继续这个测试示例直到他理解问题的程度，他不仅会学到他不知道的一件事，而且可能还会学到其他东西。诸如此类的测试程序通常是比生产程序更好的学习工具。

In our example of PL/l array assignments, the programmer could write out the DO loop in the production program and initiate a job in which the array assignment is tested in isolation. By pursuing this test example to the point where he understands the problem, he will not only learn the one thing he did not know, but perhaps will learn others as well. Test programs such as this are often better learning instruments than are production programs.

作为一个好的实践，测试程序应该在对生产程序进行“修复”之前构建。首先，一旦生产程序正常运行，人就会忘记这个问题，所以我们必须对自己施加一些约束。然而，可能更重要的是，仅通过构建测试用例的行为，我们就有可能发现问题。在我们观察到的一个案例中，程序员一直在使用 PL/I 数组赋值语句时遇到问题

As a matter of good practice, the test program should be constructed before the "fix" is made to the production program. In the first place, there will be an all too human tendency to forget about the problem once the production program is working correctly, so we must impose a little discipline on ourselves. Possibly more important, however, is the chance that by the mere act of constructing the test case we shall discover the problem. In one case we observed, the programmer had been having trouble with the PL/I array assignment statement

A = A/SUM(A);

A = A/SUM(A);

他不知道问题出在哪里，所以他创建了一个单独应用 SUM 函数的测试用例，以便他可以看到打印的总和。然而，当他这样做时，他突然意识到 SUM(A) 不会在问题陈述中单独计算——实际上，它会在每次分配 A 的元素之后计算。他能够对照这个想法来验证这个想法错误的输出（使用比他最初认为结果“错误”时更多的信息）并确认他的假设。然后将生产程序更正为

He did not know where the trouble lay, so he created a test case in which the SUM function was applied separately, in order that he might see the sum printed. As he did this, however, he suddenly realized that SUM(A) would not be computed separately in the problem statement—that it would, indeed, be computed after each assignment of an element of A. He was able to check this idea against the erroneous output (using more of the information than he had originally when he just perceived the result as "wrong") and confirm his hypothesis. The production program was then corrected to read

B =总和（A）；A = A/B;

B = SUM(A); A = A/B;

他不仅学到了一些东西，而且他的生产计划也反映了他的新见解。而且，他已经克服了很大一部分对阵法的恐惧，与凶兽生死搏斗，并取得了胜利。

He had not only learned something, but his production program reflected his new insight. Moreover, he had overcome a substantial proportion of his fear of array statements, having met the beast in mortal combat and emerged victorious.

在“学习案例”的构造中，程序员必须对“关键案例”产生一种感觉——也就是说，除了一个关键差异之外，这个案例就像手头的案例一样。通过这两个案例的对比，他准确地了解到他必须做出多少区分——不多也不少。例如，如果他在表达时遇到了一些问题

In the construction of "learning cases," the programmer has to develop a feeling for the "critical case"—that is, the case just like the case at hand except for one critical difference. Through the contrast between these two cases, he learns precisely how much discrimination he must make—neither more nor less. For instance, if he is having some trouble with the expression

INDEX(X||'ABC', 'ABC');

INDEX(X||'ABC', 'ABC');

如果他不确定 INDEX 内置函数，他可以在他的测试程序中构造几个最小对比的案例，每个案例在一个方面都与原始案例不同。因此，例如，一种情况可以使用变量而不是表达式作为第一个参数，第二种情况可以使用不同长度的字符串，第三种情况可以使用可变的第二个参数。每个案例给他的信息都与其他案例有所不同，通过同时运行多个案例，他增加了在单次运行中获得所需信息的机会。

If he is unsure of the INDEX built-in function, he can construct several minimally contrasting cases in his test program, each differing from the original in one aspect. Thus, for instance, one case could use a variable instead of an expression as the first argument, a second could use a string of different length, a third could use a variable second argument. Each case gives him information somewhat different from the others, and by running several cases at once, he increases his chances of obtaining the information he wants in a single run.

要实施这样一个积极的学习计划，程序员必须已经知道很多。例如，如果他对自己的编程语言不够熟练，无法使关键案例的构建成为一件相对简单和万无一失的事情，他将很快陷入细节的泥潭，而他不可能独自处理这些细节。因此，正式教育计划的目标应该是培训程序员，使他能够使用他的工具作为进一步学习的工具。相反，我们常常发现，正规教育只是在向程序员灌输对其工具的仇恨。有多少大学毕业生拿着毕业证书时暗自想到，现在，终于，他们摆脱了书籍和讲座之类的东西？讨厌工具的是穷工人——更何况是工具本身可以教会我们成为好工人。

To implement such an active program of learning, the programmer must already know quite a bit. If, for example, he does not have sufficient proficiency with his programming language to make the construction of a critical case a relatively simple and foolproof affair, he will quickly become embedded in a morass of detail, which he cannot possibly handle on his own. It should, therefore, be the goal of formal educational programs to train the programmer to the point where he can use his tools as tools to further his learning. Instead, we all too often find that the formal education has merely served to inculcate in the programmer a hatred for his tools. How many college graduates take their diplomas with the secret thought that now, at last, they are freed from such things as books and lectures? It is a poor workman who hates his tools—all the more because it is the tools themselves which can teach us to become good workmen.

概括

SUMMARY

我们可以对程序员的表现施加的两个主要影响是他对工作的渴望和他知道完成这项工作需要什么。第一个称为动机，第二个称为培训，或者，如果它足够普遍，则称为教育。但鲜为人知的是为什么程序员会更努力地编程，甚至他们是否已经为了自己的利益而过度努力地编程了。可能对程序员的教育知之甚少，尽管在培训计划上花费了大量资金。事实上，关于编程教育的文章和书籍比关于编程心理学所有其他方面的文章和书籍加起来还要多，但其中很少有具有持久重要性的。

The two major influences we can exert on a programmer's performance are on the desire he feels for working and on what he knows that is needed to do the job. The first is called motivation and the second is called training, or, if it is sufficiently general, education. But little is known about why programmers program harder, or even whether they are already programming too hard for their own good. Possibly even less is known about educating programmers, even though vast sums have been spent on training schemes. Indeed, more articles and books have been written on programming education than on all other aspects of programming psychology put together, yet few of them have any lasting importance.

也许我们对正式培训——从学校——期望过高。教育行业在实践上基本上仍然是中世纪的，那么为什么程序员学校应该有所不同呢？通常，在有精心制定的教育计划的地方，它是用业余习惯培养未来的专业人士，所以他们最好不要做太多的工作。至少一旦您进入真正的编程环境，就可以少忘掉一些东西。

Perhaps we expect too much from formal training—from schools. The education business is still essentially medieval in its practices, so why should schools for programmers be different? Typically, where there is a carefully worked-out educational program, it is to train future professionals with amateur habits, so perhaps it is better they don't do much of a job. At least there's less to unlearn once you get into a real programming environment.

在计算教育行业中拯救我们的一个因素是计算机本身——永远沉默，永远耐心，永远教那些只有学习技能的程序员。也许我们应该为我们的学校设定一个目标，让学生独自一人，这样他们就不会在与我们所有人真正的老师一起到达日志的另一端之前就停止学习。它可能昂贵，可能不雅，可能过时，但对于程序员来说，计算机辅助教学（但不是 CAI！） 仍然是最好的。

The one factor that saves us in the computing education business is the computer itself—ever silent, ever patient, ever teaching the programmer who has but the skill to learn. Perhaps we should set as a goal for our schools merely to leave the students alone, so that they do not turn off to learning before they get on the other end of that log with the real teacher of us all. It may be expensive, it may be inelegant, it may be old-fashioned, but for programmers, computer assisted instruction (but not CAI!) is still the best.

问题

QUESTIONS

对于经理

For Managers

 

1. 你对什么能激励你的程序员有什么印象？这对他们所有人来说都是一样的吗——男人和女人，老人和年轻人？您是否认为他们的动机与激励您的相同？

1. What is your impression of what motivates your programmers? Is it the same thing for all of them—for men and women, for old and young? Do you assume they are motivated by the same things that motivate you?

2. 你是否采取措施防止你的程序员过度工作，避免过度投入他们的工作？你羡慕过他们的参与，他们对工作的奉献吗？

2. Do you take steps to keep your programmers from overworking, from getting too involved in their job? Do you ever envy their involvement, their dedication to their work?

3、对于提供程序员教育资源（不一定是程序员学校）你是什么态度？您如何鼓励您的程序员在工作时进行自我教育？你这样做只是为了不给学校花钱的借口吗？

3. What are your attitudes toward providing resources for programmer education (not necessarily programmer schools)? What do you do to encourage your programmers to educate themselves as they work? Do you do this just as an excuse not to spend money on schools?

4. 你鼓励程序员以他们自己喜欢的模式工作吗？例如，您是否允许程序员在他们的办公室使用不同种类的设备，将工作带回家，或者将他们的工作时间从商店的正常工作时间转移？

4. Do you encourage programmers to work in their own preferred modes? Do you, for instance, permit programmers to have different sorts of equipment in their offices, to take work home, or to shift their working hours from the normal working hours of the shop?

对于程序员

For Programmers

 

1. 你的经理可以为你做些什么来让你的工作更快或更好？你有没有和你的经理讨论过这些事情？如果不是，你认为他了解它们是什么东西吗？

1. What things could your manager do for you to make your work faster or better? Have you ever discussed these things with your manager? If not, do you think he understands which things they are?

2. 写下你接受计算机编程培训的个人经历。记下哪些经历教会了你哪些事情，哪些对你最有益。根据这份清单，你打算如何处理你未来的教育？或者您已经知道关于编程的一切知识了吗？

2. Write a personal history of your training in computer programming. Make notes of which experiences taught you which things, and which were most beneficial to you. On the basis of this list, what are you going to do about your future education? Or do you already know everything there is to know about programming?

3. 你最喜欢的感知方式是什么？在您的教育工作中，您如何尝试利用它们？

3. What are your favored modes of perception? What do you do to try to take advantage of them in your educational effort?

4. 你有什么“特别”的工作习惯可以提高你的表现吗？您的经理允许还是阻止您以这些方式工作？你的经理知道你的喜好吗？

4. Do you have any "peculiar" work habits which you think enhance your performance? Does your manager permit or prevent you from working in these ways? Does your manager know of your preferences?

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

Sackman, Harold，人机问题解决：分时和批处理的实验评估，新泽西州普林斯顿，奥尔巴赫，1970 年。

Sackman, Harold, Man-Computer Problem Solving: Experimental Evaluation of Time-Sharing and Batch Processing, Princeton, N.J., Auerbach, 1970.

同样，Sackman 对程序员培训有很多重要的看法，他最大的研究是在空军学院对受训人员进行的。他的一项观察证实了本章的观点，即迄今为止帮助学员解决编程问题最需要的改进是“改进教学”。我怀疑，部分问题是对个人工作的限制，这是学院特别强调的。因此，在任何真正的编程工作中必不可少的学习中的小组合作被学校视为“作弊”。另见最后一章，其中萨克曼将他的一些发现与一般心理学文献联系起来。他似乎觉得，到头来，对于编程，

Again, Sackman has a number of important things to say about programmer training, and his largest studies were carried out on trainees at the Air Force Academy. One of his observations, which bears out the point of view of this chapter, is that by far the most desired improvement to help cadets in solving programming problems was "improved instruction." Part of the problem, I suspect, is the restriction to individual work, which is particularly emphasized at the Academy. Thus, group cooperation in learning, which is essential in any real programming effort, is set aside by the school as "cheating." See also the last chapter, in which Sackman relates some of his findings to the general psychological literature. He seems to feel that in the end, for programming, experience and training come to dominate all other variables in programming success.

Cofer, CH 和 MH Appley，《动机：理论与研究》，纽约，Wiley，1964 年。

Cofer, C. H., and M. H. Appley, Motivation: Theory and Research, New York, Wiley, 1964.

以专业的方式涵盖了多方面的动机理论，是心理学家眼中动机领域经典著作的良好开端。

Covers the multifaceted motivation theories in a professional way, A good place to start into the classical work in the field of motivation, as seen by psychologists.

希尔加德，急诊室；和 G. Bower，学习理论，第 3 版。纽约，Appleton-Century-Crofts，1966 年。

Hilgard, E. R.; and G. Bower, Theories of Learning, 3rd ed. New York, Appleton-Century-Crofts, 1966.

这本书对心理学习理论的作用就像 Cofer 和 Appley 对动机所做的一样。同样，这是一个开始无尽话题的好地方。

This book does for psychological learning theories what Cofer and Appley do for motivation. Again, a good place to start on an endless topic.

计算机人员研究会议论文集，计算机协会，纽约，每年出版一次。关于程序员培训计划和系统的文章散布在整个计算文献中，就像布丁中的李子一样。这些程序中有关培训的文章应该为读者提供足够的样本来做出自己的决定。

Proceedings of the Computer Personnel Research Conferences, Association for Computing Machinery, New York, published annually. Articles on training schemes and systems for programmers are scattered throughout the computing literature like plums in a pudding. The articles on training in these proceedings should give the reader enough of a sample to make up his own mind.

Hall, Douglas T„ 和 Edward E. Lawler 111，工作压力和研究绩效，美国科学家，卷。59（1971 年 1 月至 2 月）。虽然我们还没有研究工作压力对编程性能的影响，但编程经理可能会从阅读这篇文章中获益，只要他在脑后保留一点编程不是，到目前为止正如我们所知，与“研究”相同的活动。至少这篇文章表明，对于复杂的智力活动，各种工作压力与生产力之间的关系并不简单，过于简单化只会给管理者带来风险。

Hall, Douglas T„ and Edward E. Lawler 111, Job Pressures and Research Performance, American Scientist, Vol. 59 (Jan.-Feb. 1971). Although we still do not have a study of the effect of job pressures on programming performance, the programming manager might profit from reading this article, just so long as he keeps a slight reservation in the back of his head that programming is not, so far as we know, the same activity as "research." At least this article shows that for complex intellectual activities, the relationship between various job pressures and productivity is not a simple one, and is oversimplified only at a manager's peril.

第 10 章的评论：动机、培训和经验

Comments on Chapter 10: Motivation, Training, and Experience

从 MBTI 人格理论中，我学到了很多我 25 年前不知道的关于动机的知识。例如，我现在明白，我的类型 (INFP) 很可能会被帮助人们自己学习的想法所激发——这也是我写这本书的目标。其他 MBTI 类型可能同样有动力写一本关于同一主题的书，但出于非常不同的原因。例如，INTJ 类型可能想要展示如何将编程精简为几个基本的、优雅的模型。

From MBTI personality theory I learned much about motivation that I didn't know twenty-five years ago. I now understand, for example, that my type (INFP) is quite likely to be galvanized by the idea of helping people learn for themselves—as was my objective in writing this book. Other MBTI types might be equally motivated to write a book on the same subject, but for very different reasons. An INTJ type, for example, might want to show how programming can be stripped down to a few essential, elegant models.

MBTI 模型当然不能解释所有异质动机——远不能解释。有些人几乎可以为迈克尔·杰克逊演唱会的门票做任何事情，但对我来说，门票必须是迈克尔·乔丹的表演。没有理论可以解释我们的个性，但精明的经理可以很容易地找出每个人的动机——通过询问！当然，这种方法需要一种某些管理风格无法访问的经理-员工关系。这样的管理者只需猜测是什么激励了他们的员工。

The MBTI model certainly doesn't explain every idiosyncratic motivation—not by a long shot. Some people would do almost anything for a ticket to a Michael Jackson concert, but for me the ticket would have to be to a Michael Jordan performance. No theory will explain our individuality, but the astute manager can easily figure out what motivates each individual—by asking! Of course, this approach requires a type of manager-employee relationship not accessible to certain management styles. Such managers will simply have to guess what motivates their people.

在过去的几十年里，程序员之间一个相当显着的变化是教育多样性的减少。今天，一个系统编程团队可能包含相当多样化的个人，但他们中的大多数人都接受过“计算机科学”方面的正式培训。

One rather striking change among programmers in the past few decades has been the reduction in diversity of schooling. Today, a systems programming team is likely to contain quite diverse individuals, but most of them will have been formally trained in "computer science."

例如，去年，在为一家大型软件公司提供咨询时，我与一个由五名开发人员（但不是系统程序员）组成的团队合作，他们都拥有计算机科学的研究生学位。然而，只有两人直接完成了学业。其中两人在来这家公司工作之前已经经营了自己的成功企业；一个人旁边有他自己的蓝草乐队；一个晚上去法学院，希望从事家庭法工作；第五个在 12 岁时自学了编程，在公司工作了 5 年之后才被送回学校接受正规教育。

Last year, for instance, while consulting with a large software company, I worked with a team of five developers (not systems programmers, though), all of whom had graduate degrees in computer science. Only two, however, had gone straight through school. Two of them had run successful businesses of their own before coming to work for this company; one had his own Bluegrass band on the side; one was going to law school at night, hoping to practice family law; and the fifth who had learned programming on his own at age twelve, worked for the company for five years before he was sent back to school to get formally educated.

然而，最有趣的是他们在学校正式学习编程之前就已经学会了编程的巧合。这是个人电脑带来的重大变化。在我那个时代，在 1956 年去 IBM 工作之前，我什至没有见过计算机。在那之前，我还是一名本科生，曾在物理系当过计算机——我用手反转 10x10 矩阵，“计算机”是我的职位。

Most interesting, however, was the coincidence that all of them had learned to program before they studied programming formally in school. That's a major change brought about by the personal computer. In my day, I had not even seen a computer before I went to work for IBM in 1956. Before that, while an undergraduate, I had worked for the physics department as a computer—I inverted 10x10 matrices by hand, and "computer" was my job title.

我的孩子那一代在学校可以接触到计算机，我的儿子济慈 (Keats) 获得了计算机科学学位。我的孙子尼古拉斯 (Nicolas) 在进入学校之前就拥有这位非常耐心的老师的优势。也许他的编程心理学会有所不同，但我们必须等待心理学黄金周年纪念版才能找到答案。

My children's generation had access to computers in school, and my son Keats took his degree in computer science. Nicolas, my grandson, has the advantage of this marvelously patient teacher before he had even entered school. Perhaps his psychology of programming will be different, but we'll have to wait for the Golden Anniversary Edition of Psychology to find out.

第 4 部分。编程工具

Part 4. Programming Tools

 

... 对可能碰巧是教授的听众的忠告。我被允许使用简单的英语，因为每个人都知道，如果我愿意，我可以使用数理逻辑。以声明为例：“有些人与已故妻子的姐妹结婚。” 我可以用多年学习后才能理解的语言来表达这一点，这给了我自由。我建议年轻的教授们，他们的第一部作品应该用行话来写，只有博学的少数人才能理解。有了泰语支持，他们以后就可以用“人们能理解”的语言说出他们必须说的话。在这些日子里，当我们的生活完全由教授摆布时，我不得不认为，如果他们采纳了我的建议，他们将值得我们感激。——伯特兰·罗素

... a word of advice to such of my hearers as may happen to be professors. I am allowed to use plain English because everybody knows that I could use mathematical logic if I chose. Take the statement: "Some people marry their deceased wives' sisters." I can express this in language which only becomes intelligible after years of study, and this gives me freedom. I suggest to young professors that their first work should be written in a jargon only to be understood by the erudite few. With thai behind them, they can ever after say what they have to say in a language "understanded by the people." In these days, when our very lives are at the mercy of professors, I cannot but think that they would deserve our gratitude if they adopted my advice. - Bertrand Russell

 

如果说穷工讨厌他的工具，那么好工也讨厌劣质工具。从某种意义上说，工人的工作是由他的工具来定义的——以工具经常被用来象征工人的方式为例：木匠的三角方块，泥瓦匠的抹子，石匠的运输工具测量员，摄影师的照相机，劳动者的锤子，农民的镰刀。使用有缺陷或设计不佳的工具，即使是最优秀的工匠也会生产出低劣的作品，从而沦为低劣的工匠。任何工匠，如果他渴望在他的职业中从事最高的工作，都不会接受这样的工具；没有雇主，如果他欣赏工作的质量，会要求工匠接受他们。

If the poor workman hates his tools, the good workman hates poor tools. The work of the workingman is, in a sense, defined by his tools—witness the way in which the tool is so often taken to symbolize the worker: the tri-square for the carpenter, the trowel for the mason, the transit for the surveyor, the camera for the photographer, the hammer for the laborer, and the sickle for the farmer. Working with defective or poorly designed tools, even the finest craftsman is reduced to producing inferior work, and thereby reduced to being an inferior craftsman. No craftsman, if he aspires to the highest work in his profession, will accept such tools; and no employer, if he appreciates the quality of work, will ask a craftsman to accept them.

编程中的情况有什么不同吗？乍一看似乎是这样，但这种误解可以追溯到编程与其他工艺相比相对不成熟。任何行业的工具都在发展，但是编程工具只有一两年的时间才能达到目前的形式。因此，没有编程工具的共同标准，也没有使用现有最佳工具的共同经验。

Is the situation any different in programming? At first glance it may seem to be, but this misunderstanding can be traced to the relative immaturity of programming as compared to other crafts. The tools of any trade evolve, but the tools of programming have had but a decade or two to arrive at their present forms. Thus, there is no common standard for programming tools, and no common experience in the use of the best tools that do exist.

使用机器语言的程序员——这些语言仍然存在，比通常认为的要多得多——甚至可能没有意识到最原始的汇编语言可以提供的优势。在我们的计算机编程心理学课程中，一名学生对他的商店​​中遇到的 2000 多个编程错误进行了分析——所有程序员都在用机器语言为一台小型专用机器编写代码。在这些错误中，65% 可归因于诸如为延迟周期插入错误数量的空操作、错误的操作代码、为间接寻址等功能放置位错误、使用错误的绝对地址或计算错误等内务管理问题位移。通过使用最原始设计的汇编语言，

The programmer who is working in machine language—and many more of these still exist than is commonly supposed—may not even be aware of the advantages that the crudest assembly language can provide. In our course on the psychology of computer programming, one of the students undertook an analysis of more than 2000 programming errors encountered in his shop—where all programmers were coding in machine language for a small special-purpose machine. Of these errors, 65 percent were attributable to such housekeeping matters as inserting the wrong number of no-ops for delay cycles, incorrect operation codes, errors in placing a bit for such features as indirect addressing, using the wrong absolute address, or incorrectly calculating a displacement. By using an assembly language of the most primitive design, these programmers could have eliminated two-thirds of their coding errors—but they did not even know that such a thing was possible.

当我们提高可能的编程辅助工具的级别时，我们会发现这种情况会重复出现，因为尽管汇编语言程序员可能会嘲笑机器语言程序员，但他可能反过来成为语言用户的娱乐对象宏观设施。然而，并不是所有的兴奋都归因于一个系统优于另一个系统。事实上，其中很大一部分是一种隐藏不安全感的方式，即自己的编程系统可能不是人类技术成就的巅峰之作。

As we move up the levels of possible programming aids, we find the situation repeating itself, for although the assembly-language programmer may scoff at the machine-language programmer, he may be in turn the object of amusement for the user of a language with macro facilities. Not all of this titillation, however, is attributable to the superiority of one system over another. Much of it, indeed, is a way of concealing an insecure feeling that one's own programming system might not be the pinnacle of man's technological achievements.

在本书的这一部分，我们将尝试从心理学的角度来审视程序员使用的主要工具，看看我们能否将系统设计和选择的问题排除在无知的争吵和吵闹之外。毫无疑问，我们将无法实现这一崇高目标，但我们希望至少朝着一个比迄今为止探索的方向更有希望的方向迈出第一步。

In this section of the book, we shall attempt to examine the major tools used by the programmer from the perspective of psychology, in order to see if we cannot put questions of system design and selection out of the reach of ignorant squabbling and squalling. No doubt we shall be unable to achieve this high aim, but we hope to make at least a start in a direction which promises more than some heretofore explored.

第 4 部分的评论：编程工具

Comments on Part 4: Programming Tools

当我的老朋友的眼睛凝视着今天的编程工具时，我流口水了（希望不仅仅是因为衰老）。啊，想象一下我们可以用这样的工具做什么......！好吧，实际上，我们可能会做我们所做的，以及任何真正的专业人士会做的事情——构建更多工具。

When my old-timer's eyes gaze upon today's programming tools, I drool (hopefully not merely out of decrepitude). Ah, imagine what we could have done with such tools...! Well, actually, we'd probably do just what we did, and what any true professional would do—build more tools.

在我早期职业生涯的大部分时间里，我都在从事构建工具——操作系统；调试工具；性能分析器；静态和动态代码分析器；测试发电机、线束和模拟器；数据库系统；口译员；之类的。注意编译器的遗漏。出于某种原因，编译器构建领域从未吸引过我。似乎总是有足够多的人在构建编译器。那一点没有改变；仍然有足够多的编译器构建器。

For most of my early career, I was engaged in building tools—operating systems; debugging tools; performance analyzers; static and dynamic code analyzers; test generators, harnesses, and simulators; data base systems; interpreters; and the like. Notice the omission of compilers. For some reason, the field of compiler-building never attracted me. There always seemed to be enough people building compilers. That much hasn't changed; there are still more than enough compiler-builders.

然而，我确实对用元语言和其他工具来补充编译器非常感兴趣，所以我浏览了 MetaCOBOL。我与 Applied Data Research 的合著者一起写了一本关于 MetaCOBOL 的书，即高级 COBOL 编程。这本书是使用宏语言作为从 COBOL 到更好语言的过渡工具的实验。总的来说，这个实验没有成功，是我最后一次用工具来补充语言的主要努力。高级工具只会延长劣质语言的寿命。

I did, however, have a great interest in supplementing compilers with meta-languages and other tools, so I made an excursion into MetaCOBOL. With my co-authors from Applied Data Research, I wrote a book about MetaCOBOL, High-Level COBOL Programming. The book was an experiment in using a macro language as a transition device from COBOL to something better. On the whole, the experiment didn't work, and was my last major effort at supplementing languages with tools. Superior tools only prolong the life of inferior languages.

几年来，我为专业程序员写了一个联合专栏，作为一种激发更好的工具和更好地使用现有工具的方式。其中一些专栏收录在Understanding the Professional Programmer和Rethinking Systems Analysis and Design中。我怀疑这些书籍和专栏加在一起对更好工具的开发有任何可衡量的影响——当然不能与个人计算机的影响相提并论。

For some years, I wrote a syndicated column for professional programmers as a way of inspiring better tools and better use of existing tools. Some of these columns are collected in Understanding the Professional Programmer and Rethinking Systems Analysis and Design. I doubt that these books and columns together had any measurable influence on the development of better tools—certainly not compared with the influence of the personal computer.

回到 1950 年代和 1960 年代初期，编程工具主要是由用户设计和制造的。例如，当我们构建第一个操作系统时，我们是在各个 IBM 客户之间通力合作。IBM 参与了（我也是，作为 IBM 的一名员工），但只是作为合作者之一。因此，当时我们所有的工具都是由 SHARE 组织免费分发的，或者与 IBM 的硬件捆绑在一起。

Back in the 1950's and early 1960's, programming tools were largely designed and made by users. For example, when we built the very first operating systems, we did so as a cooperative effort among various IBM customers. IBM was involved (as was I, as an IBM employee), but only as one of the cooperators. So, at that time, all of our tools were distributed free by the SHARE organization or bundled with IBM's hardware.

到 1960 年代后期，针对捆绑软件概念的成功法律挑战由 ADR 的 Marty Goetz 领导，他是我在 MetaCOBOL 工作中的合著者之一。这一挑战使得软件可以出售（或出租），但最初让硬件制造商在很大程度上控制了编程工具业务。

By the late 1960's, a successful legal challenge was mounted against the concept of bundled software—led by Marty Goetz at ADR, one of my co-authors in the MetaCOBOL effort. The challenge made software available for sale (or rent), but initially left the hardware manufacturers largely in control of the programming tools business.

在 20 世纪 80 年代，个人电脑通过再次民主化工具构建改变了这一切，将其重新交到工具用户手中，并实现了工具之间的真正竞争。这种竞争增加了工具的吸引力，同时降低了它们的价格。这就是为什么对于像我这样的老前辈来说，今天看起来像是编程工具的乌托邦。

In the 1980's, PCs changed all that by democratizing tool-building again, putting it back in the hands of the tool-users and enabling real competition among tools. That competition has increased the appeal of tools while lowering their price. That's why, to old-timers like me, today looks like a Utopia of programming tools.

第 11 章编程语言

Chapter 11. Programming Languages

 

无数论文都致力于编程语言的主题，但在其中任何一篇都不容易找到心理学主题。一位作者表达了对编程语言最典型的态度，他呼吁努力“真正尝试理解什么是编程和编程语言”。尽管我们都同意这种值得称赞的观点，但我们可能不同意他对他认为它们“全部”的解释，即“一方面它们与我们的数学基础以及当前和想象的计算有何关系另一边的装备。” 在那个分析中，没有提到人，那些不得不使用编程语言的可怜的生物，

Countless papers have been devoted to the subject of programming languages, but the topic of psychology is not easily found in any of them. The most typical attitude about programming languages was expressed by one author who pleaded for an effort "to really attempt to understand what programming and programming languages are all about." Although we all could agree with this laudable sentiment, we might not agree with his explication of what he thought they were "all about," namely, "how they related to our mathematical foundations on the one hand and to current as well as imagined computing equipment on the other." In that analysis, there is no mention of people, the poor critters who have to use programming languages, except perhaps for the type of people who spend their time imagining computing equipment—hardly the typical language user!

在本章中，我们还将尝试理解编程语言的全部内容，但我们的观点将首先考虑人，其次是机器和数学——然后仅当它们影响心理讨论时。由于我们已经花了相当多的时间讨论什么是“编程”，因此通过考虑“语言”是什么以及编程语言在该术语的其他意义上在多大程度上是语言来开始我们对编程语言的研究是合适的。以这种理解为基础，我们将尝试对编程语言设计主题进行一些小的阐述。由于大多数程序员对语言的设计没有太多可说的，

In this chapter, we also shall attempt to understand what programming languages are all about, but our point of view will consider people first and machines and mathematics second—and then only as they impinge on the psychological discussion. As we have already spent considerable time discussing what "programming" is, it will be appropriate to begin our study of programming languages by considering what a "language" is, and to what extent programming languages are languages in other senses of the term. With that understanding as a basis, we will attempt to throw some small light on the subject of programming language design. Since most programmers do not have much to say about the design of a language, we shall attempt to satisfy a more universal need by providing principles for selection of a programming language from among those already designed for us.

编程语言和自然语言

PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE AND NATURAL LANGUAGE

如果有一个领域每个人都是专家，那就是语言。我们都说一种语言，我们中的一些人甚至可以读写我们所说的语言。如果一个外国人说“I would like of dinner”，我们任何人都可以纠正他对介词的错误使用——即使是我们这些不知道从命题或先入为主来介词的人。然而，典型的人对他所使用的语言的理解并没有深刻到阻止他将某些东西标记为一种可能仅在表面上相似的语言。因此，我们用来与计算机通信的符号系统被称为“编程语言”也就不足为奇了。事实上，最早的程序员 Lady Lovelace 似乎早在 1846 年就有了将编程语言作为一种语言的想法。尽管她是拜伦勋爵的侄女，但并不是她的诗歌知识，而是她的数学知识使她将符号系统视为一种语言——因为数学作为一种语言的想法似乎又回到了迷雾之中过去的时代。于是，“程序设计语言”的概念真的是随着程序设计本身的概念而诞生的。

If there is one area in which every man is an expert, it is language. We all speak a language, and some of us can even read and write the language we speak. If a foreigner says "I would like of dinner," any of us can correct his erroneous use of the preposition—even those of us who do not know a preposition from a proposition or a prepossession. The typical person's understanding of the language he uses, however, is not so profound as to prevent him from labeling something as a language that might resemble one only superficially. Thus, it is not surprising that the systems of notation which we use to communicate with our computers came to be known as "programming languages." In fact, the very first programmer, Lady Lovelace, seems to have had the idea of a programming language as a language as early as 1846. Although she was the niece of Lord Byron, it was not her knowledge of poetry but, rather, of mathematics which led her to think of a symbolic system as a language—for the idea of mathematics as a language seems to go back into the misty ages of the past. Thus, the idea of "programming language" was really born with the idea of programming itself.

鉴于编程语言概念的悠久历史，试图证明编程语言不是“真正的”语言是迂腐的。语言就是他们所说的那样，我们完全有权将人与计算机之间的通信系统包括在与人与人或兽与兽之间的通信系统相同的标题下。然而，可能的是询问计算机语言与其他语言之间可能存在的差异。

In view of the venerable past of the programming language concept, it would be pedantic to attempt to demonstrate that programming languages are not "real" languages. Languages are what they say they are, and we are perfectly entitled to include systems of communications between man and computer under the same rubric as systems of communication between man and man or beast and beast. What might be possible, however, is to inquire about possible differences between computer languages and the other kinds.

比较这两种语言的一个可能出发点是霍克特为人类自然语言（语音）给出的“设计特征”列表。他列出的 13 个特征中的第一个是“声音-听觉通道”的使用——也就是说，我说你听。使用这个通道有几个优点，特别是解放双手和其他器官以进行单独的活动。编程通常是手动操作——当有人要求我们“用 FORTRAN 说点什么”时，我们会笑。它是一种书面语言，尽管它与其他书面语言相似，但它与其他书面语言的不同之处在于其背后没有语音系统。并不是说书面语言是语音的简单转录，根本不是；但是像英语这样的书面语言在很大程度上受到它与口语的关系的影响。这种影响在其他书面语言中没有那么强烈，比如使用中文书写系统的语言，但这种影响——相互影响——一直存在。

One possible point of departure for comparing the two types of language is the list of "design features" which Hockett has given for the natural language of human beings (speech). The first of thirteen features which he lists is the use of a "vocal-auditory channel"—that is, I speak and you listen. The use of this channel has several advantages, particularly the freeing of the hands and other organs for separate activities. Programming is generally a manual operation—we laugh when someone asks us to "say something in FORTRAN." It is a written language, and in spite of its resemblance to other written languages, it differs from them in not having a speech system behind it. Not that written languages are simple transcriptions of speech, not at all; but a written language such as English is strongly influenced by its relationship to a spoken language. This influence is not so strong in other written languages, such as those using the Chinese writing system, but the influence—the mutual influence —always exists.

没有口头形式的编程语言的一个影响是可能会减缓语言创新，因为自然语言的口头形式通常是新语言形式的来源。另一个影响是我们很难在没有黑板或铅笔和纸的情况下谈论一种编程语言。每个编程办公室都应该有一块黑板、粉笔和许多橡皮。

One effect of not having a spoken form of a programming language is a possible slowing down of language innovations, for the spoken form of the natural language is most often the source of new language forms. Another effect is the difficulty with which we can talk about a programming language without a blackboard or pencil and paper. Every programming office should have a blackboard, chalk, and many erasers.

霍克特的第二个特征是“快速衰落”。我们需要很多橡皮擦，因为我们在黑板上“说”的程序不会像话语那样自行擦除。有时在编程语言中快速淡入淡出是一种方便。有一次，在百慕大安装计算机时，我们养成了在海浪冲刷的远地点和近地点之间的那部分珊瑚沙上勾勒出粗略的编程想法的习惯。海洋确保每个想法的持续时间都与它的价值有关。但是在普通的编程工作中，除非我们有图形终端，否则我们通常必须明确规定删除过时的列表。

The second of Hockett's features is "rapid fading." We need many erasers because what we "say" about a program on the blackboard does not erase itself the way an utterance does. Sometimes it is a convenience to have rapid fading in a programming language. Once, when installing a computer in Bermuda, we fell into the habit of sketching our rough programming ideas in that portion of the coral sand between the apogee and perigee of the wash of waves. The ocean saw to it that each idea lasted only about as long as it was worth; but in ordinary programming work, we usually have to make explicit provision for getting rid of our obsolete listings, unless we have a graphic terminal.

第三个特征是“广播传输和定向接收”，这意味着我们同时或多或少地向各个方向说话，但我们在听的时候可以检测到语音是从哪个方向传来的。当然，编程恰恰相反。编程与祈祷具有定向传输和广播接收的特点。天堂接收祈祷，计算机接收程序，同时来自四面八方。我们可能会想象，编程语言中允许的变化会在计算机中消失，但事实恰恰相反。尽管听众各不相同，但“系统”只是向所有人广播相同的消息。改变的某些可能性就在这里。

The third feature is "broadcast transmission and directional reception," which means that we speak more or less in all directions at once, but we can detect, when listening, from what direction the speech is coming. Programming, of course, is quite the opposite. Programming shares with prayer the feature of directional transmission and broadcast reception. Heaven receives prayers, and the computer receives programs, from all over at once. We might imagine that what variation is permitted in programming languages would be on the way out of the computer, but just the opposite is true. In spite of the diversity of its listeners, the "system" simply broadcasts identical messages to all of them. Certain possibilities for change lie here.

（今天的）编程语言和自然语言之间真正重要的区别可能在于 Hockett 的第四个设计特征——可互换性。虽然我们经常倾听我们听不懂的人说话，或者经常和听不懂我们的人说话，但人类语言交流的正常形象是每个参与者都可以再现任何他能听懂的语言交流。简而言之，我们“说同一种语言”。不幸的是，当我们与计算机交谈时，我们通常会说不同的语言。至少在这里，尽管机器语言存在所有其他缺点，但它们占了上风，因为至少转储看起来有点像我们放入被破坏的机器中的东西。当我们输入的是 FORTRAN 或 COBOL 时，情况并非如此——几乎不是这样。

Probably the really important difference between programming languages (of today) and natural languages lies in Hockett's fourth design feature—interchangeability. Although we often listen to people whom we cannot understand, or often speak to people who cannot understand us, the normal image of human speech communication is that each participant can reproduce any linguistic communication he can understand. In short, we "talk the same language." When we talk to our computers, unhappily, we are usually speaking in different tongues. Here, at least, for all their other faults, the machine languages have the upper hand, for at least a dump looks a little like the stuff we put into the blasted machine. Not so—not nearly so—when what we put in was FORTRAN or COBOL. How truly sad it is that just at the very moment when the computer has something important to tell us, it starts speaking gibberish.

幸运的是，如今有一种趋势是尝试通过编程语言将可互换性引入人机对话中，这一步势必会对编程效率产生重要的心理影响，尽管它可能会降低机器的“效率”。但还有另一种不可互换性，它可能更严重，但更不易受机械补救措施的影响。程序不仅用于人机交流，还用于人与人之间的交流。然而，编程语言的交流似乎并不具有我们认为在自然语言交流中理所当然的可互换性，即使是在相同的两个人之间也是如此。这个问题的极端情况是可以阅读 COBOL 程序但不会编写它们的人。也许，他也不能讨论它们，

There is, fortunately, a trend today to try to introduce interchangeability into the dialogue between man and machine through a programming language, and this step is bound to have important psychological effects on programming effectiveness, even though it may decrease machine "efficiency." But there is another kind of non-interchangeability which is perhaps even more severe and yet less subject to mechanical remedies. Programs are used not only for man-machine communication, but for man-man communication as well. Yet communication in programming languages does not seem to have the interchangeability we take for granted in natural language communication, even between the same two people. At the extreme of this problem is the case of the man who can read COBOL programs but cannot write them. Probably, he cannot discuss them, either, which makes for most difficult communication problems if he is, say, a programming manager.

在 Hockett 剩余的设计特征中，编程语言似乎确实可以与自然语言相提并论——实际上在诸如生产力、表达以前从未表达过的东西的能力等特征的展示上超越了自然语言。在某种程度上，编程语言的设计反映了与自然语言中常见的不同使用模式。可以肯定的是，从上述意义上讲，自然语言的生产力很重要，但对于编程语言而言，生产力是必要条件。

In Hockett's remaining design features, programming languages do seem to measure up to natural languages—actually going beyond them in the exhibition of such features as productivity, the ability to express something that has never been expressed before. In a way, the design of programming languages reflects different patterns of use than are commonly found in natural language. To be sure, it is important that a natural language be productive, in the above sense, but for a programming language, productivity is the sine qua non.

当我们考虑一种语言的功能，而不是实现功能的设计特征时，编程语言和自然语言之间最深刻的区别就出现了。布鲁纳给出了自然语言的六种一般功能——情感的、内涵的、指称的、元语言的、诗意的和交际的。尽管我们可以在编程语言中识别出它们中的每一个，但它们的相对重要性和使用频率却大不相同。

When we consider function of a language, rather than the design features which realize function, the deepest differences between programming languages and natural languages emerge. Bruner gives six general functions of natural language—emotive, connotative, referential, meta-lingual, poetic, and phatic. Although we can identify each of these in programming languages, their relative importance and frequency of use is quite different.

情感语言包括诸如“你好吗？”之类的话语。和“Fiddlesticks!”，这是演讲者情绪状态的仪式化表达。一般来说，计算机对程序员的情绪状态不感兴趣，尽管它的证据可能会潜入他的程序。

Emotive language consists of utterances such as "How do you do?" and "Fiddlesticks!," which are ritualized expressions of the emotional state of the speaker. Generally speaking, the computer is not interested in the emotional state of the programmer, although evidences of it may creep into his program.

交际语言由诸如“嗯嗯......但是......和......”之类的话语组成，其作用是保持沟通渠道畅通或测试其运作状态。在某些终端系统中可以找到与“and”完全对应的短语，用户可以在思考时通过摆弄 shift 键来防止其程序在优先级堆栈中被压低。如果没有转换，计算机将在很长一段时间内无法接收到通信，并假定用户的程序可以安全地置于更被动的状态。当然，轻摇 shift 键会破坏调度算法的目的，但更重要的是它可能会干扰程序员的思维过程。希望，

Phatic language consists of utterances such as "Uh hu . . . but. . . and . . .," which serve the function of keeping the channel of communication open or testing its state of operation. An exact counterpart of the phatic "and" is found in some terminal systems where the user can keep his program from being pushed down in the priority stack by fiddling with the shift key while he is thinking. Without the shifting, the computer would fail to receive a communication for a long period and assume that the user's program could safely be put in a more passive state. Of course, jiggling the shift key defeats the purpose of the scheduling algorithm, but more important than that is the interference it probably causes with the programmer's thought processes. Hopefully, such phatic communication can be removed from the already cluttered field of programming language phenomena.

乍一看，诗意的语言似乎在编程中没有立足之地，但它所起的作用应该得到越来越多的认可。在诗歌语言中，出于审美原因，语言本身的模式是最重要的。但是，在编程中，有什么可以对应济慈的这些台词呢？

At first blush, poetic language would seem to have no place in programming, yet it plays a role which should be increasingly recognized.
