As far as software documentation is concerned, it doesn't seem that we've gone very far in twenty-five years. Sure, we have some neat new tools, like code formatters and on-line documentation and hypertext, but content still counts most, and few tools have really enhanced content. There's not much point in having easier access to information you didn't want in the first place—as the Internet so often demonstrates. (I do recognize the now-ubiquitous FAQ documentation as the system I proposed back then for capturing, obviously, the most frequently asked questions.)

对内容的最大影响是将文档制作制度化为软件业务中的一项专门任务。许多商业软件公司根本不要求开发人员编写文档——当然不要求用户文档。他们不认为文档是开发人员工作的一部分。正如我当时所写，“......当我们谈论计算机程序文档时，我们根本不是在谈论计算机编程的心理学——除非程序员有一种错觉，即任何人都可以做好文档工作，只要他不够聪明，不能当程序员。”

The biggest influence on content is the institutionalization of document production as a specialized task in the software business. Many commercial software houses simply don't require developers to write documentation—certainly not user documentation. They don't consider documentation to be part of the developer's job. As I wrote back then, "... when we speak about computer program documentation, we are not speaking about the psychology of computer programming at all—except insofar as programmers have the illusion that anyone can do a good job of documentation, provided he is not smart enough to be a programmer."

结语

Epilogue

 

读完一本书的读者有权得到作者的一些赞美，因为他们已经给予了作者所能得到的最大赞美。然而，那些读到最后的读者可能比辍学的读者更不需要奖励，因为似乎不可能在没有获得学习奖励的情况下读完任何一本书。也许可以在不被触动的情况下读完这本书，尽管正如一位评论家评论的那样，

Readers who reach the end of a book are entitled to some praise from the author, since they have paid him the greatest compliment an author can receive. Yet those readers who do reach the end are probably in less need of rewards than the dropout, for it would seem impossible to go all the way through any book without receiving the reward of learning. Perhaps it is possible to go through this book without being touched, although as one reviewer commented,

“一个人离开时会觉得自己度过了一个愉快但有点‘浪费’的阅读下午，就像一句老笑话所说的那样，‘直到你试着转过头，你才会意识到剃刀有多锋利。’ “

"One comes away with the feeling of having spent a pleasant but somewhat 'wasted' afternoon of reading, and as the old joke goes, 'it ain't till you try to turn your head that you realize how sharp the razor was.'"

 

虽然我会更喜欢一个不那么暴力的比喻，但是这句话抓住了这本书试图做的事情。我的学生也有同样的反应。参加研讨会一年后发表的典型言论是：

Although I would have been happier with a less violent metaphor, the remark captures what the book has tried to do. My students have had the same reaction. A typical remark made a year after attending a seminar is:

“谈论这些事情很愉快，但后来我开始了解办公室里发生的事情。哇！”

"It was pleasant enough talking about those things, but then I began to see what was going on at the office. Wow!"

 

这个学生学到的最重要的东西不是任何特定的行为科学结果，也不是在考试中鹦鹉学舌的某某定律的名称。他学到的是，他一生都随身携带着一台装备精良的行为观察机器——一台从未经常使用过的机器。正如计算中心的一个匿名标志所说：

The most important thing that this student learned was not any particular behavioral science result or the name of so-and-so's law to parrot back on a test. What he learned was that he had been carrying around with him all his life a well-equipped machine for observing behavior—one that had never been used very much. As an anonymous sign at the computing center put it:

人的思维通常只以其容量的百分之十运行——其余的都是操作系统的开销。

The human mind ordinarily operates at only ten percent of its capacity—the rest is overhead for the operating system.

 

因此，真正被本书打动的读者不会太在意那个计算机操作系统，而是会开始在他自己的中央处理器——他的头脑中随身携带的操作系统上工作。那将是他的奖赏。

So rather than be concerned so much about that computer operating system, the reader who has really been touched by this book will start to work on the operating system he carries around in his own central processing unit—his head. That will be his reward.

但是，如果我们让自己的操作系统更高效，如果我们更仔细地观察自己和周围环境，如果这种效率和观察使我们成为更有生产力的程序员，那它有什么用呢？三个愿望的故事向我们传达了来自多种文化和古老历史的信息：“如果你实现了最美好的愿望，那又如何呢？” 如果通过心理学、社会学和人类学调查，或者通过简单的提高意识，我们成为更好的程序员，那么我们应该将我们的才能用于什么工作？因为如果某件事不值得做，那肯定不值得做对。

But if we make our own operating systems more efficient, if we observe ourselves and our surroundings more carefully, and if this efficiency and observation lead us to be more productive programmers, of what use is it? The stories of the three wishes send us a message from many cultures, and from the ancient past: "If you get your fondest wish, what then?" If, by psychological, sociological, and anthropological investigation or by simple heightened awareness we become better programmers, to what work shall we turn our talents? For if something is not worth doing, it is certainly not worth doing right.

我们用计算机做的事情值得做吗？你用电脑做的事情值得做吗？因为计算机是如此迷人的野兽，因为编程是一种游戏，如此快乐，我们编程计算机的人有可能成为那些将我们的玩具用于不那么好玩的目的的人不知情的棋子。毫无疑问，如果希特勒指挥着计算机，那么第一个应用程序之一就会密切跟踪犹太人和吉普赛人，以便所有应该去烤炉的人都去了烤炉？毫无疑问，如果彼拉多有电脑，它们会被用来存储从告密者那里收集到的信息，把那些因异端狂热而呼喊要被钉十字架的人钉在十字架上更好吗？毫无疑问，今天在我们国家的某个地方，有些人正在使用计算机作为他们武器库中的另一种更好的武器，来使其他人屈从于他们的愿望——屈服于他们对人类适当生活的观念？

Is what we are doing with computers worth doing? Is what you are doing with computers worth doing? Because computers are such fascinating beasts, because programming is such a game, such a joy, we who program computers are in danger of becoming the unwitting pawns of those who would use our toys for not-so-playful ends. Can there be any doubt that if Hitler had computers at his command, one of the first application would have been keeping closer track on Jews and Gypsies so that all who should have gone to the ovens did go to the ovens? Can there by any doubt that if Pilate had computers, they would have been used to store the information gathered from informers, the better to crucify those that were crying out for crucifixion by their heretical zeal? Can there be any doubt that somewhere in our country today some human beings are using computers as just another, finer weapon in their arsenal of ways to subjugate other human beings to their wishes—to their conception of the proper life of man?

说了这么多，毫无疑问，这些人——现在就像 1939 年或基督教时代的黎明一样——会找到许多愿意的手和脑来完成他们的工作以换取乐趣和利润？还是那些愿意的人中的一些人会为了他们的雇主的利益而持有这本书？

And having said all that, can there be any doubt that such people—now as in 1939 or at the dawn of the Christian era—find many willing hands and brains to carry out their work in return for fun and profit? Or that some of those willing hands will have held this book, to the profit of their employers?

许多年前，就在我与 Herb Leeds 合写第一本书几年后，我读到一篇文章，其中描述了猴子接受不同剂量毒气的实验，显然是为了观察它们死去需要多长时间。这项工作是在化学战研究实验室完成的，毫无疑问，其目的是将其外推到人类身上。我记得，三十六只无辜的猴子以这种可怕的方式死去，也许有一天，三千六百万人可以更有效地死去。之后几个月，这篇文章一直留在我的脑海里，事实上，它一直保留到今天。我想，纯属巧合，在一次会议上，一位好心的年轻人搭讪了我，他特意告诉我他从我们的书中学到了多少，这对他成为一名更好的程序员有多大帮助。

Many years ago, just a few years after I wrote my first book with Herb Leeds, I read an article describing experiments in which monkeys were subjected to various doses of poison gases, evidently to see how long it took them to die. The work was done in a laboratory for chemical warfare research, with the intent, no doubt, of extrapolating it to human beings. Thirty-six innocent monkeys, as I recall, met their deaths in this gruesome way so that someday, perhaps, thirty-six million people could meet their deaths even more efficiently. The article remained in my mind for months afterward, and indeed it has remained there to this day. By pure coincidence, I suppose, I was accosted at a meeting by a nice young man who had gone out of his way to tell me how much he had learned from our book, how much it had helped him to become a better programmer. I asked him what sort of work he did, and he replied that he worked at a laboratory for chemical warfare research.

之后，我试图通过想象这是一个不同的实验室来合理化我摆脱抑郁的方式，它可能是，或者他从未参与过猴子实验，这也可能是真的。但我知道在某个地方，有人从我这里学到了东西，正在参与这样的实验，甚至更糟。我知道我分担了责任——写书不仅仅是教授未知和无法想象的目的的方法。很长一段时间我无法写作，也许是因为这个原因，也许是因为其他原因。但是，最终，我的自我战胜了我，我重新开始，决心尝试让我的书只对内心纯洁的人无用。

Afterward, I tried to rationalize my way out of my depression by imagining that it was a different laboratory, which it might have been, or that he never worked on the monkey experiment, which might also have been true. But I knew that somewhere, someone who had learned from me was participating in such experiments and worse. I knew that I shared the responsibility—that writing a book is not merely teaching means to unknown and unimagined ends. For a long time I could not write, perhaps for that reason, or perhaps for others. But, eventually, my ego got the better of me and I began again, determined to try making my books unusable to any but the pure at heart.

在某种程度上，这本书可能已经实现了这个目标，因为程序员作为人的想法不会吸引某些类型的人，他们既不会读完这本书也不会从中获利。但我现在意识到，期望心地善良的人无法建立糟糕的系统是天真的想法。否则，当我遇到的几乎所有的人都很棒时，为什么我会遇到这么多糟糕的系统？不，还需要一些别的东西，一些作者无力提供给读者的东西。正如马尔罗曾经说过的那样，“造就一个人是一生的工作。” 一本书可能只是这项工作的一小部分——剩下的就看你自己了，这项工作永远不会完成。

To a certain extent, this book may have achieved that goal, for the idea of the programmer as a human being is not going to appeal to certain types of people, and they will neither finish the book nor profit from it. But it is naive, I now realize, to expect that bad systems cannot be built by people with good hearts. Otherwise, why would I encounter so many bad systems when almost all of the people I meet are wonderful? No, something else is needed, something not within the power of an author to give to a reader. As Malraux once said, "It is the work of a lifetime to make a man." A book can be but a tiny part of that work—the rest is up to you, and the work will never be finished.

话虽如此，我并没有逃避对我在撰写本书时所做的一切的个人责任。我们站在一个新时代的边缘，这个时代因计算机革命而成为可能。站在边缘，我们可能会摇摇欲坠——走向自由的黄金时代或暴政的黑暗时代，这两者都将超越世界上已知的任何事物。也许任何个人的努力都不会改变结果，但我们绝不能停止努力，因为那样的结果肯定是暴政。这本书是我反对暴政的努力，反对其他人和他们自己的无知对人的奴役。但愿它不被暴政势力自己采纳，毫无疑问，它会的。缺乏这种希望，我只能希望它对其他力量的使用，总的来说，会更大。

Having said all that, I do not shrink from personal responsibility for what I have done in writing this book. We stand at the brink of a new age, an age made possible by the revolution embodied in the computer. Standing on the brink, we could totter either way—to a golden age of liberty or a dark age of tyranny, either of which would surpass anything the world has ever known. Perhaps no individual's efforts will make any difference in the result, but we must never cease trying, for then the result is sure to be tyranny. This book is my effort against the tyranny, the enslavement of men by other men and by their own ignorance. Would that it not be adopted by the forces of tyranny themselves, as no doubt it will be. Lacking that hope, I can only hope that its use to the other forces will, in the balance, be greater.

第五部分评论：结语

Comments on Part 5: Epilogue

这段结语经得起时间的考验，我没有什么可以补充的。

This epilogue has stood the test of time, and I have nothing to add.

然而，作为本次银周年纪念版的新结语，我想邀请您做两件我在 25 年前无法提供的事情。

As a new epilogue for this Silver Anniversary Edition, however, I'd like to invite you to do two things that I wasn't able to offer twenty-five years ago.

首先，如果您想随时了解我的工作、思考、写作和教学，我邀请您访问我的网站：

First, if you'd like to keep current on what I'm doing and thinking, writing and teaching, I invite you to visit my website:

http://www.geraldmweinberg.com

http://www.geraldmweinberg.com

其次，如果您想与我分享您的一些想法、观察或经验，请访问我的网站并向我发送电子邮件。你应该总能从那里联系到我，至少只要我还在身边。希望这段时间足以让我写出心理学的黄金周年纪念版。

Second, if you'd like to share some of your ideas, observations, or experiences with me, go to my website and send me e-mail. You should always be able to reach me from there, at least as long as I'm still around. Hopefully that will be long enough for me to write a Golden Anniversary Edition of Psychology.

课程使用建议

Suggestions for Course Use

 

奥斯卡·王尔德过去常常在聚会上声称，他可以在没有事先准备的情况下就任何主题进行半小时的演讲。当一位听众要求他谈论女王时，他傲慢地回答说：“先生，女王不是臣民。” 即使对于像王尔德这样伟大的健谈者，也很难谈论不是学科的东西，而且许多人不相信计算机编程心理学是一门学科。当然，很少有大学课程提供这样的课程，因此任何希望开办一个先驱者都面临着一条艰巨的道路。像这本这样的教科书应该证明有一些帮助，但至少对于第一次尝试，一些关于它的使用的建议可能不是冒昧的。

Oscar Wilde used to claim at parties that he could discourse on any subject for half an hour without advance preparation. When challenged by a listener to speak about the Queen, he replied haughtily, "Sir, the Queen is not a subject." Even for so great a raconteur as Wilde, it is difficult to discourse on something that is not a subject, and many people are unconvinced that the psychology of computer programming is a subject. Certainly few university curricula offer such a course, so that any pioneer who wishes to inaugurate one is faced with an arduous path. A textbook, such as this one, should prove of some help, but for the first attempt at least, a number of suggestions for its use may not be presumptuous.

本书是与名为“计算机编程心理学”的课程一起编写的。该课程是为我们计算机系统项目的研究生开设的，他们都具有一定的编程经验和至少一年的研究生培训。给那些不能自己编写程序的人，或者研究生水平以下的人或计算机系统或计算机科学专业的高级水平的人开设这样的课程似乎是不可取的。

This book was developed in conjunction with a course titled "The Psychology of Computer Programming." The course was for graduate students in our Computer Systems program, all with some programming experience and at least one year of graduate training. It does not seem advisable to give such a course to people who are not able to write programs themselves, or who are at lower than a graduate level or a senior level with a strong major in Computer Systems or Computer Science.

该课程以研讨会的形式授课，因为我不倾向于向懂得阅读的人讲课。它分为两个学期，每个学期两个学分，以便为学生提供尽可能多的时间进行自己的实验。每个学生都被要求计划并完成一个小实验，其中一些学生做出了相当重要的贡献，其中许多都在本书中有所报道。班级每周开会一次，持续两个小时或更长时间，提前阅读本文和一些参考文献，为特定的讨论主题做准备。

The course is given in seminar form, for I am not inclined to lecture at people who know how to read. It was spread out over two semesters of two credits each, in order to give as much time as possible for students to pursue experiments of their own. Each student was required to plan and complete one small experiment, and some of them made quite significant contributions, many of which are reported in this book. The class met once a week for two hours or more, with readings in advance from this text and from some of the references to prepare for specific discussion topics.

一个建议是关于读数的顺序。由于所使用的许多作品都出现在晦涩的出版物或技术报告中，因此我们采取了一种做法，即提前向每位学生提供此类阅读材料的副本。这种做法似乎鼓励人们有规律地阅读作业。

One suggestion is in order about the readings. Since many of the works used are in obscure publications or in technical reports, we made a practice of providing copies of such readings in advance to each student. This practice seemed to encourage people to read the assignments with great regularity.

我们很快就进入了如何学习编程的主题，因为很少有学生有很多行为科学背景，更不用说行为科学实验了。一旦涵盖了这个主题，学生们就可以开始他们的项目，我们也可以继续学习其余的材料。虽然这样的课程没有必要要求每个学生都进行实验，但是当学生进行实验时，尽一切努力让他们早点开始是很重要的。

We got rather quickly into the subject of how to study programming, since few of the students had much background in behavioral sciences, let alone in behavioral science experimentation. Once this topic was covered, students were able to make a start on their projects, and we were able to proceed with the remainder of the material. Although it is not necessary that such a course require each student to experiment, when students do experiment it is important that every effort be made to get them started early.

如果不需要或不希望进行实验，则该课程可以很好地适应一个学期的模式——既可以是研讨会讨论，也可以是讲座讨论。在任何情况下，强烈建议每周至少有一个时间用于讨论，每章末尾的问题旨在作为可以准备的主题类型的指南——以笔记或实际书面形式任务。

If experimentation is not required or desired, the course would fit nicely into a one-semester pattern—either as a seminar-discussion or lecture-discussion. In any case, it is strongly recommended that at least one period per week be devoted to discussion, and the questions at the end of each chapter are intended as guides to the sort of topics that can be prepared—in notes or as an actual written assignment.

另一种使用这种材料的方法是在为期一周或两周的强化培训课程中，如在暑期学院或管理培训讲习班中。在这种情况下，实验被排除在外，尽管进行一个以学生为主体的简单实验很有用，这样他们就能感受到实验的味道。文中建议的许多实验中的任何一个都是合适的，但如果要满足时间限制，最仔细的预先准备是必要的。类似地，时间限制要求在这样的课堂上，每份阅读材料都可以为每个参与者提供一份副本。最后，即使只是为了必要的强度中断，无论进行什么演讲，都必须穿插频繁的讨论。当班级由经验丰富的程序员或编程经理组成时，讨论将尤为重要，因为他们的贡献将与讲师或课本一样多或更多。这个话题对他们来说如此重要，如此贴近他们，只要有教师的最轻微的提示和领导，课程的成功就可以得到保证。

Another way this material can be used is in a one- or two-week intensive training session, as in a summer institute or in management training workshops. In such situations, experimentation is ruled out, although it is useful to perform one simple experiment in which the students are the subject so that they get the flavor of experimentation. Any one of a number of experiments suggested in the text would be suitable, but the most careful advance preparation is necessary if the time constraints are to be met. Similarly, time constraints dictate in such a class that every piece of reading material be available in one copy for each participant. Finally, if only for the necessary break in intensity, frequent discussions must be interspersed with whatever lecturing is done. Discussion will be particularly important when the class consists of experienced programmers or programming managers, for they will have as much or more to contribute than the instructors or text. The topic is so important to them, and so close to them, that with the slightest of prompting and leadership by the instructor, the success of the course is assured.
